fields.headline: Epidemic threat to Irish tie
fields.trailText: The Republic of Ireland's World Cup qualifying campaign was thrown into chaos last night as the foot and mouth epidemic continued to have damaging repercussions on the sporting world.
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland's World Cup qualifying campaign was thrown into chaos last night as the foot and mouth epidemic continued to have damaging repercussions on the sporting world.

A first confirmed outbreak in the country yesterday prompted an admission from the Football Association of Ireland that its remaining Group Two qualifiers at Lansdowne Road would in all likelihood have to be postponed.

They are due to play Andorra on April 25, Portugal on June 2 and Holland on September 9, but officials fear they will have little option but to make contingency plans with Fifa, including the possibility of playing at neutral venues and behind closed doors.

"It is hard to see how we can come up with anything to cope with this. It looks ominous for everyone," said Bernard O'Byrne, chief executive of the FAI. "I would have to say that, even at this early stage, we may have to postpone as far ahead as the Holland game in September."

The outbreak in County Louth, following an earlier case in Meigh, overshadowed Ireland's preparations for tomorrow's qualifying match against Cyprus. A Fifa spokesman said it would take advice from public health authorities and was treating the matter "extremely seriously".

He added: "The qualifying programme goes on until November so we would hope to be able to find some suitable dates before then."

It is also feared the threat of foot and mouth will mean the entire League of Ireland campaign has to be scrapped for the remainder of the season.

The Republic of Ireland's away qualifier against Andorra is expected to be staged in Barcelona, with Fifa's agreement, because the tiny principality has no stadium of its own to accommodate large numbers of visiting fans.

There is also an away game against Estonia in Tallin on June 6 and the group is due to close with the game in Dublin against Cyprus on October 6.

It is nothing new for the Irish to endure chaotic qualifying campaigns. Their ill-fated attempt to reach the finals of Euro 2000 was littered with postponements because the Balkans conflict involved their group rivals Yugoslavia and Macedonia.

Already it has been a bad week in Cyprus, with the Republic manager Mick McCarthy hit by news of his father's death in the early hours of yesterday morning after a long illness.

McCarthy, who had rushed to the family home in Barnsley, Yorkshire, from Dublin on Monday when he heard news that his 74-year-old father Charlie was in a critical condition, was yesterday offered the chance to leave the squad again, but decided to stay on in Cyprus and also lead the team to Barcelona.

Meanwhile Scotland's manager Craig Brown said that Dominic Matteo would be fit for tomorrow's game against the Group Six leaders Belgium. The Leeds all-purpose defender did not train yesterday because of a slight calf strain. Brown said: "There is no major problem. It was a precautionary removal from training at my insistence."

The Hearts midfielder Colin Cameron was an injury doubt, also with a calf problem, but he put in a full training session at Ayr's Somerset Park ground near the team's hotel in Troon.

webTitle: Hyypia happy at home away from home

fields.headline: Hyypia happy at home away from home
fields.standfirst: Liverpool's defender set to play the bad guy at Anfield
fields.trailText: Sami Hyypia will probably be welcomed with open arms if he makes the mistake of walking into the wrong dressing room before England's World Cup meeting with Finland tomorrow.
fields.body:
Sami Hyypia will probably be welcomed with open arms if he makes the mistake of walking into the wrong dressing room before England's World Cup meeting with Finland tomorrow.

Despite the wealth of talent at his disposal in the heart of defence, Sven-Goran Eriksson, the England coach, would surely be happy to accommodate the man most likely to form an unbreachable barrier for Finland tomorrow.

Hyypia, the Finland centre-half who has contributed so much to the revival of Liverpool this season, will, for once, be on enemy territory when he treads the Anfield turf at three o'clock on Saturday.

The strapping defender is unlikely to be greeted with a hostile reception from the Kop, however. Hyypia may be on international duty, but the Liverpool crowd are a knowledgeable and appreciative bunch, and they will be wary of the boulder-like figure at the heart of Finland's rearguard.

The 27-year-old will treat the occasion as another day at the office, even though he admits that he may not be able to prevent himself from entering his usual dressing-room.

"It will be a strange feeling for me to walk into the ground before the game," he said. "I will be playing at the place I call home, but I must go to the away dressing room.

"Really, I would have preferred to have played this game at Wembley because I have never been there before. Unfortunately, that is not possible and we must play at Anfield.

"I don't agree that the Football Association have been foolish to play the game at Liverpool. Just because Jari Litmanen and I play at Anfield doesn't mean that we have an advantage.

"The crowd will be full of England supporters, not Liverpool fans. That is fine by me. I would rather play in front of 45,000 Englishmen than play at the Olympic Stadium in Helsinki.

"The supporters appear as though they are 200 yards away when we play at home. At least there will be a football atmosphere at Anfield and we are looking forward to it."

The prospect of facing his Liverpool team-mate Michael Owen is something that Hyypia is not so happy about, however. Although the pair have probably traded challenges on a regular basis at Melwood, Liverpool's training ground, Hyypia fears that Owen has shown signs of awakening from a quiet period in his young career. That prospect is fine if you are playing in the same team as Owen, but not so good if it is your job to mark him.

"Michael has been frightening recently and his form has really come on," Hyypia said. "This is helping Liverpool to go forward, but it's not really a good time to be playing against him.

"Obviously, we are good friends at Liverpool and we will remain so, but that friendship will be forgotten for 90 minutes on Saturday. He will become an opponent just like anybody else. After 90 minutes, he will be my friend again."

Hyypia, who has captained Liverpool in the absence of Jamie Redknapp and Robbie Fowler, admitted that for the first time he will play at Anfield with little expectation of coming up with a result.

Finland have lost on both of their previous visits to England and, with a victory almost a necessity for the home side, few are expecting the Finns to improve their record. But the Finns are quietly confident that they can cause an upset.

Hyypia said: "I have been asked many times if we can win this game. I don't know the answer to that, but I can say that it has been quite easy for us to prepare for the game.

"Nobody expects Finland to get a result, but we will make it difficult for England and then we will see what the result is.

"I was surprised by England when we played them in Helsinki earlier this season. When you look at the world stars in their team, you would have expected better, but I thought that they were poor against us.

"We were delighted to earn a draw and I think that one of the reasons why England were so poor was because we played quite well."

And a victory to help send Finland to their first World Cup finals?

"One day I hope to get there," Hyypia admitted. "But it will be very difficult for our country. We have only 5m people in Finland, so our job is to develop and make sure that the next generation improves enough.

"I feel that Finland will play in the finals one day. If it is when I retire then so be it, but it might be before I retire.

"I play in big European games for Liverpool, so not going to a World Cup isn't frustrating. Playing for Finland is a big enough honour."

fields.headline: Saunders pitches for record haul
fields.trailText: Wales had to train in a ramshackle stadium on a pitch just about fit for Sunday football as they prepared for their World Cup qualifier against Armenia.
fields.body:
Wales had to train in a ramshackle stadium on a pitch just about fit for Sunday football as they prepared for their World Cup qualifier against Armenia.

Dean Saunders said they were the most amazing conditions he had seen in 15 years of representing his country. The squad's most experienced player - who will set a 74-cap record for a Welsh outfield player if he plays in the Republican stadium tomorrow - could not believe the practice facilities. Yet they were the best the Wales manager Mark Hughes could find despite visiting seven other sites in the Armenian capital.

Saunders said: "I've never seen anything like this in all my years of playing for Wales. But this is not the Armenians' fault; their team had to train on this pitch before we got here. They are a poor country and it's obviously about the best they can provide."

Under Uefa regulations Wales will be allowed to train only once at the Republican stadium, a brand new ground, before tomorrow's Group Five match.

Hughes, too, refused to criticise his hosts. "It makes you appreciate the facilities we have back home. But this is not a rich country and we should be diplomatic about it. I don't think the pitch is dangerous but it is not ideal."

The scarred and worn pitch is used by two Yerevan profes sional sides. It is surrounded by a potholed running track and terraces which have collapsed or crumbled away.

"We had to be careful; you don't want to run the risk of turning an ankle," said Saunders. "But we needed the run-out after such a long flight, and we also have to get used to the rarefied atmosphere because this is so far above sea level.

"In some places it was just hard to stand up. But we needed the work-out as long as we were careful.

"We moan about our facilities back home, so it doesn't do you any harm to see what other countries have to contend with. You just feel sorry for them having to use places like this.

Referring to his record haul if he plays tomorrow, the Bradford striker said: "It will be a great honour if I can win the cap; it's been frustrating waiting for it. I was out for four months with a knee injury and pulled out of a couple of Wales squads.

"It's something to be proud of and something to tell the kids about after all these years with Wales."

Saunders made his debut in 1986 against the Republic of Ireland and a 74th cap would see him overtake Ian Rush and Peter Nicholas to leave only the goalkeeper Neville Southall ahead of him on 92.

Charlton's John Robinson has a stomach muscle strain but is expected to train today.

webTitle: Pakistan player reported missing in action

fields.headline: Pakistan player reported missing in action
fields.trailText: Pakistan's first tour of England, which began with a 3-0 drubbing at freezing Bury on Wednesday, has shivered from bad to worse after one of the tourists' brightest young prospects disappeared.
fields.body:
Pakistan's first tour of England, which began with a 3-0 drubbing at freezing Bury on Wednesday, has shivered from bad to worse after one of the tourists' brightest young prospects disappeared.

Nasir Iqbal, 18, has not been seen since attending a training session with his team-mates on Tuesday afternoon. Police have logged the midfielder as a missing person and believe he may be in the Bristol area.

Iqbal, who boasts 11 caps and was last seen wearing his Pakistan Football Federation green blazer, is part of a 20-man playing squad, none of whom speak English, on a two-match tour of the country. They play Coventry City at Highfield Road on Sunday.

The Pakistan manager Ali Nawaz and the tour's organisers insist Iqbal is staying with relatives in the Bolton area, having been injured before the game at Gigg Lane. "He damaged tendons in his knee on Sunday twisting his ankle on the heavy ground," said Phil Kennedy of Sapphire Enterprises.

But Greater Manchester Police confirmed last night that they were still trying to trace the teenager. "The team is flying back to Pakistan next week and they are trying to find him," said a spokesperson. "As far as we're concerned Mr Iqbal is still missing."

Alan Shearer has flown to the United States to consult a specialist over his persistent knee injury. The Newcastle and former England captain will meet Dr Richard Steadman in Colorado after suffering a setback in his recovery from surgery. The 30-year-old was sidelined for nine weeks before making his comeback in Newcastle's 1-0 home defeat to Manchester City last month, but jarred his knee in a practice match two weeks ago.

webTitle: Boro give up on deadline deal for Carbone

fields.headline: Boro give up on deadline deal for Carbone
fields.trailText: Deadline day's most high- profile transfer deal, Middlesbrough's signing of Bradford City's Benito Carbone, collapsed at the last minute yesterday. Middlesbrough had hoped to sign the Italian striker on a free transfer, but failed to agree on the length of his contract.
fields.body:
Deadline day's most high- profile transfer deal, Middlesbrough's signing of Bradford City's Benito Carbone, collapsed at the last minute yesterday. Middlesbrough had hoped to sign the Italian striker on a free transfer, but failed to agree on the length of his contract.

Carbone had passed a medical and agreed to take a small cut on his £40,000-a-week wages to move to the Riverside after only seven months in west Yorkshire, but held out for a three-year contract. Boro, though keen to add to their attacking ranks, were prepared to offer only a 15-month deal.

Though the former Internazionale striker will cost the Bantams up to another £350,000 this season, the City chairman Geoffrey Richmond put on a brave face. "I could not be happier Beni is staying with us," he said. "I know for certain the supporters will feel the same. He was absolutely magical for us against Manchester City on Saturday."

With relegation looming, City will hope to off-load Carbone, who has three years to run on his contract, to an Italian club in the summer.

The annual frenzy of big-money last-minute deals failed to materialise, with clubs reluctant to spend while doubts persist over the future of the transfer system.

West Bromwich Albion just about sealed the biggest deal of the day. They signed Leicester City's centre-half Phil Gilchrist on loan four minutes before the deadline and hope to complete arrangements for a £500,000 transfer today.

The Sheffield Wednesday striker Andy Booth, who recently spent a goalless loan spell with Tottenham, returned to his first club Huddersfield in a £300,000 deal. He scored 54 goals in 123 appearances for the Terriers before moving to Hillsborough for £2.7m in 1996.

The Wednesday caretaker manager Peter Shreeves reinvested some of the funds to make Trond Egil Soltvedt's loan move from Southampton permanent and has signed the Saints' former England winger Stuart Ripley, 33, on loan until the end of the season.

webTitle: Video releases: Keeping the Faith, Dancer in the Dark, Freeway II

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Keeping the Faith | Dancer in the Dark | Freeway II
fields.body:
Keeping the Faith
Rental and DVD rental
Buena Vista
Cert 12
Rating: ***

A romantic comedy with an IQ, which already makes it a bit of a rarity. Edward Norton and Ben Stiller are the boyhood friends who grow up to be a Catholic priest and a rabbi in New York. Jenna Elfman is the childhood friend turned high-powered businesswoman who causes emotional chaos during a visit. Keeping the Faith benefits from a smart and eccentric script by Stuart Blumberg, a debutant in director Norton, and good pacing and timing from its reliable leads. It feels like friends having fun together and letting us in on the joke. It also shows a fond regard for New York's great ethnic diversity - the plot unfolds as a drunk Norton's confession to a barman who turns out to be a Sikh Catholic Muslim with Jewish in-laws. In one of the film's most warmly funny scenes, Stiller imports a black choir into his synagogue in despair at the standard of the congregation's singing. Norton and Stiller treat preaching as a form of stand-up comedy while they consider a joint Jewish and Irish religious centre. Phrases like "kosher nostra" get flung around and for an hour or so, this is a breath of fresh air in the rather fetid ambience we call rom-com. So it's a big disappointment when Norton allows it a very orthodox (if not Orthodox) ending.

Dancer in the Dark
VCI/FilmFour Retail and DVD
(£19.99)
Cert 15
Rating: **

Perhaps the most controversial Cannes winner ever - the announcement that it had won the Golden Palm was met with a storm of booing - and it's easy to see why. In the first place, Lars von Trier's Dogme style (wobbly camerawork and apparent improvisation) is all wrong for a musical. In the second, our heroine, Björk, has to fight against the kind of manipulative plotting you thought had gone out with weepies in the silent cinema era. She's going blind, her son's going blind and she is horribly mistreated by people she thought were her friends. Director von Trier pulled off the greatest heartbreaker of the last decade in Breaking the Waves, which makes you wonder how he could get it so spectacularly wrong here. If we are supposed to be sobbing at the plight of our plucky heroine trapped in Robin Day specs and big Pauline Fowler cardigans, the natural reaction is to laugh at the Danish director's outrageous manipulation, Dickensian sentimentality and careless plotting. "In a musical, nothing dreadful ever happens," says Ms Gudmundsdottir. In this one, it's all so dreadful you wonder if the enigmatic director is having a joke at our expense, especially in the shock ending. It's especially a shame for Björk, (who has showed she can dominate a camera with no props in the video for Big Time Sensuality and did her own little mini-musical in It's Oh So Quiet) and for Catherine Deneuve, once the star of a stylish musical, The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, and here lumbered with a ludicrous best friend/fairy godmother role. For incongruous musical numbers, stick to Always Look on the Bright Side of Life, which, come to think of it, would have worked rather well with the finale here.

Freeway II
Rental High Fliers
Cert 18
Rating: ***

Aka Confessions of a Trickbaby. Gleefully trashy and outrageous road movie in which Crystal (armed robber, sexual psychopath, drug dealer, car thief and bulimic daughter of a crack addict) busts out of prison with Cyclona (just your basic delusional serial killer lesbian). They hit the road and make for Tijuana to see Cyclona's favourite nun, Sister Gomez. Crystal is played by the magisterially stroppy Natasha Lyonne and Sister Gomez, surprisingly turns out to be the great lost auteur Vincent Gallo. John Landis also turns up as a judge. fields.bodyText: Keeping the Faith Rental and DVD rental Buena Vista Cert 12 Rating: *** A romantic comedy with an IQ, which already makes it a bit of a rarity. Edward Norton and Ben Stiller are the boyhood friends who grow up to be a Catholic priest and a rabbi in New York. Jenna Elfman is the childhood friend turned high-powered businesswoman who causes emotional chaos during a visit. Keeping the Faith benefits from a smart and eccentric script by Stuart Blumberg, a debutant in director Norton, and good pacing and timing from its reliable leads. It feels like friends having fun together and letting us in on the joke. It also shows a fond regard for New York's great ethnic diversity - the plot unfolds as a drunk Norton's confession to a barman who turns out to be a Sikh Catholic Muslim with Jewish in-laws. In one of the film's most warmly funny scenes, Stiller imports a black choir into his synagogue in despair at the standard of the congregation's singing. Norton and Stiller treat preaching as a form of stand-up comedy while they consider a joint Jewish and Irish religious centre. Phrases like "kosher nostra" get flung around and for an hour or so, this is a breath of fresh air in the rather fetid ambience we call rom-com. fields.headline: They should be so lucky
fields.standfirst: The Popstars album is pure Stock, Aitken and Waterman, laments  Betty Clarke
fields.trailText: The Popstars album is pure Stock, Aitken and Waterman, laments Betty Clarke.
fields.body:
Hear'Say
Popstars (Polydor)
Rating: **
£14.99

Hear'Say have been inescapable for the past few months. Even before they became a group with a terrible name, their every move was under debate. As 3,000 hopefuls were ruthlessly - and amusingly - whittled down to five lucky victims, the personalities behind the pop dream came under scrutiny. Kym and her kids! Noel and his mum! Suzanne and her unwise hair extensions! And after the TV show, the makeovers and the freakish dolls, here, finally, is the music.

The single Pure & Simple is already at number one with its sultry, All-Saints-meets-Oasis-in-Top-Shop charm, and rightly so. It's a great pop song and would have been a success regardless of who had recorded it (word has it that Posh Spice was lined up for the honour). Unfortunately, it's entirely unreflective of the rest of the Popstars album. While Pure & Simple is an up-to-date take on the classic Motown style, Hear'Say have looked to the days of Stock, Aitken and Waterman as inspiration for most of this debut. Popstars couldn't be more indicative of the late 1980s if it came as a picture disc with Grolsch bottle-tops for your Doc Martens.

This is a place where the boys are sweet, while the girls - Kym Marsh, Myleene Klass and Suzanne - pick and choose who they want to play with. Poor old Noel Sullivan and Danny Foster don't get much of a look-in: occasionally they're allowed a duet and they're humoured with a lot of harmonies, but essentially this is a girl's world, and a world where only one girl is really allowed to be a pop princess. That's Marsh.

Marsh's vocals smother almost all of the mid-tempo songs and drown out everyone else involved. It's strange that such pains were taken to form a group, when only one singer is really allowed to shine. The producers who have put this ultra-slick album together obviously see something in Marsh's voice that goes straight over my head. She has a good range, but she's too much of a cruise-liner diva. Her bland, mannered vocals on Another Lover put a smiley face on a confusing tale of love and heartbreak, while Carried Away has her crooning about her faith on an overblown ballad that's sickly sweet. On Not That Kind, Marsh is Kylie Minogue to Foster's Jason Donovan; the pair play musical footsie to a fun-in-the-sun sound taken from Janet Jackson's The Best Things in Life Are Free. "It's good when we're together, but it's hard when we're apart," they sing. The same could be said for their album.

Three tracks in particular are just horrible. Colourblind, a utopian vision of life where love is all that counts, has a worthy sentiment, but the track, one of the few that breaks a sweat, is too fast for the vocals. The group sound like they're trying to keep up with the beat, and a melodic guitar rhythm struggles to make itself heard. There's a "Why bother?" element to the brief version of the Mama's and the Papa's classic Monday Monday, which manages to lose the atmospheric weariness of the original thanks to the stage-school pronunciation of every word. What was once light and airy becomes a leaden and cold karaoke interpretation. And then there's Bridge Over Troubled Water, which showcases Hear'Say's gift for tight harmonies, but should have remained the group's personal warm-up mantra rather than becoming an album track.

The nice moments on Popstars come wrapped in Backstreet Boys stylings. Breath and I Didn't Want You Anyway are sassy, classy slices of pop, while Make It Happen has more of a club feel, thankfully resigning Marsh to backing vocals as it sways its hips to the disco beat. Best of all is One, with the squelchy keyboards and bass from Stevie Wonders's Superstitious adding some funk to the "All I need is somebody, someone who'll be getting down at my party" refrain. It's the only time Hear'Say try something a bit different and it's great, the key change in the middle of the song adding a bit of sauce to the proceedings.

Having survived Nasty Nigel's comments to win a place in the public's affections, Hear'Say should find life in the pop jungle simple, and Popstars is destined to be a massive success. It's just a shame it couldn't be great on its own merits too.

fields.headline: Classical CD releases
fields.trailText: Strauss: Violin Sonata; Stravinsky: Divertimento; Bartok: Romanian Folk Dances | Scriabin: Complete Preludes | Ravel: Cantates de Rome - Myrrha, Alcyone, Alyssa | English String Miniatures: works by Elgar, Bridge, Wood, Ireland, Delius, Warlock, Bush, Vaughan Williams | Vaughan Williams: Symphonies 8 & 9
fields.body:
Strauss: Violin Sonata; Stravinsky: Divertimento; Bartok: Romanian Folk Dances
Repin/Berezovsky (Erato)
Rating: ****
£14.99

The choice of works may be rather bizarre - only Richard Strauss's Sonata was originally conceived for violin and piano, the other two pieces are arrangements - but the playing of both the violinist Vadim Repin and the pianist Boris Berezovsky is so full of character and commitment that the results are always involving. Repin's rich, forward tone is perfectly suited to the ripe romanticism of the Strauss, while Berezovsky's effortlessly technique is always well on top of the great fistfuls of notes in the piano part. They combine to give the music a wonderful, ambitious sweep.

Stravinsky's Divertimento was the composer's own adaptation from his ballet The Fairy's Kiss, and in that succession of numbers and the miniaturised acerbic quality of the Bartok the duo combine absolute rhythmic precision with real presence and wit.

Scriabin: Complete Preludes
Piers Lane (Hyperion, 2 CDs)
Rating: **
£26.99

An integral set of all of Scriabin's piano preludes makes a lot of sense. He kept returning to the form throughout his life, and the sequence of 90 miniatures faithfully charts the evolution of his musical language from its Chopinesque beginnings in the set of 24 Preludes Op 11, composed in the early 1890s to the rarefied harmonic experiments of his final years, when he abandoned key signatures altogether.

Unfortunately, though, Piers Lane is not the ideal pianist for such a survey; his robust, rather over-insistent playing lacks the necessary delicacy and suggestiveness to make the most of what are sometimes almost evanescent inventions, while his limited range of keyboard colour is insufficient to realise all of Scriabin's endlessly imaginative textures. Music that should glisten in an array of ever-changing hues becomes persistently monochrome.

Ravel: Cantates de Rome - Myrrha, Alcyone, Alyssa
Gens/Delunsch/Amsellem/ Beuron/Uria-Monzon/Groves/Tezier/Barrard/Orchestre Capitole de Toulouse/Plasson (EMI)
Rating: ****
£14.99

Ravel's repeated failure to win the Prix de Rome, the most coveted prize for young composers in France at the turn of the 20th century, has become part of musical folklore. In four successive years from 1900 to 1903 he entered the competition, which required candidates to jump through a series of academic hoops before finally composing a cantata on a prescribed text. On the first occasion Ravel did not even reach the final stages, but after that he did at least get as far as writing the required cantatas in which he tried desperately to conform to the academic norms expected. But he still failed to convince the jury (which included Massenet and Saint-Saëns) that he deserved the prize.

The cantatas have hardly been heard since, and this collection, which contains some wonderfully refined singing and playing, is certainly a fascinating curiosity, but it only very rarely sounds like the Ravel we know. It must have been hard for a composer of his discrimination to respond positively to texts as leaden and arch as these.

English String Miniatures: works by Elgar, Bridge, Wood, Ireland, Delius, Warlock, Bush, Vaughan Williams
English Northern Philharmonia/Lloyd-Jones (Naxos)
Rating: ***
£14.99

The tendrils of David Lloyd-Jones's English-music survey with the English Northern Philharmonia - the orchestra of Opera North in its concert-hall incarnation - spread far and wide. This is their second collection of small-scale character sketches for string orchestra, to go alongside their hugely impressive cycles of Bax and Bliss that are already well under way. With the exceptions of Elgar's Sospiri, and Frank Bridge's arrangement of Sir Roger de Coverley, nothing here is really well known - there are two more Bridge's folk-tune re-workings, a three-movement Fantasy-Concerto by Haydn Wood, Vaughan Williams' Charterhouse Suite, Delius's Air and Dance, and Peter Warlock's 60th-birthday tribute to him, as well as Geoffrey Bush's Consort Music. None of it is going to set the world ablaze, and in truth one or two pieces are rather bland, but everything is played with real affection and expertise.

Vaughan Williams: Symphonies 8 & 9
London Philharmonic/ Haitink (EMI)
Rating: ****
£15.99

Bernard Haitink ends his survey of Vaughan Williams's symphonies with the last and least performed works in the cycle. Both are products of the 1950s, when Vaughan Williams was in his 80s, and they generally recapitulate much of what he had explored in the previous half-century. Yet there are innovations, especially in the Eighth, where the array of tuned percussion in the orchestra adds a new aura to his scoring in the outer movements, while in the Ninth, the inclusion of three saxophones and an important part for a solo flugelhorn gives the work a special, rather autumnal flavour. The generally reflective mood of both pieces suites Haitink very well - his account of the third movement of the Eighth, for strings only, is raptly elegiac, and he relishes the sombre scoring and sometimes elusive meaning of the Ninth too, without ever neglecting the firm bone-structure that underpins it.

 To order any CD call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: Classical CDs of the week: new recordings of Mahler

fields.headline: Power struggle
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements on new recordings of Mahler that range from wild and wonderful to deeply tame
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements on new recordings of Mahler that range from wild and wonderful to deeply tame.
fields.body:
Mahler: Symphony No 8
Eaglen/Schwanewilms/Ziesak/Fulgoni/Larsson/ Heppner/Mattei/Rootering/Prague Philharmonic Choir/Netherlands Radio Choir/Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra/Chailly (Decca, 2 CDs)
Rating: *****
£14.99

Mahler: Symphony No 2
Suga/Stutzmann/Shinyukai Choir/Saito Kinen Orchestra/Ozawa (Sony Classical, 2 CDs)
Rating: **
£17.99

Mahler: Das Lied von der Erde
Urmana/Schade/Vienna Philharmonic/Boulez (Deutsche Grammophon)
Rating: ***
£14.99

With the release of a titanic version of the Eighth Symphony, Riccardo Chailly enters the final stages of his Mahler pilgrimage, with just the Second, Third and Ninth still to record. As a cycle it is as consistently revelatory in its own way as the previous landmark versions by Haitink, Bernstein and Tennstedt were in their own eras. Chailly's ability to combine total structural integrity with a marvellous sense of the music's inner drama is really put to the test in the two huge panels of the Eighth, the first a setting of the medieval hymn Veni Creator Spiritus, the second built upon the last scene of Goethe's Faust.

Chailly welds them together unhesitatingly, demonstrating that they make a totally complementary pair: the celebratory assertiveness of the first part, with its busy polyphony and intricate double fugue, is answered by the ever more rarefied spirituality of the second. He is as assured in his handling of the great outbursts of the opening - every strand clear every counterpoint perfectly weighted - as he is in the much more pictorial second, when the refinement of the Concertgebouw playing really comes into its own, with every scene painted in its own distinct instrumental hue.

With a superb line-up of singers, led by Jane Eaglen's Magna Peccatrix, with Ben Heppner's Doctor Marianus and Peter Mattei's Pater Ecstaticus, this is a performance of totally consistent theatricality.

Alongside such galvanised singing and playing Seiji Ozawa's account of Mahler's Second, the Resurrection Symphony, seems very tame indeed. Technically the instrumental contribution is first rate - the Seito Keinen Orchestra is a truly international-class band, though lacking any special character of its own, but Ozawa is unable to imprint any character upon it or indeed to inject any kind of drama into what is arguably the most apocalyptic of all symphonies. The first movement simply goes through its rhetorical motions, hardly hinting at any of the numinous grandeur that should come; the central movements are bland to the point of anonymity; the final vocal movements lack any kind of conviction.

The disappointments of Pierre Boulez's Das Lied von der Erde are not so obvious, but no less critical. Boulez's Mahler cycle for Deutsche Grammophon has been patchy thing, only occasionally catching fire, and this is one of the instalments in which the vital spark deserts him, though as expected he is masterly in the way in which he realises every fleck and thread of the orchestral tapestry, unfolding the final Abschied with cool assurance and the considerable bonus of the Cleveland Orchestra's ravishing playing, but none of the movements is sufficiently characterised, and the soloists lack sufficient personality to impose that extra dimension themselves. The mezzo-soprano Violetta Urmana is a fine singer, and her first appearance in the work Der Einsame im Herbst is the high point of the performance, but the tenor Michael Schade is really out of his depth in a role requiring a voice of real heroic quality combined with the perceptions of a lieder singer. All he can produce is a small-scale, rather wheedling sound that is totally inappropriate here. There are at least half a dozen versions of this extraordinary song symphony that deserve far better recommendations than this.

fields.headline: Beaten to a pulp
fields.standfirst: A band made entirely of bass players, Rod Stewart's vulnerable side, and a bit of a mix-up with Talvin Singh. The week's pop CDs reviewed
fields.trailText: A band made entirely of bass players, Rod Stewart's vulnerable side, and a bit of a mix-up with Talvin Singh. The week's pop CDs reviewed .
fields.byline: Paul Lester, Caroline Sullivan, Dave Simpson and Maddy Costa.
fields.body:
Talvin Singh
Ha (Universal/Island)
Rating: **
£15.99

Leytonstone-born Talvin Singh calls himself The Cultural Nomad; Ha, the follow-up to 1998's Mercury music prize-winning OK, was recorded in studios across the globe, from Madras and Bombay to London. Even so, Ha is no stylistically varied tour de force. Instead of a violent collision of opposites to make sparks fly you get a collage effect, all pretty patterns and curlicues. Or, to put it another way, Ha offers less friction than fusion, a puree so smooth you can barely taste it. Both extremes of Singh's musical spectrum are compromised here. Depending on your vantage point, either the drum'n'bass and electro-funk rhythms are smothered by traditional instruments such as sarengi, tablas and Indian harp, or one's enjoyment of the latter is ruined by the intrusion of the former. Ha might well prove educational, and certainly it is Singh's prerogative to provide a showcase for his heritage, but that doesn't mean it's any good. (PL)

Rothko
In the Pulse of an Artery (Bella Union)
Rating: ***
£8.99

London band Rothko are the first rock outfit to be comprised of three bassists - Jon Meade, Crawford Blair and Mark Beazley. They are aided and abetted on their third album by Simon Raymonde (ex-Cocteau Twins), who produced and engineered, sings (in a low murmur) and plays sitar on Imprint of Leaves. Considering the limited number of instruments, Rothko offer quite a full sound, exploiting the dynamic range of the bass guitar. On Smudges and Smears they achieve a choral effect reminiscent of the Cocteau Twins, while on Moments Cracked Open they evoke the cloying intimacy of My Bloody Valentine. Elsewhere there are echoes of Peter Hook's sepulchral tones for Joy Division. And the sleeve homages to everyone from Duchamp to Devo, William Blake to ZZ Top, suggest Rothko could go anywhere next. (PL)

Sandy Dillon
East Overshoe (One Little Indian)
Rating: ****
£13.99

Initially, Sandy Dillon's record company took the classically trained Massachusetts songwriter to be "a 300lb black woman". She has a feral rawness that makes the mistake easy to excuse. Despite spending the past 20 years at the hands of managers who modelled her on "Madonna or whoever was making money at the time", she has emerged with her unique voice intact, and an appetite for warped country and western. The fictional town of the album title leads you to expect something very different from the frayed, end-of-tether atmosphere that hovers over the songs. Dillon's Hammond organ lurks around corners, the icing on cracked vocals that render the lyrics pretty much indistinguishable. The words "Jesus Christ, you killed me with a knife" do leap from Filth and Dust, though - just the sort of blasphemy that would bring a smile to Nick Cave's face. But it's the crazed rural blues of Hot Potato and Girl's Desperate Measures where you really fear for her health. Some album. (CS)

Nelly Furtado
Whoa, Nelly! (Dreamworks)
Rating: ***
£14.99

Why Whoa, Nelly!? Is this meant to imply that this Canadian-Portuguese singer is so precocious that she has to be protected from her own talent? You might not believe it if your only experience of her is the twittery top-five single I'm Like a Bird, but there's an irritating kernel of truth to it. She writes, produces and is at home in several genres, including the pastoral pop of the single, the urban R&B of Shit on the Radio, and Latin sounds. Her thinnish voice could get up a few noses, but that's the price she pays for otherwise being pretty damned good. (CS)

Rod Stewart
Human (Atlantic)
Rating: ***
£15.99

While not at the stage where only a Tom Jones-style duets album can haul him into the charts, Rod Stewart was none the less smart to get on the phone to Macy Gray, All Saints producer K-Gee and ex-New Radical Gregg Alexander before recording Human. Although old granite-lungs hasn't changed much over the centuries, the beloved R&B and soul of his youth have, and his new collaborators bring him up to speed, near enough. The red-wine-and-candlelight sheen K-Gee brings to the title track is attractive, and Stewart preserves the mood by not rasping like a wildebeest. Subtlety, in fact, is the watchword most of the way through: on the Macy Gray-penned Smitten, and on Don't Come Around Here, a duet with Mercury prize-nominated Helicopter Girl that coaxes out a hitherto hidden vulnerability. Which perhaps accounts for the cover of Prince's Peach that closes the album on a more characteristic bawdy note. Old dog plus new tricks equals funny old album. (CS)

Gorillaz
Gorillaz (Parlophone)
Rating: ****
£14.99

Although his collaborators comprise various hip-hop/graphics types, much of Gorillaz sounds like the solo album Damon Albarn probably never thought he would make. After the emotionally traumatic last two Blur albums, it's almost a relief to find Albarn in sunny, wryly observant mood. Gorillaz is no Parklife, but it radiates a similarly innocent joie de vivre that suggests that, for the first time in ages, Albarn is enjoying making music. Gorillaz is steeped in old US electro, UK punk, world music and Sly & Robbie. Some tracks mimic Blur at their most lightweight, but with credit to Albarn's bandmates, things rarely stay too predictable for very long. Indeed, his "animated" pals seem to have inspired Albarn to really push his vocals. When not doing a perfectly laconic impersonation of New Order's Bernard Sumner, he's soaring into the upper reaches once occupied by Labi Siffre and Jimmy Cliff. Like any good cartoon, Gorillaz are difficult to love deeply, but impossible not to like. (DS)

South
From Here On In (Mo'Wax)
Rating: ***
£11.99

Historically, indie/guitar labels haven't done too well launching dance acts, so it will be interesting to see if hip beats luminaries Mo'Wax can reverse the process. The label proclaims that the debut from guitar protégés South "will undoubtedly become one of the albums of the year". Which year might that be? Several of South's songs are inescapably reminiscent of the Stone Roses in their pre-dance, goth period. Producer James Lavelle has done little to rein in his signing's irritating tendency towards stoned meanderings, often ending up with a dreary Beta Band. However, within the sludge, there are sparks of magic. Here On In boasts a fabulous hook, guitarist Jamie McDonald's playing is exemplary and evocative throughout, and at their best the trio radiate the intuitive chemistry that comes with playing together from the age of 14 (South are now all 22). With correct guidance, South could yet mature into something special. After bearing with them during the two years it took to make this album, it's hoped Mo'Wax will allow them time to go that extra mile. (DS)

Alfie
If You Happy With You Need Do Nothing (Twisted Nerve)
Rating: ***
£11.99

The title to Alfie's debut album almost amounts to a manifesto. Like their label-owner/mate Badly Drawn Boy, they radiate bumbling, lackadaisical charm; but whereas Damon Gough is secretly hiding a driving ambition, this young Manchester quintet seem really content to go with the flow. So this album is actually a collection of gleaming, remastered songs from their Bookends, Montevideo and Alfie EPs; Bookends aches, Manor House Farm sighs and You Make No Bones bounds delightfully, but it's still a disappointment not to find more new tracks. The two that are here are superb: Umlaut opens with quiet, skittering riffs, suddenly skates into huge metallic chords, and thrillingly maintains the dynamic interplay throughout, while Lee Gorton battles with a synth to create the squealiest sound. 2 Up 2 Down, meanwhile, is the only track where vocal duties pass over to cellist Matt McGeever; his voice is all ingenuous sweetness, and can actually hold a tune, which is more than can be said for Gorton. Elsewhere, though, it's the contrast between Gorton's cats-on-the-rooftops miaow and McGeever's lovingly drawn-out cello lines that makes Alfie such an enticing prospect. On this strength, the debut album proper promises to be extraordinary. (MC)

I Am Kloot
Natural History (We Love You)
Rating: ****
£12.99

After a couple of fantastic singles, I Am Kloot's album doesn't entirely live up to expectations. What made those early songs so exceptional was the way the Manchester trio created a dark, velvety update of cabaret torch songs that reeled with passion and drama. Twist (the one with the line "there's blood on your legs, I love you") is easily the highlight here, closely followed by opening track To You. On both, Pete Jobson's strolling basslines and Andy Hargreaves's casual, airy percussion are a blissful match for John Bramwell's heartfelt but ghostly voice and warm guitar. But if the new songs are more straightforwardly acoustic pop, they are still powerful and involving, largely because Bramwell writes a mean, slanted, invigorating lyric. Just don't leave the album playing: the final hidden track is a right old mess. (MC)

fields.headline: Jazz CD releases
fields.trailText: Joshua Redman | Tubby Hayes | Booker Ervin
fields.body:
Joshua Redman
Passage of Time (Warner)
Rating: ***
£13.99

American saxophonist Joshua Redman has enjoyed a meteoric rise since his emergence in the early 1990s. He has been very adept at meeting a non-specialist audience half-way, without compromising a serious and highly skilful commitment to improvising. Redman's influences cover a great deal of jazz sax playing, beginning in the pre-war swing era and moving up to Coltrane and beyond, though Sonny Rollins is always an insistent voice in his head. With last year's Beyond, Redman purred through a selection of postbop originals with a sharp quartet, and this disc features the same band (with Aaron Goldberg on piano, Reuben Rogers on bass and Gregory Hutchinson on drums) on eight more self-penned pieces. A typical piece of Redman quirky urbanity opens the session: an unaccompanied tenor soliloquy full of unexpectedly pastoral melody lines mixed with guttural multiphonics. Most of the subsequent music is coolly delivered, rhythmically fluid postbop. The leader's presence is at times strongly reminiscent of Wayne Shorter's in the mid-1960s Miles Davis quintet. Redman's tonal range is confirmed in the silky, diaphanous Minuet and the exquisite whisper of Time, and his relish for spontaneous conversation is irrepressible on the opening tenor/bass exchange on Enemies Within. But the tunes aren't really strong enough to suggest that Redman the composer is going to upstage Redman the sax virtuoso.

Tubby Hayes
The Eighth Wonder (Jasmine)
Rating: ***
£10.99

In the notes to this 1958/59 assortment, the late Tubby Hayes, the most technically accomplished British jazz multi-instrumentalist of the 1960s, rather undiplomatically starts off by rubbishing the UK jazz scene he was working in. Protesting that he couldn't find local musicians who could start and stop in the same places, Hayes elected to play most of the parts himself on the 1958 recordings here - three of the tracks are overdubbed takes in which he plays all the sax parts, plus piano and vibes. But if Hayes managed to tidy things up by this method, the resulting music suffers from the opposite problem to the one he was complaining about - over-orderliness and an absence of earthiness. Unfortunately, too, the selection of material reflects 1950s British jazzers' economic dependence on Mecca ballrooms. The real group takes are by far the most engaging - like the two versions of Tin Tin Deo, in which Hayes's muscular sound, inventiveness in double-time bop phrasing, and shrewd control of contrast confirm why his international reputation was so big at the time. The most dazzling episode is the Unidentified 12 Bar Theme, a lo-fi recording on a Charlie Parker-like fast blues that seems to defy the limits of dexterity, physical or mental. An uneven but fitfully fascinating collector's item.

Booker Ervin
Structurally Sound (Blue Note Connoisseur Series)
Rating: ***
£8.99

Booker Ervin, an American saxophonist of the same period as Tubby Hayes, who lent a characteristically rough gravitas to some Charles Mingus bands, was working within the same bop-based framework as Hayes. But Ervin's intonation is more wilful and raw, his texture more bluesy and impassioned. An entangling of graceful and unlovely sounds is a natural balance for him. This 1966 quintet set finds Ervin joined by Charles Tolliver on trumpet and John Hicks on piano, on a mixture of standards, originals, and soon-to-be-standards such as Oliver Nelson's Stolen Moments. It's a classic Blue Note set of the era in its directness and robustness, and hard bop is its dominant mode, despite strong infusions of Coltrane-quartet McCoy Tyner into Hicks's playing. Ervin is strongly reminiscent of later Sonny Rollins (both saxophonists owed some of their inspiration to Dexter Gordon) in the pugnacious shaking of long notes by the throat, and a bleary, shrugging, phlegmatic way of resolving phrases. Oliver Nelson's Stolen Moments gets a familiar delivery of the theme (Ervin catches the right hot, shimmery tenor sound for it) with a powerful series of variations with emphatic funk overtones. John Hicks plays with thumping chordal momentum on Tolliver's uptempo Franess, and Ervin crashes into his break on Shiny Stockings as if battering his way into a locked room. Even White Christmas has a laconic quality. Vintage hard bop on the cusp of things to come.

 To order any CD call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: Jazz CD of the week: Amaryllis

fields.headline: Reflections on the keys
fields.standfirst: John Fordham hears a brilliant pianist in a lyrical trio setting
fields.trailText:
Marilyn Crispell/Gary Peacock/Paul Motian
Amaryllis (ECM)
Rating: ****
£14.99
fields.body:
Marilyn Crispell/Gary Peacock/Paul Motian
Amaryllis (ECM)
Rating: ****
£14.99

Like running into a relative of somebody you know well, this probing set betrays a gesture here, a mannerism there, a certain chime to a laugh or intensity of glance that is at once familiar and new. At times it's like listening to a Keith Jarrett or Bill Evans trio, but with those pianists' vocabularies eerily rewritten.

For two decades, Marilyn Crispell has been one of the most highly regarded pianists at the sharp end of contemporary jazz. This Baltimore-raised musician went to the New England Conservatory to study classical music, and then became diverted by the work of Cecil Taylor and John Coltrane. She eventually became keyboard partner for the fearsome multi-instrumentalist and composer Anthony Braxton, with whom she could share enthusiasms from Coltrane to Hildegard of Bingen. Crispell's subsequent recordings for the Leo label in the 1980s and 1990s revealed that a new improvising piano giant had arrived, with such exquisite explorations of new landscapes as For Coltrane and Gaia (both 1987).

This set has Crispell investigating a more lyrical and less awesomely pianistic music. Four of the pieces were improvised from the off, but sound like compositions, such is their conviction and clarity of phrasing. The ruminative opening passages, initially draped around Gary Peacock's plummy, luxurious bass sound, reflect the atmosphere of the whole set. Paul Motian, one of the closest things to a sound-painter in jazz drumming, rustles around Crispell, scattering offbeat snare sounds and brief shimmers of cymbals, occasionally hinting at distantly martial tattoos that cajole and fade.

Marilyn Crispell has grown more intrigued by the late Bill Evans in recent years, and the connection is clear in the voicings of some chords, even if there is little of Evans's urgent orthodox swing. Requiem, a piece that echoes Crispell's baroque-music origins, also recalls the dolorous harmonies of Annette Peacock - a composer to whom Crispell devoted an earlier trio disc.

Not all the music is reflective - December Greenwings has a folksy, countryfied line and a playfully skippy feel in Crispell's improvising, and on the fast, liquid Rounds Crispell plays a devastating solo of tidal energies and hurtling precision. Maybe it is too close to contemporary classical music (in texture and pacing) for some jazz listeners, but this represents the continuing evolution of a remarkable force, in an ideal context.

The ruminative opening passages, initially draped around Gary Peacock's plummy, luxurious bass sound, reflect the atmosphere of the whole set. Paul Motian, one of the closest things to a sound-painter in jazz drumming, rustles around Crispell, scattering offbeat snare sounds and brief shimmers of cymbals, occasionally hinting at distantly martial tattoos that cajole and fade. Marilyn Crispell has grown more intrigued by the late Bill Evans in recent years, and the connection is clear in the voicings of some chords, even if there is little of Evans's urgent orthodox swing. Requiem, a piece that echoes Crispell's baroque-music origins, also recalls the dolorous harmonies of Annette Peacock - a composer to whom Crispell devoted an earlier trio disc. Not all the music is reflective - December Greenwings has a folksy, countryfied line and a playfully skippy feel in Crispell's improvising, and on the fast, liquid Rounds Crispell plays a devastating solo of tidal energies and hurtling precision. Maybe it is too close to contemporary classical music (in texture and pacing) for some jazz listeners, but this represents the continuing evolution of a remarkable force, in an ideal context.  To listen to this CD call 09068 626 828 and use code 2088*. fields.headline: Visiting Crete without flying
fields.standfirst:
I began flying in 1941 but two years ago I found I was afraid of flying. My wife and I would like (in our dotage) to visit once more the island of Crete. Are there any recognised routes for doing this?
Ken Williams
fields.trailText: I began flying in 1941 but two years ago I found I was afraid of flying. My wife and I would like (in our dotage) to visit once more the island of Crete. Are there any recognised routes for doing this?
fields.body:
 The two main Cretan ferry companies are ANEK Lines, represented in the UK by Viamare Travel (020 7431 4560) and Minoan Lines, represented here by Magnum Travel (020 8360 5353).

Both run services from Pireas to Crete, generally sailing overnight in 7-11 hours. Both companies run from Italy to the Greek port of Patra where coaches wait on the quayside for the three-hour coach journey to Pireas. The crossing from Italy takes 20-30 hours and there are daily services in summer. ANEK's Italian ports are Trieste and Ancona, while Minoan Lines sail from Venice and Ancona. All the ships are large ferries with cabins, restaurants, sun decks, swimming pools, etc, and this is normally a very relaxing part of the journey.

The Italian ports can be reached from the UK by train - the easiest routes are probably the overnight services from Paris to Venice, or Bologna where you change for Ancona. The total journey time is 4-5 days, including some time for sightseeing in Paris and Venice.
Geoff Hamer

 If time is no problem, drive to Ancona and take the car ferry to Patras. The usual route would then be on the motorway to Athens and ferry from Piraeus, but driving in Athens is like finding yourself in Le Mans race with fewer rules. So I would go from Patras through the Peloponnese (don't miss Bassae - a beautiful temple and fewer tourists than Delphi) to Gythion. Here you can get a ferry via Kithira to Crete. You will arrive at Kasteli, in the north west corner of Crete which is the quietest and most attractive parts of the island.
Antoinette Moses

fields.headline: Blair agrees PR vote deal
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy have stitched together an election manifesto compromise that keeps alive the Liberal Democrats' ambition for "fair votes" in Westminster elections - at the price of delaying the promised referendum until after a review in 2003-4.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy have stitched together an election manifesto compromise that keeps alive the Liberal Democrats' ambition for "fair votes" in Westminster elections - at the price of delaying the promised referendum until after a review in 2003-4.

The compromise has the backing of senior Labour ministers on both sides of the "fair votes" argument, as well as Kennedy loyalists. Some opponents of reform claimed that further delay will help them. A despondent Charter 88 called it a setback.

After weeks of speculation that Labour would ditch its half-hearted commitment to a referendum on proportional representation (PR) it emerged last night that Mr Blair and the Liberal Democrat leader met on Tuesday and found a face-saving formula that will encourage tactical anti-Tory voting on polling day.

As a result, Labour's manifesto will be far less hostile than many MPs expected to the "AV-Plus" version of PR suggested by Lord Jenkins in his 1998 royal commission report - shelved in the face of active pressure on Mr Blair by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and a majority of Labour MPs and activists.

Noting that the government has "introduced major innovations in electoral systems used in the UK, for the Scottish and European parliaments and Welsh and London assemblies", the draft formula for Labour's manifesto commitment goes on to promise to "review the experience of the new systems and the Jenkins report to assess whether changes may be made to the electoral system for the House of Commons".

Though it will also confirm that the referendum which Mr Blair promised Paddy Ashdown in 1997 "remains the right way to agree any change at Westminster" the imposition of a review is a vehicle for further delay in exactly the same way that Mr Brown's "five economic tests" have delayed the referendum on whether to join the euro.

In reality it means that Mr Blair wants to wait until after the PR systems introduced since 1997 - a "top-up" system for Scotland and Wales, regional lists for Europe and a second vote in the election for London mayor - bed down over a full cycle. That means no review before 2003-4 at the earliest.

Mr Kennedy and his allies - who had feared that the referendum would be ditched altogether after the enmity expressed at labour's Exeter conference last summer - were relieved, since grassroots critics had said he was caving in.

Labour's text "makes clear that the case and cause of constitutional reform, particularly fair votes, proceeds. The Liberal Democrats will continue to keep pressure on the Labour party for a referendum as soon as possible," Mr Kennedy said in a statement.

Robin Cook, the most senior pro-PR politician close to Mr Blair, was happy as were backbench campaigners for a PR system for the Commons like Stephen Twigg, the MP who beat Michael Portillo thanks to tactical voting in 1997.

But Sir Ken Jackson, the engineers' leader and a fierce defender of the traditional first-past-the-post system said he was "very relaxed".

"This certainly moves even closer to our position than we agreed at Exeter," he said. "The prospect for some sort of review after 2003 are very dim."

Pam Giddy, director of Charter 88, agreed when she said that "without a timetable we are moving back from 1997, four years on and we are further away. It's all about keeping the Labour party in line rather than moving the argument forward."

It is no secret that Lord Jenkins and Sir Paddy feel let down as Mr Blair - sitting on Labour's 179-seat 1997 majority - remains "unpersuaded" of the case for PR.

Many Labour MPs and activists with experience of PR have been dismayed by coalition politics with the Liberal Democrats in Scotland and, less formally, in Wales. They blame PR for "giving away" power.

Lord Jenkins' AV-Plus plan would keep individual constituencies while requiring MPs to get more than 50% of the votes cast before they claim victory. There would also be a top-up element of around 150 MPs to make the Commons result "fairer". Purists call the hybrid even worse than the status quo.

Millbank says the Blair-Kennedy compromise is "pretty much in line" with Labour's Exeter formula. But insiders in the pro-PR camp claim that they have rescued their cause from near-disaster since then.

"There is more to this deal than meets the eye," said one, pointing to the removal of anti-PR language which dominated Labour's policy statement at Exeter.

fields.headline: Worldwide: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: David Cohen looks at how the planet's press is viewing some familiar educational problems around the world
fields.trailText: David Cohen looks at how the planet's press is viewing some familiar educational problems around the world.
fields.body:
"It has become the fashion in Britain to affect to distrust or disdain the arts of speaking and writing so far as they are concerned with ordinary everyday life," John Ibbitson, an educator and sometime commentator, observed in a tart opinion piece published last weekend in Canada's Globe and Mail.

The nation's classrooms, he added, "have made themselves a ready agent of this crippling process".

Mr Ibbitson's words ought to have had a familiar ring for British readers: Winston Churchill first spoke them in 1924. The commentator invoked the warnings not to fulminate against the Brits but to explain an apparent fall in education standards closer to home.

His column was published in the wake of the Ontario government's recently released test scores showing that almost one of every three grade ten students in the nation's most populous province is unable to pass a basic literacy test.

In Australia, where falling educational standards are an editorial potboiler, a leader article published in the Sydney Morning Herald bemoaned a national survey showing that over half of the country's academics believe their growing dependence on private sector money prevents them criticising organisations on which their university depends.

"The sorts of financial squeeze now being applied to universities will inevitably put pressure on an intellectual culture," said the Herald. "In an environment where the attraction and retention of fee-paying students becomes the measure of success, adequate safeguards are needed more than ever to ensure that slippage of standards does not occur."

Another commentary on educational standards appeared in South Africa's Sunday Times. Op-ed columnist Cornia Pretorius examined the issue of the status of Afrikaans as a teaching language, even while insisting that it was time for the national debate to be brought to an end.

The subject had surfaced again last week when verbal blows were exchanged between the country's education minister, Kader Asmal, and Andreas van Wyk, the vice chancellor of the University of Stellenbosch, who said that English appeared to be "more equal" than other languages, despite the constitutional equality of all official languages in South Africa.

The commentator said, "The government and historical Afrikaans universities cannot allow the debate about language to drag on. The time and energy they have wasted on the topic over the past few years should rather have been spent on producing a maximum number of graduates."

The Russia Journal, a weekly business newspaper, said this week that any opposition to standardised university entrance examinations on the part of local educators was entirely understandable. "After all," it noted, with a cough, "if there are no entrance exams to hold and no grades to assign, who will be willing to bribe the universities' admissions boards?"

On a less ironic note, the article said that what perhaps needed to be first attended to in the Russian education system "are the infrastructure and ethics of test-taking".

Writing op-ed in the New York Times, however, Andrew Delbanco, a professor of humanities at Columbia University, wasn't so sure about university entrance examinations, period. Welcoming the renewed national debate over the value of the SAT, he said: "Every year I read that our incoming students have better grades and better SAT scores than in the past. But in the classroom, I do not find a commensurate increase in the number of students who are intellectually curious, adventurous or imbued with fruitful doubt."

Instead, he complained, many student "are chronically stressed, grade-obsessed and, for fear of jeopardising their ambitions, reluctant to explore subjects in which they doubt their proficiency."

A publication that has usually remained dependably close to the political line taken by its nation's government, the Daily Star in Lebanon, appeared to depart from it earlier this week.

It reprinted verbatim the contents of a passionately anti-Syrian speech delivered the night before by Selim Abou, the rector of St Joseph's University, at his campus in Christian east Beirut, where over recent months there have been dozens of arrests of students protesting against Syria's "occupation" of its smaller neighbour.

"The moment will come," the rector warned, "when Syria will understand, perhaps before the Lebanese political representatives themselves, that it is in its interest to completely withdraw from Lebanon, to respect the country's independence and sovereignty, and to establish relations of mutual recognition."

A long editorial in the Nigerian Guardian weighed in on the apparently insoluble problem of campus violence between the nation's students and government security forces.

Two universities - the University of Lagos and the Enugu State University of Technology - have recently been shut down for an indefinite period following clashes involving the two sides, and the Guardian had no hesitation in taking the side of the overdogs.

Although "the police account is substantially different from the story that is being held on to tenaciously by the students union," the leader article said, it seemed obvious that these young people have over recent times "become more violent" and their campuses were being used as "hide-outs for hardened and closet criminals ... and cultists."

The claim that police have in some circumstances needed to shoot unarmed students for their own protection "may well be right".

fields.headline: Protesters hit Huntingdon profits
fields.trailText: Controversial animal testing company Huntingdon Life Sciences plunged to a pretax loss of £10.9m last year, as protesters succeeded in scaring away customers.
fields.body:
Controversial animal testing company Huntingdon Life Sciences plunged to a pretax loss of £10.9m last year, as protesters succeeded in scaring away customers.

Attacks on the company reached a climax towards the end of the year, when banks withdrew their support and Huntingdon sought refinancing to avoid going bust.

Chairman Andrew Baker admitted yesterday that the campaign, which included threats to staff and shareholders, had "a negative impact on orders and study starts during the fourth quarter and the early part of 2001".

He added, however: "It has been encouraging to see the recent very public support for the company and the work it undertakes from a broad coalition of the media, government and from the industries we serve."

Despite the later setbacks, strong demand early in the year helped push Huntingdon's revenues up 9% to £58.2m.

Demand for testing from US companies increased, following tighter laws requiring that all products containing a certain quantity of new chemical entities were tested on animals.

A Huntingdon spokesman said the extra demand came from outside the pharmaceuticals industry. In addition to drugs, Huntingdon tests personal care products, cleaning substances and foods on animals.

Underlying losses edged up 8% to £2.6m as business slowed. On top of this, refinancing costs amounted to £1.2m, interest payments totalled £7.3m and the company took a £1.1m write-off in the value of properties.

Huntingdon has been the subject of fierce demonstrations since a documentary film showed staff being cruel to animals in 1997. The company's management has since changed.

fields.headline: Elizabeth Young
fields.standfirst: The incarnation of the counter-culture, she brought an original, unsnobbish and intellectual voice to the world of literary criticism
fields.trailText: The incarnation of the counter-culture, she brought an original, unsnobbish and intellectual voice to the world of literary criticism.
fields.body:
I first met the critic and writer Elizabeth Young, who has died aged 50, at a reading by the novelist Iain Sinclair in the old operating theatre of St Thomas's hospital, London, a sinister relic of the Victorian fascination with surgery as a spectator sport. It was the perfect environment for Liz - seriously literary and distinctly Gothic.

It is often said that people have a love affair with books; with Young, it seemed literally true. After a difficult period in the early 1980s, she emerged as one of the most brilliant literary critics of her generation.

She combined an extraordinary breadth of reading with the kind of dedication to her craft that if, by any chance, she was asked to review a novel by someone she had not read before, she would make sure to read everything they had previously published first. Above all, she knew what she liked. Her reviewing showed a fierce commitment to truthfulness as the key to literary value.

She was an extraordinarily un-snobbish reader, as happy to rave about the talent of a little-feted horror writer like Graham Masterton as to discuss her (slightly) more predictable and critically respectable favourites, such as Hubert Selby or Djuna Barnes, the Greenwich Vill- age avant-gardist whose eccentricities were a particular inspiration. It was scarcely surprising that she was the first critic to notice Irvine Welsh's Trainspotting.

Young looked for truth in strange places, both in reading and in life. Her vast book collection contained mini- libraries on the literature of drugs and of true crime - the more sensationalist the better. The issue of drugs, in particular, was always close to her heart. She wrote several powerful features for the Guardian on the mess of hypocrisy and sadism of British drugs policy.

Elizabeth Young was born in Lagos, Nigeria, the daughter of Scottish missionaries. She grew up largely in British boarding schools, then studied in London, Paris and York, where she eventually gained a B Phil. Mostly though, she educated herself through reading.

In the 1970s, she worked in London's finest alternative bookstore, the late-lamented Compendium Books, in Camden Town. More than simply a bookshop, Compendium was also a cultural centre for the punk-rock scene. And punk rock, with its dark humour, utopian nihilism and fondness for black clothing suited Young better than the hippie ethos ever had. The Clash, in particular, were regular visitors, writing The Prisoner about the shop's patriarch Nick Rochford. Young later made her only acting appearance in their feature film, Rude Boy.

The 80s were a hard decade for her, as dabblings with drugs became more serious. Late in the decade, however, with the support of her husband Pete Mannheim, she cleaned up her act and began reviewing for the left-wing London listings magazine, City Limits, encouraged by another Compendium alumnus, Nick Kimberley. She soon moved on to the New Statesman and then, in 1992, published her first book, Shopping In Space (co-written with Graham Caveney).

This was ostensibly a study of the new wave of American writers spearheaded by the likes of Bret Easton Ellis, Jay McInerney and Tama Janowitz. She was rightly feted by the magazine's literary editor, Jenny Turner, who was uncharacteristically awed by her protégé, but initially, I found her to be the weirdest, most outlandish, scariest creature I had ever clapped eyes on.

She had been the gorgeous girl giving a blow job in the public lavatory in the movie Rude Boy. She was a friend of Kathy Acker, and - astoundingly - entirely understood Ms Acker's challenging literary agenda. She was a disinherited daughter of the Rown- tree confectionery dynasty. She had a vast knowledge of voodoo. Most perverse of all, she didn't drink or smoke dope.

She also looked unbelievable; her beautiful face was white and matte, her dark purple hair was streaked with vivid colour. Her clothes, all black, trailed and wisped around her, and her hands were weighed down with gothic jewellery. Most bizarrely, she wore huge platform trainers, then by no means a fashion item.

She even smelt uniquely weird. Later, these scents would become familiar to advocates of aromatherapy. On her, in the 1980s, they recalled the whiff of an old-fashioned sweet shop. Some people smell of their family's money; Liz had contrived to cut out the middle-man.

The other great shock about Liz was her terrible shyness and lack of self-confidence. She stammered when talking to people she didn't feel at ease with - a situation she would go to great lengths to avoid. She was a gentle and unassuming soul, entirely unaware of the intimidating figure she cut, and shocked and frightened - like a maiden aunt - by the world at large.

She lived her life in the retreat of an oddly fictional existence, fuelled by novels and literary theory, sustained by her own writing, and supported by her husband and soulmate, Pete. She spotted immediately the importance of Dennis Cooper, the American writer whose exposure of the cruel, dark underbelly of gay life, made him persona non grata for most critics. Because the English tend to only value someone when they are dead, I don't doubt that Pandora's Handbag will be received with the attention it deserves. But I would like to think that this intellectual autobiography, which both warns off and seduces the reader into a life devoted to books, would have been noticed had Liz been there to enjoy its publication. And those of us close to her would not be left with the sense of having lost something very rare - an intellectual who was both sharp and compassionate.

webTitle: Science: a little of the mystery of the universe solved

fields.headline: Could white dwarfs explain a secret of the universe?
fields.trailText: British and US astronomers will report today that they have solved a bit of the biggest mystery in the universe.
fields.body:
British and US astronomers will report today that they have solved a bit of the biggest mystery in the universe. At least part of the missing 90% of its mass could be in the form of burned-out stars.

White dwarfs are are only about the size of the Earth, but they can weigh half as much as the Sun. A tea spoonful of white dwarf matter would outweigh an elephant on Earth.

Nine out of 10 stars will end up as white dwarfs - cores of stars that turn blue as they cool. According to a report in the US journal Science, these could provide some of the gravitational glue that holds the galaxies together.

Theorists argue that the tight, swirling shapes of the billions of star systems could only be explained by the gravitational pull of a mass 10 or even 100 times greater than can actually be seen.

Astrophysicists have been struggling for 50 years to explain what they call the "dark matter" that makes up the missing mass of the universe. They proposed exotic creatures such as "wimps" (weakly-interacting massive particles), bizarre phenomena called cosmic string and machoes, or massive compact halo objects.

In the latest research, scientists from the University of California at Berkeley, Edinburgh, the Institute of Astronomy at Cambridge, and Nashville, Tennessee, identified 38 previously unseen white dwarf stars. They calculated that if the rest of the sky had the same frequency of white dwarfs, then the mass of these could add up to between 3% and 35% of the galaxy.

Nigel Hambly from the Royal Edinburgh Observatory began the research with 196 digitised plates which covered 10% of the southern sky. On these, he spotted 92 puzzling objects all within 450 light years of Earth. He and colleagues looked for them through a 4-metre telescope in Chile. Of the 69 they could find, 38 were white dwarfs.

So, the researchers argue, unseen white dwarfs - if there are enough of them - could be part of the missing mass. The rest, however, could still be composed of strange, as yet unidentified things.

"This research is not just about white dwarfs and dark matter. It also has implications for the history of the galaxy," said Didier Saumon, of Vanderbilt University, Nashville.

webTitle: Action urged on student debt to cut drop-out rate dropping out

fields.headline: Action urged on student debt to cut drop-out rate dropping out
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The government is today urged by a Labour-dominated committee of MPs to give careful consideration to its plans for an expansion of the number of people entering higher education amid fears about funding and debt which could lead to new students failing to complete their courses.
fields.body:
The government is today urged by a Labour-dominated committee of MPs to give careful consideration to its plans for an expansion of the number of people entering higher education amid fears about funding and debt which could lead to new students failing to complete their courses.

In a report on student retention in higher education, the Commons education select committee said increased student numbers must be matched by increased funding. The MPs also called for urgent research on how the abolition of maintenance grants is affecting drop-out rates, particularly among students from poor backgrounds.

They also demand that the earnings threshold at which graduates have to start paying back their student loans should be raised substantially. The Tories said they would double the threshold to £20,000 a year - a figure endorsed by committee chairman, Labour MP Barry Sheerman.

The UK has the second lowest drop-out rate in the world (17%), but the MPs stress that further action must be taken to reduce the number of students who do not achieve a recognised qualification.

The prime minister set a target of 50% of those between 18 and 30 taking up university places by the end of the decade. But the MPs urged "very careful consideration to any further expansion in the number of places".

The committee recommended that universities should work towards "mutual recognition" of first year modules to allow portability so that students who left an institution in their first year would not be discouraged from returning to college.

With a clear link between student drop-out rates and quality of teaching, the government was also urged to address the growing disparity between academic salaries and those in other careers. The bureaucratic demands of annual research assessments on staff should be reduced to allow them to concentrate on teaching.
