webTitle: Alice Liddell's archive up for auction

fields.headline: Alice Liddell's archive up for auction
fields.trailText: An archive of papers, photographs, books and letters relating to Alice Liddell, for whom Lewis Carroll wrote Alice in Wonderland, is expected to fetch more than £2m at a Sotheby's auction this summer.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
An archive of papers, photographs, books and letters relating to Alice Liddell, for whom Lewis Carroll wrote Alice in Wonderland, is expected to fetch more than £2m at a Sotheby's auction this summer.

The book, one of the best selling children's books of all time, was based on a story Carroll made up to amuse Alice and her two sisters on a river boat trip in 1862. It was published three years later, sold 5,000 copies within months and has sold millions worldwide since. The Alice collector's market has been fanatical for a century. The original manuscript, handwritten and illustrated by Carroll at Alice's request, was sold at Sotheby's in 1928 for the then record price of £15,400, almost £500,000 in today's money. She sold it to pay bills on her husband's death, and it is now in the British Library.

"To collectors of children's literature or 19th century portrait photography this collection represents the Holy Grail," Peter Selley, a literature specialist at Sotheby's, said yesterday. "This was Alice's personal collection, and has never been outside her family."

The book made her famous in her own lifetime. The archive was maintained by her and by her descendants, and includes her wedding ring, the only Lewis Carroll letter to her still in private hands, and a hand-coloured version of his famous photograph of her as a bare-shouldered beggar maid.

It has an early copy of Alice in Wonderland inscribed "to her whose namesake one happy summer day inspired his story", estimated at up to £300,000.

Lewis Carroll was better known to his contemporaries as the mathematician and photographer Charles Dodgson. The sale includes an album of his photographs - of Alice and her sisters and his Oxford contemporaries - that is regarded as the best to come on the market, and is estimated at up to £800,000.

fields.headline: £250m sweetener for teachers
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: The teacher shortage
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, will today announce a £250m sweetener for the teaching profession, which will for the first time allow schools and governing bodies to give substantial pay increases direct to certain teachers under the long awaited system of performance-related pay.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, will today announce a £250m sweetener for the teaching profession, which will for the first time allow schools and governing bodies to give substantial pay increases direct to certain teachers under the long awaited system of performance-related pay.

In a speech to headteachers which may help to lift the gloom caused by industrial action, Mr Blunkett will set out details of how they will be able to use their discretion to reward exceptionally good young teachers, as well as longer serving managers such as heads of department and deputy heads.

The government wants heads and governing bodies to have the flexibility to reward staff through the new direct grants, for which £100m has been set aside for the next financial year (2002-03) and £150m for the subsequent year.

Addressing the annual conference of the Secondary Heads Association in Newport, south Wales, Mr Blunkett will reveal that more than 150,000 teachers are set to pass the "threshold" which will give them an automatic pay rise of £2,000 as well as access to a new, higher payscale.

Those rises will be funded separately by the government to the tune of £400m a year, and backdated to last September.

But for the first time, heads will be able to reward exceptionally good young teachers not yet eligible for performance-related pay, by giving them double increments. They will also be able to give extra money to so-called advanced skills teachers; teachers with a management role such as deputy heads; and senior teachers.

A teacher working outside London with seven years' classroom experience who had successfully crossed the threshold would expect to earn £31,000 with extra money from the direct grant - or £34,000 in London - while those with a management role would get £41,000 outside London and £44,000 in the capital.

Of some 200,000 teachers deemed eligible to apply to cross the threshold, about 180,000 applied and more than 150,000 are likely to be successful.

Mr Blunkett is today expected to thank heads for their work in bringing in the new system of performance-related pay.

Heads are also hopeful of some simplification of the complicated assessment task, once the first year of performance-related pay is in place.

webTitle: Nursing home funding case wins review

fields.headline: Nursing home funding case wins review
fields.trailText: A 94-year-old man refused funding for his nursing home care has won the right to take his case to a judicial review, in a case with major implications for thousands of elderly people. Maggie Murray reports.
fields.body:
A 94-year-old man refused funding for his nursing home care has won the right to take his case to a judicial review, in a case with major implications for thousands of elderly people forced to sell their homes to fund residential care.

The court hearing followed Dorset county council's decision to discontinue paying residential care fees for Christopher Beeson, who had "gifted" his home to his only son, Michael, just two years before being taken into care.

The review will examine whether a council can legitimately host an appeal against its own decision to refuse to pay for nursing home care, or whether a genuinely independent appeals body should be set up.

In what is being seen by lawyers as a landmark case, Mr Beeson's legal team argued at the high court in London that he had been denied the right to a fair trial under article 6 of the Human Rights Act.

"The case is not principally about the right to be placed or looked after by a local authority but how the authority makes the decisions about your care; particularly, in this case, about who is to fund that care. At the moment there is no independent right of appeal against a decision by the local authority," said Conrad Haley, a solicitor from the Public Law Project, who is acting for Mr Beeson.

"We are arguing that the decision that was made here was in breach of our client's human rights because they don't allow him to take his case and have it reheard by an independent body."

He added: "The only tribunal available was the social services complaints panel, which is made up of two local authority councillors, and we are saying that cannot be described as independent."

The way has now been opened for a full judicial review after the high court ruled there was an "arguable" case to answer.

Mr Beeson, who is now cared for at a residential home in Bridgwater, gave his home to his son, Michael, in April 1997. The court was told that Mr Beeson senior was concerned that his son would be homeless after the break-up of his marriage.

After Mr Beeson's health deteriorated in the spring of 1999 he was assessed by Dorset social services and found to be in need of residential care. Initially, he was funded by the local authority, but later the funding was withdrawn and an internal appeal panel upheld the decision.

The panel found there had been a "deprivation of assets for the purposes of avoiding payments for the accommodation". That finding was upheld by the council's director of social services in October last year.

A spokesperson for the council said that they did not want to comment before the outcome of the judicial review.

fields.headline: Water world
fields.standfirst: This week Sue conquers her fear of deep water and goes scuba diving off the Great Barrier Reef. Now more than half-way through her trip, she tries not to think about the length of time she has left
fields.trailText: Week 17: Alice to Cairns This week Sue conquers her fear of deep water and goes scuba diving off the Great Barrier Reef. Now more than half-way through her trip, she tries not to think about the length of time she has left
fields.body:
I can't stick to my usual chronological week this time because I'm too excited about my scuba dive on the Great Barrier Reef. Yes - I DID IT. My ears hurt, I was terrified, physically uncomfortable and very tense for the whole time - but it was worth it. What a strange, kaleidoscopic world there is down there: multi-coloured coral with waving pink and orange tentacles, huge blue clams that open and close, little purple flower-like things that pop back into the rock if you come near, and bright fish of all shapes, sizes and colours - butterfly, angel, damsel, boxfish, snappies and a huge Napoleon Maori Wrasse, to name but a few identified from the chart I bought... All in all, an experience in an alien wonder-world from which I still have not recovered. My thanks to Gay and Dee for their encouragement.

It was a great day on the Ocean Free, the sailing boat that took about 30 of us to the reef off Green Island. The was sea calm and there was not a cloud in the sky. I had a go at snorkelling first, and was not too proud to use the buoyancy vest as Katy had suggested in her email. The whole day I was impressed by how attentive the crew were, continuously counting bodies and snorkels to make sure everyone was safe and well. When it was time to do the introductory dive I was so nervous that they gave me an instructor all to myself. He was very patient, going down very slowly and making me give the OK sign every couple of minutes. Poor bloke, his hand must have been sore from my tight grip. I have to admit to feeling extremely chuffed with myself: although I doubt that I'll ever do it again, I'll probably frame my little certificate when I get home.

It has been a good week in Cairns - I've been taking it easy and not done a single tour. On Saturday evening I had a delicious meal with Peter and Sally, my real Australians, and picked their brains on the subject of where to go next. Sunday, it was off to the market village of Karunda in the rainforest - up by way of a little scenic railway which was built by hand in the late 19th century, and down on the impressive skyrail, a cable-car ride over miles of rainforest canopy.

On Wednesday, needing a day out of the sun after the boat trip, due to a few red patches despite factor 30 sunscreen, I hired a car and took myself off to Port Douglas, Mossman Gorge and Daintree. It was a lovely drive with sugar cane fields and forested hills on one side and the sea on the other. Port Douglas is a smart holiday town for the rich and beautiful - there wasn't a backpacker in sight. At Daintree a decision had to be made: should I take a trip down the river or continue to Cape Tribulation, where Captain Cook landed? I decided to press on along the winding road, broken in places by flood water. The Cape is beautiful: rainforest and mango swamps come down to meet the sea, and the reef, empty of people (the odd tour bus can be avoided with a car) was still much as it would have been when Cook landed. Here I was again able to capture one of those delicious moments of feeling at one with nature.

Thursday I was ready for more sand, sea and reef, so I caught the ferry out to Fitzroy Island for a bit of walking, swimming and a final snorkel. My batteries are definitely feeling recharged.

In yet another of life's coincidences, a young couple who had also won a trip around the world with HMV, and were financing it by writing on a website, had moved in next door. They were doing a very similar route and we swapped travel stories. I am green with envy at their lap-top. I have been in the same hostel for nearly a week - a record. Why change, when the pool even has a jacuzzi at one end? The other people in my six-bed dorm have changed though - one lot of young girls for another. Today we have a man, a 6ft 3in dreadlocked American - not much room for his stuff among the jumble of skimpy tops, mobile phones, hairdryers and assorted beauty aids which these girls have in abundance. I must be getting old - I keep wondering how they manage on so little sleep night after night.

On to Sydney tomorrow, where I'm meeting yet another Australian, Annie, who was doing the return tour that I did in India - we overlapped for a couple of days in Kathmandu. That trip seems a long time ago now. I am increasingly conscious that I have less time left to go than I have already spent on my journey... Best not to think about it.

I will be going into my New Zealand folder this coming week to start to plan where I am going and how I will travel - bus or car? My plan to learn some Spanish before going to South America is not going too well. So far I can count to 10 and say hello and goodbye. I must begin in earnest - mañana.

Until next week.

webTitle: Foot and mouth crisis hits charities

fields.headline: Foot and mouth crisis hits charities
fields.standfirst: For environmental charity organisations, the effects of the rural shutdown have been devastating, writes Louise Tickle
fields.trailText: For environmental charity organisations, the effects of the rural shutdown have been devastating, writes Louise Tickle.
fields.body:
The ramblers aren't rambling any more, environmental volunteers are kicking their heels at home, wildlife reserves are closed across the country and some charity employees are now losing their jobs.

As the government encourages the countryside to open up to boost tourism and the rural economy, what have been the wider effects of foot and mouth on the environmental organisations that help to make the British countryside a pleasure to visit?

For British Trust for Conservation Volunteers (BCTV), whose raison d'etre is the conservation work carried out by its volunteers, the rural shutdown has been devastating.

Chief executive Tom Flood said: "Most of our volunteering projects in rural areas have closed, and the environmental holidays we run in the UK have also been cancelled. The income loss caused directly by foot and mouth for this financial year alone stands at £200,000. It's unfortunately got to the stage where we are looking at laying off staff because there is literally no work that they can do."

A major concern for BTCV is the effect on its volunteers. Efforts are being made to redeploy new deal environmental task force volunteers in town parks, while others are helping to signpost the footpath restrictions.

Some people, from vulnerable or excluded groups in society, have taken a big step just by making the commitment to volunteer, and often their project is an immensely valuable source of social interaction.

"Our volunteers are a very precious resource to us and we don't know if they will still be there when this is all over - some are unemployed, or elderly or young offenders making a new start. When their projects shut down it is particularly upsetting - and of course we want them to stay with us, because there will soon be a huge backlog of work to be done," explained Mr Flood.

In a more hopeful move, The National Trust has just announced a phased reopening of 160 of its properties.

The trust's Jason Tanner explained their dilemma. "Our mission is to promote access to our properties so that everyone can enjoy them, and yet we also have important responsibilities to farming communities. The effects of a total National Trust shutdown are potentially disastrous for local people - for every National Trust job, nine other jobs are created."

The trust estimates that losses so far run at about £1m for March, and it hopes that the reopening under stringent safety criteria will encourage some of the 1.4m visitors it would normally expect in April to return.

It takes a lot to get ramblers off their beloved hills, but foot and mouth has done it. Clare Madron of the Ramblers' Association says the impact on her members has been simple; all 130,000 of them cancelled their walks with immediate effect.

Organisationally, the crisis has meant a huge increase in workload.

"Because we decided to concentrate our efforts on providing the most up to date information for members and the public, the PR and web site teams have been working 15-hour days. Advertising space that had been booked for recruitment has been used instead to get information to as wide a public as possible," said Ms Madron.

However, there are many animals that live in the countryside that foot and mouth won't affect. Spring has sprung and birds are starting to breed, their populations unmonitored for the first time in decades by the usually unstoppable combined forces of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB) staff and members.

The RSPB has a dual role in the countryside. Its reserves are visited by a million people each year, and it also manages farmland to create sustainable habitats for rare bird species. The charity emphasises that its absolute priority is to work with farmers to prevent the spread of foot and mouth, and all 160 reserves were closed a month ago. This is hitting the charity's income levels to the tune of £70,000 a month, and is also affecting recruitment.

Bird surveys have been suspended, which could affect the charity's lobbying on environmental protection, as bird populations are a vital indicator of the health of the countryside. Richard Farmer, reserves manager for RSPB Wales, said he has contract staff who were employed specifically for bird monitoring now unexpectedly racing through backlogs of paperwork.

The Lake Vyrnwy reserve in Powys highlights how interconnected his environmental work is with livestock management.

He said: "Part of managing the reserve for grouse and hen harriers involves grazing sheep on the heather moorland. We are still hoping that our sheep will get organic certification this summer, but there are foot and mouth outbreaks very nearby. Right now these are perfectly healthy sheep, but I have 300 ewes lambing in sub-zero temperatures and the restrictions mean we can't move them to a lambing shed. So, as a farming practitioner, the RSPB is going through much of the same pain as farmers in the rest of the country."

Mr Flood pointed out that however this crisis ends, there will be an enormous amount of environmental work to do in the countryside.

"Conservation charities will have to be involved in the debate about how to meet that need, and crucially, they must also have the capacity to be able to carry out whatever work is required. After the financial losses and staff cutbacks that everyone is now feeling, that capacity is going to be under tremendous strain," he said.

fields.headline: Tories face town hall misgivings
fields.trailText: Grassroots lack trust in the party's council policies, local government spokesman Nigel Waterson has said.
fields.body:
The Tories' local government leadership has yet to win the full confidence of its town hall politicians, shadow local government minister Nigel Waterson has suggested. The indication comes just weeks before local elections are scheduled to take place.

Mr Waterson said in a speech at the Conservative Councillor's Association conference in Coventry today, that many Tory councillors do not trust the party to deliver on its promises to decentralise more power to local authorities.

The Tories have over the past year unveiled a range of policies they claim will give councils and local people more choice about how they run their communities. These include pledges to end rate capping and give local authorities more power over planning decisions.

Opening the conference, Mr Waterson said: "At most of the meetings I go to, people ask what's going to happen when you become ministers [they say] when you get into government, it's all centralising."

In a bid to win over any doubters in the audience, Mr Waterson promised that the party's local election manifesto, to be unveiled next Thursday, would contain "cast-iron" pledges on local government.

These are likely to include the Tories' flagship "free councils" policy, in which the best authorities will receive new borrowing powers, a lighter-touch inspection regime and a reduction in their administrative burden.

The party's promise to review the government's best value service improvement scheme may also feature. The Conservatives believe best value and its attendant inspection regime are too costly and bureaucratic.

Mr Waterson admitted the manifesto was unlikely to contain any new policies, and a source close to the party, who has seen drafts of the document, recently said: "I don't think it's going to rock the world to its foundations. There'll be lots of stuff about free councils and losing financial restrictions on councils."

Critics of the developing Tory vision for local government point to the party's policy of putting a virtual end to council housing and its plans to effectively abolish the local authority role in frontline education provision.

Labour figures have questioned whether there is any point in devolving power to councils that have been stripped of two of their highest-spending services

fields.headline: Psychedelic dropouts
fields.standfirst: Drugs, mental illness, incongruous jazz combos - the recent batch of reissues aren't pretty, says  Alexis Petridis
fields.trailText: Drugs, mental illness, incongruous jazz combos - the recent batch of reissues aren't pretty, says Alexis Petridis.
fields.body:
One of the more disheartening pieces of recent music news was the announcement that the Beach Boys would be touring the UK this summer, as a support act to Status Quo. The Beach Boys now boast only one original member, singer Mike Love; what was once America's Favourite Band today consists of a bald man in his 60s bellowing sun-and-surfing oldies, surrounded by hired hands. A depressing sight, but after years of lawsuits and bizarre public arguments, it seems Mike Love is no longer on speaking terms either with the other surviving Beach Boys, Al Jardine and Brian Wilson, or with the concept of dignity.

As if to highlight the reduced circumstances of the current line-up, EMI has remastered and reissued the Beach Boys' 1960s back catalogue: 16 albums on eight CDs, including the dispensable Beach Boys Concert/Live in London ( ** ) and the contract-filling Beach Boys Party!/Stack O' Tracks ( * ). Unlike the bullish debuts of their British rivals the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, Surfin' Safari/Surfin' USA ( ** ) both sound tentative and awkward, a collection of songs knocked together to cash in on a teenage fad. By the time of Surfer Girl/Shut Down Volume 2 ( *** ) and Little Deuce Coupe/All Summer Long ( *** ), songwriter and producer Brian Wilson - surely the fastest learner in rock history - was already capable of crafting such sublime pop moments as Don't Worry Baby or I Get Around, but the albums still suffer from the indecent haste with which they were created. In the early 1960s, the Beach Boys were averaging an album every four months, and it shows. The CDs are padded out with teeth-gritting comedy skits, while Surfer Girl suffers from a lyrical monomania that tests the patience (Surfer Moon, Rocking Surfer, Surfers Rule, South Bay Surfer). Far better is the coupling of Beach Boys Today!/Summer (Days and Summer Nights!) ( ***** ), the one essential CD here, a startlingly mature collection of exquisitely arranged, beautifully sung tracks, as inspired as any music produced in the mid-1960s.

The remainder of the CDs hail from the era following the Beach Boys' artistic high-water mark Pet Sounds, and Wilson's drug-induced breakdown during the making of the doomed psychedelic epic Smile. Smiley Smile/Wild Honey ( *** ) and Friends/20-20 ( *** ) are disjointed and uneven: Wilson's genius only flickered intermittently - on Friends's lovely Time to Get Alone or Smiley Smile's chilling, acid-damaged Wind Chimes - as he struggled with his ruined psyche.

Brian Wilson wasn't the only Hollywood resident who spent 1967 going slowly insane while trying to create a psychedelic masterpiece. Up in Laurel Canyon, the already peculiar Arthur Lee was becoming more peculiar by the day, ingesting hopeless quantities of drugs and working on his band Love's third album, the remarkable Forever Changes (Warners/Rhino, ***** ). Now remastered, Forever Changes sounds both more gorgeous and more unsettling than ever. Few records so awash with strings and Mariachi trumpets sound this sinister, but then few records offer such a heady cocktail of impeccable pop songwriting, lavish orchestration and sweetly crooned lyrics about isolation and mental illness. It's a far cry from the buttercup-sandwich whimsy of most psychedelia: Wonder People, one of six outtakes added to the CD, was dropped from Forever Changes for sounding carefree. After the album flopped, it was all downhill for Love: the band broke up, two members were reduced to robbing doughnut stands to finance their addictions, and Arthur Lee - a zealous consumer of LSD - survived an overdose, briefly changed his name to Arthur Ex-Lax and currently resides in prison.

Another drawback of becoming a musical acid casualty is that future generations mistake your distress for charmingly dotty creativity and spend their own careers aping you. Take English singer-songwriter Robyn Hitchcock, who has spent the past 25 years as a kind of ersatz Syd Barrett, offering jangly psychedelia, deadpan vocals and look-at-me-I'm-nutty lyrics without the anguish or terror of the Pink Floyd founder's oeuvre. Largely ignored at home, Hitchcock has influential American fans: REM are sometime collaborators, Jonathan Demme made a film about him. Accordingly, the US label Matador has seen fit to add a boggling 26 extra tracks to Underwater Moonlight ( *** ), a 1980 album by Hitchcock's first band, the Soft Boys. Now a double CD, it's maddeningly inconsistent: great when it escapes its influences and delivers songs gleaming with harmonies and a pastoral eccentricity all of their own, irritating when it piles on the Monty Python rhymes and undergrad smuggery.

Drug-influenced rock of a less contrived and more disturbing nature is to be found on Royal Trux (Domino, * ), the eponymous 1988 debut of now-split alt-blues couple Jennifer Herrema and Neil Hagerty. During the album sessions, the duo's celebrated Keith Richard obsession stretched to cultivating ruinous - and audible - heroin habits: Royal Trux sounds exactly like two hopeless junkies in a cheap studio making up a horrid squall of off-key guitars, out-of-time drums, and tuneless moaning in lieu of vocals as they go along. More endurance test than album, it captures the desolation of acute smack addiction perfectly and is therefore no fun whatsoever.

Royal Trux is one of several albums from the American art-rock underground being reissued by UK label Domino. No less dolorous, but considerably more enjoyable, is Smog's 1992 mini-album Burning Kingdom ( **** ), which pits a gothic, Velvet Underground-derived guitar-and-viola grind against songwriter Bill Callahan's beguilingly mordant sense of humour. "Mother's smoking pot in bathroom," he gloomily observes on My Family, "I can hear her butt squeaking on the tub." A more mischievous wit is evident on Chicago post-rock pioneer Jim O'Rourke's Bad Timing ( *** ). A collection of lengthy acoustic guitar and piano instrumentals, Bad Timing is rescued from ponderous indulgence by self-deprecating musical flourishes, best sampled on the closing track, which meanders quietly for several minutes before its contemplative mood is disturbed by the incongruous arrival of a jaunty jazz combo.

With the compilation of early singles that comprises Pavement's Westing by Musket and Sextant ( ** ) proving only that Pavement became a lot more enjoyable when they eased up on the arty posturing and started writing songs instead, the true jewel of Domino's reissue project is There Is No One What Will Take Care of You ( ***** ), the first album by the Palace Brothers. These days, the Palace Brothers' leader Will Oldham goes under the name Bonnie Prince Billy and has his songs covered by Johnny Cash, fitting recognition for his role in rehabilitating country and western as a subversive musical force. Heartbreakingly stark and driven by Oldham's raw, cracked voice, the songs on There Is No One What Will Take Care of You strip away decades of Nashville gloss to reveal an unexpected vulnerability and tenderness. Desperate sadness has rarely sounded so wonderful.

A depressing sight, but after years of lawsuits and bizarre public arguments, it seems Mike Love is no longer on speaking terms either with the other surviving Beach Boys, Al Jardine and Brian Wilson, or with the concept of dignity. fields.headline: Broadcasters strike pay-per-view soccer deal
fields.trailText:
5pm: The Premier League is expected to complete a pay-per-view TV deal with BSkyB, ONdigital, Telewest and NTL within a month, writes Jason Deans.

Oct 18 2000: NTL pulls out of PPV soccer deal
fields.body:
The Premier League is expected to complete a pay-per-view TV deal with BSkyB, ONdigital, Telewest and NTL within the next month.

One source familiar with the deal, which is reportedly worth £181m, said it may be signed off in the next week but could take up to four weeks.

A short-form version of the agreement, which is expected to see 40 live PPV games per season offered by all four pay-TV operators over three years, has already been put before the Premier League chairmen.

The broadcasters and Premier League are now thrashing out the long-form version.

The Premier League has been seeking to put together a new PPV deal since its initial agreement with NTL was torn up by the US-owned cable TV operator in October.

That deal was worth £327m for 40 matches a year over three years.

BSkyB, which paid £1.1bn to hold onto its Premier League pay-TV contract last year, was barred from the bidding for PPV rights under the rules of the original rights auction.

Related story

Oct 18 2000: NTL pulls out of PPV soccer deal

fields.headline: Digital TV sets to get Kitemark-style label
fields.trailText:
12.45: The DTI is to speed the take-up of digital TV through a scheme to label digital TV sets, writes Jason Deans.
March 15: BBC board of governors under fire
fields.body:
In a bid to drive the take-up of digital TV, the government is expected to unveil a labelling scheme for TV sets later today.

The initiative, which will clearly label digital TV sets, is designed to clear up consumers' uncertainty about what they are buying.

Details of the scheme are due to be unveiled by the Department of Trade and Industry this afternoon.

"A lot of consumers have been misinformed on this issue," said a DTI spokeswoman.

"We want to make sure people know what they will be getting for their money."

Only last week, the Commons media select committee said there was an "urgent" need for a clear labelling scheme for digital TV sets in its report on the government's communications white paper.

Related story
March 15: BBC board of governors under fire

fields.headline: Russia calls for Balkans intervention
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Russia today blamed Nato for the current crisis in Macedonia and called on the international community to take urgent steps, up to and including the use of force, to prevent the escalation of the conflict in the Balkans.
fields.body:
Russia today blamed Nato for the current crisis in Macedonia and called on the international community to take urgent steps, up to and including the use of force, to prevent the escalation of the conflict in the Balkans.

"Now as never before the world community must show a united political will aimed at preventing a new, large-scale conflict in the Balkans," the Russian foreign ministry said in a statement.

It accused Nato of failing to quash what it called terrorist activities in Kosovo, southern Serbia and Macedonia.

The statement comes as the UN high commissioner for refugees estimated that more than 22,000 Macedonians have left their homes since fighting broke out last week.

Today, ethnic Albanian rebels engaged Macedonian government forces in isolated skirmishes, and the US military in Kosovo said that seven explosions were heard near the village of Tanusevci, on the border with Kosovo.

There were unconfirmed reports that the Macedonian army was trying to clear border villages because people there were suspected of having sympathised with the rebels.

"These developments are a direct outcome of Nato aggression against Yugoslavia and the subsequent new, misguided steps the Western countries have taken in Kosovo," the Russian foreign ministry said. "The policy of wooing the Albanian separatists and using them in fighting (former Yugoslav president) Slobodan Milosevic has led to an intractable and dangerous situation."

According to the statement, the problems in Kosovo have persisted after Mr Milosevic's departure from office because of the activities of Albanian rebels in northern Macedonia seeking to form an independent ethnic Albanian state.

The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, was to meet with the Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, at the EU meeting in Stockholm today, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. It was expected that Mr Trajkovski would seek the support of European leaders to help resolve the crisis.

Russia has historic and religious ties with the Serbs who dominate Yugoslavia, and strongly opposed Nato's airstrikes on Yugoslavia in 1999. Today's statement sees Mr Putin join Yugoslavia and Macedonia's political leaders in blaming the renewed insurgency by ethnic Albanians on Nato's failure to disarm militant groups in Kosovo.

fields.headline: Bottom, Broken, and Bent
fields.trailText: LITTLE ENGLANDERS
fields.body:
LITTLE ENGLANDERS

As usual, if you want the latest news of the crucial World Cup qualifiers, the Fiver is the place to come. Big John Hartson is likely to play alongside Dean Saunders and Craig Bellamy in a three-pronged attack as Wales take on Armenia. Scotland boss Craig Brown has no injury worries ahead of the match against Belgium. Keith Gillespie has recovered from a stiff neck and will play for Northern Ireland against the Czech Republic. And Feyenoord striker David Connolly will make his first start in nearly a year for the Republic of Ireland in Cyprus tomorrow night.

But we shouldn't just concentrate on the teams with a chance of getting to Korea-Japan 2002. What about plucky England, bottom of Group Nine with exactly the same record that the Faroe Islands have in Group One (except the Faroes have scored three more goals)? They take on Finland at Anfield tomorrow desperate to give a good account of themselves, so it's just as well star turn Steven Gerrard should be fit to play. "Gerrard practised today without any problems," coach Sven-Goran Eriksson announced this afternoon. "He did almost everything. If he does not have a reaction tonight he will be fit for tomorrow. His chances of playing are much better than 50-50!"

That's great news for the struggling minnows, who haven't even scored a goal in the tournament yet. Even better, wacky goalkeeping character Dave Seaman should be fit to entertain the crowds with his funny ponytail and amusing handling jokes. Not that he's certain to play - if you believe the manager's primitive mind games, that is. "Whatever I do with the goalkeeper it will be the right choice," promised Eriksson. "All four are very, very good. We will see tomorrow." England aren't just turning up to make up the numbers, either. "I've never thought about losing before a game," laughed their coach, his tongue surely in his cheek. "We want to win!" We're sure you'll join us in wishing this brave little nation all the best. If they fail, it certainly won't be for the want of trying!

OLD STORY

It's a curse getting old, as elderly Newcastle striker Ye Alan Shearer will tell you. The clapped-out old sod hardly ever plays these days, and has flown out to Colorado to see if Dr Richard Steadman, a specialist in pensioner ailments, can sort out his rusty old knee. Ee, it's been giving him gyp since, ooh, let me think, December. Yes, December. Anyway, the nice young doctor's taken a look, and told him to put his feet up, get some rest, and take frequent naps for at least the next four weeks. That might sort it without having to go under the knife.

However, despite this good news, Ye Alan is looking on the dark side (which, to be fair, is the prerogative of the senior citizen). "He told me that the surgery I had in December and the rehabilitation programme were both fine and there is a chance that rest will resolve the problem," he grumbled, as he shooed away a nurse who was approaching with a flannel and a bucket of soapy water. "If not, I might need additional minor surgery which would probably keep me out for the rest of the season," he harumphed, clearly unimpressed by the chap next to him who was having a little accident.

But you can't just put the elderly in a home and leave them to rot. So hooray for young Bobby Robson, who dutifully bounded in for a natter with his old warhorse. "He's such a valuable player, we need to get him absolutely right and top-deck," chirruped Bobby. "It's a slight worry to us, so we decided to go for a second opinion with full approval from our own surgeon," the Toon boss could be heard to explain, before he was totally drowned out by his captain's semi-coherent ramblings regarding varicose veins, recent episodes of Countdown, and the Blitz.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Many people in England don't like me. I was held responsible for Vialli's sacking, but just a week before, the press had been blasting him! I suddenly felt very powerful!!! I, Frank Leboeuf, was capable of getting a coach sacked!!!!!" - It's been a while, but it was only a matter of time before Frank Leboeuf went off on one again.

BENT (NOT BENT)

It can't be easy being a Chesterfield supporter at the moment. On the one hand, your club lies 10 points clear at the top of Division Three. On the other hand, it faces possible relegation following Football League charges which allege that the club is as bent as the city's famous Crooked Spire church. And today things got even murkier, with news that chairman Darren Brown has handed in his resignation, claiming "certain people" were trying to get him.

"I am convinced that certain people are trying to ruin my name and I am personally ready for the fight with them," said Brown in his best Scrappy Doo voice. Brown, whose vice-chairman Paul Grafton has also resigned, claims he has quit because the club's reputation was suffering from charges of financial irregularities made against him. But he insisted: "This in no way should be seen as me trying to run away from the current situation as nothing would have given me more satisfaction than to prove certain people wrong." And as he made his way down the M1, he added: "This decision is made purely in the best interests of Chesterfield Football Club."

Not surprisingly, it wasn't long before Chesterfield manager Nicky Law popped up with a string of footballing clichés. "I was shocked," he said. "It's news to us all and it's a shame for the chairman. He's come in with the right intentions but it hasn't worked out, which is a shame after all the effort he's put in. I got on brilliantly with him." What the loyal Spirite fans make of all this, heaven knows. This season they've endured rumour, innuendo, half their ground being shut, Football League charges, and now this. Is worse to follow at next month's tribunal, which will rule on the alleged financial irregularities? Let's hope not - although the way things are going, we'll need to keep everything crossed.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle are considering signing Argentinian teenage striker Facundo Bonvin from Boca Juniors.

Liverpool want Rangers midfielder Barry Ferguson and they're prepared to pay £10m for him.

According to the Sun, Kevin Keegan is ready for a return to football, and that's "a message that is certain to alert Southampton". Where's Glenn Hoddle going, then?

NEWS IN BRIEF

Century FM has been banned from covering England's game with Finland after waking up coach Sven-Goran Eriksson with a hoax call at 7.30am on Friday. "This is beginning to be a problem," said Eriksson. "When I phone managers to talk about players now they ask if they can call me back. They want to check that it's me and situation is not very nice. It's happened several times and now maybe I should have a code word. This is the first time it has happened to me in my career."

West Brom have completed the signing of Leicester defender Phil Gilchrist for £500,000 after he passed a medical at the Hawthorns this afternoon.

Airdrie, in provisional liquidation for more than a year, have been given the green light to complete their remaining fixtures this season. The news follows confirmation that a Fife-based consortium, led by Jim Innes, has been awarded preferred bidder status.

Hibernian wing-back Ulrik Laursen has signed a two-year extension to his contract at Easter Road.

Celtic midfielder Stilian Petrov has had an operation on his broken right leg, sustained in a collision with St Johnstone's Jim Weir.

Six players have been banned for match-fixing following an Italian Cup tie last year. Fabio Gallo, Sebastiano Siviglia and Luciano Zauri of Serie A side Atalanta and Alfredo Aglietti and Massimiliano Allegri of Pistoiese in Serie B were suspended for one year by the Italian Football Federation disciplinary committee. Former Atalanta player Giacomo Banchelli - now with Empoli - was banned for six months. Atalanta's Cristiano Doni and Pistoiese's Daniele Amerini, Girolamo Bizzarri and Gianluca Lillo were cleared of accusations.

Striker Con Boutsianis, who has been pressing for a place in Australia's World Cup qualifying squad, has admitted to being involved in an armed robbery. Boutsianis, who plays for South Melbourne, pleaded guilty to the theft of £18,000 from a Melbourne restaurant in January 1998 earlier today. The court was told Boutsianis was under financial pressure when he agreed to take part in the crime and received just £300 of the proceeds. He will be sentenced next month.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (3.05am)
"How naive you are to listen to all manner of humans, deities, demons and ex-footballers bleating about their puny scam-mongering. I am caretaker of the universe and have been since, well, 4.6bn years ago," writes Brian.

Sky Sports 1: Live International Under-21 Football - England v Finland (7.45pm)
"I spend 1/72nd of my existence reading and sometimes enjoying the Fiver. Since I operate in an infinite and timeless capacity and given that all events have a cumulative causative effect, it would be accurate to state that I have therefore spent in your timescale 63,888,888 years, 10 months, two weeks and one day reading the Fiver (and effects thereof)."

Sky Sports 2: Hold The Back Page (11pm)
"Since I own no money but am by far the most important person in your universe, it is now necessary to establish an appreciable value to my behaviour. After exhaustive research I have calculated that I am exactly 67 times more important than Elton John and would therefore not be unreasonable to charge 67 times his 'salary' of $157m per annum."

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)
"This said, my Fiver-related antics have cost the universe an unrivalled $672,047,222,212,872,000 exactly. Regards, Brian, The Big U Janitor)."

Radio Five Live: Sport on Five with Ian Payne (7pm)
Thanks, Brian. That brings the final total of the Totaliser to ... um ... actually, we can't be arsed to work it out. But it's a lot.

Talksport: The Weekend Starts Here (7pm)
We can guarantee that absolutely none of the money is going to charity. Instead, we're planning to use the cash to take out a contract on a certain celebrity chef. If anyone has any moral objections to our plan, email us by 4pm today. Otherwise we're contacting our local hit-man with your implicit blessings. Pukka!

"It's a slight worry to us, so we decided to go for a second opinion with full approval from our own surgeon," the Toon boss could be heard to explain, before he was totally drowned out by his captain's semi-coherent ramblings regarding varicose veins, recent episodes of Countdown, and the Blitz. QUOTE OF THE DAY "Many people in England don't like me. I was held responsible for Vialli's sacking, but just a week before, the press had been blasting him! I suddenly felt very powerful!!! I, Frank Leboeuf, was capable of getting a coach sacked!!!!!" - It's been a while, but it was only a matter of time before Frank Leboeuf went off on one again. BENT (NOT BENT) It can't be easy being a Chesterfield supporter at the moment. On the one hand, your club lies 10 points clear at the top of Division Three. On the other hand, it faces possible relegation following Football League charges which allege that the club is as bent as the city's famous Crooked Spire church. And today things got even murkier, with news that chairman Darren Brown has handed in his resignation, claiming "certain people" were trying to get him. "I am convinced that certain people are trying to ruin my name and I am personally ready for the fight with them," said Brown in his best Scrappy Doo voice. Brown, whose vice-chairman Paul Grafton has also resigned, claims he has quit because the club's reputation was suffering from charges of financial irregularities made against him. But he insisted: "This in no way should be seen as me trying to run away from the current situation as nothing would have given me more satisfaction than to prove certain people wrong." And as he made his way down the M1, he added: "This decision is made purely in the best interests of Chesterfield Football Club." Not surprisingly, it wasn't long before Chesterfield manager Nicky Law popped up with a string of footballing clichés. "I was shocked," he said. "It's news to us all and it's a shame for the chairman. He's come in with the right intentions but it hasn't worked out, which is a shame after all the effort he's put in. I got on brilliantly with him." What the loyal Spirite fans make of all this, heaven knows. This season they've endured rumour, innuendo, half their ground being shut, Football League charges, and now this. Is worse to follow at next month's tribunal, which will rule on the alleged financial irregularities? Let's hope not - although the way things are going, we'll need to keep everything crossed. THE RUMOUR MILL Newcastle are considering signing Argentinian teenage striker Facundo Bonvin from Boca Juniors. Liverpool want Rangers midfielder Barry Ferguson and they're prepared to pay £10m for him. According to the Sun, Kevin Keegan is ready for a return to football, and that's "a message that is certain to alert Southampton". Where's Glenn Hoddle going, then? NEWS IN BRIEF Century FM has been banned from covering England's game with Finland after waking up coach Sven-Goran Eriksson with a hoax call at 7.30am on Friday. "This is beginning to be a problem," said Eriksson. "When I phone managers to talk about players now they ask if they can call me back. They want to check that it's me and situation is not very nice. It's happened several times and now maybe I should have a code word. This is the first time it has happened to me in my career." West Brom have completed the signing of Leicester defender Phil Gilchrist for £500,000 after he passed a medical at the Hawthorns this afternoon. Airdrie, in provisional liquidation for more than a year, have been given the green light to complete their remaining fixtures this season. The news follows confirmation that a Fife-based consortium, led by Jim Innes, has been awarded preferred bidder status. Hibernian wing-back Ulrik Laursen has signed a two-year extension to his contract at Easter Road. Celtic midfielder Stilian Petrov has had an operation on his broken right leg, sustained in a collision with St Johnstone's Jim Weir. Six players have been banned for match-fixing following an Italian Cup tie last year. Fabio Gallo, Sebastiano Siviglia and Luciano Zauri of Serie A side Atalanta and Alfredo Aglietti and Massimiliano Allegri of Pistoiese in Serie B were suspended for one year by the Italian Football Federation disciplinary committee. Former Atalanta player Giacomo Banchelli - now with Empoli - was banned for six months. Atalanta's Cristiano Doni and Pistoiese's Daniele Amerini, Girolamo Bizzarri and Gianluca Lillo were cleared of accusations. Striker Con Boutsianis, who has been pressing for a place in Australia's World Cup qualifying squad, has admitted to being involved in an armed robbery. Boutsianis, who plays for South Melbourne, pleaded guilty to the theft of £18,000 from a Melbourne restaurant in January 1998 earlier today. The court was told Boutsianis was under financial pressure when he agreed to take part in the crime and received just £300 of the proceeds. He will be sentenced next month. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: World Football (3.05am) "How naive you are to listen to all manner of humans, deities, demons and ex-footballers bleating about their puny scam-mongering. I am caretaker of the universe and have been since, well, 4.6bn years ago," writes Brian. Sky Sports 1: Live International Under-21 Football - England v Finland (7.45pm) "I spend 1/72nd of my existence reading and sometimes enjoying the Fiver. Since I operate in an infinite and timeless capacity and given that all events have a cumulative causative effect, it would be accurate to state that I have therefore spent in your timescale 63,888,888 years, 10 months, two weeks and one day reading the Fiver (and effects thereof)." Sky Sports 2: Hold The Back Page (11pm) "Since I own no money but am by far the most important person in your universe, it is now necessary to establish an appreciable value to my behaviour. After exhaustive research I have calculated that I am exactly 67 times more important than Elton John and would therefore not be unreasonable to charge 67 times his 'salary' of $157m per annum." Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm) "This said, my Fiver-related antics have cost the universe an unrivalled $672,047,222,212,872,000 exactly. Regards, Brian, The Big U Janitor)." Instead, we're planning to use the cash to take out a contract on a certain celebrity chef. If anyone has any moral objections to our plan, email us by 4pm today. fields.headline: Mixmag publisher defects to IPC
fields.trailText: 5pm: Ian Jenkinson has filled the newly created position of music projects director at IPC ignite!, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
IPC has hired Ian Jenkinson, the former publishing director of Mixmag, for the new role of music projects director.

Mr Jenkins will work for IPC ignite!, the division that houses NME, Loaded, Muzik and Later.

He will be responsible for developing the NME and Muzik brands as well as overseeing NME's 50th anniversary.

Mr Jenkins will report to publishing director Robert Tame and marketing director Vijay Solanki.

"Ian is a real youth marketing guru because he has been part of the dance music scene from the beginning," said Mr Solanki.

"He will play a key role in shaping the marketing strategy for NME."

Mr Jenkins began his music career as a promoter for Tribal Gathering, which was one of Europe's first large-scale dance music festivals.

He has been publisher of Emap's Mixmag since 1999 and has also acted as a consultant for Sony PlayStation.

fields.headline: Marchioness families react to report
fields.standfirst: More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: Grieving families who lost loved ones in the Marchioness tragedy told today how they felt "emotionally raped" by their exhaustive 12-year battle for an official inquiry into the sinking.
fields.body:
Grieving families who lost loved ones in the Marchioness tragedy told today how they felt "emotionally raped" by their exhaustive 12-year battle for an official inquiry into the sinking.

The families, collectively known as the Marchioness Action Group, which represents survivors and the families of those who died, welcomed today's report by Lord Justice Clarke and asked for its recommendations to be acted upon immediately.

Their determination to see the fight through to the bitter end was plain on the faces of the handful of relatives who spoke after the report's publication.

They welcomed the completion of the inquiry, which placed blame for the tragedy in the hands of the managers and owners of the Bowbelle and Marchioness, and vowed to pursue those responsible.

Eileen Dallaglio, who lost her 19-year-old daughter Francesca Guila Maria in the tragedy, said: "We are emotionally crippled and we have been emotionally crippled and emotionally raped over the last 12 years."

Ms Dallaglio, mother of England rugby union star Lawrence Dallaglio, added: "It is time now for us to pick up the pieces in our lives and go forward, but first we have to see what can be done to tackle those people responsible."

Billy Gorman, who lost his sister-in-law, 41-year-old Carmella Ann Marie Lennon-Gorman, in the 1989 tragedy, said the report was the first time in 12 years that anyone had been blamed.

Earlier Mr Gorman presented the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, with a picture showing Mr Prescott with members of the Marchioness Action Group outside No 10 Downing Street.

Group spokeswoman Margaret Lockwood-Croft said: "Lord Justice Clarke found there was no justification for the removal of hands, that Dr Knapman took no account of the families' feelings and that families' human rights were infringed when body parts were removed and not returned and when we were not allowed to view the bodies of our loved ones."

fields.headline: Captains blamed for Marchioness tragedy
fields.standfirst:
 Dredger captain likely to escape prosecution
 Poor lookouts to blame, inquiry says
 Coroner criticised for cutting off victims' hands

More about the Marchioness disaster
The full Marchioness inquiry report
fields.trailText: Douglas Henderson, the captain of the dredger Bowbelle, who had drunk six pints of lager hours before it crashed into the Marchioness riverboat in a disaster in which 51 people died, is likely to escape prosecution, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott said today.
fields.body:
Douglas Henderson, the captain of the dredger Bowbelle, who had drunk six pints of lager hours before it crashed into the Marchioness riverboat in a disaster in which 51 people died, is likely to escape prosecution, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott said today.

Captain Henderson was partly blamed in a public inquiry into the tragedy on the Thames pleasure boat that was published this morning. Mr Prescott said the inquiry report would be passed in its entirety to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

This, he said, was "for him to consider whether action would be appropriate against Captain Henderson or any other party". However, Mr Prescott added: "The preliminary advice that I have received is that there is little prospect of a successful prosecution of Captain Henderson."

The report, by Lord Justice Clarke, held back from recommending any disciplinary action against Captain Henderson because of the amount of time that had elapsed and on human rights grounds.

The 1989 accident was a "catastrophe which should never have happened", Lord Justice Clarke said. Poor lookouts on both vessels were responsible for the collision, the report concluded.

In a separate report, published simultaneously today, Lord Justice Clarke criticised Westminster coroner Dr Paul Knapman for his decision to cut the hands off more than 20 of the Marchioness victims for identification purposes.

Lord Clarke added: "It is to my mind a shocking feature of the case that it was possible for a pair of hands to be left undiscovered in the (Westminster) mortuary, not just for months but for years.

"The hands should not have been removed and Dr Knapman must bear the responsibility for the fact that they were."

Mr Knapman said: "We have learned from our experiences following the terrible tragedy of the Marchioness. I note Lord Justice Clarke's findings in respect of my own actions. I am particularly gratified that his report concludes that I acted at all times in good faith and with the best of intentions."

Partygoers were celebrating on the Marchioness on the night of August 20 1989 when the collision occurred near Southwark in central London.

Today's report follows a 10-year battle by survivors and relatives and friends of the victims to have hearings in public.

The Clarke report said: "The basic cause of the collision is clear. It was poor lookout on both vessels. Neither vessel saw the other in time to take action to avoid the collision."

The report stated the accident was caused at least in part by the fault of Captain Henderson and Marchioness skipper Stephen Faldo to set up and operate a proper system of lookout on their vessels.

The report said Captain Henderson should himself have kept a proper lookout and that, if he had, he would have seen the Marchioness. It said that on the afternoon before the 1.45am collision, Captain Henderson "drank more than he should".

Although it was reckoned that Captain Henderson would have had no alcohol in his bloodstream at the time of the collision, the report added: "We cannot stress too strongly how much he deprecate Captain Henderson's conduct in drinking so much before returning to the vessel as master."

The Marchioness Action Group, which represents survivors and families of those who died, welcomed the reports and called for the recommendations to be acted on immediately.

Spokeswoman Margaret Lockwood-Croft said: "Lord Justice Clarke's reports are hard hitting and thorough. We fully support the recommendations, particularly for stricter alcohol regulations on waterways and for search and rescue services on our rivers."

fields.headline: Report warns of 'very large epidemic'
fields.standfirst:
 4,000 cases by June
 Blair extends firebreak cull across UK
 Infected animals to be killed within 24 hours
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today ordered the precautionary "firebreak" cull to be extended to all parts of Britain as a government report warned that more than 4,000 cases of foot and mouth disease could be recorded in the UK by June.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today ordered the precautionary "firebreak" cull to be extended to all parts of Britain as a government report warned that more than 4,000 cases of foot and mouth disease could be recorded in the UK by June.

Mr Blair's action will see all animals within a one mile radius of an infected farm slaughtered.

Today's study predicts that there may soon be 70 outbreaks a day and recommends drastic action to bring the disease under control. In answer, Mr Blair also called for all infected animals to be slaughtered within 24 hours of diagnosis.

The government report said the number of cases will rise steeply, with rapid expansion in the infected areas.

The speedier slaughter of infected animals will help to reduce the spread of the virus but the cull needs to include the immediate slaughter of all susceptible species around infected farms, it said.

The report, compiled for the ministry of agriculture by foot and mouth specialists, warned that, without such drastic action, the disease will become firmly established in Britain.

Speaking at the EU summit in Stockholm, Mr Blair said the leaders of other member states had been sympathetic to Britain's plight and had offered help in the form of veterinary expertise.

But Mr Blair refused to be drawn on whether he will postpone the May 3 local elections. "Everyone keeps asking me about elections, but my priority has to be getting this disease under control," he said.

Experts from the institute of animal health and veterinary laboratories agency, who helped to compile today's report, also said that the UK's last major epidemic, in 1967, was "quite different".

This time, they warned, more of the country was infected with the spread of the disease by sheep.

The total number of outbreaks has risen to 480, including the case in Northern Ireland. The number of animals condemned for slaughter has risen to 435,491, which is already more than the 433,987 killed in the eight-month outbreak in 1967/8, with more to come.

webTitle: Government admits foot and mouth will last for months

fields.headline: Government admits foot and mouth will last for months
fields.standfirst:
Farm crisis to last for months

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farm crisis to last for months.
fields.byline: Tania Branigan, Ian Black  and Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
The government yesterday finally admitted that the foot and mouth crisis would last for months in the hardest-hit areas, while continuing to insist it was under control.

As the number of animals condemned for slaughter in the UK passed the total killed in the epidemic in 1967, ministers announced details of measures to speed up the cull and compensation, including a £150m welfare package.

But Tony Blair was heckled by protesters as he visited Cumbria for a 45-minute meeting with farmers and tourism representatives before flying out to today's economic summit in Stockholm. He is to appeal to member states for further veterinary support.

The disease is likely to dominate the summit's agenda following its spread to the Irish Republic, where the first outbreak was confirmed in County Louth, a few miles from Northern Ireland's single case. The disease has already spread to France and the Netherlands.

In Britain, the total number of outbreaks rose to 472, including the case in Northern Ireland, with 35 new cases by yesterday evening. The number of animals condemned for slaughter has risen to 435,491, more than the 433,987 killed in the eight-month outbreak in 1967/8.

Professor Roy Anderson, the epidemiologist who has prepared disease projections for the government, said the disease would not peak until early May and would not be eliminated until August, even in the "best case" scenario.

"If this cull is applied vigorously and effectively enough, you could turn the epidemic into a decaying process hopefully within a month to two months," he told the BBC.

Professor Anderson, of Imperial College, London, added: "I think everyone is in agreement, both the government, the farming community and the independent scientific advice, that this epidemic is not under control."

But Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, insisted that the large number of new cases "means we have a bigger problem. It does not mean we do not know how to deal with it.

"The key conclusion is that the more intervention we make, the more firmly we get towards extinguishing it."

He said the worst affected areas would take the longest to clear, but that others might be disease-free much more quickly and added that a second study, which took into account the geographical pattern of the outbreaks, suggested foot and mouth would die out faster.

Mr Brown yesterday announced a fixed tariff for compulsory slaughter, so that animals can be purchased and killed straight away. Farmers who prefer to wait for an independent valuation can still do so, but Mr Brown said the fixed rates were "generous", ranging from £18 for piglets to £1,100 for breeding cows.

Vets will also be able to take slaughter teams out with them when they first visit suspected cases and will not have to remain on site while the slaughter is completed.

The £150m welfare scheme will compensate farmers who choose to have healthy animals which are stranded culled.

There was also hope for rural businesses, as Michael Meacher, the environment minister, revealed details of cuts in rates bills for affected firms.

fields.bodyText: The government yesterday finally admitted that the foot and mouth crisis would last for months in the hardest-hit areas, while continuing to insist it was under control. As the number of animals condemned for slaughter in the UK passed the total killed in the epidemic in 1967, ministers announced details of measures to speed up the cull and compensation, including a £150m welfare package. But Tony Blair was heckled by protesters as he visited Cumbria for a 45-minute meeting with farmers and tourism representatives before flying out to today's economic summit in Stockholm. He is to appeal to member states for further veterinary support. The disease is likely to dominate the summit's agenda following its spread to the Irish Republic, where the first outbreak was confirmed in County Louth, a few miles from Northern Ireland's single case. The disease has already spread to France and the Netherlands. In Britain, the total number of outbreaks rose to 472, including the case in Northern Ireland, with 35 new cases by yesterday evening. The number of animals condemned for slaughter has risen to 435,491, more than the 433,987 killed in the eight-month outbreak in 1967/8. Professor Roy Anderson, the epidemiologist who has prepared disease projections for the government, said the disease would not peak until early May and would not be eliminated until August, even in the "best case" scenario. "If this cull is applied vigorously and effectively enough, you could turn the epidemic into a decaying process hopefully within a month to two months," he told the BBC. Professor Anderson, of Imperial College, London, added: "I think everyone is in agreement, both the government, the farming community and the independent scientific advice, that this epidemic is not under control." But Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, insisted that the large number of new cases "means we have a bigger problem. It does not mean we do not know how to deal with it. "The key conclusion is that the more intervention we make, the more firmly we get towards extinguishing it." He said the worst affected areas would take the longest to clear, but that others might be disease-free much more quickly and added that a second study, which took into account the geographical pattern of the outbreaks, suggested foot and mouth would die out faster. Mr Brown yesterday announced a fixed tariff for compulsory slaughter, so that animals can be purchased and killed straight away. Farmers who prefer to wait for an independent valuation can still do so, but Mr Brown said the fixed rates were "generous", ranging from £18 for piglets to £1,100 for breeding cows. Vets will also be able to take slaughter teams out with them when they first visit suspected cases and will not have to remain on site while the slaughter is completed. The £150m welfare scheme will compensate farmers who choose to have healthy animals which are stranded culled. There was also hope for rural businesses, as Michael Meacher, the environment minister, revealed details of cuts in rates bills for affected firms. What's going on? webTitle: How will Eriksson handle the Litmanen test?

fields.headline: How will Eriksson handle the Litmanen test?
fields.trailText: If England are going to get the win they need against Finland tomorrow, special attention will have to be paid to Jari Litmanen. And I feel his Liverpool team-mate Steven Gerrard is the perfect man for the job, which means his latest injury scare is all the more worrying.
fields.body:
If England are going to get the win they need against Finland tomorrow, special attention will have to be paid to Jari Litmanen. And I feel his Liverpool team-mate Steven Gerrard is the perfect man for the job, which means his latest injury scare is all the more worrying.

What makes Litmanen so dangerous is not just his eye for a killer pass but the fact that he's very hard to pick up. Because he operates between the midfield and the strikers he'll get unmarked into little areas and do real damage if England aren't careful.

That means he's got to be taken out of the game at Anfield, and there are two ways of doing that. The first is a man-marking job, and if Martin Keown was available you might ask him to play in midfield and sit on Litmanen.

But with the way England are set up I'd be reluctant to go with a system such as that. I think it would take away too much of what we have to offer. Instead I would tell the midfielders that when we lose possession the nearest man has to get on top of Litmanen quickly, with Gerrard taking special responsibility.

He's a great tackler and he's got the quickness to get to people. To have him there would also be useful because he'll know about Litmanen's movement and the positions he likes to take up from their time at Anfield, and Litmanen may be looking over his shoulder knowing the lad can put his foot in.

Gerrard is the closest we've got to a Roy Keane or a Bryan Robson. The best central midfielder Liverpool have had in my time of watching is Graeme Souness and I think Gerrard might even be better.

He doesn't have Souness's authority yet or his ability to put people out of the game as the reducer. When we were playing Souness I always used to say: 'Don't come in here moaning that Souness is kicking you. Kick him before he kicks you because you know for certain he'll try it.'

But Gerrard's more mobile than Souness and I think he would still be able to get up the field and join in for England tomorrow. In any case, I expect Sven-Goran Eriksson will be stressing that, though Litmanen has to be looked after, the game is more about what England can do.

What would worry me is if I saw one of the centre-backs constantly pushing up on to Litmanen, because that can leave the middle of the defence exposed. You can easily find yourself one against one and, even if your defender is the quickest in the world, he's only got to slip and they're right in on goal.

I remember in 1980 when Dave Sexton was in charge of Manchester United and took the team to Ipswich. He pulled Martin Buchan from the back line to push on to Eric Gates, who played in the hole behind two strikers, and United were beaten 6-0; it left them very short at the back.

Whenever I had that problem afterwards I tended to detail someone like Bryan Robson to look after it from a central area, although I recall putting big Kent Nielsen on Nigel Clough as a man-marker when I was at Aston Villa. He was a centre-half but we brought him in to do a specific job and it worked pretty well.

Deep-lying players such as Clough, Litmanen and Teddy Sheringham are more and more important in the modern game to link play and get forward, and Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell will have to keep a close eye on Litmanen's movements because he floats and drifts so much there's no question England will lose him at some time.

Paul Scholes is maturing in his game but he's still not the greatest in the world at tracking people, and one of the centre-backs has to be prepared to take responsibility when Litmanen goes on after playing his first pass and gets into the area.

Although Litmanen has never played in a major international tournament and wasn't getting much of a look-in at Barcelona before he came to Liverpool, he's a special player who can cut you to ribbons with one pass. His ability to spot a ball early and play passes between people has given a new dimension to Liverpool's attack.

It gives anyone with a bit of pace a hell of a chance, and although the forwards Jonatan Johansson and Mikael Forssell aren't lightning quick they are persistent runners and given the chance they'll thrive on Litmanen's service.

The other thing Litmanen does exceptionally well is change the direction of play very quickly. In the FA Cup against Manchester City he had the whole side shaping one way and it seemed quids in he would play it to the left.

Instead he put his foot over the ball, shimmied and knocked a through-pass down the other side of the field which pulled the City defence all over the place. If England aren't careful the same could happen to them.

webTitle: El Salvador diary of an aid worker: overview

fields.headline: El Salvador diary of an aid worker: overview
fields.trailText: Nearly 1.5m people were affected by El Salvador's earthquakes in January and February this year; more than 1,140 people died and 133,382 homes were destroyed. For the media, an earthquake's a story that lasts a few days, while for aid agencies like Oxfam it turns into a programme of between three and six months. For Salvadoreans themselves, it is a disaster that will take months, even years, to recover from. Aid worker Rachel Stabb reports from the frontline.
fields.body:
Humanitarian emergencies come in various shapes and sizes. Conflicts often lead to the mass movement of civilians. Natural disasters like cyclones or earthquakes strike suddenly devastating lives and livelihoods. Developing countries bear the brunt in disasters. The poorer the country, the greater the impact a disaster has on ordinary people's lives.

In El Salvador's earthquakes, in January and February this year, nearly one-and-a-half million people - 22% of the population or the equivalent of nearly 13m people in Britain - were affected. More than 1,140 people died and 133,382 homes were destroyed. Apart from the residents of Santa Tecla, where a huge mudslide struck, those most affected were families living and working in the rural highlands of the poorest provinces. Living on the brink even before the earthquake, they had no resources to fall back on.

Oxfam has worked in El Salvador for more than 30 years and in this instance responded not only because of its long experience in some of the country's poorest communities, but because it has special expertise in providing emergency water and sanitation that is desperately needed after earthquakes.

In this case, Oxfam's approach was two-pronged. It provided water engineers and equipment in a matter of days to get vital water flowing again in the countryside where supplies to villages had been disrupted by landslides. At the same time, local non-governmental organisations whose projects Oxfam already supports were given extra resources to enable them to provide emergency food, clothing and shelter to families most in need.

In any emergency, coordinating work with other aid agencies and government authorities is an important aspect of making sure an operation is well organised and well targeted. In El Salvador, particularly good coordination at a local level helped make the response swift and effective.

The aim of diary stories was to paint a more detailed picture of what happens in an aid operation. With disasters frequently hitting the headlines, there's a danger that human suffering can become routine in the public mind.

A first hand account is important in giving a flavour of what it's like trying to reach people in remote areas, meeting people whose homes are nothing but rubble, setting up water tanks for people desperate for water, hearing individual stories of hardship and destruction, showing major donors how their money's being spent and, above all, feeling the real fear the Salvadorean people still feel that further devastation isn't far away.

For the media, an earthquake's a story that lasts a few days, while for aid agencies like Oxfam it turns into a programme of between three and six months. For Salvadoreans themselves, it is a national disaster that will take months even years to recover from.

In the hours after a disaster, Oxfam tackles issues of how it will get involved, what it will do, where it will work and who will fund the programme? As engineers and equipment are flown out, staff and partners on the ground consult, assess and target areas of need.

The operation gears up within days, with basic supplies being distributed and water tanks going up day after day until, in El Salvador, there were 117 in seven provinces bringing clean water to 171,000 people. Hygiene and shelter kits went out to 30,000 and a public health campaign was implemented.

But this is only the initial response. At a certain time, the rehabilitation phase gets underway when housing is the top priority and partners put forward proposals on housing, health and economic regeneration.

Aid agencies can also play a part in developing long-term plans for reconstruction after an earthquake. Experience shows that their involvement in high level meetings is vital if donors and other players are to use the opportunity to redress poverty and help those at the bottom of the social and economic ladder in El Salvador.

This aid operation is just one of 40 humanitarian disasters where Oxfam currently works and in 1999-00, the agency spent £46m on humanitarian programmes. Others crises include droughts in Afghanistan and Kenya, the earthquake in Gujarat, civil war in Sierra Leone, Angola and Sudan and renewed flooding in Mozambique.

fields.headline: One2One brings T-Mobile brand to UK
fields.trailText: 3.15pm:One2One is to introduce T-Mobile, parent company Deutsche Telekom's mobile phone brand, to the UK, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
One2One is to introduce T-Mobile, parent company Deutsche Telekom's mobile phone brand, to the UK.

T-Mobile will be rolled out globally as the mobile phone brand for Deutsche Telekom's corporate customers.

This means UK business customers will use a T-Mobile rather than a One2One service.

Deutsche Telekom will keep the existing consumer brands in each of its markets, such as One2One in the UK and Max.Mobil in Austria.

But the T-Mobile brand will begin to appear on the UK high street as the company launches international products under the brand name.

The T-Mobile products will be available to individual consumers as well corporate customers.

The company will launch the first T-Mobile product - a new international tariff - in the summer.

Deutsche Telekom is in the process of formulating a global advertising strategy for T-Mobile.

The advertising is scheduled to begin in the summer but an advertising agency has yet to be appointed.

The brand will be "distinct but complementary to" the existing T-Mobile brand, which is used in Germany.

The decision to keep separate consumer brands in different markets goes against moves by rival telecoms companies, which are busy establishing global brands.

Vodafone recently announced the rollout of its brand across the different markets in which it operates.

One2One marketing director Tim Yates said the decision was taken after extensive research.

"We recognise the strength and power of our local brands.

"One2One is a very strong, powerful brand in the UK and T-Mobile can build on it," he said.
