fields.headline: The culling fields
fields.standfirst:
Is there a better way to combat foot and mouth disease? Derek Brown looks at the options

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Is there a better way to combat foot and mouth disease? Derek Brown looks at the options.
fields.body:
There are 60m cattle, sheep and pigs in the United Kingdom. That is slightly more than one beast for every man, woman and child. But the proportion is set to drop sharply: already, a quarter of a million animals have been slaughtered, and hundreds of thousands more are condemned to premature death.

The Ministry of Agriculture and the National Farmers' Union do not always see eye to eye, but on this issue they are as one. The only way to contain and then eradicate foot and mouth is, they insist, the mass slaughter of not only already affected animals, but those vulnerable to the disease.

Opponents of the policy, including some farmers, animal "rights" activists and those simply sickened by the televised sight of burning or rotting carcasses, have come up with at least three other options: vaccination, preventive medicine, and simply allowing affected animals to recover.

Vaccination

Many people simply can't make sense of the authorities' refusal to contemplate vaccination, which was widely and effectively carried out in continental Europe until the early 1990s, when the practice was banned by the EU.

Vaccination is expensive and complex. There are seven main varieties of the foot and mouth virus, and dozens of sub-types. The present epidemic in Britain involves the particularly virulent pan-Asiatic O type. Animals can be protected by vaccination, but the treatment does not invariably work, and has to be repeated every six months or so - and in every new generation.

Because the vaccine produces antibodies, it would be impossible to distinguish between treated animals and those which have contracted foot and mouth disease. In effect, this would result in the loss of disease-free status for British animals, and kill the meat export trade stone dead. The NFU says bleakly: "With the annual value of UK exports totalling £576m, the loss of our disease-free status would spell the death of the UK livestock industry."

The counter-argument, of course, is that the accumulated loss to British farming and to the rural economy in general is set to dwarf that figure.

Moreover, if the EU reintroduced vaccination throughout the community, all member states would compete on a level playing field - though exports beyond the EU would certainly be severely curtailed.

Preventive measures

There is a rising clamour among farmers and others who remember the borax treatment widely used during the 1967 outbreak. Proponents believe that the preparation, easily administered in the animals' drinking water, provided cheap and effective protection against foot and mouth.

Not so, says the Ministry of Agriculture: "We are aware that some pharmacies have advertised a homeopathic product called Borax 30 as a preventative measure against foot and mouth disease. However this product has not been authorised under these regulations. We have received no scientific evidence to demonstrate its effectiveness against foot and mouth disease and we have not assessed its safety or quality."

Allowing animals to recover

Foot and mouth is not generally a killer disease. It is distressing for the animals affected, but most recover in two to three weeks. So why, as many people are asking, don't we simply leave the poor beasts alone?

The answer may sound ruthless, but it is logical. When animals recover from infection by one foot and mouth virus, they have little or no immunity against attack from any other variety. They are vulnerable to secondary infections, lose weight, and give lower milk yields. In short, they become unproductive. In addition, the virus can survive in the respiratory tract of recovered animals, which could go on to infect other animals.

webTitle: The Queen's speech: the issue explained

fields.headline: The Queen's speech: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords last December, set out the agenda of Tony Blair's government in the run up to the general election. The speech contained 15 main bills and four draft pieces of legislation, some of which are now before parliament. The main points relevant to the public sector follow.
fields.body:
The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords last December, set out the agenda of Tony Blair's government in the run up to the general election. The speech contained 15 main bills and four draft pieces of legislation, some of which are now before parliament. The main points relevant to the public sector follow.

Health

 A performance fund for the NHS worth up to £500m a year by 2003-04, which will be made available from April to the best performing NHS trusts.

 Care trusts will be established to deliver primary health care, community health services and social care for older people.

 A wider range of health professionals will be able to prescribe certain drugs. The bill will also establish public-private partnerships in an effort to improve primary health care premises, particularly in inner cities.

 The NHS will become responsible for paying nursing care costs in homes.

 The promotion and advertising of tobacco will be banned.

The health and social care bill, currently before House of Lords, will enable the creation of care trusts, extend prescribing rights and establish public-private partnerships to improve GP premises.

The tobacco advertising and promotion bill, which will ban tobacco advertising and sponsorship, was approved by the House of Commons in January.

Social security

 A fraud bill will give the government the power to withdraw or reduce benefit from anybody convicted twice of a benefit offence within three years.

 The department of social security will have powers to offer fines of between £1,000 and £5,000 as an alternative to prosecution in less serious cases of employers colluding with their employees to commit benefit fraud.

 The powers of the children's commissioner for Wales will be widened to cover not just children in care but children in hospitals and schools under a new bill.

 The special educational needs and disability bill will extend the 1995 Disability Discrimination Act to cover education. This will prevent disabled pupils and students being treated less favourably than their non-disabled peers.

The children's commissioner for Wales, Peter Clarke, took up his appointment on March 1 this year. He is expected to have wide powers to review and monitor complaints procedures in a range of bodies in Wales, including social services departments, local authorities, NHS hospitals, GPs and schools.

Crime

 Fixed penalties for offences of disorderly behaviour in public places.

 Police given powers to shut down rowdy pubs and clubs.

 A ban on drinking alcohol in the street.

 Curfew schemes for children aged between nine and 15 years.

 New powers for police to seize the assets of criminals, especially targeting drug barons.

The government unveiled its 10-year crime reduction plan, Criminal Justice: The Way Ahead, in February. The programme includes a package of supervised rehabilitation schemes designed to break the cycle of repeat offending and will also create 2,660 new prison places.

fields.headline: Electoral systems
fields.standfirst:
As Labour forges an agreement that supports the Liberal Democrats' ambition for 'fair votes' in Westminster elections, here is all you need to know about the various democratic voting systems in use around the world.

Special report: proportional representation
fields.trailText: As Labour forges an agreement that supports the Liberal Democrats' ambition for 'fair votes' in Westminster elections, here is all you need to know about the various democratic voting systems in use around the world.
fields.body:
First past the post

First past the post (FPTP) is the electoral system used in UK general elections. Electors vote for one individual (usually representing a political party) in single-member constituencies. The candidate with the most votes wins a seat in the House of Commons.

Strengths:
 The only system ever used in British general elections - producing strong, decisive governments with an overall majority in parliament, despite the fact that no post-war British political party has won more than 50% of the popular vote.
 With every voter represented by one MP, it provides a clear democratic link between the people and parliament.
 It is quick and simple for the voters.

Weaknesses:
 It is unfair and not remotely proportional, distorting election results so one party almost always forms the government: In 1997, Labour won 44.33% of the vote, which FPTP translated into 419 Commons seats - 63.58% of the total.
 It disenfranchises the millions of voters who don't back the winner in their constituency: their votes are, in effect, useless; their democratic voice unheard.

Where used: UK, USA, Canada and India.

The Alternative Vote (AV)

The same FPTP constituency boundaries are used and voters again return one MP from their constituency to parliament. But instead of voting for one candidate, preferences are recorded on the ballot paper. If no one candidate wins an overall majority, the candidate who received the least first-choice votes is eliminated and the second choices of the voters who backed them are allocated to the other candidates. This process continues until one candidate obtains an overall majority.

Strengths:
 It retains the single member constituency system and its advantages: it is likely to produce one clearly victorious party which can form government and keeps a clear and simple line of accountability between voters and their MP.
 It ensures all MPs are credible, having been elected by an absolute majority of their constituents.
 It makes individual votes less likely to be wasted: if your first-choice candidate isn't chosen, your second or third choice probably will be.

Weaknesses:
 It would not necessarily make the party composition of parliament more in proportion with votes cast across the country: research by Democratic Audit in 1997 discovered that results could be more distorting than under FPTP.
 The thousands who don't wish to back the one of the major political parties still remain disenfranchised.

Where used: The Australian House of Representatives.

The Alternative Vote Plus (AV+)

This mixed system, combining constituencies and a top-up vote, was proposed by the highly respected Jenkins Commission on the voting system in 1998. Voters have two votes. With one they elect a constituency MP by AV. These MPs form four-fifths of the House of Commons. With the other they vote for a candidate on a region list produced by the political parties. These "top-up" candidates are used to correct imbalances in the AV system, electing candidates from parties whose share of the national vote merits a greater share of seats in parliament than they had won with the first vote.

Strengths:
 Michael White calls it a "clever compromise".
 It retains the constituency link between people and parliament and yet its top-up formula helps correct imbalances in any FPTP or AV voting system.

Weaknesses:
 It is a new, untried and untested system: as it hasn't been used in any country in the world, it is hard to assess what teething troubles may emerge.
 Reducing the number of constituency MPs increases constituency size, meaning people may feel less close to their MPs.
 Two categories of MPs are created and, as they are elected in different ways, they may come to have different status. Those picked from a regional list may have less constituency work and be considered slavish party loyalists as they have, in effect, been chosen by parties' central offices.

The Single Transferable Vote (STV)

STV is a preferential voting system (as AV) in multi-member constituencies. Voters rank the candidates according to their preference, and each constituency elects between three and five MPs, depending on its size. Those candidates reaching a certain quota of votes are elected. Surplus votes for the elected candidates and the votes for the least supported candidate are redistributed on the basis of voters' second choices. This process continues until the required number of MPs reach the necessary quota and are returned to parliament.

Strengths:
 STV is one of the most proportional systems, producing a result which closely reflects the distribution of votes.
 In Britain, a government would almost certainly have to be a coalition of parties, which could end destructive adversarialism (opposition for opposition's sake) and produce consensual and moderate government, better reflecting the wishes of the people.
 It retains a constituency link and, compared to other voting systems, ensures that many more voters are likely to have a meaningful vote which helps select an MP from their constituency who represents their views.

Weaknesses:
 Opponents of STV argue that the coalition governments it is likely to produce in Britain would be weak, divided and indecisive.
 Coalition governments tend to be created by political deals in "smoke-filled rooms" which the voters have no control over.
 The government which emerges bears no relation to the individual parties most voters support.
 STV is also a complex system which could confuse voters and take several days to calculate.
 The large, multi-member constituencies erode the clear and direct link between voters and their MP in single-member constituencies.

Where used: The Australian Senate, the Republic of Ireland, Tasmania, Malta and for elections to the European Parliament.

Additional Member System (AMS)

Like AV+, AMS is a mixed system, combining simple constituency elections and a directly elected proportional component. Voters cast two votes - one for a constituency MP and one party vote.

Strengths:
 It retains the advantages of a simple single-member constituency system and helps balance the disproportionate results this can produce.
 By providing for a party vote it best reflects the reality of modern voting: that electorates back parties rather than individual candidates.
 A "threshold" qualification on the party vote ensures that extremists, who win less than 5% of the vote for instance, are still excluded from parliament.

Weaknesses:
 Half the MPs are, in effect, picked by their party leadership and remain unaccountable to any individual voters. The undemocratic power of party patronage is massively increased and two very different types of MPs are returned to parliament.
 The two votes are separate, so the second, purely proportional vote only mitigates, rather than corrects, the imbalances of the simple constituency election.
 In Germany, it has created strong, stable administrations, but these have never been single party governments.
 As with other coalition-forming PR systems, it tends to give a small, centrist party massive deal-making power, because larger parties need their support to form a majority government.

Where used: Germany.

webTitle: Editor's comment - Sit tight and wait for a real recovery

fields.headline: Editor's comment - Sit tight and wait for a real recovery
fields.trailText: The recent plunge in stock market indices around the world might be seen as a buying opportunity. But as Money Observer pointed out last month, there are compelling reasons to hold fire. Chief among these is that many large institutional investors see little hope of an upturn in the US, which has such a large effect on the world economy, until the second half of this year.
fields.body:
The recent plunge in stock market indices around the world might be seen as a buying opportunity. But as Money Observer pointed out last month, there are compelling reasons to hold fire. Chief among these is that many large institutional investors see little hope of an upturn in the US, which has such a large effect on the world economy, until the second half of this year.

This fundamental point, coupled with the current negative sentiment among investors, is what drives markets. Since last month, sentiment has worsened and it is set to stay that way for a few months, driven by the incessant flow of worsening profit forecasts and the threat of a US-inspired global recession.

What private investors need to see is a sustained improvement in corporate earnings accompanied by a stronger uptrend in stock market indices. This year's rallies have been unsustainable. They have been 'dead cat bounces' - some of the recent examples have been dropped from quite a height.

Individual savings account investors who have yet to take advantage of the 2000-01 £7,000 allowance face a dilemma, because the money must be in their Isa before the beginning of the new tax year on 6 April.

It is important to remember that you should never let the tax tail wag the investment dog, but all is not lost, particularly for those investors who choose to make their own investment decisions through a self-select Isa.

As long as you intend to invest your cash within a few months, there is little to prevent you from sitting back and waiting for markets to improve.

Moreover, investors who choose to take the managed Isa route, and want the growth that equities have historically provided, can place their contributions with providers that offer lower risk Isa-friendly products, such as bond funds. Many of the larger Isa providers allow you to make at least one free switch between their funds each year, so you can avoid a charge on performance from switching between funds.

Investors who want to diversify away from the markets of Europe and the UK might now consider that Japan has become very cheap. After all, this is the world's second largest economy and the stock market hit a 16-year low in March.

At the current level of 12,232, the Nikkei 225 index of leading shares is 41 per cent down on its 52-week high. But it would be a brave investor who buys Japan even at these lowly levels. Issues such as the solvency of the financial system, record levels of public debt, lack of firm political leadership and weak domestic demand must all be addressed before Japan's stock market can show signs of sustainable growth.

Investors must also ask whether the effects of the asset price bubble that helped the Nikkei 225 index peak at close to 40,000 in the early 1990s have worked their way through the system. Ten years ago, Japan's economic health had become tied to the fortunes of the stock market. The past decade bears testament to the difficulties in expelling the excesses from the system.

It all boils down to the level of risk with which you feel comfortable. Japan is undoubtedly a high-risk play. So are emerging markets, where growth prospects in the short to medium term are arguably much better.

That is a view shared by analysts at Foreign & Colonial Emerging Markets*, which points out that emerging economies are expected to grow at over twice the rate of developed economies this year. Deputy chief investment officer Humphrey Carey says: 'For sophisticated investors willing to take a contrarian view and invest in an asset class at, or near, the bottom of the economic cycle, the rewards will be great.'

Throughout its 22-year history, Money Observer has never shied away from the issues that effect the fortunes of investors and savers. In December 1991, for example, we advised investors to get out of Maxwell Communications Corporation, months before the group came to an undignified end. We also refused to get carried away by dot.com mania. And, of course, we have also provided readers with invaluable advice and tips on how to make money, as well as avoid losing it. Next month Money Observer will celebrate its 250th issue. I hope you will join us in looking forward to the next 250.

This issue went to press on 16 March. *A copy of the FCEM report can be viewed on the Foreign & Colonial web site, www.fandc.co.uk, under the subhead Emerging Markets Publications.

fields.headline: New Media Age
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 22
fields.trailText: March 22: The government's 3G licence policy has been attacked by the UK wireless industry.
fields.body:
The government's 3G licence policy has been attacked by the UK wireless industry for hobbling industry development, in a bid to back a European commission initiative to force the government to defer fee payments.

Pressure is mounting on the DMA to review its policy toward email marketing following last week's revelation in NMA that a breakaway group is to set its own guidelines for the embryonic industry.

The Chart Information Network is launching a separate digital download music chart this summer, in preparation for the explosion of subscription services such as Napster and Sony/Universal Duet.

Industry bodies, ISPs and the police will meet Home Secretary Jack Straw next week in an attempt to diffuse the criticism that the government is doing little to combat paedophile activity on the web.

The Internet Advertising Bureau could face a challenge to its industry status following calls this week from the online agency arena for the creation of a new "industry champion".

Content providers Whatsonwhen and Peoplenews have both secured new funding from their respective investors.

Insurance aggregator Screentrade has begun a final £0.5m marketing push before winding the brand down prior to the launch of Theformula.com.

Profero, the interactive advertising agency, will soon launch its first campaign in the South American market, for CNN.

Virgin.Net has unveiled its new-look portal this week and, scoring a total of 80/100, becomes site of the week.

webTitle: Two steps forward, one back for Israel's women

fields.headline: Two steps forward, one back for Israel's women
fields.standfirst: A landmark sexual harassment verdict followed by two murders has highlighted the contradictory nature of Israel's patriarchal society, writes Suzanne Goldenberg
fields.trailText: A landmark sexual harassment verdict followed by two murders has highlighted the contradictory nature of Israel's patriarchal society, writes Suzanne Goldenberg.
fields.body:
A day after Israeli women's activists celebrated the landmark legal verdict that convicted a former general and cabinet minister of sexual harrassment, there came a sobering reminder of what life can be like for the female population.

Today's front page story is about two women killed by their partners. Brascova Kaiserman, aged 82, was bludgeoned to death with a hammer by her 90-year-old husband because he was upset with the lunch she had cooked for him in their flat in an old-peoples' home in the central town of Gedera.

A few hours earlier, and a short drive away to the south, Olga Karrol, aged 30, was stabbed to death by her former partner in full view of the neighbours outside her home in Ashdod.

On March 8 - International Women's Day - she had filed her second police complaint against Shliko Hundashvili in a month, accusing him of battery. Police said yesterday they had been hunting Hundashvili before the murder, but had failed to locate him.

The juxtaposition of events has punctured the mood of euphoria that had greeted the conviction of a man once seen as a potential prime minister - Yitzhak Mordechai - for indecently assaulting a woman soldier under his command when he was a leading general in 1992, and for sexually harassing a party activist when he was the country's defence minister in 1996.

Under Israeli law, Mordechai faces a maximum sentence of 10 years although, in practise, prison terms are far lower. Women's activists said the verdict was an important step in placing the issue of sexual harassment onto the public agenda.

"The verdict in the Mordechai case has finally buried an old and loathsome world in which sexual harassment was called legitimate courting, and sexual assault was accepted with understanding," said a front-page comment in the Ma'ariv newspaper.

The fall from grace of so prominent a figure as Mordechai began making an impact well before his verdict was announced. Israel's network of sexual assault crisis centres received 15,000 complaints last year - nearly double the 8,000 cases reported in 1999 - as women drew courage about challenging what had once been accepted practice in the workplace and in the army, which has been accused of tolerating abuses of young women soldiers by generals and senior officers.

But the gruesome murders 24 hours later have highlighted the contradictory nature of Israeli society, and the limitations of progressive laws in bringing social change.

Women's activists say Israel is becoming an increasingly violent society - quite apart from the military's efforts to snuff out a six-month Palestinian uprising against its occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

A report this week declared Israeli schools to be among the most violent in the world, and figures released last year say that one in five women suffer some form of domestic abuse, physical as well as verbal.

During several weeks in the six-month intifada - including this one - more Israeli civilians have died as a result of domestic violence than drive-by shootings in the West Bank, or bombing attacks inside the borders of the Jewish state.

"Israel is a place of contradictions," said Shulamit Aloni, a veteran civil rights activist and founder of the leftwing Meretz political party. "On the one hand, the sky is the limit for women in civil life, but we also live in a patriarchal and macho society - patriarchal because in personal status we are under the direction of the clergy which is very backward, and macho because of the army. In this kind of society, whenever someone is not pleased with his life, or whenever he has a problem, the victim of his rage and disgust will be a woman."

Others argue the exigencies of daily life in Israel, and the pressures on a society which has absorbed 1m new immigrants in the last decade, are also a factor in domestic violence.

"I think there is an enormous increase in violence within the family in Israel," said Frances Rady, a law professor at Jerusalem's Hebrew university. The increase may well be the result of various pressures: the pressure of the ongoing conflict in the West Bank and in Gaza, and the massive immigration. "It is of course known that disorientation and economic difficulties in transition do probably increase violence."

Both women acknowledge the Mordechai verdict as an important landmark because it has criminalised behavior that was once deemed forgivable. The question remains, will the Israeli legal system prove as effective in combatting domestic abuse?

"There was a tendency for a long time to regard family violence as not being a real crime," said Ms Rady. "I am not talking so much about murder of a partner, but other forms of abuse. But now I think that is changing."

fields.headline: Mr £35 million
fields.standfirst: This article was first published in the Guardian on August 23 1999
fields.trailText: Martin Sorrell tells Meg Carter why the media business means high risks and big rewards.
fields.body:
An unlikely juxtaposition appeared in the news pages of the Sun last week. Sandwiched between sexy shots of model-turned-singer Caprice and a story headlined 'Vice girls eaten by cannibals' peered the besuited, bespectacled image of advertising boss Martin Sorrell. Or, as Sun readers know him: 'Mr £35 million'.

The Sun told its army of loyal readers that the chief executive of the British advertising group, WPP, is set to receive the biggest bonus in business history.

Last week's reports provided an inevitable cue for renewed discussion of fat cattery and adland excess conveniently side-stepping the more obvious question: who is he, what exactly does he do and is he worth it?

Sorrell, 54, is chief executive of the world's third-largest marketing and communication company, which owns two of the world's biggest advertising agencies J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather. It also owns a string of design, branding, PR, media, information and communication consultancies.

More telling is the fact that Sorrell has been widely credited with revolutionising media communications and redefining notions of the traditional adman. Oh, and under his stewardship, at a time when traditional advertising agencies have faced many challenges to their business, WPP's pre-tax profits rose 20% year on year to £112.6m.

The funny thing is that Sorrell isn't an adland creative whizz - he's never written a word of advertising copy in his life. Nor is he the 'bean counter' some critics have dismissed him as he's no accountant. What he is, however, is a business strategist, a fact which has delivered ample return to his shareholders in recent years, but which has provoked cynical rivals to sniff that his pursuit of stock market performance has downgraded the importance of creativity and advertising pedigree.

Talk to Sorrell about his vision for the future and it's not hard to see why traditionalists might feel, well, a little peeved.

'I prefer to use the term 'marketing communication services provider' rather than 'advertising agency',' he explains.

'Those companies that have positioned themselves as doing more than advertising are better prepared to deal with the challenges that lie ahead. In today's business climate, clients must have a whole panoply of weapons at their disposal, and that applies to those supplying them with these services, too.'

Much of the advertising industry is too conservative, he believes. 'Our industry's image is a modern one. We are thought of as being at the cutting edge of progress, focusing on new trends, fads, and fashions and youth. In truth we are probably more conservative than bankers or accountants or lawyers.'

Sorrell's success has come from applying lessons learned by his agencies' clients to WPP's own business. When describing what sets WPP's approach apart from that of its competitors, he draws parallels with brand-owning businesses such as Procter & Gamble and Nestle.

'The challenges we face are the challenges faced by our clients,' he explains.'An over-capacity of brands in the marketplace, the explosion of new channels of distribution and the need for effective internal communications.'

He is a hands-on manager, constantly touring the far reaches of an empire which extends to 92 countries and employs 33,000 staff.

'It's no good sitting in New York or Chicago - you've got to feel the excitement,' he said recently. 'You have got to develop new ways of doing things, and new ways of thinking about things.' A key challenge, he says, is cultivating the identities of WPP's constituent companies to fuel innovation and creative thinking.

As advertisers have grown disenchanted by the relative cost of TV airtime and new technology has offered alternatives to traditional advertising, Sorrell believes ad agencies can no longer assume theirs are the only solutions. But as he admits, many still do.

'He recognised before many the changing demands of clients and the importance of developing an integrated, rather than advertising-led approach to brand communication,' one agency executive observes.

Cambridge and Harvard-educated (he studied economics before taking the Harvard Business School MBA), Sorrell sounds more management consultant than adman. In fact, after completing his studies he did work as a management consultant in America, then for sports marketer Mark McCormack in London before joining Saatchi & Saatchi as chief financial officer.

By the mid-80s, he was widely credited for the Saatchis' success with his focus on the bottom line and cost control. Saatchis, however, was not his. So he decided to go it alone, acquiring a stake in Wire and Plastic Products - a small, listed company that made shopping baskets. This gave him a platform to acquire advertising and marketing businesses; initially small ones, such as direct marketing agencies, and eventually adland giants JWT and O&M.

Unfortunately, Sorrell bought O&M at the worst possible time just before recession struck, bringing WPP to the brink of insolvency in the early 90s with debts of around £500m. It was at this time that he negotiated the now famous incentive scheme which required a significant investment of his own money for an eventual return linked to the company's future performance. He re-built the business. And he made a personal fortune, too - £35m in bonuses over the past five years - and maybe a further £30m over the next five under a new senior executives' bonus scheme proposed last week.

Critics paint Sorrell as an adland philistine, interested only in the bottom line with little passion for the art itself. And indeed, he has described himself self-deprecatingly as 'a dull, boring little clerk'.

Married with three children, he has homes in Hampstead and the South of France. 'He's a money man. Full stop,' one senior executive at a London ad agency sniffs. 'He might just as well be running a chain of shops, or a bank.'

One recent report concerning the sorry state of Marks & Spencer named him a possible contender for the retailer's top job. Flattering, but inaccurate, is Sorrell's response. 'Although I did once work behind the cheese counter during business school for a project.'

Sorrell insists he is hooked on advertising and marketing. True, he ended up in it by chance. 'But as an industry, it's very similar to investment banking, or management consultancy,' he says.

'Firstly, because it's fun. Secondly, because it's a business where virtually every commercial situation you read about in the newspapers we are involved in, with one tentacle or another. It can be any industry, any country in any part of the world, political or social issues. It's what makes it interesting and keeps you fresh. Like entertainment, or sport, you're only as good as your last campaign.'

And as technology increases opportunities for would-be media owners, he looks forward to fresh challenges. 'We've had proposals to partner in overseas TV channels where our involvement would not be restricted, as it is in the UK. We've not done so yet. I'd not rule it out. But we would consider opportunities to invest in highly targeted, specialist media opportunities. There are tremendous opportunities with new media. With the web, everybody's a media owner. Life has changed.'

Well to a point. For Sorrell admits: 'I'm not as wired as I should be.' And of his own media habits, he observes: 'Given the amount of travelling I now do, I'd have to say I'm consistent with anyone else in my demographic group.' By which he means he's a voracious consumer of business media, watches little TV but enjoys humorous British commercials when he can.

'I couldn't single out any one campaign for fear of causing offence - my life wouldn't be worth living,' he says. But he does know a good ad campaign when he sees one. 'David Ogilvy (the late founder of O&M) always said he didn't like humorous advertising because advertising should be there primarily to sell. Well, like [him] I believe that the best ads are the most effective ads.'

It's common sense, after all. For even the most precious adland traditionalist would have to admit that good advertising communication makes more money than bad.

fields.headline: British market bounces back
fields.standfirst: MoneyUnlimited: what's the FTSE doing now?
fields.trailText: London shares rallied by nearly 100 points today, staging a comeback from yesterday's massive losses as tech and telecoms stocks shot ahead.
fields.body:
London shares rallied by nearly 100 points today, staging a comeback from yesterday's massive losses as tech and telecoms stocks shot ahead.

After just an hour's trading this morning, the FTSE-100 index of leading shares jumped 94.2 points ahead to 5409. Telecom shares sparked following gains made on the US Nasdaq exchange last night, with Vodafone, Colt Telecom and BT all surging.

Yesterday saw the FTSE suffer its worst percentage fall since October 1992, with billions of pounds wiped off the value of shares. The Index closed down 225.9 points at 5314.8, as investors rushed to sell off telecoms, techs and banks.

But last night Wall Street staged a late recovery, closing down less than 100 points after having fallen 380 at its lowest point. The Nasdaq closed ahead by 67 points.

Far Eastern markets also helped, with both the Nikkei and the Hang Seng posting overnight gains.

Shares have been falling because of worries over a United States recession, jitters about the Japanese economy, and bad news updates from a number of companies.

The recent plunge in stocks was seen by some as being sparked by the decision of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to shave just 0.5% off American interest rates - rather than the more aggressive 0.75% for which the markets had hoped.

Analysts have commented that the markets are so jittery at the moment that the slightest hint of bad news is sending shares plummeting.

Today was a quiet day for corporate announcements, and with no blue-chip profit warnings announced in early trading, the FTSE gained confidence.

In London, the biggest movers and shakers after an hour's trading included Telewest Communications, up 13%, telecoms equipment firm Energis, posting a 9% hike, computer services firm Logica, rising 11%, and chip designer Arm, sparking 6%.

Among the smaller shares, hand-held computer firm Psion rose 5%, telecoms group Thus sparked 12% ahead and software firm Autonomy was up 7%.

fields.headline: Eriksson: Gerrard should be fit
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has confirmed that Steven Gerrard should be fit for tomorrow's World Cup qualifier with Finland.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson has confirmed that Steven Gerrard should be fit for tomorrow's World Cup qualifier with Finland.

Gerrard was a doubt because of his persistent back problems, but he trained today and looks likely to start in the centre of midfield alongside Paul Scholes.

"Gerrard practised today without any problems," Eriksson told a press conference this afternoon. "He did almost everything. If he does not have a reaction tonight he will be fit for tomorrow.

"His chances of playing are much better than 50-50. Yesterday I was a little bit worried but after practice today I feel very positive about it."

Eriksson also said he expects to be able to field David Seaman, although he wouldn't reveal who his first choice goalkeeper will be.

"Whatever I do with the goalkeeper it will be the right choice - all four are very, very good. We will see tomorrow," he said.

Asked if he had told his players what the team will be, Eriksson said: "I think they know. I will tell them tomorrow. But because of the way we have been practising I think they know.

"We have not talked about who is going to play, only how we are going to play," he added.

England defeated Spain 3-0 in their first match under Eriksson last month, but the England coach has warned the press not to read too much into the result.

"This is for real now," he said. "There is a big difference between a friendly and this. We know if we want to play in Japan and Korea we have to play very well tomorrow."

There has been much talk in the build-up to tomorrow's game about the reception that David Beckham in particular, and Manchester United players in general, will receive from the crowd at Anfield.

United players are used to a hostile reaction when they face Liverpool at Anfield but Eriksson stressed that he expected tomorrow's crowd to get behind all of England's players.

"I want good support for England. If they (the fans) want us to play in the 2002 World Cup (finals) that's what I expect from them."

Asked about the rivalry between the two sets of fans, Eriksson added: "Those things are very important when Liverpool play Manchester United but are to be forgotten when England play Finland.

"We need to play football and to do that need good support. We hope it will be good support tomorrow."

After much success as a club manager, Eriksson is now relishing his first taste of international management and is aware of the increased expectations that go with the territory.

"I've always been a club manager. The difference now is that is this case (managing England) there are a lot more supporters than I'm used to.

"I know there are 50 or 60 million people (taking an interest in England's fortunes). In that way it's more important than anything I've done before."

Eriksson refused to entertain the possibility of failing to beat the Finns tomorrow in a game England must win to revive their hopes of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup.

"I've never thought about losing before a game," said Eriksson. "Unfortunately it happens sometimes but talking about losing before a game is very negative and as a manager you should never do that.

"I'm not thinking about losing. We want to win but in football nothing is for sure. You can't guarantee anything."

Eriksson offered encouragement to Beckham, who skippered England to victory in the friendly against Spain, the Swede's first game in charge and suggested that he was more concerned about how the Manchester United midfielder plays than his credentials for remaining England captain.

"I think he (Beckham) will grow into the role of captain. But even more important tomorrow is that David Beckham plays as David Beckham can play."

"Gerrard practised today without any problems," Eriksson told a press conference this afternoon. "He did almost everything. If he does not have a reaction tonight he will be fit for tomorrow. "His chances of playing are much better than 50-50. Yesterday I was a little bit worried but after practice today I feel very positive about it." "Whatever I do with the goalkeeper it will be the right choice - all four are very, very good. We will see tomorrow," he said. Asked if he had told his players what the team will be, Eriksson said: "I think they know. I will tell them tomorrow. But because of the way we have been practising I think they know. fields.headline: Microsoft issues virus warning
fields.trailText: Microsoft has issued a warning to computer users that someone may be using stolen verification certificates to deliver computer viruses over the internet.
fields.body:
Microsoft has issued a warning to computer users that someone may be using stolen verification certificates to deliver computer viruses over the internet.

The Seattle software giant said that a fraudster posing as a Microsoft employee managed to obtain two authentic digital certificates from VeriSign, a California computer security company. These certificates would allow the person to pass off rogue programs and possibly computer viruses as legitimate Microsoft software.
VeriSign notified Microsoft that it issued the two digital certificates - a key security feature of Microsoft's internet software - on January 29 and 30.

The problem is serious and the effects could last for years, said Russ Cooper of TruSecure Corp.

"This is an extremely huge mistake by VeriSign," he said. "There's no way that this certificate should have been given to a non-Microsoft employee."

Microsoft and VeriSign were working to correct the problem, both companies said. Users were warned to inspect for certificates that were issued on January 29 and 30, since no legitimate certificates were given on those dates, and to notify Microsoft or VeriSign if they discover them.

The FBI has also been notified, said Mahi deSilva, VeriSign's vice president, adding that the person who obtained the certificates had a sophisticated knowledge of ways to try to fool the company's security procedures. So far, VeriSign believes no one has used the certificates.

Microsoft also advised customers to set security levels to prevent viruses from being transmitted by e-mail in case the fraudulent program was opened. The company hoped to have a program available in the next two weeks that will automatically check for the fake certificates.

The program will be available to download for free off the internet for products including Windows and Internet Explorer.

webTitle: Small beer in the tourist trade

fields.headline: Small beer in the tourist trade
fields.standfirst: What foot and mouth is doing to farmers is bad enough, but  the knock-on effects could be even more disastrous for rural communities.  Derek Brown reports from Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: What foot and mouth is doing to farmers is bad enough, but the knock-on effects could be even more disastrous for rural communities. Derek Brown reports from Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire, in the latest in our series of dispatches from the front line.
fields.body:
It never rains but it pours - or in our case this week, it snows. On Tuesday and Wednesday this week, the town was partly white, partly slushy, and almost wholly deserted. Most of the traders in the weekly open air market didn't even bother to turn out. And although the sun is shining again now, there isn't much of a silver lining behind the clouds of economic gloom.

The restaurateur

Brian Galbraith and partner Jan Blackburn, who run the bar-restaurant Stones in the town centre, have escaped to Lanzarote for a couple of weeks, leaving a business which is, at best, ticking over.

On Wednesday there were a handful of customers at the bar. Yesterday there was something of a bonanza: three lunch tables occupied.

Roy Sparry, who is looking after Stones, is more usually found at a hotel in Burford, one of the main tourist hotspots in the Cotswolds even at this time of year. But not this year: the tourists and trippers have deserted in droves, and the hotels are letting rooms at any price they can get.

The closure of Blenheim Palace, the biggest single attraction in this part of Oxfordshire, has had a huge impact. More ominous still is the reluctance of couples and families from the cities to come into the countryside.

Before they left, Brian and Jan's friend David Smith popped into Stones to buy them a send-off drink. He runs the Red Lion in the small somnolent village of Little Compton, between Chipping Norton and Moreton-in-Marsh.

The pub has a deserved reputation for good food and fine beer, but no local trade to speak of. It depends on the passing trade, and on regulars who are normally more than willing to drive fair distances.

That's all gone for the moment. Like most catering businesses around here, the Red Lion lost out badly when the Cheltenham Festival was postponed. There are no bookings for its three letting bedrooms, and scant prospects for the upcoming Mother's Day weekend - usually a time of handsome takings in the restaurant.

David's beer order last week was his smallest in 12 years, and that is yet another ripple in the outflowing tide of lost trade: the Red Lion is tied to Donnington brewery, an old family concern with a tiny estate of just 15 countryside pubs, all presumably suffering in the tourism drought.

Everyone has a story to tell about the depressed state of the local economy. There is the haulier who used to specialise in moving livestock, but now has utterly no business, and a brand new £250,000 truck on his hands.

There are the caterers specialising in farm fairs and the like, whose bookings for spring and summer have evaporated.

There are the hotel workers who are being laid off or put on part time working.

The butcher

Just occasionally, you hear of the handful of people actually benefiting from the crisis, like the straw contractor who is working flat out to locate and transport the material needed to fuel the ghastly animal pyres in infected districts.

More modest, but still encouraging, is the steady increase of new customers at John Kench the butcher's shop.

Even better, from his point of view, are the small reductions in the wholesale prices of lamb, pork and bacon, which have allowed him to restore his squeezed profit margins.

John welcomes the new business, of course, and the changing attitudes which it portends. Customers are more conscious of quality, and want to know exactly where their food is coming from.

But there is a downside: "To be honest, I'm getting a bit fed up of answering the same questions all the time," he says ruefully. "When it's a busy day, and you have 150 people all saying the same thing, it gets a bit wearing."

The supermarket manager

Trade is also healthy at the town's Co-op supermarket. "Everything is running along on an even keel. We are able to offer a full range of products. Our sales are not depressed in any way, but we are not seeing any panic-buying. Prices are stable, although there has been a bit of pressure on cooked meats. On the whole, things are much as normal," says manager Tony Hatch.

The Co-op, like all other local businesses, normally looks ahead to Easter and the start of the tourism season proper, for increased trade.

This year Easter holds no such promise. The hoteliers and guest house keepers are already counting the cost of business which is lost forever, and looking ahead to the summer with apprehension.

But at least in Chipping Norton itself there is a resident population of some 6000 people who will need food and other supplies. For them, Tony has come up with a neat little slogan: "Stay local, and stay spending!" The farmer

It's a slogan which will appeal to Marilyn Ivings, who is constantly urging consumers to support local produce. Her small herd of suckler cows at Mill Farm in Church Enstone will not be contributing to the human food chain until August, which puts Marilyn in the relatively privileged position among farmers of not having to move her animals for at least four months.

Still, the restriction on movement is uncomfortably close to home, in a quite literal sense: the latest official boundary is the road along the side of Mill Farm. And as if that is not enough to worry about, Marilyn has received some new advice from the National Farmers Union, of which she is a stalwart member and spokeswoman.

"They're telling us to be aware of any unexpected packages which may arrive, and not to open them if we have any doubts. It seems they have been told that anyone speaking out in favour of the cordon sanitaire operation (the culling of healthy animals in areas vulnerable to infection) could be getting some unwelcome attention," she said.

It seems extraordinary that now, of all times, farmers should be obliged to think about the potential threat from animal 'welfare' extremists. But then these are extraordinary times in the countryside.

fields.headline: Scoot calls in Merrill Lynch
fields.trailText:
1pm: Scoot.com has called in an investment bank amid rumours that it is about to sell, writes Amy Vickers.
Jan 10: Scoot shares surge on takeover rumours
fields.body:
Online directory service Scoot.com has called in an investment bank amid rumours that it is about to put up a "for sale" sign.

Merrill Lynch will carry out a strategic review of the company, a consultation that could lead to new partners being brought in.

Scoot has repeatedly been at the centre of takeover speculation in the past year.

Reports have suggested French media group Vivendi Universal may enlarge its 25% stake in Scoot Europe.

Analysts view Vivendi as crucial to Scoot's cultivation of business subscribers in Europe.

Reporting its results this morning for the 15 months to December 31, Scoot Europe pledged to invest £35m in new business interests and laid out plans to expand into other European countries later this year.

Scoot is reporting over 15 months this year to adopt the same financial year as its existing European businesses.

The online directory revealed pre-tax losses of £71.5m, against its previously reported £21.1m losses in the 12 months to September 30 1999.

Revenues rose to £24.1m from £15.4m, and Scoot declared it still had £31.1m left in the bank.

Scoot said it was on track to double UK revenues this year and expected its subscriber base to reach 110,000 in the UK, up from 55,658 and 85,000 in Europe.

"With our UK business on track to profitability, it is critical to ensure that Scoot can fully exploit its exciting business opportunities," said Dick Eykel, chairman of Scoot.

"As a result, the group and its advisers are formally reviewing a range of strategic options."

fields.headline: Express sports chief quits
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Daily Express head of sport Mike Allen is quitting the paper after 15 years to take voluntary redundancy, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 20: Express newsmen take redundancy
Mar 15: Sports writers under threat
fields.body:
Daily Express head of sport Mike Allen is quitting the paper after 15 years to take voluntary redundancy.

"I've had a good innings," said Mr Allen. "It's time for someone else to take on the responsibility of running what is a fantastic staff, which produces some of the best sports pages.

"They will continue to do so, providing they are given the resources," he added in a hint to the newspaper's owners about the importance of spending money on editorial.

Mr Allen denied his departure was connected with last week's announcement that new Express owner Richard Desmond was to make 145 editorial redundancies.

He said he would be interested in working at another newspaper.

"I love newspapers," he added. "Even after all this time I still get a thrill when one comes through the letterbox."

It is not known who will replace Mr Allen.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week thirty

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week thirty
fields.standfirst: Blue Square gave us £400 which, in retrospect, we may as well have spent down the boozer
fields.trailText: Bets. Bets, bets. Bets, bets, bets. Bets, bets, bets, bets. Bets, bets, bets, bets, bets.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.54
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £39.08
Sean Ingle = £19.82
Paul MacInnes = £15.01

Scott Murray: Finland to beat England £5 @ 10/1

Not many English supporters will go into English bookies tomorrow and place a bet against the English national team. You won't even catch the open-minded, liberal ones who sing No Surrender doing it. As a result, the bookies will artificially shorten the price of Sven's men while lengthening the odds of the opposition.

Finland aren't as bad as a price of 10/1 suggests. OK, so they may not have a great shout on paper, but repeat after me: oppose a bad favourite. Come on Finland, etc.

Richo the Geordie of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Cyprus v Republic of Ireland - 4 goals or more, £5 @ 15/8

Given that it's a World Cup weekend, I can't rely on Man U's last-minute wins, Chelsea's reliable away record, or Leeds snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.

The questions I ask myself are: Can England win? (dunno); can Scotland score? (ditto); can NI hold out? (I suspect not); who plays for Wales? (?); and, most pertinently, what's going to happen in Nicosia?

The Irish should win this comfortably, and score a few in the process, but their defence is, well, Irish, and the Cypriots can't be relied upon to roll over and die any more; and they have been scoring reasonably well at home.

Accordingly, and with the combined pub lunch input from other expats, we're going to put our £5 on 4 or more goals at 15/8. Better odds are available elsewhere, but I like this best.

Sean Ingle: £5 win double - Wales to beat Armenia @ 6/4, Faroe Islands to beat Luxembourg @ 11/8

It's hard to find value on this weekend's coupon. Most matches look shoo-ins, and as a result the bookies are offering stingy prices on almost every game. And who can blame them with Johnny Punter waiting in the wings, hoping his ten-match accumulator comes off?

That was me once. I was Johnny Punter, with my betting-slip fingers and my nervous tic. But no more. So in an admittedly belated search for value, I've looked at games like Euro 2000 finalists Slovenia to win in Russia (6/1), and Poland to overcome struggling Norway (11/4). Both offer good chances. However, as usual I've shirked the big bet and chosen a safer-looking double instead.

Wales should beat Armenia more times than not. Armenia finished bottom of their Euro 2000 qualifying group, while Wales - after a 2-1 defeat in their opening game in Belarus - have improved and drew away at Poland last time out.

I'd also expect the Faroe Islands - who, admitted, aren't as good as they were - to overcome Luxembourg. Now Luxembourg are improving, and those 8-0 defeats against the top teams have become two or three-goal losses. But they still lose every game they play, and I think it's more likely than not they will lose this one as well.

All-in-all the double pays 3.75-1, which is reasonable. But I've said that before

The Prince of Punts: England v Finland - Draw/England £10 @ 4/1

When the Prince of Punts saw those galoots from Kilmarnock miss their golden opportunity to get invited to my annual barbeque (quail sausages a speciality), it was almost enough to persuade one to chuck in gambling in favour of something more profitable - like sheep farming. But a quick glass of laudanum and a wrestle with the manservant has convinced one otherwise.

So England to scrape a late win against the Finns it is. Despite the presence of the impressive Sven, it wouldn't be England if there wasn't a slight sense of anticlimax about this Saturday's performance. fields.headline: Crisis enlivens Swedish summit
fields.standfirst: The EU's Nice summit in December was a big affair, but now Tony Blair and friends are doing it all again in Stockholm. Should we care, asks Andrew Osborn?
fields.trailText: The EU's Nice summit in December was a big affair, but now Tony Blair and friends are doing it all again in Stockholm. Should we care, asks Andrew Osborn?
fields.body:
There's nothing like a decent crisis to enliven EU summits, which, if the truth be told, usually turn out to be interminably dull affairs. So, the spread of foot and mouth disease across Europe, coupled with the Macedonian crisis and plunging world stock markets, have, in a perverse way, happened at exactly the right time.

For the official agenda of the EU's two-day Stockholm summit, which kicked off today, was packed with intangible, worthy items of the upmost importance and of the upmost dryness.

A summit free of such crises would of course be far more preferable in the general scheme of things. Nobody in the real world wants a virtually uncontrollable animal disease on their doorstep, a potentially explosive ethnic conflict or a rampant bear market.

But, for Tony Blair and the other summiteers, the truth is that it helps - they will be able to strut their stuff as European statesmen and be seen to be grappling with some really serious issues.

For Europe's media it is also a godsend and, in the ponderous run-up to the summit, journalists all over Brussels could be heard praying for a row on the sidelines - preferably of the Anglo-French variety - to liven up the party.

Keith Vaz, the UK's "embattled" Europe minister must also be breathing a sigh of relief - his own problems in connection with the controversial Hinduja brothers now seem like small beer compared to the situation in the Balkans.

He will be hoping that the Tories, keen not to be seen as engaging in petty domestic sniping at a time of crisis, will call off the dogs for the time being.

In its pre-crisis form it is no exaggeration to say, however, that the summit's original agenda offered a cure for even the most troubled insomniacs.

A high-level meeting to discuss how best the EU can be transformed into the world's most dynamic economy by 2010, leaving the US for dust, sounds, on the face of it, to be interesting. But don't be fooled. The nuts and bolts and technicalities of achieving that goal are uninspiring to say the least. The highlights are:

 1. Trying to persuade all EU countries to open up their electricity markets to competition by 2005.
 2. Seeking to clinch an agreement on a single framework for regulating Europe's securities market.
 3. Ratifying a series of nebulous employment targets.
 4. Talking about centralising Europe's air traffic control system.

That these issues are important is beyond dispute, but even the most ardent of europhiles has found it hard in recent weeks to summon up enthusiasm for this particular meeting. But then nobody ever claimed that building Europe would be interesting all of the time.

Sweden, the EU's current president, tried to provide a welcome distraction to the summit's official business by inviting the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, to come along and discuss EU-Russia policy. It was a good idea and, had the likes of Lionel Jospin and Gerhard Schroeder been short of a crisis to get their teeth into, might have done the trick.

For it is now an honoured tradition that every summit of this kind is hijacked by more pressing and more interesting issues - it is usually just a question of what they will be.

In the past the EU's great and good used to get together twice a year for a major summit, but in recent times there has been a tendency to hold four such meetings every year.

Each EU member state takes it in turn to be the bloc's president for a six-month period, during which they hold two summits on their own territory. The current president is Sweden, hence today's meeting in Stockholm - there will also be another one in Gothenburg later this year.

The thinking, until recently, was that hosting such summits was prestigious, profile enhancing and lucrative. However, the increasingly common phenomenon of sometimes violent anti-globalisation demonstrators shouting and throwing paving stones outside the conference room means that the cost of policing such an event has spiralled.

Belgium has, in theory, won the right to host all EU summits in future but some politicians are beginning to fret about the costs involved. However, the truth about EU summits is simple - some are more important than others.

Nice, in December, was a big one because EU leaders effectively redrew the rule book, hammering out a new treaty to allow the bloc to take in new countries from eastern Europe.

Other gatherings in Maastricht and Amsterdam in the past were also significant, but inbetween there has been a plethora of also-ran meetings, which are vital to making progress on important dossiers, but eminently dull.

Thank God, then, for a crisis.

webTitle: Major warns Blair against May election

fields.headline: Major warns Blair against May election
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: John Major, the former prime minister, today laid down an ultimatum to Tony Blair over the timing of a general election, telling the current premier not to go to the country unless he was sure the foot and mouth epidemic was under control.
fields.body:
John Major, the former prime minister, today laid down an ultimatum to Tony Blair over the timing of a general election, telling the current premier not to go to the country unless he was sure the foot and mouth epidemic was under control.

In a move designed to turn up the political pressure on Mr Blair as he decides whether or not to go for a May 3 poll - the same date as the local elections - the former PM pleaded that two stringent tests must be met if a general election is called.

The tests are that the foot and mouth disease is under control, and that Labour ministers will be able to devote as much time to tackling the epidemic as if there were no campaigning.

Mr Major said: "The prime minister still seems determined to proceed as if all were serene in the countryside.

"The government and its spin doctors are now advancing the truly ludicrous notion that, were the planned local elections for May 3 to be delayed , it would highlight the crisis and thereby damage the tourism industry."

Although Mr Major - who will himself retire as an MP at the next election - falls short of calling for the general election to be postponed indefinitely, his demands would appear designed to rule out a May 3 date.

He adds: "I look at the blank, fearful faces of the farmers and my heart bleeds for them: it seems malign fate is forever lying in wait for to bat them around the ears."

Mr Major's voice of concern is added to that of the newly-formed Electoral Commission, whose job is to ensure elections are carried out in a "free and fair" manner.

Sam Younger, the chairman of the commission, yesterday expressed concern that postal services would be functioning properly across rural areas, for those voters who have chosen to use a postal vote.

Although technically the prime minister does not need to call an election until the end of May 2002, all three parties have geared up so-called "war rooms" at their London head offices for a May 3 contest.

The last date for announcing a May 3 general election would be April 5.

fields.headline: Murphy talks up C5 ratings
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: Eddie Murphy proved a top draw last night, pulling in 2.5m viewers for Channel 5, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Eddie Murphy proved a ratings puller for Channel 5 last night, with his action thriller Metro drawing nearly 2.5m viewers.

Metro, which features Murphy as a San Francisco police hostage negotiator, went out in the Channel 5 movie slot from 9pm.

The film had 2.4m viewers and a 12% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

It set Channel 5 up nicely for a strong run of late-night ratings.

Documentary Rankin's Raw Nudes followed Metro from 11.15pm, with saucy drama Red Shoe Diaries taking over between 12.15-12.50am.

Rankin's Raw Nudes had 1m and a 14% share, while Red Shoe Diaries pulled in 0.4m and 13%.

Elsewhere last night ITV dominated the peaktime ratings battle with BBC1, with Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? - Couples and Peak Practice running between 8pm and 10pm.

Millionaire had 10m and a 42% share and Peak Practice got 8.1m and 35%.

On BBC1 from 8pm, Animal Hospital kicked off with 6.5m.

A Changing Rooms repeat followed at 8.30pm with just 4.7m; while a Car Wars Special had 5.2m between 9pm and 10pm.

But BBC1 did win the 10pm head to head news battle.

The Ten O'Clock News had 5.2m, just piping News at Ten, with 5.1m.

fields.headline: Punch editor wins court case
fields.trailText: 12pm: Former Punch editor James Steen has cleared his name after a high court ruling against him was overturned, reports Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Former Punch editor James Steen today won his battle to clear his name after a court overturned a high court ruling against him.

The court of appeal today reversed a high court ruling in November that Mr Steen was in contempt of court by publishing an article by former MI5 officer David Shayler in breach of a gagging order.

The court dropped the £5,000 fine and ordered the attorney general to pay the estimated £300,000 costs of the case.

Punch last year ran an article by Mr Shayler claiming M15 did not take enough security precautions in the run-up to the 1993 IRA Bishopsgate bombing. The magazine was found to be in contempt of court and fined £25,000.

Mr Steen said he was "absolutely delighted" at today's verdict. His lawyer, David Price, said the ruling established "that the courts are not just paying lip service to freedom of expression".

Mr Steen, who left Punch shortly after last year's high court ruling, said he had "gone past the point where I felt sorry for myself, and I now feel sorry for the British taxpayer, who is now going to have to pay over £300,000.

"After the high court ruling I had to think very hard about whether I wanted to take this case on. I've always felt that if I've got something wrong I'll say sorry and leave it," he added.

"But in this case I couldn't leave it."

Mr Price said the case had helped set a precedent in establishing that once something was in the public domain, it was very difficult to prosecute someone for republishing it.

Lord Phillips, master of the rolls, said today he had "difficulty" in accepting the attorney general's assertion that it could be a criminal offence for a newspaper to fail to obtain clearance from him before publishing material to which he might object.

"Such a proposition results in the imposition of a restriction on freedom of the press that is disproportionate to any public interest and thus in breach of Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights," he added.

A key factor in the judge's initial ruling last November was a letter from government lawyers, printed on the front of the magazine.

Mr Justice Silber, the presiding judge at last year's high court hearing, said the letter had been put there to increase sales.

webTitle: In brief: Jackie Chan calls for crack down on organised crime

fields.headline: Jackie Chan calls for crack down on organised crime
fields.standfirst: Plus: John Woo teams with Harrison Ford for actioner
fields.trailText: Plus: John Woo teams with Harrison Ford for actioner
fields.body:
 Jackie Chan has called for measures to fight organised crime, after a triad member was arrested for blackmail at a Hong Kong location for Rush Hour 2. According to Screen Daily, the triad member was caught collecting $1,000 (£702) at a café where the sequel was shooting. Chan has now suggested launching a Film Industry Workers' Confederation. The proposed organisation would unite around 1,200 film professionals with the aim of keeping illegal organisations out of the industry. "I worry that foreign film-makers will not come to Hong Kong to shoot their films anymore," Chan told Screen Daily.

 John Woo is to team up with Harrison Ford for a new action film. According to Mr Showbiz, Woo, whose recent hits include Mission: Impossible 2 and Face/Off, is said to be working with script writer Andrew Marlowe (who wrote Hollow Man and End of Days) on the project. Woo is currently in post-production on the second world war drama, Windtalker, starring Nicolas Cage and Christian Slater. Ford is already returning to the action genre with Russian submarine suspenser, K:19 (see earlier story).

According to Mr Showbiz, Woo, whose recent hits include Mission: Impossible 2 and Face/Off, is said to be working with script writer Andrew Marlowe (who wrote Hollow Man and End of Days) on the project. Woo is currently in post-production on the second world war drama, Windtalker, starring Nicolas Cage and Christian Slater. Ford is already returning to the action genre with Russian submarine suspenser, K:19 (see earlier story).

fields.headline: Digital divide to deepen
fields.trailText: A report out today from think tank Demos argues that information held and shared electronically is increasingly used to exclude the poor and the old from wider society.
fields.body:
A report out today from think tank Demos argues that information held and shared electronically is increasingly used to exclude the poor and the old from wider society.

Demos says that the real digital divide is not about getting the country online by providing access to hardware such as personal computers or internet-enabled mobile phones. It is, the researchers suggest, about the information held on individuals which marks them as unworthy of credit, insurance, electronic cash or employment.

Just last week, the department for education and employment announced a £10m plan to tackle the digital divide by providing internet and digital access to 12,000 homes in six deprived communities across England.

But the Demos report found that access to the internet is not the issue and that government efforts have been misplaced.

Perri 6 - one of the authors of the report, Divided by Information - said: "Government ministers have spent a lot of time and a not inconsiderable amount of money on solving a problem - access to kit - that will solve itself. The real worry is that information itself will be the engine of exclusion."

He explained that the organisations - such as credit ratings agencies - that hold personal information about people do not offer second chances or rehabilitation, and that negative profiles create a class of permanently "digitally redlined" people. And the Data Protection Act offers little defence against exclusions which are based on correct information, he says.

"Banks used to give second chances on an inefficient basis. Now they deny second chances on an efficient basis, and the price we pay is social exclusion," Perri 6 said.

The real discussion about the digital divide, he says, should centre on how society plans to overcome social exclusion that is based on accurate but financially damning information. If the British economy moves to electronic cash as Canada, Finland and Norway have done, information passed around the internet could prevent people from making even basic purchases.

The report concludes that the government should spend more time thinking about how to subsidise those who will be routinely turned down by banks and employers on the basis of widely available digital profiles, and less time subsidising internet cafes.

webTitle: Mir today: safe splashdown for space station

fields.headline: Mir today: safe splashdown for space station
fields.standfirst:
Gallery: see the end of Mir
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Russian space station Mir has crashed into the southern Pacific ocean, ending its 15 years in orbit above the earth.
fields.body:
Russian space station Mir has crashed into the southern Pacific ocean, ending its 15 years in orbit above the earth.

Up to 40 tonnes of debris from the space station safely plunged into the sea hundreds of miles south-east of Fiji at 5.58am UK time.

The space station made a spectacular display in the sky as it burned up in the atmosphere, with a golden light show above Fiji.

Nobody was thought to have been injured at sea as Mir made its final descent.

Most of the 150-tonne spacecraft had already burned up as it re-entered Earth's atmosphere, while the remainder broke up into as many as 1,500 chunks, some as big as a small car.

Two planes carrying people who had paid a total of £1.4m to see the re-entry were thought to be the closest to the splash-down site, although as many as 30 fishing boats were also in the area.

Mir's watery grave ended a journey of more than 2bn miles, which had seen it play host to 104 cosmonauts from around the world, and set the record for the longest space stay, at 438 days.

It had been seen by eyewitnesses on Fiji 15 minutes before the end in a display which CNN reporter Hugh Williams said was "unbelievable".

"The Mir came streaking across the horizon in five, six, seven, maybe nine pieces making a huge golden trail," he said.

"The people here were just in awe. A collection of very bright golden-coloured lights were tearing across the sky."

Talk about it
What do you think?

fields.headline: ITV unveils Popstars follow-up
fields.trailText:
11am: ITV is to follow up Popstars with Pop Idol, a format that lets viewers decide who gets a shot at the big time. By Jason Deans

Mar 19: Popstars on song with 7m viewers
fields.body:
ITV is to follow up the smash hit success of reality show Popstars with Pop Idol, a format that lets viewers decide which wannabe gets a shot at the big time.

Pop Idol is similar to Popstars in that a panel of experts will choose a shortlist from open auditions across the UK that are expected to draw thousands of hopefuls looking for fame.

But after that the public will get to vote on which individual gets a shot at pop stardom.

The winner will be offered a deal with former Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller's 19 Management and a recording contract with RCA.

"After the phenomenal success of Popstars it will be wonderful to give our viewers the chance to decide who should be next for pop stardom," said Claudia Rosencrantz, ITV controller of entertainment.

Pop Idol will be made by Pearson Television and 19 TV, a subsidiary of Mr Fuller's 19 Group.

The format was created by Mr Fuller, who now manages S Club 7 and Annie Lennox, and Simon Cowell, the RCA A&R executive responsible for Westlife, Five and Robson and Jerome.

The pair will be closely involved in choosing the shortlist for Pop Idol.

The programme will be supported by a multimedia marketing campaign across TV, radio, press and the internet.

Pearson TV chief executive of UK production Alan Boyd will executive produce the show.

Related story

fields.headline: Mother's Day
fields.standfirst: Our online guide on to how to best keep mum this weekend
fields.trailText: Our online guide on to how to best keep mum this weekend.
fields.body:
1. If you haven't passed any card or chocolate shops lately, you may not have noticed that Mother's Day is this Sunday. Yes, two days away.

2. You never call and you never write, so I do not really expect that you will remember me on this one day a year even though I spent 39 hours in labour and every spare penny on you. Just send me an email card, dear. I don't mind.

3. I don't want you to spend all your hard-earned cash on a holiday with no real history.

4. Of course, you don't need to spend a lot of money. You could write me a poem.

5. In fact, if you're out of cash, you can try winning me a gift in a competition.

6. If you must, though, you could take me out for a meal. You know how I love it when you visit.

7. And perhaps just something small from the shops to open along with the wine at dinner.

8. I do fancy getting away for a few days, too.

9. And of course you know that the car has been causing me some problems for the last few months.

10. Anything, dear, really anything will be fine. Just make sure you get it fast.

fields.headline: Heineken brewer hires marketing chief
fields.trailText: <B<11.30am: The company behind some of the UK's biggest beer brands has hired a dedicated marketing director, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The company behind some of the UK's biggest beer brands including Stella Artois, Boddington's and Heineken, has hired a dedicated marketing director as part of a board-level shake-up.

Interbrew UK has promoted Richard Evans from brand marketing director to marketing director, in charge of the company's £30m annual advertising spend.

Previously the role of marketing and sales director was combined.

Mr Evans became brand marketing director in 1999 and last year took on responsibility for new product development.

He was formerly take home marketing controller at the then Whitbread Beer Company, having joined in 1994 as marketing manager for Heineken.

His career began at Procter & Gamble where he worked on brands including Ariel, Fairy Liquid and Pampers.

The appointment of Mr Evans to the board as marketing director follows the promotion of sales and marketing director Stewart Gilliland to the position of managing director.

The brewer has now restructured its board, with Mr Gilliland replacing Miles Templeman, who will continue to advise Interbrew UK as an external consultant.

The new board comprises Whitbread and Interbrew executives because Interbrew is being forced by the UK competition authorities to sell off the Bass business it acquired for £2.3bn last June.

A high court review into the government's decision to block Interbrew 's purchase of Bass will begin on May 9.
