fields.headline: Surviving by stealth in a county clinging to its traditional values
fields.standfirst: In the second of a three-part series looking at the health of local government, Roy Hattersley puts Kent county council under the microscope and finds success stories amid the political tensions
fields.trailText: In the second of a three-part series looking at the health of local government, Roy Hattersley puts Kent county council under the microscope and finds success stories amid the political tensions
fields.body:
Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, the leader of Kent county council, prides himself on being a thinking politician. That is why - purely in the spirit of intellectual inquiry - he enlivened a meeting of the Local Government Association by asking Peter Mandelson how ministers could be either convincing or consistent if they were not guided by a coherent ideology.

The former Northern Ireland secretary replied that he was not prepared to answer that, or any other question, from so prejudiced a source. But, despite feeling "bruised" by the rebuff, Mr Bruce-Lockhart remained a seeker after truth. When Hillary Armstrong, the minister for local government, visited the south-east of England regional assembly last July, he invited her to define "economic, social and environmental well-being" - the happy state which the white paper on local government requires councils to encourage.

According to Mr Bruce-Lockhart's paraphrase, Ms Armstrong replied that the meaning of the phrase was "in the head of the beholder" - a view which he decided, after some careful thought, he shared. He has worked out how he wants it to be beheld in Kent. At a time when the old certainties - church, royalty, family - no longer hold society together, local government must engender "a sense of purpose, a sense of order, a sense of community and a sense of belonging". That aspiration is not in the down-to-earth tradition of local government. But Mr Bruce-Lockhart can provide a practical example of how his objective is being achieved.

"There are already places around the United Kingdom where regeneration - city development - has brought a vitality, a vibrancy into town centres and created a sense of civic pride which is tangible."

That - as Mr Bruce-Lockhart, "a great admirer of Albert Bore", gladly concedes - is an exact description of what the City of Birmingham, whose council Mr Bore leads, hopes it has achieved in its urban renewal initiative. When the Tory leader of England's largest county council endorses the municipal philosophy of the Labour leader in England's second city, the idea of "new local government" creating its own agenda for general "improvement" has to be taken seriously. But the pattern of change cannot be the same in town and country. Kent county council, in the new century as in the old, will have to share what power local government retains, with the 12 borough and district councils within its boundaries.

Partnerships

This year the Kent county council plans to spend £1,267m - basically in three areas. Education (together with libraries) will account for more than half, social services for more than a quarter and strategic planning (which includes the management of the roads programme) for something like 10%. The boroughs and districts - from Dover, through leafy Sevenoaks to the virtual London suburb of Dartford - provide the other local services. They also collect the 25% of the county council's income which is directly contributed by local citizens. The Treasury contributes twice as much. In Kent, local government politics as well as powers divide the councils. The county has been Conservative since the brief ruling Lib-Lab coalition was defeated in 1997. Three of the subsidiary district councils are still controlled by the Labour party.

County local government works best when the "two tiers" operate in co-operation rather than competition - an objective which the Kent Association of Local Authorities was formed to promote. Real partnerships are most easily achieved when powers are shared in the hope of improving the efficiency of a service which is not the subject of political dispute. For years the district councils collected refuse and then handed it to the county for disposal. Now the whole operation is under the control of a joint board. The rationalisation will not be an issue in the county council election campaign. Nor will the "falls strategy" - an example of good practice which qualifies Kent for commendation by the Local Government Association in its survey of "partnerships" in healthcare. The Tunbridge Wells borough council and the county council are working together to reduce the accident rate among elderly people. It is a worthy but prosaic policy - exactly the sort of unpolitical activity with which councils are traditionally associated.

Despite his enthusiasm for joint ventures, Mr Bruce-Lockhart remains a highly political figure, described by Trudy Dean, the Liberal leader, as "centralist, secretive and arrogant". He has caused his opponents constant irritation by blaming every problem on the Lib-Lab coalition which lost power four years ago. Principal amongthem is the council's huge debt. Since 1996 Kent council borrowing has risen to £610m - far more, as the auditors thought it necessary to point out, than the total in comparable counties. The debt has honourable origins. Much of it is largely the result of Kent channel rail link infrastructure programme - which the government "finances" by agreeing to the council increasing its borrowing. But Mr Bruce-Lockhart persists in blaming the deficit on his predecessors - even though it has increased under his administration and although in opposition he did not vote against one of the loan applications. Sometimes even the most rational local government leaders have to contrive disputes to meet the wishes of less pragmatic political activists who support them. Not all Kent Tories are old-fashioned country gentlemen.

Mr Bruce-Lockhart undoubtedly believes that a fundamental ideological divide separates the Labour and Conservative visions of local government. Although the two parties share "an absolutely sincere desire to improve the quality of life", Labour "thinks it is best achieved by more external controls". The Tories "want to give more responsibility to the people who are actually doing the job". Yet, despite his deep conviction that "the need is for more independence", and the open hostility of some of his Conservative colleagues, he has committed the county to signing a public service agreement (PSA) with the Whitehall government. Indeed, Kent has become one of the "pilot authorities" which are pioneering an idea which is a benign extension of ministerial interference in local affairs. Mr Bruce-Lockhart rejects the allegation of inconsistency by describing PSAs as a compromise between centralism and independence. "We are setting our own targets, but the government is encouraging us to stretch them and making it possible for us to meet them."

Even the officials who advise the council had their doubts about the voluntary surrender of yet more autonomy. A briefing note - appended to a paper which recommended participation in the first wave of PSAs - concluded that "counties have to decide whether the benefits of leading the pack" outweigh the risks of "supping with the devil". Mr Bruce-Lockhart decided that the PSA had benefits for Kent, and material improvement was more important than either party antagonism or political dogma.

The decision to lead the pack was taken after the discovery that the devil shared many of Kent county council's aims. The Next Five Years, Kent's 1998 "strategic statement" (which contained more substance than its glossy format suggests), and Opportunities for Kent - The Vision (drawn up two years later at greater length but with less precision) set out targets for improvement. At least by impli cation it advocated "joined-up government", the jargon for the local and national co-operation which Whitehall believes is essential to improved efficiency and delivery of local authority services.

Some of Kent's independent promises were too imprecise to make them part of any scheme which requires the achievement of statistically defined goals. The Next Five Years aimed "to support as many elderly people as possible to remain in their own homes" and Opportunities for Kent aspired to "reduce the number of children in care". The county's draft proposal for a public service agreement - submitted last September as the basis for partnership with Whitehall - put numerical flesh on the skeleton of earlier aspirations. Local target 11 stipulates a reduction in "the placement rate of elderly people who need to be supported in local authority supported residential and nursing care from 152 per 10,000 people to 100 per 10,000 people by March 2004". Target 13 aims to "reduce the number of children who have to be looked after by the local authority from 1,505 in March 2000 to 1,100 by March 2004". It is not so much that targets have been "stretched" than that they have been given real meaning.

The plan to improve the provision of help for the elderly was welcomed by critics of Kent's Tory majority as a sign that the sinner had come late to repentance. Half way through last year, the county council imposed a "moratorium" (described by the Labour opposition as a "freeze") on social service spending. The social services budget was almost £10m overspent and the county council's audit service board condemned the committee for setting unrealistic targets. Much of the publicity which followed the cutback focused on the decision to "sack" 16 care managers in east Kent. But the arguments which surrounded that decision - the need to support recently discharged hospital patients and the eventual redeployment of the redundant social workers - trivialised the fundamental issue. For at least a year, the county council had failed (the ruling Tory group would say was un able) to provide the social services which Kent needed.

Mr Bruce-Lockhart blames the problems on the government insisting on the improvement of provision without the Treasury increasing the support grant to meet the extra costs. "Bathrooms attached to bedrooms in care homes are", he says, "essential but expensive". Councillor Cheryl Hall, the leader of Kent's Labour minority, attributes the crisis to a combination of financial incompetence and doctrinal prejudice. She cites, as her example of the second failing, the decision to privatise 92 of Kent's 96 link services centres, or residential homes as they might be called in other counties. A consultation on their future produced a vast majority of the 30,000 people polled for continued public ownership. Two letters said sell. The council sold. It seemed an easy way to save money. Wages are lower in the private sector. Unfortunately for the council, they were not low enough to avoid a financial crisis.

Conflict

There are 18,000 residential care beds in Kent. Peter Gilroy, the county director of social services, speaks of them in the language of the market. One third are "bought" privately. An equal number is "purchased" by neighbouring local authorities. Kent county council "procures" the rest. That in itself puts the county council in a seller's market. Minimum wage legislation and the European Union's working time directive began to bite just as he was "reletting his contracts". As wages have risen, so have the cost of both beds and domiciliary care and Mr Gilroy complains that the Treasury's insistence on "best value" makes no allowances for the high wage levels of the south-east. His success is judged against 100 "performance indicators" - most of which, he says, are "not performance driven". That is to say the Treasury is interested in price not product. He is left to resolve the conflict between cost and quality.

That difficulty of reconciling savings and service is not exclusive to the provision of residential care. Many of the grants, which Kent receives, are "hypothecated" for spending on specific schemes. "The grant rules are highly prescriptive," says Mr Bruce-Lockhart. As a result, the council is denied the flexibility which would allow it to shuttle payments between projects and it loses "the capacity to innovate and develop improved ways of providing service".

The only way Kent could reduce its social services deficit was to change the "eligibility criteria" - some needy people received less, others nothing at all. The implication is that, left to itself, Kent would have done more and better. That is by no means certain. The Next Five Years contained assurances that Kent county council is "committed to assisting those who need our help". The government, in reply, will argue that public sector agreements are intended to transform the platitudes of local propaganda into real improvement in services.

For Kent, there is no real alternative to dancing at least to some of the government's tunes. Its future prosperity depends in great part on the completion of the high speed rail link between London and the Channel Tunnel. East and north Kent are nothing like as prosperous as the south of the county. The east Kent coalfield has closed. The navy's decision to abandon Chatham dockyard cost 20,000 jobs in a single day. All hopes are now built around the completion of the Thames gateway project which will, in the council's estimate, attract 50,000 jobs to Kent and justify the building of 30,000 houses at Ebbsfleet in what will then amount to a new town just outside Dartford.

Everybody wants phase two of the rail link to begin as promised in 2002 - a year before phase one is finished. In mid-January ministers renewed their assurance that it would start on time and that the council would be allowed to increase its contingent debt by borrowing part of the cost for whatever related infrastructure projects were needed.

Even co-operation in schemes which are essentially part of a national programme is likely to come accompanied by what Mr Bruce-Lockhart calls "strings". He lists five different types of restraint - "planning, guidance, regulation, inspection and prescribed bidding", the process by which councils compete to win government grants for special schemes.

Kent feels particularly oppressed by the need to take part in a whole series of planning exercises. The local transport plan "has to be completed in a high degree of detail, right down to the traffic calming scheme in Folkestone". The education asset management survey required officers to measure classrooms in pursuit of 560,000 separate pieces of information. That work cost the council £150,000 and took 20 hours to email to the Department for Education (DfEE). It is an exercise of that sort which the Kent council leader believes is "diminishing diversity in local government". But he cannot be surprised by the DfEE's desire to keep a watchful eye on Kent schools. Kent education is at the centre of a long-running controversy.

Arguments about the quality of Kent secondary schools are embittered by the failure of two attempts to end selective education in the county. During the coalition years, the Lib-Lab majority submitted a proposal for the introduction of comprehensive education. It was turned down by the Tory government. Then, when Labour won the 1997 election, campaigners took the promise to "let parents decide" at its face value - only to discover that the regulations governing the parental ballot were too heavily biased in favour of the status quo to make change possible.

A year ago, the Sunday Times published a table of what it called the top education authorities. It was based on the location of the 250 schools which achieved the best GCSE results. Kent headed the list with 32. Nick Henwood, the county's education officer, dismisses the claim to supremacy as "about as valid as comments about the number of schools in the bottom 250" - a category in which Kent also figures prominently. In 20% of Kent secondary schools, less than a quarter of the students achieve five or more A* to C GCSE passes. Mr Henwood describes the county average as "the best indicator I know". In 2000, a little more than 50% of the secondary students who were entered for the examination obtained five or more GCSEs at grade C or above. The national average was 49.2%. Almost 96% achieved at least one GCSE at Grade C or above. The national average was 94%. But comparisons of percentage passes are not a wholly reliable guide. They are influenced by the decision of some counties to enter everybody in the appropriate age group for the examination while others avoid future embarrassment by eliminating no-hopers. On the basis of Mr Henwood's chosen indicator, Kent's achievement is statistically just about adequate.

However, the county's critics claim Kent should do better. John Studley, head of Our Lady of Hartley, the top performing primary school in the county, says: "There are some good grammar schools in Kent. But with their staff and resources you would expect them to produce far better results than they achieve." In any case: "The problem is for the 75% of pupils who do not get a grammar school place. He is not alone in his concern. Although the number of "failing schools", subject to Ofsted "special measures", has fallen from 11 to seven, Kent tops the league in the calculation of second order failure. Last year, education minister Baroness Blackstone told the House of Lords that Kent had "the highest number of schools in the country with serious weaknesses". Her comment was based on the Ofsted report which revealed, in its general examination of the whole education authority, that "the number of schools which have serious weaknesses have risen from 12 to 33". Clearly, the DfEE still believes Kent has special problems. When a couple of months ago it distributed extra funds to improve "weaker schools", Kent received more than any other authority. It works out at almost £20 per pupil, almost twice as much as comparable counties.

Class divide

Professor David Jesson, of York University, has produced the one objective analysis of Kent's examination results. He concludes that "in comparison with similar schools" some Kent grammar schools are "quite strikingly underperforming". He adds that "Kent already has more than its fair share of failing schools". His judgment that "selective education systems fail to deliver the same levels of performance as those organised on comprehensive lines" will remain a matter of dispute within the county. But one thing is certain about the selective system as it works in Kent. It deepens the class divide. In some of the county's high schools (secondary modern in fact, if not in name) over 40% of the students qualify for free school meals. There is not one grammar school in which the free school meal entitlement totals 5%.

The Ofsted report - dealing with the allegation that "selection has adverse effects" on the county's education observes that "the inspection team cannot comment on the principle of selection which is the council's policy and beyond our remit". That conclusion - correct as a question of fact though it may be - implies that the council has the power to decide how its secondary schools are organised. In fact, that is no longer so. The pattern of secondary education is in theory decided by parents. In practice, it is determined by DfEE decisions to create specialist schools and to allow individual heads to introduce an element of selection into their entrance criteria. Kent remains selective because that is Whitehall's wish.

Robbed of their traditional powers, Kent councillors cast about to find ways in which they can pursue the diversity which is the essence of local government. Some of the policies which the Tory group hopes will emphasise the county's unique character will be regarded as idiosyncratic in other authorities.

Kent county council announced that, if clause 28 were repealed, it would devise its own method of preventing the dissemination of "homosexual propaganda" in schools, and it refused to take part in a pilot scheme to test the demand for "baby-naming" as an alternative to christening.

Council officials reported that the authority was ready and able to be one of the 12 pioneer authorities who tested the popularity of the secular ceremony. But the ruling Conservative group first said that costs were too high, then added that it was still uncertain if the Westminster government would contribute towards the additional expenditure and finally ex plained: "We feel the government is gradually nibbling away at all the institutions of our country and we are destroying some of them, which is sad." The "sense of purpose, sense of order and sense of community" in which Mr Bruce-Lockhart believes is built on traditional values.

There is no doubt that those values are shared by much of the county. And that ethos makes Kent an inhospitable refuge for the asylum seekers who land there. Mr Bruce-Lockhart puts the objectors' case in moderate terms. It was, he says, unfair that Kent should bear so much of the financial burden. Even now that the Home Office has agreed to meet the £50m that accommodating the refugees costs each year, the money will be refunded in arrears. So Kent council taxpayers will be have to pay the interest on the borrowed money. The essential reasonableness of his approach is emphasised by an expression of concern about juvenile asylum seekers who travel without adult companions. "Humanity requires them to be dealt with more quickly." But his compassion does not characterise the attitude for all his colleagues.

Councillor Keith Ferrin, Mr Bruce-Lockhart's deputy, expresses the county's concern rather differently. "By far the greatest number of asylum seekers in Kent are brought in by highly organised criminal gangs. It's also quite likely that there are a number of young women among them, being brought into Britain to act as sex slaves and prostitutes. Welcome to Tony Blair's Britain. It may not be everybody's idea of heaven but it is for another 200 asylum seekers in Kent alone every month." Mr Bruce-Lockhart says the Ferrin outburst resulted in "a great deal of straight talking" - by which, we must assume, he meant a dressing-down. But it is not the only subject on which Councillor Ferrin chooses to argue with his leaders.

Mr Bruce-Lockhart, sensitive to the suggestion that he leads a divided party, emphasises that he has only lost one vote in the "cabinet" which acts as Kent's executive authority. But there was clearly a great deal of private agonising over the decision to sign the public service agreements with the Whitehall government. And the creation of a "cabinet system" - as advocated in the local government white paper - was only formally endorsed after a strange procedure which suggests that arms had to be twisted, if not actually broken. Tory councillors who attacked the idea at the May council meeting voted to adopt it in July.

But Kent is not always at the leading edge. When the cabinet system was agreed, the council determined that it should meet in private.

Perhaps Mr Bruce-Lockhart believes that willing acquiescence to the "modernising agenda" is the price that the county council has to pay for its survival. When Kent's future was last examined, the local government commissioner initially favoured the creation of seven new "all purpose" authorities made up of amalgamated districts - Dartford and Gravesend in the north, the Medway Towns of Rochester, Chatham and Gillingham, and Folkestone with Dover on the coast. In the end only one new metropolitan district, the Medway Towns, was carved out of the county. Kent, and the Tory majority on its county council, were saved.

Satisfaction with how the council works and what is done is hard to measure. Four years ago local and national elections were held on the same day, producing a turnout in the council poll of over 70%. The council's own polls show no enthusiasm for the council itself but approval of much of what the council has achieved and is attempting.

The only sensible assumption is that in Kent, as in the rest of the country, most people hardly think about local government at all - until they are directly affected by one of its failures.

Kent facts & figures

 The population is 1,332,000

 Kent covers an area of 352,296 hectares

 It is the largest county council in the UK. It comprises 12 district councils and more than 300 town and parish councils

 Average weekly earnings are £418.90 for men and £317.10 for women.

 There are 365,000 owner-occupied homes and 134,200 rented homes

 73.3% of the population own a car or a van

 6 million tourists visit the county every year

 There are more than 4,200 miles of public footpaths, bridleways and byways - the largest networks in England

 There are 106 libraries plus 12 mobile libraries

 There are 623 schools and two universities
fields.bodyText: Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, the leader of Kent county council, prides himself on being a thinking politician. That is why - purely in the spirit of intellectual inquiry - he enlivened a meeting of the Local Government Association by asking Peter Mandelson how ministers could be either convincing or consistent if they were not guided by a coherent ideology. The former Northern Ireland secretary replied that he was not prepared to answer that, or any other question, from so prejudiced a source. But, despite feeling "bruised" by the rebuff, Mr Bruce-Lockhart remained a seeker after truth. When Hillary Armstrong, the minister for local government, visited the south-east of England regional assembly last July, he invited her to define "economic, social and environmental well-being" - the happy state which the white paper on local government requires councils to encourage. According to Mr Bruce-Lockhart's paraphrase, Ms Armstrong replied that the meaning of the phrase was "in the head of the beholder" - a view which he decided, after some careful thought, he shared. He has worked out how he wants it to be beheld in Kent. At a time when the old certainties - church, royalty, family - no longer hold society together, local government must engender "a sense of purpose, a sense of order, a sense of community and a sense of belonging". That aspiration is not in the down-to-earth tradition of local government. But Mr Bruce-Lockhart can provide a practical example of how his objective is being achieved. "There are already places around the United Kingdom where regeneration - city development - has brought a vitality, a vibrancy into town centres and created a sense of civic pride which is tangible." That - as Mr Bruce-Lockhart, "a great admirer of Albert Bore", gladly concedes - is an exact description of what the City of Birmingham, whose council Mr Bore leads, hopes it has achieved in its urban renewal initiative. When the Tory leader of England's largest county council endorses the municipal philosophy of the Labour leader in England's second city, the idea of "new local government" creating its own agenda for general "improvement" has to be taken seriously. But the pattern of change cannot be the same in town and country. Kent county council, in the new century as in the old, will have to share what power local government retains, with the 12 borough and district councils within its boundaries. Partnerships This year the Kent county council plans to spend £1,267m - basically in three areas. Education (together with libraries) will account for more than half, social services for more than a quarter and strategic planning (which includes the management of the roads programme) for something like 10%. The boroughs and districts - from Dover, through leafy Sevenoaks to the virtual London suburb of Dartford - provide the other local services. They also collect the 25% of the county council's income which is directly contributed by local citizens. The Treasury contributes twice as much. In Kent, local government politics as well as powers divide the councils. The county has been Conservative since the brief ruling Lib-Lab coalition was defeated in 1997. Three of the subsidiary district councils are still controlled by the Labour party. County local government works best when the "two tiers" operate in co-operation rather than competition - an objective which the Kent Association of Local Authorities was formed to promote. Real partnerships are most easily achieved when powers are shared in the hope of improving the efficiency of a service which is not the subject of political dispute. For years the district councils collected refuse and then handed it to the county for disposal. Now the whole operation is under the control of a joint board. The rationalisation will not be an issue in the county council election campaign. Nor will the "falls strategy" - an example of good practice which qualifies Kent for commendation by the Local Government Association in its survey of "partnerships" in healthcare. The Tunbridge Wells borough council and the county council are working together to reduce the accident rate among elderly people. It is a worthy but prosaic policy - exactly the sort of unpolitical activity with which councils are traditionally associated. Despite his enthusiasm for joint ventures, Mr Bruce-Lockhart remains a highly political figure, described by Trudy Dean, the Liberal leader, as "centralist, secretive and arrogant". He has caused his opponents constant irritation by blaming every problem on the Lib-Lab coalition which lost power four years ago. Principal amongthem is the council's huge debt. Since 1996 Kent council borrowing has risen to £610m - far more, as the auditors thought it necessary to point out, than the total in comparable counties. The debt has honourable origins. Much of it is largely the result of Kent channel rail link infrastructure programme - which the government "finances" by agreeing to the council increasing its borrowing. But Mr Bruce-Lockhart persists in blaming the deficit on his predecessors - even though it has increased under his administration and although in opposition he did not vote against one of the loan applications. Sometimes even the most rational local government leaders have to contrive disputes to meet the wishes of less pragmatic political activists who support them. Not all Kent Tories are old-fashioned country gentlemen. Mr Bruce-Lockhart undoubtedly believes that a fundamental ideological divide separates the Labour and Conservative visions of local government. Although the two parties share "an absolutely sincere desire to improve the quality of life", Labour "thinks it is best achieved by more external controls". The Tories "want to give more responsibility to the people who are actually doing the job". Yet, despite his deep conviction that "the need is for more independence", and the open hostility of some of his Conservative colleagues, he has committed the county to signing a public service agreement (PSA) with the Whitehall government. Indeed, Kent has become one of the "pilot authorities" which are pioneering an idea which is a benign extension of ministerial interference in local affairs. Mr Bruce-Lockhart rejects the allegation of inconsistency by describing PSAs as a compromise between centralism and independence. "We are setting our own targets, but the government is encouraging us to stretch them and making it possible for us to meet them." Even the officials who advise the council had their doubts about the voluntary surrender of yet more autonomy. A briefing note - appended to a paper which recommended participation in the first wave of PSAs - concluded that "counties have to decide whether the benefits of leading the pack" outweigh the risks of "supping with the devil". Mr Bruce-Lockhart decided that the PSA had benefits for Kent, and material improvement was more important than either party antagonism or political dogma. The decision to lead the pack was taken after the discovery that the devil shared many of Kent county council's aims. The Next Five Years, Kent's 1998 "strategic statement" (which contained more substance than its glossy format suggests), and Opportunities for Kent - The Vision (drawn up two years later at greater length but with less precision) set out targets for improvement. At least by impli cation it advocated "joined-up government", the jargon for the local and national co-operation which Whitehall believes is essential to improved efficiency and delivery of local authority services. Some of Kent's independent promises were too imprecise to make them part of any scheme which requires the achievement of statistically defined goals. The Next Five Years aimed "to support as many elderly people as possible to remain in their own homes" and Opportunities for Kent aspired to "reduce the number of children in care". The county's draft proposal for a public service agreement - submitted last September as the basis for partnership with Whitehall - put numerical flesh on the skeleton of earlier aspirations. The social services budget was almost £10m overspent and the county council's audit service board condemned the committee for setting unrealistic targets. "Bathrooms attached to bedrooms in care homes are", he says, "essential but expensive". Councillor Cheryl Hall, the leader of Kent's Labour minority, attributes the crisis to a combination of financial incompetence and doctrinal prejudice. She cites, as her example of the second failing, the decision to privatise 92 of Kent's 96 link services centres, or residential homes as they might be called in other counties. A consultation on their future produced a vast majority of the 30,000 people polled for continued public ownership. Two letters said sell. The council sold. It seemed an easy way to save money. Wages are lower in the private sector. Unfortunately for the council, they were not low enough to avoid a financial crisis. Conflict There are 18,000 residential care beds in Kent. Minimum wage legislation and the European Union's working time directive began to bite just as he was "reletting his contracts". All hopes are now built around the completion of the Thames gateway project which will, in the council's estimate, attract 50,000 jobs to Kent and justify the building of 30,000 houses at Ebbsfleet in what will then amount to a new town just outside Dartford. Kent feels particularly oppressed by the need to take part in a whole series of planning exercises. The local transport plan "has to be completed in a high degree of detail, right down to the traffic calming scheme in Folkestone". A year ago, the Sunday Times published a table of what it called the top education authorities. It was based on the location of the 250 schools which achieved the best GCSE results. webTitle: Leader: Powers to make peers misused

fields.headline: A sunset home for MPs
fields.standfirst:
The power to make peers is being misused

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour's high command  hopes, it seems, to air-drop their best and brightest into seats rendered suddenly vacant just in time for the election.
fields.body:
Like the best world war two generals, Labour's high command is drawing up secret plans involving that most reliable of battle aids: the parachute. They hope, it seems, to air-drop their best and brightest into seats rendered suddenly vacant just in time for the election. Under Labour rules, an imminent polling day enables them to present local parties with shortlists of one. That way they can find a home for the likes of Tory defector Shaun Woodward - the sort of would-be MP not many constituency Labour parties would choose on their own.

Usually the outrage at such a manouevre concentrates on the imposition of candidates. Witness Newport East in 1997, where the last-minute resignation of Roy Hughes made way for former Tory minister Alan Howarth. But our outrage points in a different direction: less at the way the new man is chosen, than at how the old one is got rid of.

For Mr Hughes admitted yesterday that his decision to leave the Commons was not born solely of a desire to spend more time with the proverbial family. Rather he asked for, and received, a promise from Tony Blair of a peerage: today he is Lord Islwyn. Now Barry Jones MP has told a similar story, letting slip that he, too, has discussed retirement with the PM.

Now this is a shoddy business. No one wants to be too harsh, but Labour's insistence that Roy Hughes won his ermine solely on the strength of his contribution to British civic life will not wash. On the contrary, this is one more proof that today's Lords appointments system - even if less blatantly in the personal gift of Number 10 - is essentially an invitation for abuse. All too often, membership of our upper house comes either to those who make a big bucks donation to the political parties or those whose exit from the Commons comes in handy. The sooner we sweep away this rotten system of patronage and replace it with election the better.

fields.headline: Farmyard blues
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A year ago Tony Blair gave grumbling farmers an emergency £2m package, the third big one in two years, taking additional agricultural aid under Labour to£635m. But he insisted that generous help must be matched by willingness to restructure that last great bastion of subsidy.
fields.body:
A year ago Tony Blair gave grumbling farmers an emergency £2m package, the third big one in two years, taking additional agricultural aid under Labour to£635m. But he insisted that generous help must be matched by willingness to restructure that last great bastion of subsidy.

Slowly, farming is indeed restructuring. Britain is taking the lead in switching spending from food production - frequently, overproduction - which consumes half the EU budget, to supporting the broader rural economy.

This is becoming far more important to the countryside than agriculture - although the hysterical overreaction to the foot and mouth outbreak makes you wonder where priorities lie in Whitehall when panic sets in. Tourism, which stands to lose£250m a week, is on its knees. The Youth Hostels Association, that pillar of budget travel for the young and cash-strapped, is facing its biggest crisis. Small businesses are approaching bankruptcy.

The localised impact of foot and mouth - a personal tragedy for farmers involved - should not be underestimated. But our view of farming is often locked in a romantic time-warp of Clydesdales leisurely pulling a plough, smiling shepherds coaxing herds of sheep along narrow lanes, cows grazing contentedly in the pasture and milk churns (long since disappeared) awaiting collection at the farm gate.

When the story of this latest crisis is finally told, the reality might dawn that some livestock, particularly pigs fed on swill from questionable sources, might have been kept in conditions (how can we put it?) far from ideal. The agencies supposed to monitor animal welfare, their ranks currently depleted, might have some explaining to do. But in the wider context, this disease outbreak is certain to stimulate a serious debate about the kind of farming we want on the countryside we apparently hold so dear.

Labour has been plagued by protesting farmers who seemed strangely absent during the final years of the last administration. On the back of the clash over hunting, this government has been blamed for so many rural ills that you would think no farms went bankrupt, village schools, bus services or post offices closed - and, most importantly, no council houses were given away at rock bottom prices in areas desperately short of low cost homes - under John Major or Margaret Thatcher.

In truth the rapid growth of out of town superstores in the 80s and 90s, courtesy of a free-market planning regime, did more to damage country high streets and undermine village shops than any high-handed action by Tony Blair.

Farmers, sure, have had a rough time with collapsing incomes on the back of the BSE crisis, the big supermarket chains squeezing margins, and now foot and mouth. What the industry rarely tells you, however, is that this recession followed the bonanza years of the mid-90s when takings were at a near-record high, ranking alongside the early 70s when Britain joined the then Common Market and an over-generous subsidy regime kicked in. From this high, the much-quoted 70% fall in farming incomes since the mid-90s (the reason for Tony Blair's largesse a year ago) seems less severe.

Most analysts seem to agree that agriculture's overwhelming problem has not been the BSE crisis (largely paid for by the taxpayer), or greedy superstores, but the strength of the pound against the euro which has undermined exports and - more importantly - effectively reduced the EU subsidy, which is set in euros; when the pound was weak in the early to mid-90s, these subsidies - and consequently farming incomes - soared.

None of this, of course, helps farming out of its present plight; since the mid-90s alone, about 20,000 farmers have left the land, bringing their numbers to about 353,000. We can be sure that, in the next year or so, many more will disappear - to do what?

Well, maybe diversify, with more cash from a much despised common agricultural policy being diverted into the wider rural economy - and the real world. Fifteen months' ago, the Cabinet Office produced a lengthy report urging the government to get real and sweep away a price support framework developed after the last war which had little relevance to the new century.

After the present turmoil, a radical government might finally address that last bastion of statism which has somehow remained aloof from the realities of the market place. By then, however, a lot more government cash will have flowed from Whitehall to bail out the victims of this latest crisis.

webTitle: Sketch: Byers in the torture chamber with no torturers

fields.headline: Byers in the torture chamber with no torturers
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: Trade and industry questions in the Commons. We crammed into the gallery to watch the Tories savage the trade secretary, Stephen Byers.
fields.body:
Trade and industry questions in the Commons. We crammed into the gallery to watch the Tories savage the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, over allegations that he helped cover up payments Robert Maxwell had made to the former minister Geoffrey Robinson - payments which Mr Robinson had denied.

We were expected to witness a slaughter. The Tories would cut down Mr Byers like a platoon of paratroopers despatching a diseased pig. And they had a whole hour to do it in. No wonder Mr Byers looked nervous; it was no surprise that his team of four press officers had an anxious mien as the session began.

On the whole, politicians love to see another politician having a hard time, especially a politician on their own side. So most of them were looking forward to this hopelessly one-sided fight. As a journalist I am of more kindly disposition, and I felt a slight frisson of sympathy for Mr Byers. Nobody should suffer the planned torment for an entire hour.

Things got off to a slow start. Peter Hain was asked about wind turbines on "environmentally sensitive sites" which is what we used to call beauty spots before the new jargonmeisters got to work.

Tories accused the government of missing their targets on turbines, and someone yelled that they were all "puff and wind". No one said anything about Mr Byers.

Soon the trade and industry secretary was himself in action. Someone asked about the Springfield nuclear power station. I thought this was where Homer works in The Simpsons. Apparently there's one in England too. Mr Byers answered boldly. "It can be a vibrant manufacturing facility, employing many people," he said. Or, I thought, an indoor craft fair, or a Bart Simpson theme restaurant, which is what vibrant manufacturing facilities usually become.

No one mentioned Geoffrey Robinson. Of course, his name wasn't on the order paper. But that shouldn't stop the top Tory troublemakers. What was the matter with them? Were they asleep?

The answer might be supplied by David Heathcoat-Amory, who is Mr Byers's shadow. Mr Heathcoat-Amory is a toff. I see him as the younger son of Sir Josiah Heathcoat-Amory, who built up the family's fortunes from nowt and the family's name from Josh Heath.

Slightly vague, somewhat other worldly, the young mester has only a passing interest in manufacturing or trade and would rather be at home translating the later work of Herodotus. He had nothing to say about Mr Byers's involvement in the affairs of Geoffrey Robinson. I suspect he would not have thought it a gentlemanly thing to inquire about.

Patricia Hewitt, a junior minister, talked about "business incubation programmes" and "establishing a seed corn fund". You'd think they'd avoid farming metaphors, but the point of Labour jargon is that people who use it don't actually listen to themselves saying it.

We touched on compensation for diseased miners, on post office closures and the impact of the minimum wage on Cleethorpes. Still the Tories couldn't find anything to throw at Mr Byers, now at the centre of what may turn out to be the greatest scandal of the present government. Suddenly it was 12.30. "Order, order!" said the Speaker, and the minister was out of the door as fast as a rat fleeing the Dyno-rod.

Peter Lilley raised the subject later in business questions. But that doesn't count. Mr Byers wasn't there. The Tories are pathetic; like members of a humiliatingly defeated football team they think they can score afterwards by kicking the ball into the net, long after the goalie has departed.

fields.headline: Bullying bosses
fields.standfirst:
Employee rights are a vote winner for Labour. Let the Tories hang themselves with 'red tape' hysteria

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Employee rights are a vote winner for Labour. Let the Tories hang themselves with 'red tape' hysteria.
fields.body:
Red tape! Bureaucracy throttling industry! Thousands of regulations and taxes burden British industry! The leaders of business organisations are coming together in a joint assault on the government before the election: the CBI and Institute of Directors are joining the Chambers of Commerce annual conference next week, addressed by William Hague. These are threatening battalions, as frightening to the government as the unions once were - and every bit as over-mighty in their pretensions to power. If Labour once cowered before union barons, now they blench when business bellows.

Yesterday the Institute for Public Policy Research published some damning research, commissioned by the employment department, showing how low-paid workers are being denied new rights the government has introduced. Many are forced to sign a "voluntary" waiver from the 48-hour maximum working time law as a condition of employment. Britain was the only country to insist on a loophole making the 48-hour rule voluntary: the idea was that high-powered people should work as long as they liked. But as many predicted at the time, the reality is that the low-paid are now forced to work the longest hours in Europe. The survey found serious violations of new rights to sick pay and holidays: some knew their rights but dared not demand them. It proved beyond doubt the need for an enforcement agency which workers can call in when their rights were denied.

The IPPR - the think tank created within New Labour - has been laying out a far more radical agenda than the government currently looks inclined to adopt. But Labour should be considering it carefully - in particular, their ideas on work. Here is fertile territory for a profound policy difference with the Tories. Hague and Portillo may promise to match all Labour's spending plans, but they carve their own niche in cutting red tape and regulation. Here is a chance for Labour to take the "red tape" and wrap it round the Tories' necks. (It is unfortunate that Labour has so often itself played the "red tape" card in Europe, trying to woo the business lobby by resisting quite reasonable EU proposals.)

The CBI's "red tape challenge" and the Chambers of Commerce "burdens barometer" campaigns all follow identical themes. The CBI claim £12.3bn extra is paid out by industry for Labour's new employment rights. (This turns out to be notional, and not an annual sum but an arbitrary three years' worth rolled up together). They list billions they say the working time regulations cost - that is the 48-hour week, and four weeks' holiday for the first time given as a right to every worker, with pro-rata holiday rights for every part-timer too. They add in the minimum wage and other "burdens" to create a portrait of a country weighed down by socialism.

There is no truth in any of this. The OECD - conservative economists - finds Britain has the least market regulation, the lowest corporation tax (lower than any time in its history), and the lowest employment costs - not just lower than the rest of Europe - but, when everything is added in (including US employers' health insurance), lower than the US too. Social insurance and labour taxes average 24% in Europe, 21% in the US and only 13% in Britain.

And it feels like it in this under-taxed and over-worked island. Yesterday's Warwick University research showed how British workers' stress levels had risen and job satisfaction plummeted in the last decade. The IPPR's focus groups found a weary acceptance of bad working conditions among middle and lower-level workers, little expectation of anything much better. Adair Turner, previous head of the CBI, writing in the Financial Times this week, praises a high productivity and success in European countries unaffected by their high taxes and tough employment regulation. "The Dutch economy has performed better than the US over the past 10 years in spite of regulatory and tax burdens that are anathema to a simplistic ultra-liberal creed." Britons, he finds, work 25% hours longer than workers in Europe and the US.

So in the manifesto the government should rebut all this "red tape" talk. The bosses' red tape is most people's decent pay and conditions. It is time for a great leap forward in the way Labour talks about work and people's aspirations. Employment minister Tessa Jowell was (without firm commitments) reaching out in that direction in a speech to the IPPR yesterday. "Quality of work and equality of opportunity are the important challenges for the next stage. Quality of work is about employees - whatever their income - achieving four key factors: a feeling they are in control, employment rights, training and development and work-life balance." Better work, better conditions and an upward ladder for all, not just any old job, but a better job. Will employers be forced to deliver evidence of equal pay and non-age discrimination policies? John Monks at the TUC waits to see if Britain will fight in the EU against a right for employees to be consulted before mergers and closures affecting their lives. The IPPR points out that Gordon Brown's full employment is unachievable without something he has always refused - job-creation in the worst areas - gardeners, caretakers, bus-conductors - doing useful work that improves neighbourhoods.

Hard tests lie ahead. There is a fierce battle going on for the right for new mothers to return to work as part-timers. If even this minimal demand is thrown out, then Labour will have missed a chance to enthuse voters with a new political agenda.

The big idea is to reconnect politics with what really matters in people's lives - quality of life, happiness, family, freedom and control over their time. Ask people what matters most to their lives, and often it is the chance to take half a day off work for something special, control over their time without feeling chained to a desk or bench. It might be the right to start work later or leave work earlier. It might be a right for all to work part-time if they wanted to train for a better job, spend more time with children, or pursue some richer aspect of their lives. This would be subject to feasibility - but the onus would be on the employer to prove why it couldn't be done. It is quite remarkable how resistant virtually all employers are to job-sharing, even though research shows that two part-timers work harder and better. Many employees could not afford to work less, but knowing they could vary the pace of their work would give them a new control over their lives. In this time of plenty, giving people back their time is easily affordable. Tory red tape is Labour freedom.

fields.headline: MPs back secret Speaker ballot
fields.trailText: Veteran leftwinger Tony Benn won half of probably his final parliamentary battle last night when MPs voted to reform the way the Speaker of the Commons is elected. But he lost his last argument too, when MPs approved the introduction of a secret ballot by the narrow margin of two votes.
fields.body:
Veteran leftwinger Tony Benn won half of probably his final parliamentary battle last night when MPs voted to reform the way the Speaker of the Commons is elected. But he lost his last argument too, when MPs approved the introduction of a secret ballot by the narrow margin of two votes.

The current procedure - in use for hundreds of years - led to what were widely condemned as shambolic proceedings when it took seven hours for MPs to elect Michael Martin to replace Betty Boothroyd last October. Mr Benn, Labour MP for Chesterfield, led the attack on the system which provoked an all-party inquiry and the recommended changes, including a secret ballot, which were approved yesterday.

Under the new system, candidates will need the support of 12 candidates - three from other parties - to avoid the charge of party prejudice. The successful candidate will have to get more than half the vote: if that does not happen on the first ballot, the procedure will be repeated the next day.

The idea of a secret ballot - a breach of the tradition of open, recorded votes - was introduced in an attempt to ensure the Speaker's independence. Both government and opposition whips notoriously try to fix the election. It will also mean that the Speaker will not know who did not support them.

The Speaker is regarded as guarantor of the rights of backbench MPs. Betty Boothroyd let it be known that she resigned from the job early to make sure her successor was elected by MPs with some experience of the Commons rather than potentially more impressionable members of a post-election house. Mr Benn, who has spent years in opposition establishing himself as the champion of parliament against the executive, chose yesterday's debate on the changes to make what will almost certainly be his last speech before he retires at the forthcoming election.

"The role of the Speaker today is that you are protecting us from the triple powers of Buckingham Palace, Millbank Tower and Central Office which in combination represent a serious challenge to our role," he said, taking a final swipe at the party headquarters he sees as a serious threat to democracy. He praised the independence of Mr Martin, but criticised the introduction of a secret ballot which undermined the notion of representation.

"If you vote as yourself it must be secret," he said. "But when we vote in a representative capacity people must know what we've done."

In an unprecedented move, Mr Benn and Sir Edward Heath, the former Conservative prime minister who is also retiring and who like Mr Benn will not go to the Lords, have been granted the "freedom of the house", allowing them to continue to use Commons facilities.

But he lost his last argument too, when MPs approved the introduction of a secret ballot by the narrow margin of two votes. The current procedure - in use for hundreds of years - led to what were widely condemned as shambolic proceedings when it took seven hours for MPs to elect Michael Martin to replace Betty Boothroyd last October. Mr Benn, Labour MP for Chesterfield, led the attack on the system which provoked an all-party inquiry and the recommended changes, including a secret ballot, which were approved yesterday. Under the new system, candidates will need the support of 12 candidates - three from other parties - to avoid the charge of party prejudice. The successful candidate will have to get more than half the vote: if that does not happen on the first ballot, the procedure will be repeated the next day. The idea of a secret ballot - a breach of the tradition of open, recorded votes - was introduced in an attempt to ensure the Speaker's independence. Both government and opposition whips notoriously try to fix the election. It will also mean that the Speaker will not know who did not support them. The Speaker is regarded as guarantor of the rights of backbench MPs. Betty Boothroyd let it be known that she resigned from the job early to make sure her successor was elected by MPs with some experience of the Commons rather than potentially more impressionable members of a post-election house. Mr Benn, who has spent years in opposition establishing himself as the champion of parliament against the executive, chose yesterday's debate on the changes to make what will almost certainly be his last speech before he retires at the forthcoming election. "The role of the Speaker today is that you are protecting us from the triple powers of Buckingham Palace, Millbank Tower and Central Office which in combination represent a serious challenge to our role," he said, taking a final swipe at the party headquarters he sees as a serious threat to democracy. He praised the independence of Mr Martin, but criticised the introduction of a secret ballot which undermined the notion of representation. "If you vote as yourself it must be secret," he said. "But when we vote in a representative capacity people must know what we've done." In an unprecedented move, Mr Benn and Sir Edward Heath, the former Conservative prime minister who is also retiring and who like Mr Benn will not go to the Lords, have been granted the "freedom of the house", allowing them to continue to use Commons facilities.

webTitle: Labour veteran admits offering seat for peerage

fields.headline: Labour veteran admits offering seat for peerage
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: A Labour lord yesterday denied that he had been bribed with a peerage to allow a Blairite candidate to be "parachuted" into his safe Welsh seat, and claimed instead that he had volunteered to go to the Lords without being asked.
fields.body:
A Labour lord yesterday denied that he had been bribed with a peerage to allow a Blairite candidate to be "parachuted" into his safe Welsh seat, and claimed instead that he had volunteered to go to the Lords without being asked.

As would-be Labour MPs looked towards tonight's selection battle in another Welsh seat - Alyn and Deeside, where the retiring MP may also get a peerage - Lord Islwyn, formerly Roy Hughes MP, startled colleagues by admitting his role on Radio 4.

It was his Newport East seat that Alan Howarth - the formerly Thatcherite minister now a Labour culture minister - won at the last minute in 1997 after defecting to the Blair camp in the fading years of Tory rule.

At the time Welsh Labour MPs assumed that party HQ in Millbank had made overtures to Ray Powell, MP for Ogmore, and Allan Rodgers, MP for Rhondda, that had been rejected, only to find another Welsh veteran, Mr Hughes, willing to accept a seat-for-peerage offer.

Yesterday Lord Islwyn told the BBC's Today programme a different story. "I was re-selected. And then I thought, 'well I wonder'. "So I put out a feeler, anyway, to go to the Lords, you see. And there was a very quick response that Tony Blair will definitely send you to the Lords, so the result of course was that Alan Howarth was selected."

The issue is still controversial because MPs believe that Downing Street would like to reward the high-profile Tory defector, Shaun Woodward, with a seat if they can find him one. The Ogmore seat held by 72-year-old Sir Ray Powell, who has been narrowly reselected but is ailing, is a prime option. There are also persistent rumours that Ed Balls, Gordon Brown's chief economics adviser, has his eye on the safe seat of Normanton.

There are 20 to 30 Labour candidacies still to fill. The battle to succeed Barry Jones in Alyn and Deeside sees the former Millbank membership official, Nick Smith, competing against Margaret Hanson who is the wife of neighbouring Delyn MP, David Hanson, and AEEU official, Mark Tami.

webTitle: Rail plans crippled by cash crisis

fields.headline: Rail plans crippled by cash crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The prime minister was last night facing a new crisis after a sombre warning that rail expansion is in jeopardy because Railtrack is rapidly soaking up £15bn of public money to repair Britain's ailing system.
fields.body:
The prime minister was last night facing a new crisis after a sombre warning that rail expansion is in jeopardy because Railtrack is rapidly soaking up £15bn of public money to repair Britain's ailing system.

Government sources revealed that Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the strategic rail authority, has warned his colleagues that he has precious little money to back new schemes, and that the Treasury is refusing to give him any more.

Mr Blair is preparing to make an important statement on the future of the rail industry before calling a general election, but has been concentrating on the foot and mouth epidemic.

Whitehall sources said yesterday that Sir Alastair is insisting that the issue must be resolved by next week. They take this to mean that he is saying the government must agree to put more money into an industry which has grown by more than 30% since privatisation.

The government faces a political dilemma. It does not want to face a potentially damaging row with the SRA or with Sir Alastair, who is already angry at government suggestions that his position is not secure. It was suggested that he may be using this threat to hasten his exit.

Three big schemes are "under the hammer", according to the SRA.

The modernisation of the east coast main line between Scotland and London is in jeopardy, it says, as is the Thameslink project in London to improve the capital's north-south links.

The third scheme at risk is the second stage of the Channel Tunnel rail link between the M25 and central London, on which work is due to start in three years at a cost of more than £2bn.

Railtrack should be funding a considerable part of these projects, backed by private investment.

But Sir Alastair is concerned that it will abandon them, leaving the problem with the SRA, because of money soaked up over the next five years on repairs.

Sir Alastair is angry that the SRA is having to underpin Railtrack's special safety company set up as a result of the Paddington rail crash. He has told the SRA board that Railtrack should be funding the project.

Railtrack is still trying to rehabilitate the network in the wake of the Hatfield rail crash last October, but its dates for completion keep changing. It has already budgeted for more than £650m in repairs, but has asked the SRA for up to £1.5bn more on account from the £15bn promised by the chancellor.

The SRA has lost its first member in frustration at government policy. Lord Bradshaw, a former general manager of British Rail's western region, is to quit the SRA in June.

He says he is no longer willing to be contacted by senior civil servants who were "almost paranoid" about anything which seemed to deviate from the official view.

Lord Bradshaw says Railtrack is "holed below the waterline", and that ministers share his views. He is angry that the rail regulator can take cash from the SRA for strategic purposes and give it to Railtrack.

Another SRA member said: "It is quite wrong that we should be bailing out Railtrack. Our budget is being attacked and we can do nothing about it. Railtrack appears to be throwing money away trying to restore the railway without any proper control over its expenditure. That and the Treasury's tight squeeze on what we can do is making our job impossible."

The SRA refused to comment last night.The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, yesterday expressed "serious concerns" about Railtrack's processes in getting new rolling stock on track.

More than 100 new trains are idle, either because of reliability problems or because they have not been approved. Mr Winsor is insisting on an accelerated process to get the trains into operation. Some rolling stock ordered three years ago is still not fully working.

Railtrack said the industry had 236 trains on order with 125 delivered. But only 40 had entered service.

It said it agreed with Mr Winsor that strict safety checks needed to be carried out to ensure that new trains did not clip any other as they passed.

webTitle: Will the European economy keep going?

fields.headline: Euroland logs on
fields.standfirst:
As they meet in Stockholm, Europe's policymakers will be asking whether they can keep the continent's economy going despite America's woes

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: the European parliament
fields.trailText: As they meet in Stockholm, Europe's policymakers will be asking whether they can keep the continent's economy going despite America's woes
fields.body:
Stockholm is a good place to hold a European summit at a time of growing anxiety about economic prospects this side of the Atlantic. Look at what the chart says about Sweden's investment in information technology. Guardian Online yesterday put Sweden top of the world "information society" league table, which shows the US in fourth place and the UK sixth. If - and it is a bigger if after the dot.com collapse and profits warnings from such companies as Ericsson - a stake in the new economy helps growth prospects, Scandinavia has a lot to offer as the European Union's conference venue when how to keep expansion going is topic of the day.

In an ideal world, the script would be symmetrical. As the Americans taste recession, the European loco rounds the bend, pulling global growth in its van. It is a bit like that. Last year was good. Across the eurozone 2.5m jobs were created and aggregate growth was 3.4%. This year even the pessimists (UBS Warburg is saying 2.5%) accept growth will be at the EU long-run trend rate; optimists say 2.8%, to be compared with a forecast for the US of 1.7%. True, industrial production fell away during the winter but is still 5% up on this time last year.

Looked at through one end of the telescope the weakness of the euro in recent days is a sign of financial markets' lack of confidence in European economic leadership; through the other it means eurozone exports stay that much cheaper. American downturn may pinch Germany, where exports of goods to the North American Free Trade Area were worth about $4.5bn two years ago, but will have much less impact on France and Italy. (Despite all the hooha about transatlantic ties, the UK is less exposed than Germany.) That said, Europe's top 300 companies derive 21% of their sales from the Americas and biggies such as Philips are now joining Ericsson on the corporate casualty ward.

If the game is fending off a premature recession a major player is Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank. His critics, who these days outnumber his supporters by a large margin, say he should have been sent off already. Eurozone interest rates would have had to be cut last year if this week's sharp fall in German business confidence were to have been prevented. The ECB's permanent problem is marrying the monetary needs of Germany - for which recent signs of decline in money supply are bad news - with those of France, Spain and the Netherlands where expansion is still on course. Those three account for 36% of euroland's GDP compared with Germany's 32%. Meanwhile Finland, Greece and the Irish Republic are growing by 4% to 8%. How far the bank should bother with minnows which could benefit from monetary tightening is another question to darken the Frankfurt skies. A rate cut of 0.25% off the main ECB rate of 4.75% is being tipped for the bank's April meeting. If it moves when it meets at the end of next week, Mr Duisenberg's recent assurances that euroland would be largely immune from American recession would look hollow and his credibility further diminish.

The other people who hold Europe's economic future in their hands are the policy makers now assembled in Stockholm. In Lisbon a year ago Tony Blair, aided by his pal Jose-Maria Aznar of Spain (a friendship that stops at Gibraltar, however) set out a neo-liberal vision for making the EU "the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the world by 2010". Europe would prosper if government got off people's backs, labour and capital markets freed and a concerted move made towards the IT-based new economy. The Centre for European Reform has just published its (Britocentric) score card on what has happened since.* The European commission gets good marks for pushing the agenda - Romano Prodi's enthusiasm absolves Mr Blair from the charge that is all an Anglo-American plot. Germany has liberalised telecoms and plugged away at research. (The Germans invented the MP3 music transfer technology but though they spend longest online in hours per week of all the EU countries and have an impressive ISDN network, by general consent they lack techno-zest.)

But the Germans have joined with the French to block de-regulation of energy and France has, by this account, stuck in the statist mud. Never mind that the French taxpayer subsidises UK electricity consumption...

Lionel Jospin notes that the Lisbon protocol also mentioned "social cohesion". He would not have to search too hard (power cuts in California, British Telecom's crisis) to find examples of the shortcomings of deregulation and private enterprise, either. Economic theory as under stood by Mr Blair has no room for the German sense that banking arrangements are part of an integrated national culture - Germany has been standing out against the recommendations of the Lamfalussy committee in favour of lighter and Europe-wide financial services regulation.

If the EU agreed a new liberalisation package in Stockholm that would not of itself impede what has started to look like euroland's inevitable slide down the growth curve. Which leaves Labour with a political problem, in addition to the grief it would experience if the UK economy lost track. Joining the blossoming eurozone while the Americans were in the doldrums would be a lot easier than major currency adjustment at a time of gloom all round.

*Edward Bannerman, The Lisbon Scorecard, www.cer.org.uk

webTitle: Anger at Byers warning to book shops

fields.headline: Anger at Byers warning to book shops
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, was yesterday accused of "intimidatory tactics" and "suppressing freedom of speech" by warning bookshops not to stock Tom Bower's controversial book on the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, was yesterday accused of "intimidatory tactics" and "suppressing freedom of speech" by warning bookshops not to stock Tom Bower's controversial book on the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.

Ian Chapman, managing director of the book's publishers, Simon & Schuster, criticised the action by Mr Byers' solicitors in sending warning letters to distributors.

"I think it is quite an unusual step for a member of the government which has incorporated the freedom of speech provisions of the European convention on human rights into English law."

His warning came after one book chain, WH Smith, decided not to stock the book, The Paymaster, for fears of an injunction or writ from the government. Waterstones initially said it would not be selling the book, but then announced that it had changed its mind and would now be selling the volume.

The book claims that Mr Robinson misled MPs over his financial connections with crooked tycoon Robert Maxwell. The spectre of legal action hangs over the volume, and solicitors acting for Mr Byers have sent warning letters to distributors.

Mr Byers is furious about allegations that he "covered up" the findings of a secret DTI inquiry into Mr Robinson's former and now bankrupt company, Hollis Industries.

A WH Smith spokeswoman said yesterday: "We have decided to take it off the shelves while we seek further legal advice. It is a temporary measure." But a spokeswoman for Waterstones said it was now satisfied sales could go ahead.

Mr Chapman told BBC Radio 4's World at One that his company was standing by the author's claims and had no intention of climbing down.

"The Daily Mail and ourselves are standing as one. We utterly stand by the contents of the book and by our author.

"There is no question that this book will not be published or distributed today ... and we will defend any action against us vigorously."

Under Treasury rules Mr Byers will have to notify parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, if he decides to issue writs against booksellers or sues the Daily Mail.

fields.headline: Fury over cardinal's voting advice
fields.standfirst:
Electorate told to question candidates on abortion stance

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Electorate told to question candidates on abortion stance
fields.body:
Leaders of the Roman Catholic church provoked a storm of protest yesterday when they called on voters to consider withholding support from candidates in the general election who support a woman's right to have an abortion.

Women's sexual health groups reacted furiously after Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the church in England and Wales, said voting against pro-abortion candidates was for the "common good" of the nation.

At the launch of a document entitled Vote for the Common Good, the cardinal said abortion should be top of the list of questions a constituent should ask. "Clearly, what we would be saying to people is that a candidate's attitude on abortion should have quite considerable sway, but it shouldn't be the only matter. We've made the importance of human life clear, and we would feel quite strongly about it."

A spokesman for the Brook Clinic, which provides free sexual advice for young young people, said it was a "sad day" if people were being told how to vote. "We would consider that to be a backward and disappointing step. We don't want to see a return to the days of back street abortions."

A spokeswoman for Marie Stopes International, which performs abortions and provides sexual health advice, said: "We strongly believe in women's right to choose. Women should be able to do what's best for them."

The Conservatives, who have tried to turn abortion into a political issue, welcomed the cardinal's remarks. David Lidington, home affairs spokesman, said the issue was a matter for each MP's conscience, but added: "Moral questions can never be divorced from politics, and the bishops are to be congratulated for their strong support for marriage and the traditional family."

Liam Fox, shadow health secretary, was roundly criticised this year when he called on Tories to "pray [for] a huge restriction, if not abolition, of our pro-abortion laws".

The Catholic church's 16-page document, to be circulated to its churches in England and Wales this month, also calls on voters to question candidates about euthanasia and embryo research. The church has led the protests against the decision by MPs and peers to allow scientists to harvest "stem" cells from early-stage embryos for research.

The document says: "Most recently a moral chasm has been opened by parliament's decision to permit the creation and destruction of cloned human embryos. It is possible that in the next parliament attempts may be made to legalise euthanasia. To do so would be both wrong and dangerous. Whatever the motive, euthanasia amounts to murder. The candidate's view on these and other issues should be considered before voting."

Robin Lovell-Badge, head of developmental genetics at the National Institute for Medical Research, said he could not understand why the church had decided to speak out on embryo research after parliament had spoken. "The number of people affected by diseases such as Parkinson's runs into millions, and they would be appalled if there was yet another attempt to derail a sensible decision," he said.

"There has been so much debate on this, and the majority of people in this country seem to favour research. Why don't [those opposed to it] believe in democracy?"

David Lidington, home affairs spokesman, said the issue was a matter for each MP's conscience, but added: "Moral questions can never be divorced from politics, and the bishops are to be congratulated for their strong support for marriage and the traditional family." Liam Fox, shadow health secretary, was roundly criticised this year when he called on Tories to "pray [for] a huge restriction, if not abolition, of our pro-abortion laws".
