webTitle: Blair forced to run gauntlet of rural wrath

fields.headline: Blair forced to run gauntlet of rural wrath
fields.standfirst:
Premier visits Cumbria to get first-hand reactions and is confronted by a tearful show of rage and despair

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Premier visits Cumbria to get first-hand reactions and is confronted by a tearful show of rage and despair.
fields.body:
Tony Blair ran flinching from his Jaguar and into a Cumbrian pub last night as farmers in tears shouted: "You're a coward, you don't give a shite about the north."

Two weeks after local farmers' representatives began begging the prime minister to witness the devastation of Cumbria's foot and mouth crisis, Mr Blair's cavalcade pulled up outside the Auctioneer pub in Carlisle.

The setting was symbolically perfect - a farmer's drinking house decorated with watercolours of lambs, next to a deserted cattle market.

It was five miles from the burning livestock pyres and the stench of thousands of carcasses lying hooves up in farmers' backyards.

The prime minister met for 45 minutes with a dozen representatives from farming, tourism, the local council, the army and vets before leaving for a European Union meeting in Stockholm.

Outside the pub, around 40 protesters gathered, shouting "The only good Blair is a dead one".

The crowd included depressed farmers, newly-redundant climbing instructors, and destitute publicans, as well as two misty-eyed seven-year-olds whose pet lambs had been put down that afternoon.

All hoped that Mr Blair would acknowledge their presence after waiting an hour in the rain. He did not.

Ignoring banners saying "Save our jobs", he uncomfortably looked away and sped off.

Richard Batey, a dairy farmer from Houghton, was in tears about his cousins' three thousand head of cattle that had been destroyed.

"This is not a disease we have now. It is a plague. Cumbria is going to be wiped out. Mr Blair doesn't care tuppence about the north of England," he said.

"He should have been here three weeks ago. He didn't even look at us. He hasn't even got the guts to tell us it's out of control. Get yourself out on to the farms, Mr Blair, it's carnage."

Cumbria has one third of the country's foot and mouth cases. The number of confirmed cases in the county yesterday rose to 162.

Farming is losing £5m a week. At least 50 people a day lose their jobs in the tourist industry as knock-on effect.

Tens of thousands of diseased cattle are awaiting slaughter. Tens of thousands of carcasses are lying rotting out side farmers' kitchens.

Marian Burnip, a publican from Keswick, stood holding a banner saying "Cumbria in crisis".

Her pub had lost £1,500 revenue this week. "I have just driven up the M6 past four or five burning pyres. Blair's visit is too late," she said.

Philip Chappelhow, who is standing as a Conservative councillor in the May 3 local elections, held a banner asking Mr Blair to postpone the elections.

"He has just come up here for a photocall. We have been ignored," he said.

Inside the pub, Peter Allen of the National Farmers' Union, who met Mr Blair, said: "I wish we could have had this meeting two weeks ago. We have been pushing for it for two weeks."

Nick Utting, from the NFU, said the meeting was productive and farmers felt they had impressed upon Mr Blair the serious organisational and bureaucratic "sticking points" that had allowed the disease to get out of control.

Eric Matlew, the local Labour MP, who earlier this week said the government had been clueless as to the reality of the north, maintained that there would have to be a public inquiry into the handling of the crisis.

After the meeting, the prime minister said the government would do anything that was necessary to overcome the disease. Mr Blair said red tape would be removed and every resource would be made available. "Whatever practical resources in the area to get the thing and get it done properly we will do." He said it was a "terrible situation for the farming community and the tourist industry".

Responding to criticism that the slaughtering was not happening fast enough, he said: "Speed is of the essence." He added: "I understand all the criticisms, I simply say there was a fear a week ago that we were over-reacting with the slaughter policy. But now I would think people would say 'We want that policy carried out and carried out quickly'."

He said the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, had done "a superb job in extremely difficult circumstances".

Commenting on the reason for the Carlisle visit, a Downing Street spokesman said: "Essentially, Mr Blair wants to hear from the people at the sharp end how the logistical operation in particular is going.

webTitle: Hope for carers in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Hope for carers in Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Carers in Northern Ireland could see their fortunes boosted if the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety's (DHSSPS) proposals for a carers and disabled children's bill become law.
fields.body:
Carers in Northern Ireland could see their fortunes boosted if the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety's (DHSSPS) proposals for a carers and disabled children's bill become law.

The proposals, published a week ago and now open for consultation, centre on giving all of Northern Ireland's estimated 250,000 carers the right to an assessment of their needs and subsequent provision of assistance.

The bill would bring legislation closer in line with the 1995 Carers (Recognition and Services) Act. This gave informal carers in Britain a statutory right to an assessment of their needs, but because of devolutionary measures this was not extended to Northern Ireland where non-statutory assessments are offered when possible.

The proposals have been warmly welcomed by unions and carers' associations in Northern Ireland. The latter argue that, to date, carers' needs have been tagged on to the needs of the person being cared for. They particularly welcome provisions that would give the carer the right to an assessment, even if the person being cared for refused one.

Carole Cohrane, operations manager at the Princess Royal Trust for Carers, said: "This provision not only recognises the work carers do, it recognises that they have needs in their own right. Often someone who needs care will be sent home on the condition that they get help with the cooking or going to the toilet.

"The person may assume that his or her children will do this for them. But have they actually asked their children if they can manage? People with mental health problems often get confused and refuse an assessment of their needs. Their carer, however, will still have needs and deserves to have them assessed."

The fact that assistance will be paid direct to the carer has also been applauded. At present, health boards assess the needs of the person being cared for and arrange and pay for the services for them. The carer is on the outside of the whole process.

"Making funds directly available to the carer would give them considerably more freedom as to how they meet their needs. Often, for example, carers don't mind doing the caring. What bothers them is that they have no time to do the gardening or paint the hall. If they can access funds and services directly, they can decide to pay someone to do the gardening, or hire someone to do the caring while they do the gardening," said Ms Cohrane.

The proposals include giving carers respite breaks so they can have time to themselves, even if only for a few hours. And, recognising that carers can't always take time off when it's convenient, the bill suggests issuing them with vouchers they can redeem for a break at a more convenient time. Carers would be able to get the funds for all these activities in the same way that any social security benefit is accessed, usually through the Post Office.

Measures designed to ease the burden on child carers or disabled children aged 16-18 have also been welcomed. Helen Ferguson, director of Carers National Association in Northern Ireland, said: "At the moment, disabled parents can only spend money on themselves. Under the proposals, they would be able to buy services for their children, which we think is a great way of supporting young carers and disabled parents with their parenting.

"Current social service provisions focus on child protection. As such, child carers tend to come further down the list of priorities, after children at risk in the home or involved in crime. These provisions would help the child bypass this avenue and get services more quickly."

Ms Ferguson points out that the proposal to give 16-18-year-old disabled children direct access to services, rather than access through their parents, would also go a long way towards easing parental anxiety when children want to leave home. She said: "If they know their child will be able to access services directly and efficiently, their fears will be eased."

The proposals are not, of course, without criticism. Some people are worried that child carers may be edged into a life of caring if more funds are made available to them. For example, children not eligible for job-seekers allowance or other benefits may decide to become carers instead. But by the far the biggest concern is that the consultation document makes no mention of extra funds being made available to turn the proposals from theory to practice.

Peter Deazley, head of the elderly and community care unit at the department for health, social services and public safety, said: "It's the age-old dilemma. Resources are limited, so how do you decide who gets priority? At the moment there is no submission for extra funding but I think that once the consultation period is over and a wider carers' strategy put in place later this year, the DHSSPS will be able to apply to the assembly for more money."

Certainly, there is no lack of interest in the issue. Since being released the department has had hundreds of requests for copies of the consultation document. This is perhaps not surprising in a country where an estimated 18% of the population carry out a caring role, but what the carers need to do now is turn this interest into a promise of more money.

fields.headline: Lawsuit deepens Amazon's woes
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Amazon.com is being sued by shareholders over "false and misleading" financial statements, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Amazon.com's woes deepened yesterday when it emerged that the online retailer was being sued by shareholders over alleged "false and misleading" financial statements.

The five class action lawsuits filed in Washington allege that Amazon misrepresented its financial condition and future prospects.

They claim the company violated federal securities laws on artificially inflating stock prices.

The shareholders maintain they were kept in the dark about the company's performance.

In particular, the lawsuits relate to Amazon.com joint venture investments that initially showed revenues, but actually ended up producing massive losses.

Three lawsuits were filed on behalf of investors who purchased Amazon stock earlier this year and two covered February to March last year.

All five are seeking to recover damages.

In a statement, Amazon.com said: "We have always worked hard to be extremely open, careful and accurate in our public disclosure.

"We are confident that our financial and accounting disclosures, including those related to the Amazon Commerce Network, have been correct and appropriate.

"Based on the allegations we have reviewed so far, it is clear that these lawsuits are without merit, and we expect that they will be dismissed by the court."

The court action comes at an uneasy time for the company. Even Amazon boss Jeff Bezos has advised investors to steer clear of Amazon stock for the time being.

Press reports last week suggested that Mr Bezos was being investigated by US stock market watchdog, the Securities and Exchange Commission.

webTitle: Agenda: lunch, breakfast (and a few meetings)

fields.headline: Agenda: lunch, breakfast (and a few meetings)
fields.standfirst: Lisa Christensen has a long list of engagements, from a 7.30am breakfast meeting to a working lunch
fields.trailText: A long list of engagements, from a 7.30am breakfast meeting to a working lunch
fields.body:
Started this three-week period with early breakfast with one of my lead members. One of the brighter aspects of working for Lambeth is being based in Clapham, with its plethora of good coffee houses. Sad but true that the only time we could fit in this meeting was at 7.30 on a Monday morning.

A quick scamper through the list of engagements reveals the following myriad spectrums of activity - chairing the corporate telephone performance taskforce, which will be sending in help squads to poor performers in the council (Aha! The chance to sit in the monitoring chair); attending a huge meeting of the community safety partnership (the size of the meeting proving just how the crime agenda touches us all); a couple of performance management meetings with the chief executive and the leader; leading up to the pinnacle of our annual review meeting with SSI, district audit and the NHS regional office - which went smoothly and apparently coherently. (I await the letter confirming their view.)

The budget was set, which means I will have a little bit more next year to put toward the bottomless pit of residential care costs, and the council's restructure was confirmed.

There were a couple of work-related social events that brightened up the weeks - one was having lunch with the director from our mental health trust who is now the manager of our integrated mental health service. We met to talk through what accountability mechanisms need to be in place. I wouldn't say we have definitively cracked it, but having lunch in Abbevilles, a high class restaurant staffed by people with learning disabilities, was extremely enjoyable.

We also had a reception for partners in the new reception area at our headquarters. This was a riproaring success, with a big turnout and loads of contacts being made or cemented. Excellent food produced this time by the catering workgroup at our local social education centre - plenty of potential customers showing interest in their catering for the future.

To prove that I do take an active interest in strategic issues - rather than more basic things like eating and drinking - these past few weeks have also seen me at the HAZ partnership board, helping to work through its new role as an organisational change resource (rather than a motley collection of projects); at the departmental information strategy meeting, where we are trying to address the cultural and practical issues of getting tooled up to support effective performance management and the partnership agenda; and at the first meeting of the new borough-based drugs action team.

I also went to the national mental health conference in Birmingham, at which we heard lots about the opportunity afforded by the NSF and less about the resources to support it. (Most exciting moment was the "after dinner speaker" who turned out to be an alternative comedian who would go down a storm at the Hackney Empire - but was less well-received by the 400+ NHS chief execs and directors of social services.)

This period was rounded off with a discussion with colleague directors and our director of public health about the future for public health in the modernised world no doubt more on this anon.

fields.headline: Milosevic's messy legacy
fields.standfirst:
A drastic constitutional and structural overhaul is needed in Yugoslavia, writes Ian Traynor

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: A radical constitutional and structural overhaul is needed in Yugoslavia, writes Ian Traynor in Belgrade.
fields.body:
The plain-clothes policemen never leave the third floor of the Moskva hotel in central Belgrade.

Operating in shifts, the guards keep a round-the-clock watch on room 321 where Yugoslavia's interior minister, Zoran Zivkovic, has taken up residence these past few months.

Zivkovic is clearly a busy man. The top cop in a country thoroughly criminalised by 13 years of Slobodan Milosevic's bloody rule, the interior minister's in-tray is piled high with pressing issues, not least whether to arrest Milosevic on any number of charges from property fiddles to mass murder.

The challenges daily confronting the new interior minister are such that he has not yet got round to finding himself somewhere to live in Belgrade, notching up a lengthening room service bill at the 50 pounds-a-night Moskva.

Across the river at the lavish Hyatt Hotel, more ministers and officials new to government have moved in. The Yugoslav prime minister, Zoran Zizic, was given a roasting on a radio phone-in this week heard as callers showed faint interest in policy or his government's activities. Instead they demanded answers as to how Zizic could justify the 5,000-pound a month bill he was running up at the Hyatt while Serbia is utterly broke.

Teething problems, no doubt, for the inexperienced band of former dissidents, intellectuals, and activists who have been catapulted into government in Serbia and Yugoslavia after last October's street revolution which drove the hated Milosevic out of power and into a suburban Belgrade villa where he could be arrested any day.

It is a curious country that Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica and Serbian prime minister, Zoran Dzindzic have inherited from Milosevic. Belgrade itself, as the capital of a federation which a decade ago extended from the Alps almost to the Aegean, boasts a bloated infrastructure of ministries, government buildings, and accommodation designed for running a country three times bigger than that under the new government. But the ample accommodation, it seems, does not stretch to finding suitable digs for the Yugoslav prime minister or interior minister.

As a result of Milosevic's military disasters in Croatia, Bosnia, and Kosovo, Yugoslavia or Serbia is a constantly shrinking country. A decade ago, on the cusp of disintegration, Yugoslavia was a country of 23 million. Serbia today is a country of eight million. And the disappearing act is not concluded yet.

While Macedonians and Albanians do battle on Serbia's southern border, Vojvodina to the north is getting restive and Montenegro, Serbia's small sister republic in what remains of Yugoslavia, is poised to secede.

Elections next month in Montenegro are likely to bring a triumph for the separatist camp of President Milo Djukanovic, followed by an independence referendum perhaps in June. The result: the final end of Yugoslavia and a new Serbia reduced to its rump essence - no Kosovo, no Montenegro, and Vojvodina pressing for greater decentralisation from Belgrade.

But as the country shrinks, the government structures and bureaucracy remain as oversized as ever. There is a Yugoslav government, a full cabinet under Kostunica in Belgrade. Then there is a Serbian government under Dzindzic, also in Belgrade, both cabinets duplicating each other.

When, for example, a delegation was sent to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague this week, it comprised two justice ministers from Belgrade - one Yugoslav, one Serbian. Then there is a Montenegrin government utterly separate from and opposed to the Belgrade apparatus. And for each of the three governments, there is also a separate parliament.

The Serbian government alone has seven deputy prime ministers under Dzindzic. Some of them have nothing to do or appear not to know what they should be doing. But the perks and positions are deemed necessary because the post-Milosevic government is carved out of a coalition of 18 parties, all of them clamouring for a slice of the government cake.

As a constitutional lawyer, President Kostunica is a stickler for the rule of law and the strict observance of constitutional niceties, an honourable characteristic which, however, frequently verges on nit-picking pedantry while blocking or slowing down urgently needed reforms.

Yugoslavia needs a radical constitutional and structural overhaul, ultimately acknowledging the fact that the land Kostunica has taken over from Milosevic is Yugoslavia in name only.

It's early days for the new democrats in power. But once they've moved out of Belgrade's hotels and plumped their feet properly under the tables, they will have to confront the painful fact that the Yugoslavia they are governing no longer exists.

fields.headline: Government housing plan sparks row
fields.trailText: Countryside campaigners have accused the government of ignoring its own planning guidance by approving the building of an extra 15,600 homes a year on greenfield land in the south-east without forcing a redistribution of the homes to urban areas.
fields.body:
Countryside campaigners have accused the government of ignoring its own planning guidance by approving the building of an extra 15,600 homes a year on greenfield land in the south-east without forcing a redistribution of the homes to urban areas.

The new regional planning guidance confirms a proposed allocation of 39,000 homes between the south-east counties made last December. Around 40%, or 15,600, of new homes will be built on greenfield sites.

The Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) was hoping that the government would apply its own new planning guidance by switching more of the homes from the leafy west of the region to previously developed land in the east, particularly in Kent and Essex.

The CPRE claims that as little as 25% of the homes, or 9,750, should be built on greenfield land.

But announcing the guidance yesterday, Nick Raynsford, housing and planning minister, said: "In the absence of any consistent regional rationale to justify a new distribution, the proposed distribution has not been changed."

The guidance also explains that because of increased household projections for the south-east, the total number of homes required will climb from 39,000 to 43,000 homes a year in five years' time.

Nigel Kersey, the CPRE's senior regional policy officer, said: "We are dismayed that the government has ignored its own guidance by failing to concentrate house building in those counties which are likely to offer the greatest scope for developing vacant urban land."

"What was the point of three years of consultation on a new policy it they are going to ignore it?"

Confirmation of the 39,000 figure comes after years of controversy. The South-East Regional Planning Authority recommended only 33,000 new homes a year in the regions, but some analysts claim that 55,000 homes would be needed. The guidance sets out that nearly half of the new homes will need to be affordable housing, a figure welcomed by the National Housing Federation in the South-East, the trade body representing housing associations in the region.

Policy officer Sharon Hedges said: "The affordable housing numbers are far greater than those achieved in the past. Immense effort will be needed to achieve this. It will need increased investment, higher grant rates and improvements to the planning system to ensure that the affordable homes can be delivered."

fields.headline: GWR Group attempts to reassure market
fields.trailText: 10.45am: GWR has moved to calm investors' fears after Capital's profit warning hit commercial radio shares. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
GWR Group has moved to allay the fears of investors after yesterday's profit warning from Capital Radio Group saw share prices totter across the commercial radio industry.

The radio group, which owns Classic FM, said yesterday it expected to report revenue growth of just over 10% up on the same period last year.

The statement was designed to reassure investors the downturn in advertising markets would not hit the group as hard as it had Capital, whose shares lost 22% of their value yesterday.

The update noted that GWR has a "broad spread" of activities, and that 40% of revenues are generated by the UK local market.

GWR Group's shares were up 4.14% this morning at 432.50p.

But the statement seems only to have pulled the shares back marginally, after a fall yesterday of 16%.

Radio groups have suffered in recent weeks from fears of declining advertising revenues, compounded by fears from analysts that commercial radio is failing to grab audience share from the BBC.

webTitle: Democrats in search of a cause

fields.headline: Democrats in search of a cause
fields.standfirst: Bill Clinton is the forgotten man of US politics. Does the party he used to lead face a similar fate, asks Martin Kettle?
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton is the forgotten man of US politics. Does the party he used to lead face a similar fate, asks Martin Kettle?
fields.body:
Late yesterday afternoon I realised, with a not unpleasant shock, that I had not read about Bill Clinton for days. Well, maybe that is not exactly right. I know he has been in Holland or somewhere, giving a lecture, but the point still stands.

Right now, he is marginal. All of a sudden it seems to be over.

He has been off the screen, out of the headlines, not even in my mind, for almost a week now. I feel a bit like I felt when I gave up smoking many years ago. Hey, I can do without it. Well, maybe.

But now I am nagged by another question. Is the feeling the same for the Democratic party? Now that Clinton is gone - at least for a while - does his party feel bereaved or liberated? Answer: probably a bit of both.

Have they seriously begun to contemplate life after Clinton? Answer: not systematically, but there are signs that a kind of process is beginning.

Time is cruel to ex-leaders. They slip - or in Clinton's case, they crash and blunder - off the stage and then, quite without one noticing, they become forgotten. Today, and not before time, Clinton is in the past.

It is George Bush who commands the airwaves and the daily attention of the media today, as Clinton did for so long. If the Democrats have a figurehead today, it is not Clinton and it certainly is not Al Gore, who has disappeared with far greater grace than his former boss.

As a result, right now, the effective leader of the party is Tom Daschle. If you want a sign that things are moving on, then this week's appearance of an article in the New Republic magazine putting the case for Daschle as the Democratic nominee against Bush in 2004 was as good as any.

Two months ago, it was hard to believe that anyone outside the Daschle household had even given a passing thought to the possibility of President Daschle. Now the quietly spoken Democratic senate leader from South Dakota - a state Bush carried, by the way - is being described in print as his party's "last, best hope".

Well, perhaps he is and perhaps he isn't. If you are looking for a Democratic dark horse in the 2004 stakes, I would be inclined to offer John Edwards of North Carolina myself. But what is important at this stage is that people are beginning to think about things like this.

Nevertheless, before the Democrats can choose a nominee, they need to do a bit more work on deciding what kind of party they are in the post-Clinton era.

Clinton's one-time friend Robert Reich, his first-term labour secretary, penned a devastating little op-ed piece on this subject in the Washington Post earlier this month. Taking his theme from the Monty Python "dead parrot" sketch, Reich took over the John Cleese role in the sketch and pronounced: "This political party - the Democratic party - it's dead."

Just consider the past eight years, Reich argued. The Democrats have lost the presidency, lost both houses of Congress, lost almost all their state legislative majorities, and lost most governorships. Most judges on the supreme court have been appointed by Republicans and there are clearly more to come.

The party, like the parrot, has been nailed on its limited perch, wrote Reich. "Clinton is utterly disgraced. Gore ran a lousy campaign". Instead, why doesn't the party insist that the budget surplus is spent on health care - and child care - and new schools? Why doesn't it challenge the $300bn that the US spends on the military each year? Why does it play dead on the environment?

Answer, says Reich, because it is dead.

That may seem excessive. This is, after all, the party whose presidential candidate won some 50m votes, which holds half the seats in the senate and which, if the traditional midterm patterns repeat themselves, could win the house of representatives in 2002.

Moreover, it is a party which mobilised its core voters more successfully than many thought possible last November. It is also a party which, in the eyes of at least some of its centrist supporters, for whom Reich reserved some of his cruelest barbs, has successfully reinvented itself as a potential majority party rather than as a collection of minorities that can never quite oust the Republicans.

This is a huge subject, the stuff of many columns. But the point that needs to be made right now is that Reich speaks for more people at the moment than he would have done four years ago. It is a case that demands to be answered seriously, as the Ralph Nader campaign showed.

The Democrats have lost more than they have gained at the end of the Clinton years, and they need to rally behind something much greater than the ability to raise as much soft money as their rivals. A certain humility - and not just about Clinton's personal failings - is in order from the centrists who led for so long.

Right now, the Democratic party needs a cause more than it needs a leader.

fields.headline: Blair agrees PR vote deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: parliament
Special report: election countdown
Special report: proportional representation
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy have stitched together an election manifesto compromise that keeps alive the Liberal Democrats' ambition for "fair votes" in Westminster elections - at the price of delaying the promised referendum until after a review in 2003-4.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy have stitched together an election manifesto compromise that keeps alive the Liberal Democrats' ambition for "fair votes" in Westminster elections - at the price of delaying the promised referendum until after a review in 2003-4.

The compromise has the backing of senior Labour ministers on both sides of the "fair votes" argument, as well as Kennedy loyalists. Some opponents of reform claimed that further delay will help them. A despondent Charter 88 called it a setback.

After weeks of speculation that Labour would ditch its half-hearted commitment to a referendum on proportional representation (PR) it emerged last night that Mr Blair and the Liberal Democrat leader met on Tuesday and found a face-saving formula that will encourage tactical anti-Tory voting on polling day.

As a result, Labour's manifesto will be far less hostile than many MPs expected to the "AV-Plus" version of PR suggested by Lord Jenkins in his 1998 royal commission report - shelved in the face of active pressure on Mr Blair by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and a majority of Labour MPs and activists.

Noting that the government has "introduced major innovations in electoral systems used in the UK, for the Scottish and European parliaments and Welsh and London assemblies", the draft formula for Labour's manifesto commitment goes on to promise to "review the experience of the new systems and the Jenkins report to assess whether changes may be made to the electoral system for the House of Commons".

Though it will also confirm that the referendum which Mr Blair promised Paddy Ashdown in 1997 "remains the right way to agree any change at Westminster" the imposition of a review is a vehicle for further delay in exactly the same way that Mr Brown's "five economic tests" have delayed the referendum on whether to join the euro.

In reality it means that Mr Blair wants to wait until after the PR systems introduced since 1997 - a "top-up" system for Scotland and Wales, regional lists for Europe and a second vote in the election for London mayor - bed down over a full cycle. That means no review before 2003-4 at the earliest.

Mr Kennedy and his allies - who had feared that the referendum would be ditched altogether after the enmity expressed at labour's Exeter conference last summer - were relieved, since grassroots critics had said he was caving in.

Labour's text "makes clear that the case and cause of constitutional reform, particularly fair votes, proceeds. The Liberal Democrats will continue to keep pressure on the Labour party for a referendum as soon as possible," Mr Kennedy said in a statement.

Robin Cook, the most senior pro-PR politician close to Mr Blair, was happy as were backbench campaigners for a PR system for the Commons like Stephen Twigg, the MP who beat Michael Portillo thanks to tactical voting in 1997.

But Sir Ken Jackson, the engineers' leader and a fierce defender of the traditional first-past-the-post system said he was "very relaxed".

"This certainly moves even closer to our position than we agreed at Exeter," he said. "The prospect for some sort of review after 2003 are very dim."

Pam Giddy, director of Charter 88, agreed when she said that "without a timetable we are moving back from 1997, four years on and we are further away. It's all about keeping the Labour party in line rather than moving the argument forward."

It is no secret that Lord Jenkins and Sir Paddy feel let down as Mr Blair - sitting on Labour's 179-seat 1997 majority - remains "unpersuaded" of the case for PR.

Many Labour MPs and activists with experience of PR have been dismayed by coalition politics with the Liberal Democrats in Scotland and, less formally, in Wales. They blame PR for "giving away" power.

Lord Jenkins' AV-Plus plan would keep individual constituencies while requiring MPs to get more than 50% of the votes cast before they claim victory. There would also be a top-up element of around 150 MPs to make the Commons result "fairer". Purists call the hybrid even worse than the status quo.

Millbank says the Blair-Kennedy compromise is "pretty much in line" with Labour's Exeter formula. But insiders in the pro-PR camp claim that they have rescued their cause from near-disaster since then.

"There is more to this deal than meets the eye," said one, pointing to the removal of anti-PR language which dominated Labour's policy statement at Exeter.

As a result, Labour's manifesto will be far less hostile than many MPs expected to the "AV-Plus" version of PR suggested by Lord Jenkins in his 1998 royal commission report - shelved in the face of active pressure on Mr Blair by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and a majority of Labour MPs and activists. Noting that the government has "introduced major innovations in electoral systems used in the UK, for the Scottish and European parliaments and Welsh and London assemblies", the draft formula for Labour's manifesto commitment goes on to promise to "review the experience of the new systems and the Jenkins report to assess whether changes may be made to the electoral system for the House of Commons". Though it will also confirm that the referendum which Mr Blair promised Paddy Ashdown in 1997 "remains the right way to agree any change at Westminster" the imposition of a review is a vehicle for further delay in exactly the same way that Mr Brown's "five economic tests" have delayed the referendum on whether to join the euro. In reality it means that Mr Blair wants to wait until after the PR systems introduced since 1997 - a "top-up" system for Scotland and Wales, regional lists for Europe and a second vote in the election for London mayor - bed down over a full cycle. That means no review before 2003-4 at the earliest. Mr Kennedy and his allies - who had feared that the referendum would be ditched altogether after the enmity expressed at labour's Exeter conference last summer - were relieved, since grassroots critics had said he was caving in. Labour's text "makes clear that the case and cause of constitutional reform, particularly fair votes, proceeds. The Liberal Democrats will continue to keep pressure on the Labour party for a referendum as soon as possible," Mr Kennedy said in a statement. Robin Cook, the most senior pro-PR politician close to Mr Blair, was happy as were backbench campaigners for a PR system for the Commons like Stephen Twigg, the MP who beat Michael Portillo thanks to tactical voting in 1997. But Sir Ken Jackson, the engineers' leader and a fierce defender of the traditional first-past-the-post system said he was "very relaxed". "This certainly moves even closer to our position than we agreed at Exeter," he said. "The prospect for some sort of review after 2003 are very dim." Pam Giddy, director of Charter 88, agreed when she said that "without a timetable we are moving back from 1997, four years on and we are further away. It's all about keeping the Labour party in line rather than moving the argument forward." It is no secret that Lord Jenkins and Sir Paddy feel let down as Mr Blair - sitting on Labour's 179-seat 1997 majority - remains "unpersuaded" of the case for PR. Many Labour MPs and activists with experience of PR have been dismayed by coalition politics with the Liberal Democrats in Scotland and, less formally, in Wales. They blame PR for "giving away" power. Lord Jenkins' AV-Plus plan would keep individual constituencies while requiring MPs to get more than 50% of the votes cast before they claim victory. There would also be a top-up element of around 150 MPs to make the Commons result "fairer". Purists call the hybrid even worse than the status quo. Millbank says the Blair-Kennedy compromise is "pretty much in line" with Labour's Exeter formula. But insiders in the pro-PR camp claim that they have rescued their cause from near-disaster since then. "There is more to this deal than meets the eye," said one, pointing to the removal of anti-PR language which dominated Labour's policy statement at Exeter. fields.trailText: "I'm Carla." Oliver felt a lump in his trousers. "Er... would you like to go out with me?" "Sure. Why not?"
fields.body:
"Ooh, you've noticed my medals," giggled Mrs Baldry.

Oliver blushed and averted his eyes from the stripes on his patient's bum and focused on the muscle knot at T5. He felt ashamed. Andrea, his wife, had only been dead a week and he was already having sexual fantasies about someone else. We may have had our difficulties, but our 17-year age gap never really got between us, he thought.

"You're all a bunch of fucking tosshers," slurred Barry, as he drank 10 bottles of vodka after the funeral. It had been bad enough losing his wife to a younger man all those years ago, but to an osteopath? "I'm off to finish my fucking column."

"Perhaps, you'd like to come to my men's group on Tuesday," said Oliver.

As if, thought Barry. What would an old hack want with that?

"Hello, Barry," said Sophie, the well-connected socialite. "Have you got my rent? Thought not, so I'd like you to move out of the Tite Street flat for a while."

"Bugger," drooled Barry over 25 pints. "I'll have to get Oliver out of his house. It was once half mine after all."

"Nice of you to come to the group," gushed Oliver. "You're all a bunch of fucking poofters," said Barry, several gallons later. "I'm off."

Oliver heard a noise in the garden. "Oh, help. Barry's had a heart attack," he shrieked. "You'd better come and stay with me," he added once Barry had got the all-clear from the hospital.

"Who are you?" asked Oliver when he went to Barry's flat to get his clothes.

"I'm Carla." Oliver felt a lump in his trousers. "Er... would you like to go out with me?" "Sure. Why not?"

"You've fallen for Carla, haven't you?" laughed Barry. "She's a call-girl. Too expensive for you."

"Wah, wah," wailed Oliver. "Why am I such a wetty that I misread every social situation?"

The phone rang. "I've lost my weekly column," Barry said quietly. "Maybe it's time I stopped drinking heavily and started treating people a little better."

"You can have the house, Barry," said Oliver. "I'm going to live in your flat."

Sophie took Oliver under her wing and introduced him to her expensive friends. Within days he had become an osteopath to many and a shag to some. Suddenly he was brimming with self-confidence. Life was good.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: Oliver and Barry plod their way through 184 pages of mind-numbing self-discovery

webTitle: The filming of VS Naipaul's novel, The Mystic Masseur

fields.headline: Trouble in paradise
fields.standfirst: When Ismail Merchant decided to film a VS Naipaul novel on the balmy island of Trinidad, he expected cheap overheads, cooperative extras and lucrative sponsorship. Instead he got locals demanding cash to get off set, a desperate shortage of props and rumours of a political coup.  David Tindall reports
fields.trailText: When Ismail Merchant decided to film a VS Naipaul novel on the balmy island of Trinidad, he expected cheap overheads, cooperative extras and lucrative sponsorship. Instead he got locals demanding cash to get off set, a desperate shortage of props and rumours of a political coup. David Tindall reports.
fields.body:
Ismail Merchant has a winning smile that he can turn on like a light bulb - a feature that came in very handy when he was directing the new Merchant-Ivory production of VS Naipaul's novel, The Mystic Masseur. Because, having decided to shoot the film in Naipaul's native Trinidad, Merchant-Ivory Productions couldn't possibly have chosen a worse time to arrive.

The cast and crew - travelling from New York, London and Bombay - landed three months ago, jetlagged, in the middle of the furore surrounding Trinidad and Tobago's general election. The country's predominantly Indian-Trinidadian party, the United National Congress, had just scraped to a contentious election victory. Allegations of large-scale gerrymandering and fraud filled the newspapers, while the prime minister, Basdeo Panday, and President Robinson were engaged in a constitutional mud-slinging contest.

Robinson had refused to sign documents allowing Panday to appoint seven ministers who lost their seats in the election. Panday had been presented with a libel suit for calling someone a "pseudo racist", and added further fuel to the fire by claiming that the islands were being threatened by an impending coup.

It was a warning that many took seriously. In 1990, after all, there had been a real coup attempt, in which several people were killed near the parliament building. However, those responsible for that particular drama now said they knew nothing about this latest scare. Nor had the chief of defence staff heard any whisper of danger. Perhaps the prime minister, having only narrowly won the election, wanted to create a little tension so that he could be seen as a safe pair of hands.

Another possible explanation was simple scaremongering - Panday's way of making the president see things his way over the constitutional impasse. The two are old sparring partners and they don't call Panday, former union leader and actor of no mean repute, the "Silver Fox" for nothing. He insisted that Robinson - a physically sick man - was no longer fit to hold office. The president, in return, described the prime minister's rule as a "creeping dictatorship".

At first, none of this swordplay perturbed the film's producers. They assumed, quite reasonably, that it was none of their affair. "You've got to be a supreme optimist in this business or you never get anywhere," said Merchant, smiling. "Maybe the government, or someone, will be interested in investing in the film." With that in mind, he instructed his young nephew - Nayeem Hafizka, who was leading the production team - to seek out some useful contacts.

Nayeem is his uncle's clone: same charming smile, same soft manner of speaking, same tenacious approach to wheeling and dealing until he gets a discount on everything - from meals in restaurants to rented property for himself, the cast and crew. And he is very good at his job. Before long, the prime minister himself had handed over his mobile phone number. And the cameras had barely started rolling on the island's lush north-western peninsular when a local industrialist announced that he would be putting in half a million US dollars in return for a credit as executive producer.

However, Nayeem's smooth approach did not wash with BWIA, the national airline. The press officer was adamant: "We can't even consider giving discounts to film people." From Nayeem's point of view, though, it was worth a try: "It's very important to keep a close watch on the budget all the time."

Indeed, Merchant-Ivory had come to the tiny Caribbean state with a tight budget, believing that, as in Bollywood, they would be able shoot the movie for under $3m - a sum that would hardly have paid the food bill on some of their more lavish productions. Here, chicken and rice were the order of the day, with a few local vegetables and a slab of currant cake for dessert (although on the day Basdeo Panday took a break from his various crises to pop in for lunch on the set, they had shrimp).

Despite Nayeem's efforts, the purse-strings were at times pulled a little too tight. Om Puri, star of East Is East and City of Joy, who plays the scheming village storekeeper Ramlogan in the film, is prone to backache. After a few days and nights, he was in need of rest, but all he could find to to lie down on were some planks of wood. "There were only six chairs between 60 people," he said. "Not even a nurse or doctor handy on the set - which is usually the case." He spent much of his first day off from filming receving much-needed treatment from a Trinidadian masseuse.

Actor James Fox, who flew 4,000 miles from London on a Saturday to play a spiritual recluse in a single scene, found himself filming the next morning and flying back to England the following Tuesday. Merchant wasn't about to subsidise a leisurely break on a palm-fringed beach. "He really is quite mean," said Fox.

But it took just one frenetic day to vindicate Merchant's frugality. While filming in the island's old capital, Port-of-Spain, the crew cordoned off a street to traffic. They had chosen as their location an old printing works with a hand press - just the sort of place used in the novel by its protagonist, Ganesh Ramsumair, mystic healer and aspiring writer of books (played by Aasif Mandvi).

Suddenly, as they were preparing for the first take, a commotion broke out in the street. A family sitting outside their house refused to budge out of shot until they been properly compensated. "We want 1,500 [Trinidadian] dollars [about £150] ... and put it in writing," they said. Nayeem and Ismail turned on the smiles. No go; the locals claimed that no one had warned them that the street would be closed for two days. The police were called. Still no go.

Sensing an opportunity, a barber and a barkeeper decided to join in. Both complained that they would lose so much trade, they would not be able to pay the rent at the end of the week. The family, meanwhile, who were now squatting on the pavement, were opening up to the idea of negotiation. If three of them were taken on as extras, they said, they might reconsider. For the first time that day, Nayeem and Ismail lost their smiles, and capitulated. Finally, filming got under way.

Opportunism was not the only problem facing the crew. Naipaul's story - that of a simple faith-healer who becomes a successful diplomat - describes an honest man's struggle against ignorance, greed and big-city corruption in the 1950s, a time when Trinidad was struggling for independence. Accordingly, some of the period props proved very hard to track down. Top of the wanted list were a 1937 Vauxhall and a 1952 Rolls-Royce; then there were the pre-war bicycles and all the stock for the specially built village store and various wooden houses. As the film-makers soon realised, Trinidad has little in the way of film infrastructure; no storehouse of historic treasures saved for posterity. Long before the first roll of film was completed, the two Englishwomen responsible for set design and dressing were exhausted. Fortunately, a Trinidadian woman with a lot of contacts and energy stepped into the breach and worked miracles.

One local producer, who had spent weeks hunting for suitable locations, quit the film in exasperation over the terms of her contract. So much was expected of her so quickly, and for so little reward, she said, that she felt she was being exploited.

A local film director, Tony Maharaj, brought in as associate producer to help Merchant "fix things", said: "It's been a nightmare of leaving things until the last minute. When we needed a rain scene, they only asked for the fire brigade the night before filming."

The Mystic Masseur was Merchant's fourth film as director - James Ivory has taken the helm on most of their previous collaborations - but it was his first film in Trinidad, and he was having to learn the ways of the island by trial and error. He arrived in the country with the impression that the Pulitzer prize-winning Naipaul was a local hero, and that the locals would be only too happy to cooperate. But it was not to be so. It soon emerged that the relationship between the author and his countrymen is something of a love-hate affair: Naipaul's fiction captures every twist and turn in the Trinidadian psyche, and many do not appreciate his candour.

Some locals, however, were more sympathetic, and keen to play some small part in the making of the movie. Although as the producers admit, they might not have been quite so keen if they had known what they were letting themselves in for.

When it came to the filming of the Governor's Ball scene, for example, 60 or so Trinidadians were hired as extras. They arrived on the Saturday evening full of enthusiasm, chattering excitedly as they were dressed for the shoot. Soon afterwards, however, they discovered what being an extra really entails: endless hours of waiting around for something to happen.

The first attempts at filming were catastrophic. Someone had forgotten to hire the string quartet; the lighting was not quite right; the choreography wasn't coming together. At 2am they abandoned the set, and told everyone to come back on Sunday afternoon.

The long-suffering extras were paid just 100 Trinidadian dollars a day [just under £10] for their pains. Fortunately, the majority were not in it for the money. Most were thrilled simply to be involved in the film - especially in such a grand scene as the governor's dinner, filmed in prime minister Panday's newly refurbished offices. Some of those at the colonial bash, seated at the long dinner table, resplendent with cut glass and silver, came from old Trinidad plantation families whose grandparents would have attended such affairs in the past. Being from the country, like the film's hero Ganesh, they didn't have a clue about codes of dress or the parade of wine glasses and cutlery glinting at them from the snow-white linen.

However, the novelty and grandeur of the occasion had long worn off by the time filming ended. Further complications meant that the scene was finally wrapped at 5am - only an hour before the prime minister wanted his office back. Ivory, who had flown in from New York to escape the cold and cast a back-seat eye over the production, laconically referred to the night-long filming ordeal as all part of "the degradation of being an extra".

In spite of such stressful days, all concerned are agreed that the experience of filming The Mystic Masseur has ultimately been a useful one - as much for Trinidad as for the Merchant-Ivory team. The government's tourist office, for example, is hoping to leave the little village of Mount Pleasant, created by the film-makers in Chaguaramas, just as it is, as part of a heritage site.

fields.headline: Emap eyes Cabal lads' magazine
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Emap is believed to have approached Cabal Communications in a bid to buy lads' magazine Front, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap is believed to have approached Sally O'Sullivan's Cabal Communications in a bid to buy its lads' magazine Front.

Front, edited by the larger-than-life Piers Hernu, was catapulted into public notoriety after a BBC documentary last year.

Cabal denies the magazine is for sale.

In the BBC film, Trouble Between the Covers, Mr Hernu was seen being ejected from a club, joshing with the gangster Dave Courtney and remarking, "This bog roll by my bed is because I've got a cold, not because I'm a wanker".

Ms O'Sullivan was not available for comment.

But Mr Hernu said: "There have been some enquiries about the magazine, but it is not officially up for sale."

Emap Elan boss Barry McIlheney has admitted "going out and having a chat" with Ms O'Sullivan, about the state of the men's magazine market in general.

He said: "We have got an aggressive strategy in the men's market and she has got a good title that has done well."

"But that stopped short of discussions about Emap buying Front," he added.

"We do look at bolt-on acquisitions at all times, but we're not specifically negotiating."

webTitle: Letters: Lawyer Jonathan Sumption answers back

fields.headline: Eating up the rich
fields.trailText: You have accused me of the horrid crime of earning as much as eight high court judges and 69 refuse workers put together. I admit it. But the reason is not that our society worships money, still less that I do. It is that we prize the services that some people can provide as individuals.
fields.body:
You have accused me of the horrid crime of earning as much as eight high court judges and 69 refuse workers put together. I admit it. But the reason is not that our society worships money, still less that I do. It is that we prize the services that some people can provide as individuals. Although we think better of nurses, teachers, and refuse workers as groups than we do of disc jockeys or chief executives, no single one of them makes as much difference financially.

I earn what I do because that is what my services are worth to the people who pay for them, all of whom are hard-nosed professionals spending their own money, with plenty of cheaper alternatives to choose from. The same is true of Kirsty Hume, Charlotte Church, Sean Connery and all the other high earners whom you hold up as symptoms of a sick society.

The real problem is with your distinction between private wealth and public squalor, which is emotionally satisfying but false. I would not want to live in a society without decent public services. But then neither would I want to live in a society where it was impossible for someone with enough talent, effort and luck to make a fortune, especially as a society like that could probably not afford much in the way of public services.

Why should we choose when we can have both advantages? It is not as if Bernie Ecclestone's £617m or my puny £1.6m is made at the expense of the public purse, or unwillingly extracted from the private purses of school cleaners or speech therapists.
Jonathan Sumption
Brick Court Chambers

fields.headline: Please, sir
fields.trailText: For once I've really enjoyed reading a broadsheet newspaper instead of being plunged into feelings of gloom and cynicism. The supplement on the Common Good (March 20) wrapped around the paper is wonderful.
fields.body:
For once I've really enjoyed reading a broadsheet newspaper instead of being plunged into feelings of gloom and cynicism. The supplement on the Common Good (March 20) wrapped around the paper is wonderful - an in-depth discussion of principles and issues that affect us all, surrounded by the voices of people who actually work in our long despised public services. How refreshing to read about the possibility of working for the common good rather than how badly this or that politician or government department is behaving or what some mediocre celebrity has been up to. As Oliver Twist says: more please.
Mark Humphries
London

fields.headline: A pressing pre-election message for Labour
fields.trailText: Thank you, Guardian, for raising the issue, and indeed, raising the profile of the public sector. As you rightly say, now is the time for this country and, please, this government to recognise that decent public services are both measures of and prerequisites for a decent nation.
fields.body:
Thank you, Guardian, for raising the issue, and indeed, raising the profile of the public sector. As you rightly say, now is the time for this country and, please, this government to recognise that decent public services are both measures of and prerequisites for a decent nation. Let us take this political (general election) and financial (£20bn surplus) opportunity, to celebrate and enrich our public services, maintaining the welfare state for the benefit of our future generations.
Sarah Webb
Sheffield area child protection committee
sheffield@sacpc.demon.co.uk

New Labour will take an election victory as an endorsement for the state-subsidised privatisation of public services they and their Tory predecessors have already wasted untold billions upon. Accelerated by the general agreement on trade in services (Gats) that the government is signing up to, the result will be the takeover of the former welfare state by transnational corporations providing all "public" services with choice determined by ability to pay. An independent defence of public services and values is required, one that fosters joined-up opposition to the privatisation policy of joined-up government.
Patrick Ainley
Ilford, Essex

Thank you for publishing such a broad and unpatronising analysis of the public sector, which acknowledges that ordinary people, not do-gooders and private sector rejects, choose to do useful, meaningful work. I work in regeneration and it annoys me that many people of my age (26) don't have a sense of social responsibility - or if they do it in a vague, global sort of way. While they may think overseas development or charity work is cool and worthwhile, they can't see the appeal in wanting to improve the public infrastructure of their own country. I hope your article is right in suggesting that a change is on its way. My generation (Thatcher's children) have never experienced a fully functioning public sector and might stop believing in it if it doesn't happen soon.
Nina Massarik London Development Agency
NinaMassarik@lda.gov.uk

New Labour needs to reformulate its approach - too often just ritualistic condemnation of the efficiency and ethos of the public sector. The assumption that public employees are motivated predominantly by self-interest or even selfishness must be put to rest. New Labour must learn to work in a spirit of co-operation with its public servants to develop and deliver the high-quality, properly funded, services which will benefit us all. By engaging with those who deliver public services, as your journalists have done, New Labour will be in a much better position to construct the progressive policies needed to counter the legacy of Thatcherism.
Robert Page
University of Birmingham
R.M.Page@bham.ac.uk

fields.headline: Nursing hopes for change
fields.trailText: I am writing in response to your excellent series on the state of our public sector (The Common Good, March 20 and 21).
fields.body:
I am writing in response to your excellent series on the state of our public sector (The Common Good, March 20 and 21). I am a staff nurse at the children's hospital here in Bristol and much of the debate and discussion gave me new insight into my position and of those unsung heroes up and down the country.

It dismays me to read that the public (our clients) demand higher standards, shorter waiting lists and cleaner hospitals, and at the same time agreeing that we should be better paid, but refusing to pay for it from higher taxes. (Remember I am a tax-payer too.) Society today is self-centred and losing its altruism in return for money, mobile phones, more foreign holidays etc. In the recent referendum held by Bristol council asking us to decide on the level of council tax, a majority voted for a freeze in bills for the third year in a row - despite the council's stark outline of the consequences of a freeze for local schools (the sacking of teachers, fewer classes, fewer books).

People must accept responsibility for the society we live in, rather than the self-centred attitude that has become the accepted norm. Maybe your articles will open people's eyes to the state of our nation, which worships footballers, yet has no respect for those caring for their own elders.
Sebastian deGange
Bristol

I longed to believe Tony Blair's commitment to the provision of "good public services" (March 20). However, in Oxfordshire, "we've made a good start" is so demonstrably inaccurate. The city and county can hardly be called a deprived area, yet such is the state of our public services that accident victims are waiting 10 hours for "emergency treatment" in the casualty department of John Radcliffe hospital. In the county council, we are upwards of 20 workers short in our children and families section, and in Oxford city, schools are covering for two dozen seemingly unfillable teacher vacancies.

Further, we have had to reduce the number of children taken into care, not because families in Oxfordshire are treating their children better, but because we haven't the money to provide for them. All this and much more imposes huge strains on staff (and councillors for that matter).

Recruitment and retention of staff is increasingly difficult because of the low wages paid to those who serve the public and the high cost of living in this area. The position is further exacerbated by the lack of social housing. The huge sums mentioned in Mr Blair's article are meaningless to the many people working in hospitals, schools and social services in Oxfordshire who are desperate for decent working conditions and affordable accommodation and surroundings for themselves and their families.
Cllr Tom Richardson
Oxfordshire county council

The problem in the public sector is one of money, but also of trust. In the belief that we will do our jobs badly unless we are bullied to do them well, the government has imposed an audit culture which produces so much work of its own that increasingly little time is left to do the job which is being audited. In AuditWorld the only incentives are fear and suspicion, and the effects on motivation are corrosive. Audits have practically driven out flexibility and innovation in university teaching and those supposed to benefit from them - students - have suffered the most.
Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University
a.n.h.dobson@pol.keele.ac.uk

webTitle: Letters: Union leaders congratulate The Guardian

fields.headline: Working in Unison
fields.trailText: I cannot overstate how much I welcome the Guardian's focus on the public services and, in particular, the contribution that the staff make. Such public debate and analysis is long overdue on this subject.
fields.body:
I cannot overstate how much I welcome the Guardian's focus on the public services and, in particular, the contribution that the staff make. Such public debate and analysis is long overdue on this subject. Our 1.3m members have always provided us with an insight into the public services, that has led us to campaign on many of the issues covered in your supplement.

Unison's new charter for public services, due out next week, echoes many of your arguments - particularly the detrimental effect of transferring staff and responsibilities over to private companies.

Your opinion polls also confirm what our members have been telling us for years: that public service staff are perceived as dedicated professionals who deserve to be appropriately rewarded.

The government has to accept that to improve public services they must invest for change and show the extent to which they value the work of public servants.
Dave Prentis
General secretary, Unison

Congratulations. Let's hope this section will establish a trend whereby the Guardian can continue to give voice to those who ultimately make social and political policy.
Doug Nicholls
Community and Youth Workers' Union

webTitle: Morale among overstressed GPs at all time low, says report

fields.headline: Morale among overstressed GPs at all time low, says report
fields.trailText: Morale among GPs is at an all time low, according to a report yesterday which claims four out of five would leave the NHS if they could.
fields.body:
Morale among GPs is at an all time low, according to a report yesterday which claims four out of five would leave the NHS if they could.

High stress levels and disenchantment with government health policy are to blame for the growing feeling of hopelessness, a report in the Doctor claimed.

Recent cash incentives introduced by Tony Blair, including a £10,000 "golden handshake" for new GPs, have done nothing to improve morale, the newspaper claims.

The research said 68% of GPs were considering retiring early while 80% would not recommend general practice as a career to young doctors.

Lester Russell, 41, a GP in Southsea, told Doctor he was leaving his job next month. "I have only one choice. When the job starts interfering with family, then family comes first."

Jenny Reynolds, a GP from Sutton Coldfield, said of the government's recent financial incentive scheme: "Take your offer and shove it. They would have to add a zero for me to even seriously think about it."

The main complaint was constant change. Nine out of 10 GPs said NHS reforms were adversely affecting morale.

More than 90% said they were stressed at work and 69% said they would take industrial action to vent their anger.

Phil Johnson, editor of Doctor, said: "The shocking results of our survey reveal a profession not just down-hearted but at the end of its tether."

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said: "The unprecedented scale of disillusionment amongst GPs, which this survey reveals, is a shocking indictment of Labour's incompetence."

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said: "There are over 29,000 GPs in the country of which around 550 have responded to this survey. However, we do know that many GPs are under pressure from the pace of change. The department greatly appreciates the work that GPs.

"That's why we have introduced a raft of measures to improve working lives of GPs. These include cutting paperwork, recruiting 2,000 more GPs, introducing a payment of £5,000 for all new GPs and £10,000 for GPs who work until 65."

fields.headline: Murdoch hopes to Shine with £10m Sky deal
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Elisabeth Murdoch has unveiled details of her new production company Shine, including a £10m output deal with Sky, writes Jason Deans. Mar 22: Murdoch signs Lord Alli
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch has unveiled further details of her new production company Shine, including a two-year TV and film output deal with BSkyB worth at least £10m.

Ms Murdoch is the company's chairman and chief executive, with Lord Waheed Alli coming on board as executive director, with an equity stake.

"We intend to be the home for the best creative talent in the industry, which we will combine with a strong commercial infrastructure," said Ms Murdoch.

Shine has four operating divisions, encompassing TV, films, rights management and venture programming, which will act as a broker between TV producers and brand owners looking to develop content.

Shine venture programming, which is headed by former managing partner of St Luke's advertising agency David Pemsel, has already signed a deal with IPC Media to develop a daytime TV format.

The TV and film production arms will be boosted by the two-year BSkyB output agreement, which is said to have formed part of the deal Ms Murdoch negotiated when she left her job as managing director of Sky Networks in May last year.

The BSkyB deal is understood to be worth a minimum of £5m a year.

Ms Murdoch has hired Sally Anne Howard, whose production credits include Trisha, This Morning, Vanessa and Jerry Springer, as executive producer of lifestyle.

Former BBC controller of documentaries and history Paul Hamann is joining Shine as creative director, factual.

Mr Hamann has a remit to develop long running factual series for broadcasters including Sky One and Channel 4, rather than one-off documentaries.

Ms Murdoch has already hired Royle Family producer Kenton Allen as creative director, entertainment and comedy.

She is also looking to hire a head of drama, or link up with an existing independent drama producer.

Other Shine appointments include Andrew Hill as director of planning. Like Mr Pemsel, Mr Hill is joining the firm from St Luke's, where he was communications director.

Shine has appointed William Morris to handle the US distribution of its programming and formats.

fields.headline: Reuters gains from Bridge collapse
fields.trailText: Reuters yesterday said it was sticking to its revenue forecasts despite the turmoil that has wreaked havoc in the financial markets. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Reuters, the news and financial information group, yesterday said it was sticking to its revenue forecasts despite the turmoil that has wreaked havoc in the financial markets.

Chief executive-designate Tom Glocer said the company was weathering the worsening conditions by gaining market share, largely at the expense of rival Bridge Information Systems. "It's very nice when one of your two major international competitors is in bankruptcy court," he said.

"Obviously, from an overall point of view, the pie in 2001 is not growing quite as fast as it did in 2000. But there are a significant number of counter-cyclical positives for us which mask that trend."

He noted that redundancies at financial institutions had been accompanied by increases in technology spend. "In a downturn, people are looking at financial institutions to substitute technology solutions for staff," he said. "They are reducing head count but they are actually spending on systems."

The comments failed to prevent a slide in the company's share price, which fell a further 7% to 769p.

Mr Glocer also said there was no change in Reuters plans to float its electronic broking unit Instinet. The float is planned for the first half of this year, "subject to market conditions".

Mr Glocer's comments were made at the launch of an alliance with Microsoft and 25 financial institutions to develop a high security messaging system.

The service, Reuters.Net Messaging will launch towards the end of the year. The aim is to provide a system allowing financial institutions to talk to their staff and clients electronically in a highly secure environment.

A global contacts directory for the financial services industry will be developed as part of the new service. "In an industry where security, reliability and speed are paramount, Reuters.Net Messaging will deliver a genuine competitive edge," Mr Glocer said.

fields.headline: BT fights to tame £30bn debt
fields.trailText: BT shares continued their slide into ignominy yesterday, losing another 5% of their value to close at 469p.
fields.body:
BT shares continued their slide into ignominy yesterday, losing another 5% of their value to close at 469p.

The fall came amid reports that the beleaguered company has begun discussing means of refinancing its £18bn syndicated loan.

Negotiations with bankers are part of the company's wider attempt to get a handle on its debts which have mounted to £30bn.

BT's £18bn loan facility does not mature until August but increasingly difficult borrowing conditions for telecoms companies have prompted the group to begin renegotiating early. The capital markets have virtually closed to the sector which borrowed to the hilt to finance the bids for next generation mobile phone licences.

The company has not issued its full quota of commercial paper that the facility supports and BT is considering reducing the debt, according to reports.

The renegotiation of the loan is likely to lead to BT paying higher terms. At present it is spread between 12 banks which are expected to ask for the risk to be spread further.

BT has been caught out by the slide in equity markets which has thrown its plans to reduce debt into disarray. The company had hoped to seek stock market flotations for up to 25% of BT Wireless and Yell, its directories business.

Earlier this week the group called off a meeting with key investors. Directors of the company had hoped to explore the levels of support for alternative options.

In return for supporting a massive cash call some investors are calling for the heads of senior BT executives including chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman Sir Iain Vallance. The meeting was cancelled because of claims that it had descended into a "media circus" according to a BT insider.

fields.headline: New London stadium open for sponsors
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: London's new £87m athletics stadium could carry a sponsor's name, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
London's new £87m athletics stadium, being built for the 2005 World Championships, could carry a sponsor's name.

The Picketts Lock stadium, being built with National Lottery money, still needs to find £15m and commercial deals increasingly look the best way to make up the shortfall.

Unveiling the design for the stadium yesterday, sports minister Kate Hoey said the government may allow a private company to have naming rights at the venue.

Venues built with lottery funding are not usually allowed to release their naming rights to private companies.

The Lee Valley National Athletics Centre will seat 43,000 spectators. After the championships are over, it will be modified into a 20,000-seat national athletics stadium.

Some football clubs are named after sponsors - Bolton Wanderers's ground is known as the Reebok Stadium and Huddersfield awarded its naming rights to McAlpine.

UK Athletics chief executive David Moorcroft is talking to financial consultants KPMG about options for getting private companies involved in the stadium. Construction is due to begin in June 2002.

fields.headline: Mail on Sunday picks Peart as editor
fields.trailText: 8am: Sue Peart is to be new editor of the Mail on Sunday's You magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sue Peart is to be new editor of the Mail on Sunday's You magazine, which has been without an official head for five months.

She has been acting editor since the departure of Dee Nolan, who was poached last November by Time Inc to head the UK launch of its women's glossy magazine In Style.

Staff on the magazine are breathing a sigh of relief.

Industry sources speculated that Associated Newspapers managers interviewed a number of external candidates for the post, believing that finding the right candidate was as key as the editorship of one of their flagship papers.

You magazine is one of the best-respected of the Sunday supplement magazines, which Associated believes to be crucial in driving sales on the Mail on Sunday.

The magazine's staff were shocked last year when Ms Nolan left on a reported salary of £120,000, taking several members of staff with her.

The newspaper sold 2.3m copies a week at the last ABC audit, but the circulation of You magazine is believed to be three times that amount.

Ms Peart was not available for comment, and insiders said it was too early for her to discuss her plans for the magazine.

She joined You magazine in 1993 from the Times Weekend magazine, which she edited.

Before joining the Times, she worked as Ms Nolan's deputy on the Sunday Express, which she later went on to edit.

webTitle: Huge bill for foot and mouth

fields.headline: Scottish Tourist Board faces massive bill after pulling plug on advertising campaign
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Scottish Tourist Board has been landed with a huge bill after cancelling a major advertising campaign due to foot and mouth, writes Claire Cozens.

Mar 22: Blair combats crisis with £10m advertising blitz
fields.body:
The Scottish Tourist Board has been hit with a bill for tens of thousands of pounds after cancelling a major advertising campaign due to foot and mouth.

The £2m campaign to encourage people to visit Scotland was due to have launched earlier this month. But the organisation decided to postpone it until freedom of movement is restored to the countryside.

"A marketing campaign to encourage people to come and enjoy the countryside was just not deemed to be appropriate at a time like this," said a spokeswoman for the Scottish Tourist Board.

"We did lose money, but we decided that was better than wasting the entire £2m."

Advertisers that cancel their bookings can be liable for up to 90% of the cost of the media space if they cancel at the last minute.

The Scottish Tourist Board had hoped to run the campaign in April, but even that is now looking unlikely. Restrictions on walking in the countryside are not expected to be lifted until May at the earliest.

Several major advertisers including Waitrose and McDonald's have pulled advertising campaigns due to the foot and mouth crisis, adding to the generally moribund advertising market.

Related story
