fields.headline: We still aim to stir controversy, says Channel 4
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Channel 4 is to rediscover its controversial roots this summer
fields.body:
Channel 4 is to rediscover its controversial roots this summer by screening a once-banned scene from a comedy series, a documentary calling for the decriminalisation of heroin, and a voyeur's treat: round-the-clock Big Brother.

The broadcaster announced yesterday that it will show a spoof about the Yorkshire Ripper conceived by the comic satirist Chris Morris, which proved so contentious four years ago that it was dropped by the then chief executive, Michael Grade.

But Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, said audience tastes had changed.

Morris's sketch shows how a well known figure is duped into commenting on a fictitious plan to turn the Ripper story into a musical. It was part of the Brass Eye series, that demonstrated the ease in which celebrities and politicians can be manipulated to rally behind a cause they know little about.

Channel 4 will not reveal the identity of the interviewee who was lured into discussing the Ripper "musical" until Brass Eye - with the reinstated scene - is shown again this year.

This was originally due to be aired in November 1996, and was eventually shown four months later without the Ripper scene. Morris took his revenge by including an obscene subliminal message about Grade.

At the channel's new season launch yesterday, Mr Gardam revealed plans to screen a series in which the award-winning Guardian journalist, Nick Davies, will explore the "drugs of choice" in club culture. Davies will present an argument for decriminalisation of heroin. "I want to make programming tougher and edgier," Mr Gardam said. "Times are changing, there's a lot of frustration and suspicion and we've got to reflect that and be more edgy and disruptive. I'm going to clear slots for that.

"The riots in Seattle and what's happening in the countryside show that something is afoot and I don't think TV is picking up on that."

Channel 4 plans to screen a second version of Big Brother this summer. A number of changes are planned, and executives are discussing ways of making the series more interactive.

One option is to clear the schedules of the broadcaster's digital entertainment channel E4, to allow 24-hour coverage of the 10 participants in the Big Brother house.

Mr Gardam announced a joint venture with the Irish broadcaster RTE to screen all 19 of Samuel Beckett's plays, starting with Waiting for Godot.

The season, which will span two years, includes the final performance by Sir John Gielgud, who died last year, in Beckett's short play Catastrophe.

There is also a new game show: Lost will follow teams of two contestants who are dropped in remote locations overseas and are expected to use their ingenuity to find their way back to Trafalgar Square in London on a budget of just £100.

Royalty and the Ashes

Arts

After criticism that Channel 4 had abandoned the arts in the winter season, music and theatre feature strongly in the spring and summer offerings, with the Beckett season, a documentary on Miles Davis, and Hello Culture - a series on cultural trends.

Drama

There is new drama with Men Only, in which a group of friends graduate from a weekly football date to lap-dancing bars, class A drugs and violent crime in the pursuit of pleasure.

Royal wedding

There is a season of shows to mark the 20th anniversary of the wedding between the Prince and Princess of Wales - Royals and Riots will contrast the celebrations with the summer of social unrest in 1981.

Documentary

Channel 4 also presents Hitler's Holocaust, with German film-makers examining the horrors of their country's recent history. The documentary series has been produced under the guidance of Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal.

The Ashes

The station will build on its innovative cricket coverage with the "hawkeye" device which will detect LBWs and tracks the flight and speed of the ball. It will make its debut in the summer's Ashes series.

Comedy

Channel 4 staples Ali G, Trigger Happy TV, Friends, and Ally McBeal return - with new comedy from Armando Iannucci, the spoof Japanese game show Banzai, and a new show from the makers of Smack the Pony.

fields.headline: Advertising downturn bites at Capital
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Capital Radio yesterday became the latest casualty of the downturn in advertising when its shares fell by 24% on a warning that growth in revenues had ground to a halt in the past two months.
fields.body:
Capital Radio yesterday became the latest casualty of the downturn in advertising when its shares fell by 24% on a warning that growth in revenues had ground to a halt in the past two months.

Unless conditions improve the radio group's full-year profits are likely to be 10% lower than last year, the company said in a statement.

Advertising growth across the first half to the end of March will be 2% ahead of last year, compared with a forecast of 4% in December.

But Capital chief executive David Mansfield said revenues had worsened during February and March, with growth falling away to nothing.

The warning continued a bruising week for Capital which saw its share price hit on Monday by a downgrade from the investment bank UBS Warburg. The price fell 212.5p yesterday to 665p, bringing the total decline since the beginning of the week to almost 37%. The shares are at a two-year low.

Evidence of a sharper slowdown in the advertising market than analysts had forecast is now inescapable.

RTL, Europe's largest commercial television and radio group, similarly warned earlier this week that full-year earnings would be flat. RTL shares fell a further 9% yesterday in Brussels.

The Capital statement dragged other radio stocks down in its wake. GWR fell 16% to 422.5p and Chrysalis dropped 11% to 259p.

Mr Mansfield said it was "very difficult" to predict what would happen to the advertising market this year. He has, he added, lived through these conditions before.

"Advertising is a cyclical business and we will come out the other side. The markets are hugely sensitive at the moment and there's nothing we can do about that.

"We have arguably the best portfolio of analogue radio stations, we are a very focused company with great brands and a strong management team. The growth will come back."

The group's London stations have suffered most severely after taking a large chunk of the dot.com and telecoms adver tising which accounted for rapid growth last year and has fallen away in 2001.

Revenues including acquisitions for the first half are likely to be 8% higher.

Analysts have downgraded their full-year profit forecasts from around £40m to a range of £34m-£36m.

The UBS Warburg note changed its recommendation from "reduce" to "sell". The note said Capital's maturing portfolio of assets set the com pany apart from other, younger radio businesses and suggested it no longer warranted a similar valuation.

It noted that the uncertainties still surrounding ownership restrictions in Britain and the problems faced by potential international suitors such as RTL meant there was little chance of Capital playing a part in industry consolidation.

"Investors need to differentiate between winners and losers in this sector," said Warburg media analyst Simon Mays-Smith. "Things are tough for Capital. They have lost their highly rated paper and are restricted from buying anything by regulators.

"But there is a broader issue here, facing all of the large established broadcasters in Europe, of a fragmenting market which is impacting on audiences and market shares. That's why some of the younger, growing media groups are more attractive."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: And so to the UK Press Gazette awards, held on Wednesday night at the Park Lane Hilton, and an evening whose wretchedness can best be gauged by the fact that rightwing comedian Jim Davidson emerged as the unlikely victim.
fields.body:
 And so to the UK Press Gazette awards, held on Wednesday night at the Park Lane Hilton, and an evening whose wretchedness can best be gauged by the fact that rightwing comedian Jim Davidson emerged as the unlikely victim.

Barely had Jim settled down to enjoy a quiet Campari with a lady friend in one of the hotel's bars when a contingent of Mirror journalists burst in to get an early start on the drinks. "I don't believe this," said Jim, recognising them."How many more of you are there?" The reply "About a thousand, Jim" elicited the sort of look normally reserved for the most backward of Generation Game contestants, but what a credit to Jim's showman credentials that he turned the situation into the sort of pantomime of which he is so fond.

Forcing his companion into a passionate clinch, he announced, "Ladies and gentlemen of the press, I think the game's up. Meet my new mystery girlfriend. Thank you, and goodnight."

 Hapless victim number two was surely Rick Brooks, the Metro cartoonist told by at least 500 hacks that he must be alopecian's Sun editor's long lost twin. Also popular was the theory that News International executives had positioned Saddam style lookalikes round the room in order to deflect unwanted attention from the real David Yelland. As for the tumbleweed spotted blowing across the acres of tables taken by David when Newspaper of the Year went to the Mail - well, we'd better draw a line under the whole sorry business.

 Good news for Matthew Norman, though, who found himself feted by paparazzo-turned-Express Newspapers' editorial director Jason Fraser. "You write very well," purred our long-lensed friend. High praise indeed. "But you're wasted at the Guardian. Why don't you come and work for me?" He's right of course - how much better Matthew's talents would be suited to filing picture captions to accompany fuzzy snaps of beached celebrities than the meaningless toil which currently sustains him. Will he put the Guardian "at a respectful distance"? We'll see, we'll see.

 On balance, the rest of the evening is best not brought to a wider audience. Although I fear it might be.

 Max Clifford is in touch to point out that the Max Clifford whose public relations skills we called into question after he sent the Diary a cut price holiday offer for its "Late Availability column" is in fact, not him. Unusually for us, it's not an out-and-out cock-up, for the Max Clifford in question is in fact Max 1's nephew. And idle chat with Max 1 unearths the curiosity that his Uncle Norman also named his son after the PR maestro, bringing the grand total of Maxes in this branch of the Clifford family to three. Chuckles about a little tribe of Cliffords all named after their shaman-like relative lead us seamlessly into Max's final thought. "Perhaps when you clarify it you could mention Saffron Travel, my nephew's company...?" he muses. "Only if you can." Max, Max, how could I ever have doubted you?

 Press agent Jonathan Theobald calls. "I've just received a press release which I was going to stick straight in the bin," he begins, "But then I thought of you." You're very kind, Jonathan. Still, the offending article has made it so your assessment of this column as a repository for items not fit for the rubbish can't have been too wide of the mark. "For every bottle of Inis cologne sold in the UK, £1 is being donated to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society," it proclaims."And as a special token for Mother's Day, Inis is kindly offering to give away an Inis T-shirt, a 100ml bottle of Inis cologne, and a 'Seven Surfing Dolphins' poster to all editors who include this special story for Mother's Day in their news sections." Normal Guardian address, then, you big-hearted lot, and we shall pass your wares on to the boss.

fields.headline: Tales of the Oscars
fields.standfirst: Why are soft poached eggs and toast so important to Geoffrey Rush? What made Michael Caine crack up? Why does Angelina Jolie have a gothic-looking stand-in? As the film world prepares for the most celebrated awards on earth, Guardian film writers ask past nominees and winners what the ceremony meant to them
fields.trailText: Why are soft poached eggs and toast so important to Geoffrey Rush? What made Michael Caine crack up? Why does Angelina Jolie have a gothic-looking stand-in? As the film world prepares for the most celebrated awards on earth, Guardian film writers ask past nominees and winners what the ceremony meant to them.
fields.byline: Mari Cartel, Will Hodgkinson, Stuart Husband, Matt Keating and Gary Susman
fields.body:
Geoffrey Rush

 Won best actor for Shine in 1997, nominated best actor this year for Quills

Inevitably, I was flying completely blind. But somewhere in the back of my head there was the absurd notion that, should my name be called, I'd know what to do because I've seen people do it from childhood onward. There are those almost mental, Arthur Murray-type dance steps that say: "Walk up that staircase, go to the middle, turn to face front." So somehow, you get to do that.

That was the year that independent film was knocking very loudly at the mainstream door. The Elton John Aids benefit bash afterwards was a great place to be because it was in honour of all the independent films. So there was a lot to celebrate. This year, Giorgio Armani has kindly offered to prepare something.

It's a huge event, so that's always nerve-wracking, exciting and bewildering. But I have no anticipation about getting it. It's a cliche to say it's an honour to be nominated - and there are 10 or 20 other performances that should have been in there. People will go into an outrage and a tailspin that their favorites aren't. But the nominations are a good cross-section of what's out there in movieland at the moment. If I've learned anything, having been there twice before and presenting one year, it's to have a couple of soft, poached eggs with a bit of toast at about 2pm because you're not going to get anything in your stomach until about 10.

That's a practical tip - if anyone ever wants to write the book What to Do on Oscar Morning.

Timothy Everest

 Tom Cruise's tailor

Lauren Scott, who looks after Tom Cruise, was appointed Oscars 2000 style director, vetting the clothes of everyone onstage. She asked me to assist. So a week later I was in LA, heading to the ceremony, but I missed my driver and couldn't get anywhere near the Shrine because of the police and security and the fact that my Access All Areas pass had expired at 1pm. My afternoon and evening passes were in our limo. So I was running down the road in black tie looking for the car, which was stuck in the limo-lock, but each time I got near, it pulled another 20 yards further forward. It was like running for a bus. I eventually jumped in just as it was pulling up to the entrance and almost immediately had to get out the other side, red-faced and sweating.

We came out on to the red carpet and I did the whole Ronald Reagan thing, saluting and pointing to strangers in the crowd and waving while they all tried to work out who I was. The red carpet is actually really tatty and should probably have been thrown out years ago.

The first thing I noticed in the auditorium was that they have all these lookalike seat-filler stand-ins in case someone gets up to receive an award or have a pee or something. I was sitting behind Angelina Jolie and her brother - and they had a gothic-looking stand-in for her and a peroxided double-pierced-ear stand-in for him. I had to keep running out the back and checking clothes and it was like Gerry Cottle's circus. Everyone has their own caravan and some had filled them with flowers and fruit; others just had gigantic bowls of M&Ms. During the commercial breaks everyone just gets up and starts networking. The front row is where the main action is. Clint Eastwood was chatting to Tom Cruise, and Billy Crystal was trying to calm Jack Nicholson down. He's shouting "Billy, I love you!" and turning to Erykah Badu behind and going "I love your headdress!" and Billy's saying "I love you too, Jack, but please sit down 'cos we're coming back live in 10, 9, 8 ..."

It's not really a feverish atmosphere; everyone's trying to be very controlled. It's more like a glammed-up works outing. At the Vanity Fair party after, you have these fans checking people off as they go in the door, shouting "Val!" and ticking his name off as he waves and goes in, then "Jude!" then "Ethan!" then "Uma!" It's like trainspotting. They all wind up early and I suppose everyone then goes home and has a cup of cocoa. It was a very surreal experience.

Tom Hanks

 Won best actor for Philadelphia in 1994 and for Forrest Gump in 1995. Nominated best actor for Big in 1989 and Saving Private Ryan in 1999. Nominated this year for Cast Away

My joke the first time I won was that if you're nominated and you don't win, everybody forgets it after a week; if you're nominated and you win, everybody pretty much forgets it after two weeks. I don't think about it any more. We all do it because we love movies and because it's our job and it's also one of the barometers for how you're doing. It's like having a baby. The day you have a baby it's just the greatest thing in the world. Well, the next day you have this baby to take care of and you have the memory of that baby coming out, but other than that, now you're into the nuts and bolts of that one damn thing after another that life seems to be and that's what this is.

The day itself is a very personal experience because the family is supercharged, people are stopping by. It's like a wedding. There's a spirit of excitement that lasts about 18 hours and you're exhausted at the end of it. I'm lucky enough to be able to say you're exhausted whether you win or lose. My attention is so splayed in the course of the day that I don't remember what I do from one minute to the next.

I don't think it's possible to stick to a prepared script. I always have five things to say and I always screw up one of them, and forget another one completely and then replace the other three with other things that entered my head at the last moment. So, it's not something you can control. It's like suddenly jumping out of an airplane.

Billy Crystal

 Host in 1990-93, 1997-8, 2000

The third year I was presenting was perfect for me, what with Jack Palance winning. I tell you, it was the greatest running gag in the history of the Oscars.

When Jack won, I came back on and said: "Jack's now on a Stairmaster backstage - he may enter the Iron Man competition." Then I said: "We'll keep you posted." That's when the light really went on. We went to commercial and I said to the two or three writers backstage: "We're going to run with this. Next time I come out, what will I tell them he's done?" We started pitching lines. When I came back out of commercial break, I said: "Jack Palance just bungee-jumped off the Hollywood sign." The audience went nuts. The next time I came on was after a big production number with 50 kids from the film Hook. I turned to the audience and said: "You know, Jack's the father of all of these children." And I just kept running it the whole night, right until I said: "I won't be your host next year, it'll be Jack Palance. Goodnight."

The other moment I would pick out was when Hal Roach didn't have the microphone on and the show stopped dead. It looked like he was talking to nobody. I said: "Well, it's appropriate because he got his start in silent films." And the place went nuts. At that point, I was really a good comedian, as good as I've ever been. I saved the moment. If I never do any stand-up again, that moment, that little millisecond of that moment, is like a great thing and I felt great about it.

I needed to stop presenting the Oscars. I was burnt out on doing award shows. So I stayed home, a guy brought a pizza over, and I watched it and said what everybody who watches the Oscars says: "Why is this so long?"

Angelina Jolie

 Won best supporting actress for Girl, Interrupted in 2000

My dad [Jon Voight] kept his Oscar in a goldfish bowl on his mother's mantel piece in New York. I've never held it. I grew up thinking it was just this strange thing in grandma's house.

My parents came over to the hotel when I was getting ready [for last year's ceremony]. They both surprised me and brought gifts. My dad gave me something from my whole family that said: "We love you and we're proud of you." That's all that mattered. There are other actors and actresses that I admire so much and I'm so happy to be in a room with them. That they would think it was OK to put me on stage for a minute is, you know, I just feel like, you know, those moments where you feel OK. It's like you may be living your life right, you know.

I really didn't expect [to win]. We grew up in this business and, you know, dad has an Oscar and it's like the big thing you try to attain as an actor. We've always watched it and so we both were sitting there and I think we were both going: "Can you believe we're here and they let us in?" I don't think he could really move. He stayed in his seat.

Jenny Shircore

 Make-up artist who won an Oscar for Elizabeth in 1999

On the day of the Oscars, I woke up with a very bad hangover. Our lot got round the pool at the Four Seasons and had breakfast. Everybody stays there. I remember seeing Andie MacDowell. Then you go and get some free sunglasses. Calvin Klein or somebody like that gives them to you so you're seen walking in with them on. The limos arrive - each nominee has one - at about four, and it takes ages to get to the place because there are about 2,000 limos. But it's OK because you get a bottle of champagne in the limo.

The whole thing takes about four or five hours and it's great fun. Whoopi Goldberg was very entertaining. But the strange thing was, when we got to the auditorium, I saw a crowd of people waiting outside. I imagined that they were waiting for free tickets. But, in fact, if you leave your seat at any time, immediately it's filled by one of these people, so the camera never passes an empty seat. You come back from the loo and find someone in your seat.

People tend to keep their speeches short, but Gwyneth Paltrow went on and on and on. She thanked her parents, her brother, her grandparents, her great-grandparents, everyone. Cate Blanchett looked the most wonderful - I really think she should have won best actress for Elizabeth. The amazing thing is that everybody wants to hold the Oscar - people grab you in the street and have their photograph taken with it.

Jack Nicholson

 Won best actor for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in 1976 and As Good as It Gets in 1998. Won best supporting actor for Terms of Endearment in 1984. Has been nominated on eight other occasions

I dropped about three quarts of water the minute they said my name. Up until then I was numb, very nervous. Usually I just come out because I like seeing movie stars, having a good time and all that, but I was real nervous.

I find it a little bit strange. I'm looking around at stars, like you are, and I feel almost like I shouldn't be here. You know, when I saw my picture come up on the television set, I was kind of shocked. I looked real on there.

Having a career that covers three decades is nice. Won one in the 70s, one in the 80s, and one the 90s. I'm really happy. You know, one of the things I meant to say in my speech was if you have young children, you always wish they get to see you do something big, you know. So I know they were sitting home having a ball. They don't know the difference between this and bowling, but they know dad won and that was great for me.

All comparisons are odious, as my mother told me. I always have a good time working. I suppose those of you who know anything about me know I've always worked with good directors. I choose material well and after that I think I'm lucky."

Freddie Francis

 Cinematographer who won Oscars for Sons and Lovers in 1961 and Glory in 1990. He is the only person in history to win Oscars for a B&W and colour film

The first time I won an Oscar, they didn't send lowly people like cinematographers out there. So, as I was working at the time, I didn't go. It came slightly out of the blue as well. I read that I was nominated in American Cinematographer magazine, then they notified me.

With Glory, the company looked after me royally - limousines pick you up to take you to the awards ceremony, and people are always giving lunches and dinners and you're invited to them in the meantime. It's really like showbusiness should be. The ceremony itself seems to go on for ever, although I must say it's a very exciting ceremony - by the time I got the second Oscar I'd been in the business a hell of a long time, but I was still excited to be there. If I said everybody was there, I'd be right. The terrible thing is I can't remember offhand who even presented it.

I've been in movies since I left school, but once you're at the Oscars, you feel that the whole thing has been worthwhile. You feel that you're equal to the rest of them - mind you, I'd always thought that. It's instilled into you not to say too much, and there's very little you can say, really. Some people go through a list saying I want to thank this and that, which is nonsense, because if you're serious about it you've won it with your own talent.

It's like going to the theatre - all the seats are allocated, and you just sit down and have a pleasant evening. It was getting on a bit by the time it was over, and I think we just went to bed. Obviously, you stand around for a while and people come up and admire the statuette, but other than that, I didn't do anything afterwards. Lots of people go off to party, but I'm not a party bird really, so I had a few pleasant conversations and went to bed.

Michael Caine

 Won best supporting actor for Hannah and Her Sisters in 1987 and The Cider House Rules in 2000. Nominated best actor for Alfie in 1967, Sleuth in 1973 and Educating Rita in 1984

It is very, very, very nerve-wracking. I thought that every single person in my category could have won. So I didn't feel that there was any real winner, I was just there to collect it for all of us. I'm a survivor, that's why they gave it to me. I'm still here after all these years.

When you see all the performances on the enormous screen in there, it's quite astonishing. We were all just as good as each other, so why should one of us win? I pointed out that they don't say "The winner is ..." any more. They say "The Oscar goes to ..." and that was when I decided. I turned around and saw Michael [Clarke Duncan] and Tom [Cruise], then I saw little Haley [Joel Osment] and I didn't know where Jude Law was sitting - and I thought: "This can't go by without mentioning their performances." So I did.

I went up the steps and turned. That's when I sort of went. The standing ovation threw me, 'cos it's not something you expect. I could hardly believe it. I'm very difficult to throw and they did it. To be held in such regard in a town so full of talent is an incredible compliment.

I thought [Billy Crystal's tribute] was wonderful. He sang that song and had everybody going: "Caine!" I thought: "This is the cream of Hollywood here, singing my name!" I mean, I thought: "It's OK if I don't win, you know, it's OK, it's OK." But it's not OK, I won. I didn't win. See, you say win. Even I'm doing it.

Rachel Portman

 Composer who won for Emma in 1997, was nominated for The Cider House Rules in 2000 and Chocolat this year

You have to drive about 10 miles and it takes two hours, then you hang around, and the whole thing starts at around 5.30 and ends about 10. Then you go to the ball, then you start going off to all the parties. It's funny - if you've won you get this elation, but of course four-fifths of all the people at the parties haven't won. You can't pretend that it isn't nice to have won. On the one hand it doesn't mean anything, on the other it means a lot. It's the only event in which you're nominated by your peers, after all.

People do let their hair down and enjoy themselves at the parties, and you're bound to see massively famous actors which is quite fun too. The parties aren't particularly cliquey, although some are harder to get into than others. The most extraordinary aspect of the whole thing is that there is such a big build-up, and then it's over in a flash, completely forgotten, and everything goes back to normal.

I was glad Michael Caine won best actor last year, but it was annoying: if you go to the bathroom you aren't allowed back to your seat until the commercial break, and while I was gone I missed three in a row, including his. The corridors outside are full of people not allowed to go back to their seat. The acceptance speeches are the most entertaining part, but they're very strict now about how much time you've got. When I went up there, the minute I started talking I was aware of this man in my sightline, looking at me and waving, saying: "10, 9, 8, 7 ..."

But nobody pays much notice. The guy who won best supporting actor for Jerry Maguire - Cuba Gooding Jr - went on and on and on, started jumping up and down, and was a real star. He was genuinely, really thrilled.

People wear the most extraordinary things - spray-on dresses. Julia Roberts stood out for having so much grace and style, but what most people wear is fascinating rather than beautiful. The Oscars couldn't be more glamorous. I'm taking my sister this year, who lives a very quiet life up in Scotland and she can't believe it. I think it's more exciting for her than it is for me.

Martin Childs

 Art director, won an Oscar for Shakespeare in Love in 1999 and is nominated for Quills this year

The day starts with a nervous breakfast around the pool as soon as the LA Times comes out, which has predictions of who will win the awards. It was a surprise that Shakespeare in Love was top - we all thought it was going to be Saving Private Ryan. Then I realised that I was the favourite. Up until then I had no idea.

The limo turns up filled with champagne at about 3.30. When we got in we realised that the driver didn't know her way around LA so we arrived very late. We were quite literally locked out. Luckily Judi Dench was in the car with us and they recognised her. So we said, "We're nominees too!" and managed to get in. If you watch the video you can see these people quietly stomping over to their seats with bended knees just as James Coburn is announced as best supporting actor. Then within five minutes someone came up to me and said: "Are you Martin Childs? You're up next."

Before I knew it I was doing my acceptance speech, nervous as a cat, and this huge monitor in front of me said "Wrap up" almost as soon as I'd begun. You don't think about the millions of people looking at you, but you do look down to see Warren Beatty and Annette Bening lightly clapping a few feet away. Then you have to go up to a room to talk to the press, who make it very clear that they'd rather be talking to a big star and not some speccy bloke from England who's won an award for drawing some pictures.

The year I went, there were all these people with banners outside protesting against Elia Kazan getting a lifetime achievement award because of his involvement with the House Un-American Activities Committee. Then when he went up to collect it, Susan Sarandon and Ed Harris pointedly didn't applaud. It was very silly - just because he did a bad thing it doesn't meant that his films weren't good. I did the British thing and clapped politely while hiding behind a chair, just in case Susan Sarandon saw me.

I also remember Sophia Loren looking absolutely stunning. This year I hope Penelope Cruz will be there - she's already won for most glamorous actress as far as I'm concerned. After the Governor's Ball we went to the Miramax party, which is a legendary one. There was no getting out of it for me, considering I had won an award for Shakespeare in Love [a Miramax production]. This year I probably won't be invited to anything.

Stephen Frears

 Nominated as best director for The Grifters in 1991

They go on for hours. You get dressed up at three o'clock in the afternoon so you feel like a waiter shortly after lunch. Ten years ago, people didn't get as excited about these things as they do now - I got home one day and there were a lot of messages on the phone from people congratulating me on my nomination. I didn't even know I was up for it. Nowadays people go out and campaign to win but I was actually in California at the time preparing Accidental Hero for Columbia studios.

The night before the Oscars I was told that with The Grifters I'd won a prize for best independent film of the year. I said: "I see the prize for best independent film is that you get to give up your independence." There's an enormous traffic jam while long cars filled with famous people inch down the spider's web to a building in Los Angeles. Once you are inside you soon discover that you can go to the bar with impunity because people fill your seat if you leave it empty.

I don't remember anyone making spectacular idiots of themselves. Joe Pesci won a prize that year and his acceptance speech was: "Thank you very much. I'm honoured." Hats off for brevity. It's changed because the British press have got over-excited about the whole event but it's only jerks like me who are the voters. Pauline Collins was funny. She said: "I'm only here for the beer." And Danny Boyle came out and said: "We wuz robbed."

Kevin Costner had won as best director for Dances With Wolves the year I went, beating Scorsese, who was there with GoodFellas. Scorsese was sitting there very depressed and I remember saying to him: "Surely you knew that you weren't going to win." When Billy Wilder won the second of the three Oscars he won for The Apartment, Moss Hart handed him the trophy saying: "Quit while you're ahead." And it was good advice; that was the peak of Wilder's career.

I imagine it's always a cruel evening. Afterwards there's a do called the Governor's Ball, then a lot of famous people hang around, waiting for their limos to be brought. That year it was raining.

Russell Crowe

 Nominated best actor for The Insider in 2000 and this year for Gladiator

It's great, man, what can I say? It's the highest acknowledgement in my profession. So, I don't have any glib lines about it. I'm not cynical about it at all. I was blown away last year and this year even more so. I don't have the time, funnily enough, to kind of come in and really enjoy the process of it because I always seem to be working. But maybe that's actually a good thing. The food's not as fancy as my mum's cooking, mate. She's a damn fine cook. She was a caterer for film and TV shows from the late 60s for about six or seven years and, in 1969, we had bean curd, which is tofu, in the refrigerator and I was the only kid that had that. I couldn't eat it, but we had it.

Alisandra M Rand

 Producer/writer, Fast Track Pictures; 1994 Oscar attendee

I was invited by a friend. Actually I forced him (and it wasn't so easy) to take me, his friend, rather than use it as a way to get laid on some hot date. I wore a black sequinned dress, a flapper dress. The one formal dress I'd brought from Boston because as mom said: "You just never know." And this time she was right.

I ran to the guy who cuts my hair, a crazy Frenchman, Didier, who's got a shop on Main Street in Santa Monica called Scissors. He gave me big hair, even though he told me it was out that year. Of course that just added to my jitters. And he did my make-up. Even gave me a lipstick.

I'll never forget being all dressed up in the middle of the afternoon in that crazy southern California heat, trying to get close to the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in a borrowed convertible with all the fans flocking to catch a glimpse of the stars. And the red carpet - my God! This was before I'd been to a million and one premieres. I was still a grad student for Christ's sake, and though I was embarrassed to admit it, at the time, I'd probably only seen the show once on TV. The red carpet was pretty overwhelming.

Everywhere, I looked there was someone famous. Funny thing about famous people - you have the same reaction you do to people you haven't seen since high school. You're excited to see them, and then you think: "Huh, do I really have anything to say to them?" And then you follow the code - give them their space, pretend they're just normal people dressed up for the opera - and kick yourself later for not having thought of something clever to say because, had you introduced yourself, who knows, maybe you would have made it in Hollywood.

The only thing I really remember about the show itself was running back and forth to the bar, hanging out with the celebrities, having drinks, because, trust me, everyone was bored. It's endless. We weren't, of course, invited to the fancy schmancy ball afterwards. And, though we've since gotten pretty good at getting into parties we have no business being at, that was a bit too intimidating even for us. We went to Le Dome, a famous old bar on Sunset, and watched the after parties on TV, just like everybody else.

And after the event, we actually talked to a little-known kid named Leo DiCaprio, who had just been nominated for his performance in What's Eating Gilbert Grape. We told him how impressed we'd been with his work. He told us this was a dream for him, too. He grew up in the area, and Oscar day was always a little like a snow day; everything shut down. He used to watch the limousines pull up to the Oscars, and now he was in one of them.

It's funny to think about now. He wasn't big enough then to keep us from keeping protocol and giving him space. Now we couldn't get near him.
fields.bodyText: Geoffrey Rush  Won best actor for Shine in 1997, nominated best actor this year for Quills Inevitably, I was flying completely blind. But somewhere in the back of my head there was the absurd notion that, should my name be called, I'd know what to do because I've seen people do it from childhood onward. There are those almost mental, Arthur Murray-type dance steps that say: "Walk up that staircase, go to the middle, turn to face front." So somehow, you get to do that. That was the year that independent film was knocking very loudly at the mainstream door. The Elton John Aids benefit bash afterwards was a great place to be because it was in honour of all the independent films. So there was a lot to celebrate. This year, Giorgio Armani has kindly offered to prepare something. It's a huge event, so that's always nerve-wracking, exciting and bewildering. But I have no anticipation about getting it. It's a cliche to say it's an honour to be nominated - and there are 10 or 20 other performances that should have been in there. People will go into an outrage and a tailspin that their favorites aren't. But the nominations are a good cross-section of what's out there in movieland at the moment. If I've learned anything, having been there twice before and presenting one year, it's to have a couple of soft, poached eggs with a bit of toast at about 2pm because you're not going to get anything in your stomach until about 10. That's a practical tip - if anyone ever wants to write the book What to Do on Oscar Morning. Timothy Everest  Tom Cruise's tailor Lauren Scott, who looks after Tom Cruise, was appointed Oscars 2000 style director, vetting the clothes of everyone onstage. She asked me to assist. So a week later I was in LA, heading to the ceremony, but I missed my driver and couldn't get anywhere near the Shrine because of the police and security and the fact that my Access All Areas pass had expired at 1pm. My afternoon and evening passes were in our limo. So I was running down the road in black tie looking for the car, which was stuck in the limo-lock, but each time I got near, it pulled another 20 yards further forward. It was like running for a bus. I eventually jumped in just as it was pulling up to the entrance and almost immediately had to get out the other side, red-faced and sweating. We came out on to the red carpet and I did the whole Ronald Reagan thing, saluting and pointing to strangers in the crowd and waving while they all tried to work out who I was. The red carpet is actually really tatty and should probably have been thrown out years ago. The first thing I noticed in the auditorium was that they have all these lookalike seat-filler stand-ins in case someone gets up to receive an award or have a pee or something. I was sitting behind Angelina Jolie and her brother - and they had a gothic-looking stand-in for her and a peroxided double-pierced-ear stand-in for him. I had to keep running out the back and checking clothes and it was like Gerry Cottle's circus. Everyone has their own caravan and some had filled them with flowers and fruit; others just had gigantic bowls of M&Ms. During the commercial breaks everyone just gets up and starts networking. The front row is where the main action is. Clint Eastwood was chatting to Tom Cruise, and Billy Crystal was trying to calm Jack Nicholson down. He's shouting "Billy, I love you!" and turning to Erykah Badu behind and going "I love your headdress!" and Billy's saying "I love you too, Jack, but please sit down 'cos we're coming back live in 10, 9, 8 ..." It's not really a feverish atmosphere; everyone's trying to be very controlled. It's more like a glammed-up works outing. At the Vanity Fair party after, you have these fans checking people off as they go in the door, shouting "Val!" and ticking his name off as he waves and goes in, then "Jude!" then "Ethan!" then "Uma!" It's like trainspotting. They all wind up early and I suppose everyone then goes home and has a cup of cocoa. It was a very surreal experience. Tom Hanks  Won best actor for Philadelphia in 1994 and for Forrest Gump in 1995. Nominated best actor for Big in 1989 and Saving Private Ryan in 1999. Nominated this year for Cast Away My joke the first time I won was that if you're nominated and you don't win, everybody forgets it after a week; if you're nominated and you win, everybody pretty much forgets it after two weeks. I don't think about it any more. We all do it because we love movies and because it's our job and it's also one of the barometers for how you're doing. It's like having a baby. The day you have a baby it's just the greatest thing in the world. Well, the next day you have this baby to take care of and you have the memory of that baby coming out, but other than that, now you're into the nuts and bolts of that one damn thing after another that life seems to be and that's what this is. The day itself is a very personal experience because the family is supercharged, people are stopping by. It's like a wedding. There's a spirit of excitement that lasts about 18 hours and you're exhausted at the end of it. I'm lucky enough to be able to say you're exhausted whether you win or lose. My attention is so splayed in the course of the day that I don't remember what I do from one minute to the next. I don't think it's possible to stick to a prepared script. I always have five things to say and I always screw up one of them, and forget another one completely and then replace the other three with other things that entered my head at the last moment. So, it's not something you can control. It's like suddenly jumping out of an airplane. Billy Crystal  Host in 1990-93, 1997-8, 2000 The third year I was presenting was perfect for me, what with Jack Palance winning. I tell you, it was the greatest running gag in the history of the Oscars. When Jack won, I came back on and said: "Jack's now on a Stairmaster backstage - he may enter the Iron Man competition." Then I said: "We'll keep you posted." That's when the light really went on. We went to commercial and I said to the two or three writers backstage: "We're going to run with this. Next time I come out, what will I tell them he's done?" We started pitching lines. When I came back out of commercial break, I said: "Jack Palance just bungee-jumped off the Hollywood sign." The audience went nuts. The next time I came on was after a big production number with 50 kids from the film Hook. I turned to the audience and said: "You know, Jack's the father of all of these children." And I just kept running it the whole night, right until I said: "I won't be your host next year, it'll be Jack Palance. Goodnight." The other moment I would pick out was when Hal Roach didn't have the microphone on and the show stopped dead. It looked like he was talking to nobody. I said: "Well, it's appropriate because he got his start in silent films." And the place went nuts. At that point, I was really a good comedian, as good as I've ever been. I saved the moment. If I never do any stand-up again, that moment, that little millisecond of that moment, is like a great thing and I felt great about it. I needed to stop presenting the Oscars. I was burnt out on doing award shows. So I stayed home, a guy brought a pizza over, and I watched it and said what everybody who watches the Oscars says: "Why is this so long?" Angelina Jolie  Won best supporting actress for Girl, Interrupted in 2000 My dad [Jon Voight] kept his Oscar in a goldfish bowl on his mother's mantel piece in New York. I've never held it. I grew up thinking it was just this strange thing in grandma's house. My parents came over to the hotel when I was getting ready [for last year's ceremony]. They both surprised me and brought gifts. My dad gave me something from my whole family that said: "We love you and we're proud of you." That's all that mattered. There are other actors and actresses that I admire so much and I'm so happy to be in a room with them. That they would think it was OK to put me on stage for a minute is, you know, I just feel like, you know, those moments where you feel OK. It's like you may be living your life right, you know. I really didn't expect [to win]. We grew up in this business and, you know, dad has an Oscar and it's like the big thing you try to attain as an actor. We've always watched it and so we both were sitting there and I think we were both going: "Can you believe we're here and they let us in?" I don't think he could really move. He stayed in his seat. Jenny Shircore  Make-up artist who won an Oscar for Elizabeth in 1999 On the day of the Oscars, I woke up with a very bad hangover. Our lot got round the pool at the Four Seasons and had breakfast. Everybody stays there. I remember seeing Andie MacDowell. Then you go and get some free sunglasses. Calvin Klein or somebody like that gives them to you so you're seen walking in with them on. The limos arrive - each nominee has one - at about four, and it takes ages to get to the place because there are about 2,000 limos. But it's OK because you get a bottle of champagne in the limo. The whole thing takes about four or five hours and it's great fun. Whoopi Goldberg was very entertaining. But the strange thing was, when we got to the auditorium, I saw a crowd of people waiting outside. I imagined that they were waiting for free tickets. But, in fact, if you leave your seat at any time, immediately it's filled by one of these people, so the camera never passes an empty seat. You come back from the loo and find someone in your seat. People tend to keep their speeches short, but Gwyneth Paltrow went on and on and on. She thanked her parents, her brother, her grandparents, her great-grandparents, everyone. Cate Blanchett looked the most wonderful - I really think she should have won best actress for Elizabeth. The amazing thing is that everybody wants to hold the Oscar - people grab you in the street and have their photograph taken with it. Jack Nicholson  Won best actor for One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in 1976 and As Good as It Gets in 1998. Won best supporting actor for Terms of Endearment in 1984. Has been nominated on eight other occasions I dropped about three quarts of water the minute they said my name. Up until then I was numb, very nervous. Usually I just come out because I like seeing movie stars, having a good time and all that, but I was real nervous. I find it a little bit strange. I'm looking around at stars, like you are, and I feel almost like I shouldn't be here. You know, when I saw my picture come up on the television set, I was kind of shocked. I looked real on there. Having a career that covers three decades is nice. Won one in the 70s, one in the 80s, and one the 90s. I'm really happy. You know, one of the things I meant to say in my speech was if you have young children, you always wish they get to see you do something big, you know. So I know they were sitting home having a ball. They don't know the difference between this and bowling, but they know dad won and that was great for me. All comparisons are odious, as my mother told me. I always have a good time working. I suppose those of you who know anything about me know I've always worked with good directors. I choose material well and after that I think I'm lucky." Freddie Francis  Cinematographer who won Oscars for Sons and Lovers in 1961 and Glory in 1990. He is the only person in history to win Oscars for a B&W and colour film The first time I won an Oscar, they didn't send lowly people like cinematographers out there. So, as I was working at the time, I didn't go. It came slightly out of the blue as well. I read that I was nominated in American Cinematographer magazine, then they notified me. With Glory, the company looked after me royally - limousines pick you up to take you to the awards ceremony, and people are always giving lunches and dinners and you're invited to them in the meantime. It's really like showbusiness should be. The ceremony itself seems to go on for ever, although I must say it's a very exciting ceremony - by the time I got the second Oscar I'd been in the business a hell of a long time, but I was still excited to be there. If I said everybody was there, I'd be right. The terrible thing is I can't remember offhand who even presented it. I've been in movies since I left school, but once you're at the Oscars, you feel that the whole thing has been worthwhile. You feel that you're equal to the rest of them - mind you, I'd always thought that. It's instilled into you not to say too much, and there's very little you can say, really. Some people go through a list saying I want to thank this and that, which is nonsense, because if you're serious about it you've won it with your own talent. It's like going to the theatre - all the seats are allocated, and you just sit down and have a pleasant evening. It was getting on a bit by the time it was over, and I think we just went to bed. Obviously, you stand around for a while and people come up and admire the statuette, but other than that, I didn't do anything afterwards. Lots of people go off to party, but I'm not a party bird really, so I had a few pleasant conversations and went to bed. Michael Caine  Won best supporting actor for Hannah and Her Sisters in 1987 and The Cider House Rules in 2000. Nominated best actor for Alfie in 1967, Sleuth in 1973 and Educating Rita in 1984 It is very, very, very nerve-wracking. I thought that every single person in my category could have won. So I didn't feel that there was any real winner, I was just there to collect it for all of us. I'm a survivor, that's why they gave it to me. I'm still here after all these years. When you see all the performances on the enormous screen in there, it's quite astonishing. We were all just as good as each other, so why should one of us win? I pointed out that they don't say "The winner is ..." any more. They say "The Oscar goes to ..." and that was when I decided. I turned around and saw Michael [Clarke Duncan] and Tom [Cruise], then I saw little Haley [Joel Osment] and I didn't know where Jude Law was sitting - and I thought: "This can't go by without mentioning their performances." So I did. I went up the steps and turned. That's when I sort of went. The standing ovation threw me, 'cos it's not something you expect. I could hardly believe it. I'm very difficult to throw and they did it. To be held in such regard in a town so full of talent is an incredible compliment. I thought [Billy Crystal's tribute] was wonderful. He sang that song and had everybody going: "Caine!" I thought: "This is the cream of Hollywood here, singing my name!" I mean, I thought: "It's OK if I don't win, you know, it's OK, it's OK." But it's not OK, I won. I didn't win. See, you say win. Even I'm doing it. Rachel Portman  Composer who won for Emma in 1997, was nominated for The Cider House Rules in 2000 and Chocolat this year You have to drive about 10 miles and it takes two hours, then you hang around, and the whole thing starts at around 5.30 and ends about 10. Then you go to the ball, then you start going off to all the parties. It's funny - if you've won you get this elation, but of course four-fifths of all the people at the parties haven't won. You can't pretend that it isn't nice to have won. On the one hand it doesn't mean anything, on the other it means a lot. It's the only event in which you're nominated by your peers, after all. People do let their hair down and enjoy themselves at the parties, and you're bound to see massively famous actors which is quite fun too. The parties aren't particularly cliquey, although some are harder to get into than others. The most extraordinary aspect of the whole thing is that there is such a big build-up, and then it's over in a flash, completely forgotten, and everything goes back to normal. I was glad Michael Caine won best actor last year, but it was annoying: if you go to the bathroom you aren't allowed back to your seat until the commercial break, and while I was gone I missed three in a row, including his. The corridors outside are full of people not allowed to go back to their seat. The acceptance speeches are the most entertaining part, but they're very strict now about how much time you've got. When I went up there, the minute I started talking I was aware of this man in my sightline, looking at me and waving, saying: "10, 9, 8, 7 ..." But nobody pays much notice. The guy who won best supporting actor for Jerry Maguire - Cuba Gooding Jr - went on and on and on, started jumping up and down, and was a real star. He was genuinely, really thrilled. People wear the most extraordinary things - spray-on dresses. Julia Roberts stood out for having so much grace and style, but what most people wear is fascinating rather than beautiful. The Oscars couldn't be more glamorous. I'm taking my sister this year, who lives a very quiet life up in Scotland and she can't believe it. I think it's more exciting for her than it is for me. Martin Childs  Art director, won an Oscar for Shakespeare in Love in 1999 and is nominated for Quills this year The day starts with a nervous breakfast around the pool as soon as the LA Times comes out, which has predictions of who will win the awards. It was a surprise that Shakespeare in Love was top - we all thought it was going to be Saving Private Ryan. Then I realised that I was the favourite. Up until then I had no idea. The limo turns up filled with champagne at about 3.30. When we got in we realised that the driver didn't know her way around LA so we arrived very late. We were quite literally locked out. Luckily Judi Dench was in the car with us and they recognised her. So we said, "We're nominees too!" and managed to get in. If you watch the video you can see these people quietly stomping over to their seats with bended knees just as James Coburn is announced as best supporting actor. Then within five minutes someone came up to me and said: "Are you Martin Childs? You're up next." Before I knew it I was doing my acceptance speech, nervous as a cat, and this huge monitor in front of me said "Wrap up" almost as soon as I'd begun. You don't think about the millions of people looking at you, but you do look down to see Warren Beatty and Annette Bening lightly clapping a few feet away. Then you have to go up to a room to talk to the press, who make it very clear that they'd rather be talking to a big star and not some speccy bloke from England who's won an award for drawing some pictures. The year I went, there were all these people with banners outside protesting against Elia Kazan getting a lifetime achievement award because of his involvement with the House Un-American Activities Committee. Then when he went up to collect it, Susan Sarandon and Ed Harris pointedly didn't applaud. It was very silly - just because he did a bad thing it doesn't meant that his films weren't good. I did the British thing and clapped politely while hiding behind a chair, just in case Susan Sarandon saw me. I also remember Sophia Loren looking absolutely stunning. This year I hope Penelope Cruz will be there - she's already won for most glamorous actress as far as I'm concerned. After the Governor's Ball we went to the Miramax party, which is a legendary one. There was no getting out of it for me, considering I had won an award for Shakespeare in Love [a Miramax production]. This year I probably won't be invited to anything. Stephen Frears  Nominated as best director for The Grifters in 1991 They go on for hours. You get dressed up at three o'clock in the afternoon so you feel like a waiter shortly after lunch. Ten years ago, people didn't get as excited about these things as they do now - I got home one day and there were a lot of messages on the phone from people congratulating me on my nomination. I didn't even know I was up for it. Nowadays people go out and campaign to win but I was actually in California at the time preparing Accidental Hero for Columbia studios. The night before the Oscars I was told that with The Grifters I'd won a prize for best independent film of the year. I said: "I see the prize for best independent film is that you get to give up your independence." There's an enormous traffic jam while long cars filled with famous people inch down the spider's web to a building in Los Angeles. Once you are inside you soon discover that you can go to the bar with impunity because people fill your seat if you leave it empty. I don't remember anyone making spectacular idiots of themselves. Joe Pesci won a prize that year and his acceptance speech was: "Thank you very much. I'm honoured." Hats off for brevity. It's changed because the British press have got over-excited about the whole event but it's only jerks like me who are the voters. Pauline Collins was funny. She said: "I'm only here for the beer." And Danny Boyle came out and said: "We wuz robbed." Kevin Costner had won as best director for Dances With Wolves the year I went, beating Scorsese, who was there with GoodFellas. Scorsese was sitting there very depressed and I remember saying to him: "Surely you knew that you weren't going to win." When Billy Wilder won the second of the three Oscars he won for The Apartment, Moss Hart handed him the trophy saying: "Quit while you're ahead." And it was good advice; that was the peak of Wilder's career. I imagine it's always a cruel evening. Afterwards there's a do called the Governor's Ball, then a lot of famous people hang around, waiting for their limos to be brought. That year it was raining. Russell Crowe  Nominated best actor for The Insider in 2000 and this year for Gladiator It's great, man, what can I say? It's the highest acknowledgement in my profession. So, I don't have any glib lines about it. I'm not cynical about it at all. I was blown away last year and this year even more so. I don't have the time, funnily enough, to kind of come in and really enjoy the process of it because I always seem to be working. But maybe that's actually a good thing. The food's not as fancy as my mum's cooking, mate. She's a damn fine cook. She was a caterer for film and TV shows from the late 60s for about six or seven years and, in 1969, we had bean curd, which is tofu, in the refrigerator and I was the only kid that had that. I couldn't eat it, but we had it. Alisandra M Rand  Producer/writer, Fast Track Pictures; 1994 Oscar attendee I was invited by a friend. Actually I forced him (and it wasn't so easy) to take me, his friend, rather than use it as a way to get laid on some hot date. I wore a black sequinned dress, a flapper dress. The one formal dress I'd brought from Boston because as mom said: "You just never know." And this time she was right. I ran to the guy who cuts my hair, a crazy Frenchman, Didier, who's got a shop on Main Street in Santa Monica called Scissors. He gave me big hair, even though he told me it was out that year. Of course that just added to my jitters. And he did my make-up. Even gave me a lipstick. I'll never forget being all dressed up in the middle of the afternoon in that crazy southern California heat, trying to get close to the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in a borrowed convertible with all the fans flocking to catch a glimpse of the stars. And the red carpet - my God! This was before I'd been to a million and one premieres. I was still a grad student for Christ's sake, and though I was embarrassed to admit it, at the time, I'd probably only seen the show once on TV. The red carpet was pretty overwhelming. Everywhere, I looked there was someone famous. Funny thing about famous people - you have the same reaction you do to people you haven't seen since high school. You're excited to see them, and then you think: "Huh, do I really have anything to say to them?" And then you follow the code - give them their space, pretend they're just normal people dressed up for the opera - and kick yourself later for not having thought of something clever to say because, had you introduced yourself, who knows, maybe you would have made it in Hollywood. The only thing I really remember about the show itself was running back and forth to the bar, hanging out with the celebrities, having drinks, because, trust me, everyone was bored. It's endless. We weren't, of course, invited to the fancy schmancy ball afterwards. And, though we've since gotten pretty good at getting into parties we have no business being at, that was a bit too intimidating even for us. We went to Le Dome, a famous old bar on Sunset, and watched the after parties on TV, just like everybody else. And after the event, we actually talked to a little-known kid named Leo DiCaprio, who had just been nominated for his performance in What's Eating Gilbert Grape. We told him how impressed we'd been with his work. He told us this was a dream for him, too. He grew up in the area, and Oscar day was always a little like a snow day; everything shut down. He used to watch the limousines pull up to the Oscars, and now he was in one of them. It's funny to think about now. He wasn't big enough then to keep us from keeping protocol and giving him space. Now we couldn't get near him.
fields.bylineHtml: Mari Cartel, Will Hodgkinson, Stuart Husband, Matt Keating and Gary Susman

fields.headline: 15 Minutes
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There is something smug and exploitative about these hand-wringingly earnest themes, and the way we are invited to give a solemn and faintly contrite assent to their importance.
fields.body:
There are lots of Issues in this chaotic, over-long thriller, or rather bite-sized Issue McNuggets, paraded under the banner of that cliched Warhol quote. This just in! The news is being turned into one big pseudo-event! Reality is twisted by the media! Celebrity culture is taking over everything!

But guess what? It's wicked old television that's at fault - rather than, say, the movie business. Robert De Niro plays a famous New York cop who knows how to get the media on his side - and he's secretly dating a beautiful TV news reporter. Edward Burns is a naive young fire marshal helping De Niro on an arson-murder killing spree, the perpetrators being Russian and Czech gangsters who plan to video their crimes, plead insanity and sell their footage to an unscrupulous Hard Copy-style journalist, played by Kelsey Grammer.

There is something smug and exploitative about these hand-wringingly earnest themes, and the way we are invited to give a solemn and faintly contrite assent to their importance. And yet writer-director-producer John Herzfeld supplies a mad, brawling energy, along with an unexpected plot twist, which partly redeems this implausible tale.

fields.headline: An Everlasting Piece
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Anna Friel as Colm's girlfriend has got her Belfast accent by crossing Frank Carson with Jennifer Saunders and sadly the film has Billy Connolly in it.
fields.body:
A quirky sectarian comedy directed by Barry Levinson set in Belfast of the grim 1980s - it seems oddly too recent to count as period drama, yet not recent enough to do justice to the rapidly changing events in today's Northern Ireland. At any rate, it's got a lively script by Barry McEvoy, the Belfast-born actor who plays the lead as Colm, a Catholic barber who goes into business with a Protestant selling wigs. The pair of them eventually bridge the cultural divide by flogging hairpieces to British soldiers whose hair is falling out through stress - poetic justice for enforcing Brit imperialism in the North.

McEvoy and his partner, Brian F O'Byrne give enjoyable, relaxed performances. But Levinson's direction is heavy-handed and the jokes land on us in a succession of heavy thuds. Anna Friel as Colm's girlfriend has got her Belfast accent by crossing Frank Carson with Jennifer Saunders and sadly the film has Billy Connolly in it, shouting and running about the way he did during Comic Relief - only fully clothed, which is something.

fields.headline: Brother
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The result is distinctive and watchable, but let down by Kitano's very uneasy on-screen relationship with Omar Epps.
fields.body:
This is Takeshi Kitano's first English-language movie, and his first outside Japan. So that famous face, an anthology of twitches, tics, flinches and snorts, together with his slouching simian walk, is now presented to us in an American landscape - in the limos and boulevards of LA. One of the tics, needless to say, affects Kitano's trigger finger, both as actor and director. The bodies simply pile up, riddled with bullets, digits chopped off, intestines dangling tactlessly on the wrong side of the stomach wall.

In fact, it is a rare collection of besuited wiseguys in this picture who don't end up jitterbugging helplessly, clutching their guts as Beat Takeshi and his American homies loose off their weaponry. But often Brother doesn't look like a realistic crime/action movie so much as a strange Noh cinema-drama, with Kitano composing static group shots in tableaux, sometimes for deadpan comic effect, just as in his Chaplinesque kid's comedy Kikujiro.

The result is distinctive and watchable, but let down by Kitano's very uneasy on-screen relationship with Omar Epps, who gives an uncharacteristically dull performance as Denny, the gangsta-turned-honorary yakuza.

The bodies simply pile up, riddled with bullets, digits chopped off, intestines dangling tactlessly on the wrong side of the stomach wall. In fact, it is a rare collection of besuited wiseguys in this picture who don't end up jitterbugging helplessly, clutching their guts as Beat Takeshi and his American homies loose off their weaponry. But often Brother doesn't look like a realistic crime/action movie so much as a strange Noh cinema-drama, with Kitano composing static group shots in tableaux, sometimes for deadpan comic effect, just as in his Chaplinesque kid's comedy Kikujiro. The result is distinctive and watchable, but let down by Kitano's very uneasy on-screen relationship with Omar Epps, who gives an uncharacteristically dull performance as Denny, the gangsta-turned-honorary yakuza.

fields.headline: You Can Count On Me
fields.standfirst:
Kenneth Lonergan's family values debut is
raunchy, intelligent and should raise more than
a few sniffles
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A film with the virtues of classic American furniture: sturdy, unfussy, pleasingly substantial. And the star, Laura Linney, has it all.
fields.body:
Can the cinema swallow its pride and learn from humble television drama? Traffic showed that it can, with its ingestion of a multiple-storyline epic originally shown over several episodes on Channel 4. Now writer-director Kenneth Lonergan's You Can Count On Me - a handsome, well-acted and often very moving family drama with an Academy award-nominated performance from Laura Linney - seems effectively to have done the same thing with the daytime soap genre.

The movie started life as a one-act stage play, so perhaps Lonergan would regard the soap comparison as an insult. Yet why should it be? Why should the film not invest soap with the same cultural supercharge that Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger gave the kung-fu serial? And why should it not harness some of the power that soap has, which sophisticated critical opinion now readily and enthusiastically concedes?

It's got everything: a Peyton Place-ish location in small-town Scottsville, NY, and an involved family drama: a single mother, an absent father, covert sexual shenanigans, a Prodigal Son, and the fraught dual existences of home and office. It's not that hard to imagine You Can Count On Me on TV rather than celluloid, and with regular ad breaks - and it's not as if it's even that high budget in the first place.

Crucially, the movie privileges the brother-sister relationship above the romantic and sexual unions that drive most Hollywood movies: this is at the heart of the picture, and the resulting emphasis on the homely virtues of "family" is somehow very soapy. In one Crossroads-ish moment, the microphone appears at the top of frame, perhaps the most blatant invasion in recent memory. The fluffy boom practically comes down and musses up Linney's hair-do: you can get this sort of accidental alienation effect in any feature film, but removing it in post-production costs money - so in it stays.

Linney gives a thoroughly credible performance as single mother Sammy, holding down a white-collar job in a bank and looking after her son, Rudy. The boy's role is given to Rory Culkin, brother of the egregious Macaulay and a fine example of the way in which child acting has developed since the young Home Alone prince bestrode the world. Then it was big and brash; now, since Haley Joel Osment's success in The Sixth Sense, it's de rigueur for boys to do this sensitive, quiet little voice, a teeny-weeny voice emanating from somewhere within the recesses of his T-shirt. Sammy is bright, chipper, community-minded, a church-going, priest-consulting sort of woman who lives in the house where she was brought up (parents killed in a car crash long since), but combines these wholesome attributes with a matter-of-fact meeting of her bedroom needs with an on-off boyfriend. Linney plays all these aspects adroitly - it's an accessible, unassuming performance, far from her opaque and intimidating Bertha Dorset in Terence Davies's The House of Mirth.

When her sloppy, whiny and clearly druggy brother Terry (Mark Ruffalo) turns up out of the blue, Linney pulls off the considerable feat of conveying anger, relief and love: she's been worried about him; she's delighted to have him back; she's furious that he wants to touch her for another loan. But he comes in useful for looking after young Rudy, while she pursues an affair with her new boss, played by Matthew Broderick.

This is great stuff from Broderick, a hugely enjoyable development of his uptight teacher-figure in Alexander Payne's classic Election. He is prissy, anally retentive and an appalling control freak: he and Linney have so much in common. They rub each other up the wrong way, and yet end up having a raunchy scene in a motel room - a scene made all the hotter for being so real. Broderick has an extraordinary knack of portraying lasciviousness with pomposity, self-pity and self-congratulation - he appears, post-Ferris, to have hit a rich seam with this archetypal middle-American middle-class male.

Linney and Ruffalo as brother and sister turn in actorly, masterclass performances that perhaps owe more to the techniques of the stage than the cinema. Their relationship gives meaning to the phrase emotional intelligence. It is premier league screen acting and Ruffalo's final "goodbye" speech to his sister will live on as an audition piece for the next few decades, I predict, as well as enforcing quite a few sniffles in the cinema. They demonstrate an acute and responsive approach to Lonergan's writing - a script that sets out to hit a lot of emotional buttons, coming sometimes quite close to the melodrama of the daytime small-screen. But the two principals, happily cast and directed, shape it back into a dramatic piece of clarity and force.

It is a film with the virtues of classic American furniture: sturdy, unfussy, pleasingly substantial. And the star, Laura Linney, has it all. She can do a steamy sex scene, she can get laughs, she can provoke tears - and most importantly of all she is loyal to the American small town. It's the kind of sentiment and range that the Academy loves, and she surely deserves to beat Julia Roberts to that statuette next week.

fields.headline: Miss Congeniality
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Bullock's style is so tricksy and mannered, so peppered with nudges signalling "funny", and so divorced from real-world behaviour, that she's on her way to being a kind of butch Meg Ryan.
fields.body:
How often do we need to see Sandra Bullock do her comedy falling-down act (straight vertical drop, facing camera, disappearance out of shot)? How often does this nugget of physical comedy need to be performed to establish beyond a doubt that it is completely rubbish?

The answer is once. But Sandra wheels it out three or four times in this derivative comedy about an FBI agent who goes undercover at a beauty pageant - with wobbly heels! - to catch a serial killer. She is teased and crimped and bullied into shape by freelance "pageant consultant" Michael Caine: a role that requires him to be a cantankerous old queen, but never gives him anywhere near enough funny lines to make this work.

However, Caine does his considerable best with the part and makes a serviceable crimplene purse out of a sow's ear. But poor old Sandra, producer and star, fails to convince either as the tomboy-ish agent or the cleaned-up foxy babe. It's a transformation for which the phrase "By George, she hasn't got it" applies to both before and after.

Candice Bergen and William Shatner are adrift with underwritten (and presumably heavily cut) roles as the pageant directors and Bullock's style is so tricksy and mannered, so peppered with nudges signalling "funny", and so divorced from real-world behaviour, that she's on her way to being a kind of butch Meg Ryan.
