webTitle: What went wrong with An Everlasting Piece

fields.headline: I really shouldn't talk about this...
fields.standfirst: Barry McEvoy was thrilled when DreamWorks took up his script about rival Irish wigmakers. But the film's release was a disaster, and recrimination is in the air.  Rupert Mellor  reports
fields.trailText: Barry McEvoy was thrilled when DreamWorks took up his script about rival Irish wigmakers. But the film's release was a disaster, and recrimination is in the air. Rupert Mellor reports.
fields.body:
Barry McEvoy came close - very close - to being a movie star. An unknown apart from a small role in the Sharon Stone remake of Gloria, the 33-year-old pulled off an amazing coup when his first script, An Everlasting Piece, attracted the backing of both director Barry Levinson - who won an Oscar for Rain Man - and the DreamWorks studio. McEvoy himself took the lead.

But two years later, the two Barrys are locked in a bitter row with DreamWorks over its handling of the picture, which sank without trace on its US release. Allegations abound: unsubstantiated rumours say that Levinson was asked by the studio to withdraw scenes that reflected badly on the British with regard to Northern Ireland, and that Steven Spielberg, one of DreamWorks' three bosses - sniffing his imminent honorary knighthood - buried the film for fear of dismaying Tony Blair.

Peter Dunne, DreamWorks' head of international publicity, confirms that the studio have consistently denied the story. McEvoy remains firm in his belief. "If DreamWorks hadn't so actively dumped the movie, I would think that was preposterous. At first we joked about it - Sir Steven, the secret SAS agent, running around the woods with his face blacked. But as it goes on, the theory becomes less ludicrous. I shouldn't really talk about this at all. My lawyers told me not to. I'm a young guy, I don't need to get blackballed this early in the game."

An Everlasting Piece is a gentle comedy about two barbers, one Protestant, one Catholic, attempting to corner the monopoly in toupees in 1980s Belfast. McEvoy's script, inspired by the reminiscences of his father, was first aired in readings in pubs in his adopted home town, New York. He found his director when producer Louis DiGiaimo attended a reading and then gave the script to Levinson. Confirmation that DreamWorks would finance and distribute the picture was McEvoy's next bit of good news.

"It was an incredible break," McEvoy says. "Especially as DreamWorks had passed on the script once. Then suddenly I'm at a meeting with Harvey Weinstein, who says: 'Why didn't we get this script?' I told him: 'I sent it you, and you passed.' So he tells his assistant, 'Find out who passed on that', like he's going to fire him.

"Months later, I was standing on set on the first day of shooting, waiting for the call of 'Action'. When it came, I was thinking, I can't believe this is happening!" Come release time, however, McEvoy's fairy tale came crashing down around his ears. An Everlasting Piece made a disastrous $73,000 against its $9m cost and disappeared from screens after just seven days.

"About 15 people in America saw the movie," McEvoy says. "Basically, DreamWorks should never have done this film. DreamWorks is set up to launch blockbusters - have a massive opening weekend, bang, make $20m and the film takes off. They have no idea how to make a little film snowball in the way that Miramax or FilmFour do. The money involved must have seemed pointless to them."

Levinson agrees. "I'm furious with DreamWorks. Sometimes, you do all you can and it just doesn't come across, and everyone involved has to hold up their hands and accept that it didn't work. That was not the case with this film.

"First, it should never have opened in the US. A movie like this only has a chance if it is opened in its target market and builds, as The Full Monty did. Then, although we had many good reviews, which is a crucial selling point for a non-mainstream movie, the trailer that DreamWorks made only showed one quote.

"Next, they opened the movie on Christmas Day, against all the big holiday movies, on precisely eight screens. They ran it for a week, then told us it wasn't working and closed it. Now I have agents calling and asking for a tape because they never knew it had played. My own mom couldn't find it. And DreamWorks think they did everything they could."

DreamWorks' position is that the film was always small-scale, stating: "Everyone involved with this movie has been aware from the start that it was always on a limited-release pattern." Levinson counters: "I didn't want to make this movie with that studio. I had the cash to do it independently, and wanted to. But I believed that they had a contract and owned the script, which they did not. We were already in production when I discovered there was no contract."

It's a shame that An Everlasting Piece never got a chance to fight its corner. An aggrieved McEvoy says: "You try and do something a bit different and a bit better than your average fare, and you get kicked for it, you know? It has been very hard to go through such a long battle, then have it all go down the tube like it did. You start to think, why bother? I could just be on some crappy TV show, or churning out a bunch of shite and earning a fortune with no headaches. I've just been to LA and the scripts I read were really, really garbage."

Nonetheless, he is doing his best to think positive. "Barry saw what was going on before I did, and he said, 'Just let it go. Think about Europe, because it's not going to happen here.' I really didn't want to hear that. But I have to hope that Columbia Tri-Star does a better job here."

In the meantime, McEvoy is looking to his mum for perspective. "I got very depressed about all this, but my ma says, 'Listen. You are the lead in a DreamWorks film, which Barry Levinson directed. What are you complaining about?' "

fields.headline: Don't Look Now
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's a ghost story; it's a meditation on time, memory and the poignancy of married love. And it's a masterpiece.
fields.body:
A chance to revisit Nic Roeg's greatest achievement: a brilliant, in many ways unique, conflation of the erotic and the uncanny, with a masterly feel for images and mood that will reverberate in your mind for days. Donald Sutherland and Julie Christie give performances of deeply felt humanity and sensitivity as the parents of a dead child who encounter, in Venice's dankly crumbling splendour, presentiments of her existence beyond the grave.

Attractively studded with 1970s high-cultural references - how many love-making couples now keep a copy of Rolf Hochhuth's The Representative by the bed? - the movie looks nevertheless fresher than ever. It's a ghost story; it's a meditation on time, memory and the poignancy of married love. And it's a masterpiece.

fields.headline: The Firemen's Ball
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There is a human scale to this gentle comedy.
fields.body: Milos Forman's final Czech film before taking up US residence was a sly, sure-footed satire of his native land's bumbling bureaucracy and pompous uniform-wearing officialdom. It is composed in an allusive, indirect political idiom, which may perhaps look tame and even lenient from our post-Soviet perspective. But there is a human scale to this gentle comedy, which follows, almost in real time, an evening fundraiser for the local fire service, in the course of which all the raffle prizes get stolen, the Miss Firemen beauty contestants are too shy to appear in public, and a local farmhouse burns to the ground. In his pre-credit sequence Forman has an inspired visual comedy routine that made me laugh out loud.

webTitle: Oscars 2001: Contenders in the main categories

fields.headline: Oscars 2001
fields.standfirst: Contenders in the main categories
fields.trailText: Contenders in the main categories.
fields.body:
Best picture

Gladiator 1-5

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon 4-1

Traffic 5-1

Erin Brockovich 6-1

Chocolat 15-1

Using nifty computer-generated images, Gladiator recreated the blood, intrigue, sandals and pageantry of ancient Rome. It won a Golden Globe and is now bookies' favourite. With another double nomination, Steven Soderbergh et al may be miffed if neither Erin Brockovich nor Traffic wins best film or direction; but tipsters put Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon ahead of both.

Best actor in a leading role

Russell Crowe (Gladiator) 5-9

Tom Hanks (Cast Away) 3-2

Ed Harris (Pollock) 7-1

Geoffrey Rush (Quills) 7-1

Javier Bardem (Before Night Falls) 8-1

Antipodean demigod Russell Crowe is favourite for his portrayal of Colosseum butcher Maximus Meridius. But going by this year's Golden Globes, gushing Academy veteran Tom Hanks could take home his third Oscar for playing Chuck Noland - the Cast Away Fed-Ex brownshirt with yo-yoing waistline and fearsome beard. Outsider Ed Harris is worth a flutter.

Best actress in a leading role

Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich) 1-10

Joan Allen (The Contender) 5-1

Juliette Binoche (Chocolat) 6-1

Ellen Burstyn (Requiem for a Dream) 9-1

Laura Linney (You Can Count on Me) 9-1

Tipsters reckon Golden Globe-winner Julia Roberts has this stitched-up for her portrayal of Erin Brockovich. It garnered Hollywood's highest-paid actress her second Oscar nomination. Joan Allen, the character-assassinated vice-president nominee in The Contender, and Juliette Binoche, Chocolat's mysterious chocolatier, are worth a bet too.

Best actor in a supporting role

Benicio Del Toro (Traffic) 1-6

Albert Finney (Erin Brockovich) 3-1

Joaquin Phoenix (Gladiator) 6-1

Willem Dafoe (Shadow/Vampire) 8-1

Jeff Bridges (The Contender) 13-1

Benicio Del Toro is out in front with his portrayal of Traffic's Javier Rodriguez - the Tijuana cop caught up in the drug trade. Eating his dust are five-times nominated Albert Finney, the world-worn attorney in Erin Brockovich; Joaquin Phoenix, the deliciously reptilian Commodus in Gladiator; and Willem Dafoe - uncanny in Shadow of the Vampire.

Best actress in a supporting role

Kate Hudson (Almost Famous) 1-1

Judi Dench (Chocolat) 7-5

Frances McDormand (Almost Famous) 7-5

Marcia Gay Harden (Pollock) 6-1

Julie Walters (Billy Elliot) 8-1

Favourite is celebrity du jour Kate Hudson, for her Golden Globe-winning portrayal of Penny Lane in Almost Famous - the epitome of groupie chic. If she wins, Hudson and Oscar-winning mum Goldie Hawn could be the first mother-daughter winners. It may be two times lucky for Judi Dench for Chocolat, though a Julie Walters win is possible too.

Best director*

Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot)

Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger)

Ridley Scott (Gladiator)

Steven Soderbergh (Traffic)

Steven Soderbergh (Erin Brockovich)

Bets are off: many pundits tip Ridley Scott for Gladiator - his homage to Hollywood's toga epics. But Steven Soderbergh must be in with a chance, for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich. It would be good to see Ang Lee complete the Globe-Oscar double with Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

* odds unavailable
fields.bodyText: Best picture Gladiator 1-5 Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon 4-1 Traffic 5-1 Erin Brockovich 6-1 Chocolat 15-1 Using nifty computer-generated images, Gladiator recreated the blood, intrigue, sandals and pageantry of ancient Rome. It won a Golden Globe and is now bookies' favourite. With another double nomination, Steven Soderbergh et al may be miffed if neither Erin Brockovich nor Traffic wins best film or direction; but tipsters put Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon ahead of both. Best actor in a leading role Russell Crowe (Gladiator) 5-9 Tom Hanks (Cast Away) 3-2 Ed Harris (Pollock) 7-1 Geoffrey Rush (Quills) 7-1 Javier Bardem (Before Night Falls) 8-1 Antipodean demigod Russell Crowe is favourite for his portrayal of Colosseum butcher Maximus Meridius. But going by this year's Golden Globes, gushing Academy veteran Tom Hanks could take home his third Oscar for playing Chuck Noland - the Cast Away Fed-Ex brownshirt with yo-yoing waistline and fearsome beard. Outsider Ed Harris is worth a flutter. Best actress in a leading role Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich) 1-10 Joan Allen (The Contender) 5-1 Juliette Binoche (Chocolat) 6-1 Ellen Burstyn (Requiem for a Dream) 9-1 Laura Linney (You Can Count on Me) 9-1 Tipsters reckon Golden Globe-winner Julia Roberts has this stitched-up for her portrayal of Erin Brockovich. It garnered Hollywood's highest-paid actress her second Oscar nomination. Joan Allen, the character-assassinated vice-president nominee in The Contender, and Juliette Binoche, Chocolat's mysterious chocolatier, are worth a bet too. Best actor in a supporting role Benicio Del Toro (Traffic) 1-6 Albert Finney (Erin Brockovich) 3-1 Joaquin Phoenix (Gladiator) 6-1 Willem Dafoe (Shadow/Vampire) 8-1 Jeff Bridges (The Contender) 13-1 Benicio Del Toro is out in front with his portrayal of Traffic's Javier Rodriguez - the Tijuana cop caught up in the drug trade. Eating his dust are five-times nominated Albert Finney, the world-worn attorney in Erin Brockovich; Joaquin Phoenix, the deliciously reptilian Commodus in Gladiator; and Willem Dafoe - uncanny in Shadow of the Vampire. Best actress in a supporting role Kate Hudson (Almost Famous) 1-1 Judi Dench (Chocolat) 7-5 Frances McDormand (Almost Famous) 7-5 Marcia Gay Harden (Pollock) 6-1 Julie Walters (Billy Elliot) 8-1 Favourite is celebrity du jour Kate Hudson, for her Golden Globe-winning portrayal of Penny Lane in Almost Famous - the epitome of groupie chic. If she wins, Hudson and Oscar-winning mum Goldie Hawn could be the first mother-daughter winners. It may be two times lucky for Judi Dench for Chocolat, though a Julie Walters win is possible too. Best director* Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot) Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger) Ridley Scott (Gladiator) Steven Soderbergh (Traffic) Steven Soderbergh (Erin Brockovich) Bets are off: many pundits tip Ridley Scott for Gladiator - his homage to Hollywood's toga epics. But Steven Soderbergh must be in with a chance, for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich. It would be good to see Ang Lee complete the Globe-Oscar double with Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. * odds unavailable

webTitle: Frequently asked questions about the Oscars

fields.headline: Frequently asked questions about the Oscars
fields.trailText: When is it on TV? | Who is hosting? | Can I go in person?
fields.body:
When is it on TV?

Live broadcast begins at 2.30am, Sunday, on Sky Premier, with highlights on the same channel at 8pm, Monday.

Who is hosting?

It's Steve Martin's turn this year, butting into the Billy Crystal-Whoopi Goldberg axis; they tend to dominate MC duties. Crystal has run the show seven times since 1990, and Goldberg three.

Can I go in person?

Members of the public can queue on Oscar morning for a seat to watch the red-carpet crawl. Gates are closed at noon, and the lucky viewers aren't allowed to leave the seating area before the ceremony starts at 5.30pm. No food or water is available, but the organisers have provided "restroom" facilities.

Will the thank-yous be shorter this year?

A 45-second limit has been put on acceptance speeches, with the Academy offering a high-definition TV as a prize for the shortest. To compensate for the dull-but-necessary list of thanks, a website for Oscar acknowledgements is planned.

Who is the lifetime achiever?

And the Irving G Thalberg Memorial Award goes to producer Dino de Laurentiis. Until Hannibal, he specialised in such fiascos as Dune and the Madonna vehicle Body of Evidence.

Are all the awards handed out in one go?

The scientific and technical awards were presented on March 3. These include such arcana as: "To Rob Cook, Loren Carpenter and Ed Catmull for their significant advancements to the field of motion picture rendering, as exemplified in Pixar's Renderman."

Foreign film fact

Crouching Tiger is the third film to be nominated for best film and best foreign-language film. The others were Z in 1970, and Life is Beautiful in 1999. And with 10 nods, it's by far the most nominated subtitled film ever.

webTitle: Remakes and sequels hog Hollywood summer schedules

fields.headline: Summer of same
fields.standfirst: Goodbye originality, hello deja vu as remakes and sequels hog the summer schedules
fields.trailText: Goodbye originality, hello deja vu as remakes and sequels hog the summer schedules.
fields.body:
I have this recurring nightmare in which I wake up in the centre of a huge conference table. I am surrounded by movie producers, one of whom is saying, "...And the big project for next summer is our John Patterson remake. We'll buy up the original negative of him and burn it so no one can compare the two versions. Then we'll do a soup-to-nuts retread, give him a new plot, new writer, hot young director, tons of effects, tits and ass, a buncha guns, and an MTV blowout for the soundtrack album. We'll test-screen the ass off his new ending, and if no one salutes, hey, we'll just off-load him straight to video."

The nightmare was prompted by a look at what's coming our way this summer: remakes, rip-offs, retreads - the sugar-heavy, nutrition-lite junk food of contemporary cinema.

First, the sequels: The Mummy Returns, Dr Dolittle 2, Scary Movie 2, Rush Hour 2, American Pie 2, Jurassic Park 3. Videogame adaptations include Tomb Raider and Final Fantasy. The major remakes are Planet of the Apes (which Fox brazenly insists "isn't a remake") and Rollerball. Also in development are The Sixth Sense 2 (The Seventh Sense, surely?), Shanghai Noon 2, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, Austin Powers 3, Blade 2, a Dirty Dancing sequel, Stuart Little 2, another remake of The Time Machine, and an English-language version of Benigni's The Monster.

The last item alone makes me want to hurl myself into a swimming pool holding a plugged-in toaster-oven. Or perhaps I should just lie back and have that makeover after all...

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Keeping the Faith | Dancer in the Dark | Freeway II
fields.trailText: Keeping the Faith | Dancer in the Dark | Freeway II
fields.body:
Keeping the Faith
Rental and DVD rental Buena Vista Cert 12

A romantic comedy with an IQ, which already makes it a bit of a rarity. Edward Norton and Ben Stiller are the boyhood friends who grow up to be a Catholic priest and a rabbi in New York. Jenna Elfman is the childhood friend turned high-powered businesswoman who causes emotional chaos during a visit. Keeping the Faith benefits from a smart and eccentric script by Stuart Blumberg, a debutant in director Norton, and good pacing and timing from its reliable leads. It feels like friends having fun together and letting us in on the joke. It also shows a fond regard for New York's great ethnic diversity - the plot unfolds as a drunk Norton's confession to a barman who turns out to be a Sikh Catholic Muslim with Jewish in-laws. In one of the film's most warmly funny scenes, Stiller imports a black choir into his synagogue in despair at the standard of the congregation's singing. Norton and Stiller treat preaching as a form of stand-up comedy while they consider a joint Jewish and Irish religious centre. Phrases like "kosher nostra" get flung around and for an hour or so, this is a breath of fresh air in the rather fetid ambience we call rom-com. So it's a big disappointment when Norton allows it a very orthodox (if not Orthodox) ending.

Dancer in the Dark
VCI/FilmFour Retail and DVD (£19.99) Cert 15

Perhaps the most controversial Cannes winner ever - the announcement that it had won the Golden Palm was met with a storm of booing - and it's easy to see why. In the first place, Lars von Trier's Dogme style (wobbly camerawork and apparent improvisation) is all wrong for a musical. In the second, our heroine, Björk, has to fight against the kind of manipulative plotting you thought had gone out with weepies in the silent cinema era. She's going blind, her son's going blind and she is horribly mistreated by people she thought were her friends. Director von Trier pulled off the greatest heartbreaker of the last decade in Breaking the Waves, which makes you wonder how he could get it so spectacularly wrong here. If we are supposed to be sobbing at the plight of our plucky heroine trapped in Robin Day specs and big Pauline Fowler cardigans, the natural reaction is to laugh at the Danish director's outrageous manipulation, Dickensian sentimentality and careless plotting. "In a musical, nothing dreadful ever happens," says Ms Gudmundsdottir. In this one, it's all so dreadful you wonder if the enigmatic director is having a joke at our expense, especially in the shock ending. It's especially a shame for Björk, (who has showed she can dominate a camera with no props in the video for Big Time Sensuality and did her own little mini-musical in It's Oh So Quiet) and for Catherine Deneuve, once the star of a stylish musical, The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, and here lumbered with a ludicrous best friend/fairy godmother role. For incongruous musical numbers, stick to Always Look on the Bright Side of Life, which, come to think of it, would have worked rather well with the finale here.

Freeway II
Rental High Fliers Cert 18

Aka Confessions of a Trickbaby. Gleefully trashy and outrageous road movie in which Crystal (armed robber, sexual psychopath, drug dealer, car thief and bulimic daughter of a crack addict) busts out of prison with Cyclona (just your basic delusional serial killer lesbian). They hit the road and make for Tijuana to see Cyclona's favourite nun, Sister Gomez. Crystal is played by the magisterially stroppy Natasha Lyonne and Sister Gomez, surprisingly turns out to be the great lost auteur Vincent Gallo. John Landis also turns up as a judge. Huge amounts of violence and throwing up ensue and it's sporadically very funny. Stylistically, this is like a Roger Corman 1970s exploitation film, or a twisted sister to Gregg Araki's recent trilogy of doomed kids. It's "based on Hansel and Gretel" (as the bloody Freeway, starring Reese Witherspoon, was based on Little Red Riding Hood) but only a contracts lawyer could spot the similarity. Good original soundtrack too: Surf Trio and Veruca Salt, we salute you.

webTitle: Macedonia: killing of ethnic Albanians filmed

fields.headline: Minute of madness watched by the world
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: The first body lay sprawled behind the silver Suzuki, an arm outstretched, a palm turned towards the sky, a balding head just visible behind the half-open passenger door.
fields.body:
The first body lay sprawled behind the silver Suzuki, an arm outstretched, a palm turned towards the sky, a balding head just visible behind the half-open passenger door.

The body of his father, identified by his nickname, Berzi, lay a little further away where he had been dragged by the Macedonian interior police after he was shot, leaving behind a trail of blood. Beside him lay the cylindrical canister of the grenade he had pulled from his pocket.

The killing of these two ethnic Albanians, at a police checkpoint near the centre of Tetovo yesterday, has raised tension in this divided city almost to breaking point.

In the immediate aftermath of the killing Albanians claimed the two victims had been assaulted, summarily executed and the grenades planted on them by police. Macedonians said it proved that Albanian terrorists were now operating among them.

The deaths of Berzi and his son resulted from fear and panic on both sides and summed up the bitter and febrile hatred that has been released in the former Yugoslav republic.

The killings happened in a minute of desperation amid the boom of shell fire from the Macedonian gunners 200 metres away who were pounding the hilltop positions of the ethnic Albanian National Liberation Army.

The Albanians - visibly terrified of the helmeted and flak-jacketed police - hurled their grenades with a palpable sense of panic. The young policemen fired wildly, spraying bullets in all directions.

What makes these killings so important in a country on the edge of catastrophe is that the death of Berzi and his son were played out in the full view of the world, captured on film by Frederic Nairac, a French cameraman working for ITN, and by Russian and Czech TV.

What Nairac saw was this. A car pulls to a stop by a checkpoint with armed police standing on either side. Berzi is an elderly man, wearing the white felt fez and dark suit favoured by many older Albanian men. Nervously he gets out of the car, accompanied by the policeman, to the boot, which he dutifully opens.

Berzi then turns quickly to reach through the driver's window for something. In the passenger seat, his son - a scruffy man in his late forties - shifts uncomfortably, reaching behind him to move something from a pocket.

The camera follows the older man then suddenly swings to catch the son struggling with the policeman who hits him with his traffic baton.

The faces of both are transfixed with fear. In a moment it becomes obvious why. The Albanian is pulling at something from beneath his jacket and as the policeman begins to run it is clear he has pulled the pin from a grenade and the fuse is smoking.

And as he ducks to hurl it at the fleeing policeman the security forces in the sandbagged position open fire, immediately cutting him down as three bullets smash the windscreen, the grenade bouncing harmlessly by the fleeing policeman's boots. The policeman is in more danger from his comrades pouring automatic fire towards him.

Berzi is now running from the car. He makes it a few metres and pulls a grenade from his own pocket before being fatally wounded. As an officer with a handgun runs round and shouts to his men for calm the younger man is shot again and killed.

Later we watch footage in a bar packed with ethnic Albanian men. Only the aftermath is shown - police dragging Berzi's body along the pavement. Anger crackles in the air. A young law student, Agram Iseni, says: "This is a catastrophe. It makes more and more people want to grab guns. They say if it happens to men like this then it can happen to me."

fields.bodyText: The first body lay sprawled behind the silver Suzuki, an arm outstretched, a palm turned towards the sky, a balding head just visible behind the half-open passenger door. The body of his father, identified by his nickname, Berzi, lay a little further away where he had been dragged by the Macedonian interior police after he was shot, leaving behind a trail of blood. Beside him lay the cylindrical canister of the grenade he had pulled from his pocket. The killing of these two ethnic Albanians, at a police checkpoint near the centre of Tetovo yesterday, has raised tension in this divided city almost to breaking point. In the immediate aftermath of the killing Albanians claimed the two victims had been assaulted, summarily executed and the grenades planted on them by police. Macedonians said it proved that Albanian terrorists were now operating among them. The deaths of Berzi and his son resulted from fear and panic on both sides and summed up the bitter and febrile hatred that has been released in the former Yugoslav republic. The killings happened in a minute of desperation amid the boom of shell fire from the Macedonian gunners 200 metres away who were pounding the hilltop positions of the ethnic Albanian National Liberation Army. The Albanians - visibly terrified of the helmeted and flak-jacketed police - hurled their grenades with a palpable sense of panic. The young policemen fired wildly, spraying bullets in all directions. What makes these killings so important in a country on the edge of catastrophe is that the death of Berzi and his son were played out in the full view of the world, captured on film by Frederic Nairac, a French cameraman working for ITN, and by Russian and Czech TV. What Nairac saw was this. A car pulls to a stop by a checkpoint with armed police standing on either side. Berzi is an elderly man, wearing the white felt fez and dark suit favoured by many older Albanian men. Nervously he gets out of the car, accompanied by the policeman, to the boot, which he dutifully opens. Berzi then turns quickly to reach through the driver's window for something. In the passenger seat, his son - a scruffy man in his late forties - shifts uncomfortably, reaching behind him to move something from a pocket. The camera follows the older man then suddenly swings to catch the son struggling with the policeman who hits him with his traffic baton. The faces of both are transfixed with fear. In a moment it becomes obvious why. The Albanian is pulling at something from beneath his jacket and as the policeman begins to run it is clear he has pulled the pin from a grenade and the fuse is smoking. And as he ducks to hurl it at the fleeing policeman the security forces in the sandbagged position open fire, immediately cutting him down as three bullets smash the windscreen, the grenade bouncing harmlessly by the fleeing policeman's boots. The policeman is in more danger from his comrades pouring automatic fire towards him. Berzi is now running from the car. He makes it a few metres and pulls a grenade from his own pocket before being fatally wounded. As an officer with a handgun runs round and shouts to his men for calm the younger man is shot again and killed. Later we watch footage in a bar packed with ethnic Albanian men. Only the aftermath is shown - police dragging Berzi's body along the pavement. Anger crackles in the air. A young law student, Agram Iseni, says: "This is a catastrophe. It makes more and more people want to grab guns. They say if it happens to men like this then it can happen to me." What's going on? The fighting in Macedonia explained Map: where is Tetovo? fields.headline: Death on the street
fields.standfirst:
Albanians shot in Tetovo

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Albanians shot in Tetovo
fields.body:
Tensions soared in Tetovo, the heartland of the Balkan republic's ethnic Albanian minority, yesterday after two men were shot dead during a routine search at a police checkpoint. The incident began when the Albanians' car was stopped and one of the men dragged out of it by an armed Macedonian police officer.

Photographs and television footage show that the officer, realising the Albanian was carrying a grenade, panicked and ran. The Albanian dropped to his knees and threw the grenade in the direction of the running policeman. It landed at his feet but failed to explode.

At the moment the grenade was thrown, a cordon of Macedonian troops, positioned behind sandbags, unleashed a volley of gunfire at the Albanian. At first he slumped against the car, then fell on the kerb, dead. His fellow Albanian was also shot a few yards away.

The Tetevo area was braced for further violence last night as news of the killings spread.

webTitle: Nato pays price for letting extremists off the hook

fields.headline: Nato pays price for letting extremists off the hook
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Nato troops and international agencies in Kosovo should have done more to disarm Albanian extremists and bring them to justice
fields.body:
Nato troops and international agencies in Kosovo should have done more to disarm Albanian extremists and bring them to justice, senior British defence officials admitted yesterday.

Many of the extremists, including Macedonian Albanians, fought with the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) during Nato's bombing campaign in 1999 and were advised by the SAS, special forces from other Nato countries and the CIA.

"They are very clearly KLA-linked," a well-placed Whitehall source said, referring to Albanian guerrillas who have been infiltrating Macedonia.

The defence sources also made it clear they were disillusioned with ethnic Albanian political leaders in Kosovo for not taking a more aggressive stand against the extremists. "They disown responsibility but there is no active political leadership," they said.

The sources painted a picture of a disparate group of Albanian rebels engaged in political extremism and organised crime. Some wanted a Greater Albania, which would take in Kosovo, south-east Serbia and north-west Macedonia.

Thousands were bound together by clan links, and a diaspora, mainly in the US and Germany. Some were simply after territory, others were mafia groups or smugglers.

They will present a "long-term problem", said the sources who added: "You cannot disinvent a mind-set."

British military officials described the attacks across the Macedonia border as a "limited insurgency" involving between 300 and 800 guerrilla fighters. They were "well consolidated" in the hills above Tetovo, Macedonia's second city.

British troops have adopted a more robust approach to Albanian extremists than others, notably, until very recently, American soldiers.

Defence sources said that all K-For peacekeepers would now adopt a more aggressive presence on the Kosovo side of the Macedonian border. But they admitted the mountainous border between Macedonia and Albania, where there are no K-For troops but a plentiful supply of arms, was extremely difficult to control.

Significantly, for the first time this week, Robin Cook and Javier Solana, the UN's security supremo, described Albanian guerrillas as "terrorists", a term previously used by Russia.

In an implicit defence of the KLA's activities during the Kosovo war - and Nato's support for it - Mr Cook argues that there is a huge difference between the "brutal" government of the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, and the multi-ethnic democratic government of Macedonia. "This is not Kosovo," said a senior defence official.

Nato and the EU say that while the territorial integrity of Macedonia must be maintained, "legitimate" grievances of the ethnic Albanian minority, forming up to 30% of Macedonia's population, must be recognised.

webTitle: Macedonia stands on edge of war

fields.headline: Macedonia stands on edge of war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonian security forces reclaimed some ethnic Albanian rebel positions in mountains overlooking Tetovo yesterday
fields.byline: Rory Carroll  in Tetovo and  Jonathan Steele in Skopje
fields.body:
Macedonian security forces reclaimed some ethnic Albanian rebel positions in mountains overlooking Tetovo yesterday after the government came under pressure from European Union officials and opposition parties to abandon an all-out offensive.

During the day heavily-armed police units inched up the slopes above Tetovo under covering fire from 120mm mortars and T-55 tanks. The search-and-sweep operation yielded dozens of prisoners, rocket-propelled grenades, mortar rounds, explosives and ammunition, a police spokesman said.

The guerrillas were changing into civilian clothes and retreating towards Kosovo, he added. No evidence was offered to support this claim.

No resistance was encountered as police ventured into woodland already abandoned by the self-styled National Liberation Army (NLA).

A tour of Tetovo's northern outskirts showed its fighters remained dug into sniper positions on both sides of the mountains, near the villages of Poroj and Sipkovica. Their headquarters in Selce, a half-hour drive above the city, was shelled but police units made no effort to enter its hinterland, a guerrilla interviewed by mobile phone said. "We don't believe they will even try to come."

The NLA political leadership announced a unilateral ceasefire on Wednesday night but said it would respond if security forces moved in.

"We wanted to show our political will and not allow the extremists to impose their agenda", Srdjan Kerim, the Macedonian foreign minister, said yesterday when asked why the government had not followed through on Tuesday's ultimatum stating it would attack if the gunmen did not withdraw within 24 hours.

A government spokesman, Antonio Milososki,said: "The ultimatum stated that we would use all available means but the timing and the way we would use them was not said."

The change of policy to a more drawn-out, low-profile effort to counter the gunmen was prompted in part by the guerrillas' own offer of an unlimited ceasefire. Foreign diplomats have also pressured Macedonia not to risk civilian casualties or upset its delicate ethnic and political balance.

One of the main Albanian parties is in coalition with the government, and the other party, though in opposition, has given broad backing to the government's strategy. They would be tempted to change position if the army caused massive casualties among Albanians in an assault.

Earlier President Boris Trajkovski had said government forces would "neutralise and eliminate" the armed Albanian militants who have brought mayhem to western and northern Macedonia since last week.

A government spokesman said responsibility for tackling the guerrillas would pass to the military. "From now on our response will be clear and every action will depend only on the decisions of our field commanders."

Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, made his second visit to Skopje in three days yesterday, this time accompanied by Chris Patten, the external affairs commissioner, and Anna Lindh, the Swedish foreign minister.

"A ceasefire is always a positive thing. I was very pleased yesterday that the people in the mountains in response to the government said they would stop fighting," Mr Solana said.

Mr Patten added "No one should allow armed extremism to provoke extremism by others. The armed extremists are going to lose. All that is required is for people to keep their nerve and show continued commitment to solving problems by political means".

But just outside the capital Skopje a rocket-propelled grenade wounded a police officer hours after a colleague was gunned down in the city. Mortar rounds also wounded a policeman at a checkpoint near the village of Gracane, 15 miles north-east of Tetovo.

Refugees continued fleeing in cars and buses. Women bound for Istanbul wept as husbands and brothers waved goodbye. "It's not safe even in Skopje. Far away, that's the best," said one man.

The UN refugee agency said more than 8,000 people, mostly ethnic Albanians, had left their homes since fighting started last month.

webTitle: Outbreak puts paid to Irish restart

fields.headline: Outbreak puts paid to Irish restart
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Hopes of racing resuming in Ireland next month have been thrown into grave doubt by the first confirmed case of foot and mouth disease in the Irish Republic.
fields.body:
Hopes of racing resuming in Ireland next month have been thrown into grave doubt by the first confirmed case of foot and mouth disease in the Irish Republic.

Racing in Ireland had been suspended on February 27 but with only one outbreak, in Northern Ireland, hopes were high for a resumption on April 14.

Following yesterday's confirmation of foot and mouth disease at County Louth, that date looks certain to be put back by at least a fortnight.

Leading trainer Ted Walsh said: "Prospects for an early restart look bleak."

Willie Mullins, president of the Irish Racehorse Trainers' Association, said: "We are waiting to hear from the Ministry of Agriculture. Hopefully, we can still go ahead on April 14, but it looks as though there might be a further delay."

Professor Joe Quinn, who is on the minister's team of advisors, said: "We must continue to take things very carefully. I would imagine racing would be very much in doubt now. The sport has been hit pretty bad, but I suppose it's only a small price when you consider what some people are having to pay."

Any chance of Irish horses coming over for the Grand National or the Cheltenham Festival are even more remote than before, while the four-day Punchestown Festival, starting April 24, looks certain to be cancelled.

Further delay would put paid to the Irish National Hunt season and also throw preparations for their Flat into turmoil.

Martin Heffernan of the Irish agricultural ministry press office, said: "The view of the department's expert group is that horse racing still remains a category 3 event (high risk).

"It is up to the horse racing authorities to decide if they wish to race, but in light of the confirmed foot and mouth outbreak, the agriculture ministry may impose a ban on all horse movement which would prevent a resumption of racing on April 14.

"There is already a ban on transport of horses except under permit."

Today's National Hunt card at Newbury is under threat from waterlogging. The course will be inspected at 7.30 this morning. Monday's rearranged Huntingdon meeting is also in doubt and may be subject to an inspection on Sunday.

webTitle: Dutch employ double-edged sword in attempt to control outbreak

fields.headline: Dutch employ double-edged sword in attempt to control outbreak
fields.standfirst:
Ring of slaughter and vaccination tried in the Netherlands

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Ring of slaughter and vaccination tried in the Netherlands.
fields.body:
As Britain yesterday prepared to slaughter thousands more animals, the Dutch agriculture ministry was piloting a very different strategy to try to bring under control their third and fourth cases of foot and mouth.

As one team of Dutch vets started killing all the animals at the centre of each outbreak, moving out to the edge of a three kilometre circle, another team was starting on the outside and moving in towards them vaccinating all animals it came across.

Eventually, the two teams will meet, by which time all the animals in the exclusion zone will have been killed, but the last ones to die will have already been inoculated, hopefully having prevented the disease spreading.

Holland is the only country in Europe to have developed and used a dual slaughter / ring-vaccination policy. The ministry concluded it was the safest way to control the virulent type O virus after watching the fraught British experience where the authorities were unable to keep up with the outbreaks and failed to control the rapid spread of the disease round the country.

The new Dutch policy was developed in the past few days but the ministry yesterday said that it followed "intense" discussions with all parties, including vets and farmers.

Many European countries are now preparing similar "Plan B" type policies which combine rapid slaughter with vaccination. But although vaccination is superficially attractive, it is not foolproof .It must be of the right type, it must be administered quickly, it can take several days to kick in, and crucially, depending on whether the vaccinated animals are later slaughtered, it can take up to a year after the last case before the country resumes its exports.

The Irish government, which confirmed its first case yesterday, dismissed vaccination. "We are not considering it for the moment", an embassy agriculture spokesman said. This is partly for geographical reasons, because they believe the outbreak can be relatively easily contained, but mainly for economic reasons. Ireland exports £5bn of meat a year, compared to Britain's £400m, and the fear of a loss of exports worth 10% of GNP for up to a year is too great to take.

Spain has indicated that it would vaccinate if outbreaks were found in Portugal. In Germany, where several states said yesterday that they were "expecting" outbreaks, the environment minister of the North Rhine Westphalia state urged the federal government to drop its opposition to vaccination. Hesse state has already said that it was preparing plans for emergency vaccinations.

The US veterinary service, which last year ran a mock outbreak to test its preparedness, concluded that slaughter alone, its first option, might not be enough to contain a major outbreak.

The British experience has been closely watched in all countries. The lessons learned, said one European government spokesman yesterday, is that you have to act extremely fast. "It seems that Britain did not go fast enough. In just a few days the virus can spread far and wide. Vaccination may be an option but only if you move quickly."

Yesterday in London, the Soil Association, which represents many of Britain's organic farmers called for emergency vaccination to be used. "The time has come for a rethink on the slaughter-only policy, said broadcaster Jonathan Dimbleby, the organisation's president.

"There should be a wide debate. Vaccination is a tool we should be thinking of using. A slaughter-only policy only works if you deal with the outlying areas, which has not happened. It has been demonstrated to be effective in a number of outbreaks in the 1980s and 1990s."

Britain has so far strongly resisted vaccination for veterinary reasons, but some observers say it may be that the virus has now spread too far to be able to be contained by vaccination. It would be logistically difficult if not impossible to ring vast areas in Cumbria and the Scottish borders, and the West country, though a consensus is building that it could be worth trying to inoculate around some of the more isolated outbreaks.

webTitle: Irish Republic in shock as foot and mouth arrives

fields.headline: Republic in shock as disease arrives
fields.standfirst:
Multi-billion pound business at risk after first case confirmed

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Multi-billion pound business at risk after first case confirmed.
fields.body:
Fears were growing for Ireland's multi-billion pound agriculture and food export business after the first case of foot and mouth was confirmed yesterday in Co Louth, just south of the Northern Ireland border.

Farmers in the area were in shock as they had hoped the Irish government's clampdown, which led to the cancellation of most sport and country events since the disease was first discovered in Britain, could keep it out.

Northern Ireland has had one case in Meigh, south Armagh, on March 1, just 10km from the latest outbreak. But there is not believed to have been any movement of animals between the two farms, which is even more worrying, as the Louth case could have another source, or the virus could have been carried in the air.

Irish police and soldiers are helping enforce a 3km exclusion zone around the farm, and a 10km surveillance zone, extending back across the border to Armagh. Troops were also sent to Dublin port to monitor disinfectant procedures.

The Irish government has imposed an immediate ban on livestock exports, but it is hoping a meat and dairy produce ban can be restricted to items from the infected region.

The Irish agriculture minister, Joe Walsh, said: "The hope is that, due to the stringency of the response to the alert, the outbreak will be limited to the Cooley peninsula of Co Louth.

"We would make the case to both the EU and other countries to continue to accept our beef and dairy products from all parts of the country outside the exclusion zone."

But even so, the news is devastating for the economy in both parts of the island, which relies so heavily on agriculture. The Dublin stock market tumbled 5% in response.

There are 130,000 farms in the Irish republic, where agriculture and agri-related business employ 270,000 people. In Northern Ireland, farms and the agri-food industry employ 60,000.

Ulster exports around 80% of its farming produce. In the republic, the annual agri-export market is worth almost £5bn, or 13% of total exports.

A total of 138 sheep on the infected Louth farm have already been destroyed, and Mr Walsh has pledged an aggressive policy of strategic slaughter. Culling of around 4,000 animals on farms within 1km started last night.

Tom Parlon, head of the Irish Farmers' Association, said he thought all 40,000 sheep in the area might have to be slaughtered.

webTitle: A soldier's diary of foot and mouth

fields.headline: Called up to the slaughter
fields.standfirst:
My week: Ken Moore

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: My week: Ken Moore.
fields.body:
Ken Moore is a warrant officer with the First Battalion of the King's Own Royal Border Regiment. On Monday he was deployed to Cumbria to help with the disposal of culled foot and mouth infected livestock.

I am what they call a permanent staff instructor for a Territorial Army unit. Every TA centre in Britain has an instructor from the regular army. A general daily routine would be planning the forthcoming weekend's training, planning the Tuesday evening get-together, what we call the drill night, and sending people on courses. So what I am doing now is vastly different.

I was called up at home at 10am on Monday and told to be at Carlisle Castle by 3.30pm. A group of about 10 or 12 of us from different regiments were the first to be called in. When we first arrive on a farm we speak to the farmer, making ourselves known to him, and letting him know that we are there to try and help. Then in conjunction with Maff and the vets, we come up with the best plan of how to dispose of the animals. Basically, my day is spent liaising with the people back in Maff headquarters, telling them what we are short of, what we require, how the operation's going on the farm and how the disposal is going.

When I first got to the farm I was posted to the farmer was devastated. He was emotional, very upset. It was obviously a great shock to him that all his stock was going to go. He was never against the cull. He realised that he had got foot and mouth on his land, and the animals needed to go. But I suppose if it is your livelihood, it's still going to devastate you. I haven't spoken to any other local farmers, I've just been too busy. But speaking to the rest of the lads, it seems the other farmers feel the same way.

I started work on the farm after I was deployed on Monday afternoon, then worked all day on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. I'll be here until they start cleansing the farm - we don't know how long that will be.

webTitle: G2: Farmer's diary on foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Foot and mouth creeps closer to our diarist's farm. The disease is now only 10km away

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth creeps closer to our diarist's farm. The disease is now only 10km away.
fields.body:
Our second new calf of the season has been safely delivered, and Peter and Graham (our shepherd cum stockman) are cleaning out the big cow shed. To all intents and purposes, life on this farm goes on, but underneath the monotony of our day-to-day chores, the reality is very different.

We all feel like sitting ducks, waiting to be the next farm to go. Two more of our friends have had their holdings confirmed as infected and the disease is travelling much too fast. Now it has reached a farm just north of Haltwhistle and Peter is very worried it will simply rip along the Roman Wall corridor from west to east and annihilate us.

Meanwhile the preparations for lambing continue: I have a long list of medicines to collect from the vet and one for the agricultural merchants. The freezers and cupboards must be full, as there is no time to shop when the lambing starts. Every year we have two extra casual staff who help us. Archie Hall (a retired shepherd) comes for four or five weeks, and Ian Todd will be coming for three weeks.

Ian is taking holiday from his normal office-based job to come. As he is worried about bringing infection in to the farm he will move in with us next week. We'll have to do some furniture-moving this weekend to give him his own bedroom and bathroom suite. We'll be six for every meal, and in order to cope with the immense physical work and long hours the meals must be big and nourishing.

Margaret Addison farms near Penrith. I spoke to her at the beginning of the week and although she was anxious (as we all are) all was well. But now their animals have contracted foot and mouth and they are to be killed (probably today). The nearest other case to their holding is five miles away and Margaret blames the seagulls swooping in from the Solway, drawn in by newly ploughed fields. Their 350 ewes are in the middle of lambing, and all their stock including a pedigree Simmental cattle herd, built up over many years, is to be destroyed.

The vet came quite quickly to look at their sick cow, and the diagnosis didn't take long. The problem is still the disposal. Margaret has been told there will be a wait of 10 to 12 days for a pyre. There is no coal. There will be an exploratory dig on their farm to see if burial is possible, but Margaret thinks it will be unlikely. The winter has been so wet that the water table is too high, and there might be seepage into the water courses and eventually into the nation's water supply.

Now the current message from the scientists is that this nightmare we are all unwittingly caught up in could go on until August, and peak may not be until May. Is it surprising, then, that we wonder how to carry on with daily lives? We are still hoping to keep our sheep alive and disease-free, but we wonder if we do escape the scourge of foot and mouth, will we ever be able to sell the lambs?

It is true we are all becoming paranoid about our livestock and upset at the slightest thing. I have had tears in my eyes several times this week - it is no pleasure to see big Cumbrian farmers cry on the Channel 4 news, and watch healthy, Blackface ewes rounded up for slaughter. It is not in the proper order of things.

While the prime minister visits Cumbria, I'm off outside to check on some sheep. We're all very concerned and constantly monitor the large flock's progress. Instead of day by day, we are now down to checking the flock hour by hour, as there is something we're worried about ... Or is it just our over-active imaginations?

Latest news via the phone is bad. Another confirmed case in Northumberland, that makes three today. This one is at Wark in the North Tyne valley, a heavily stocked area only 10 kilometres west of here.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-wall, Northumberland. Her diary will be back on Tuesday. Talk to Sarah today on the Guardian network at 2.30pm at Special report: foot and mouth

fields.headline: Car tsar as output falls 20%
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: The government yesterday moved to boost Britain's car industry with fresh support as the domestic auto sector suffered two damaging blows.
fields.body:
The government yesterday moved to boost Britain's car industry with fresh support as the domestic auto sector suffered two damaging blows.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry, said a new innovation and growth team - made up of industrialists and DTI officials - would examine ways of underpinning the UK industry. The group, to be chaired by Sir Ian Gibson, Nissan's senior vice-president, will, he said, look at medium and long-term issues facing the car sector.

Mr Byers' move came as official figures showed a near-20% fall in UK car production last month to 129,099 cars. Output for the home market fell 15.2%; that for export dropped 23.1% in what was due to be a record year for sales.

Christopher Macgowan, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, said: "It would be wrong to view February's drop in production as part of a slide in fortunes in UK car manufacturing." He said output would climb as new investments and models came on stream.

But Ford sent a shiver through the industry by pulling out of October's biennial London motor show - the latest after BMW, Peugeot, Toyota, VW and Audi.

webTitle: US, Russia in tit-for-tat 'cold war' expulsions

fields.headline: US, Russia in tit-for-tat 'cold war' expulsions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The biggest barrage of tit-for-tat diplomatic expulsions between Washington and Moscow since the end of the cold war was under way last night, sending US-Russian relations to a new low and providing the Bush administration with its first big test on the international stage.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and Amelia Gentleman in Moscow
fields.body:
The biggest barrage of tit-for-tat diplomatic expulsions between Washington and Moscow since the end of the cold war was under way last night, sending US-Russian relations to a new low and providing the Bush administration with its first big test on the international stage.

Fewer than 24 hours after the US told 50 alleged Russian spies to pack their bags in the wake of the arrest of the suspected FBI spy Robert Hanssen, the Russian foreign ministry was reported to be preparing to expel an unspecified number of alleged US agents from Moscow.

Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, telephoned the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, and told him that Russia did not want to get rid of the American diplomats but that "adequate measures" had to be taken after Wednesday's action by the US. None of Washington's expulsions was justified, Mr Ivanov told Mr Powell.

The exact number of Americans being expelled was not immediately clear, but Reuters reported Mr Ivanov as confirming that 50 would be involved.

The ministry of foreign affairs, in a statement to the Interfax news agency last night, denied that Mr Ivanov had said 50 Americans were involved. "Russia will respond adequately. You will not have to wait long," the ministry quoted Mr Ivanov as saying.

President Bush and his top advisers battled to present their action as only a temporary chill in relations with Russia brought on by the Hanssen case. Mr Bush said he expected to have "a good working relationship" with Moscow.

But Mr Ivanov called the expulsions a "political act" and an adviser to President Vladimir Putin condemned them as "a relapse into the cold war era".

"Presented with the facts, I made the decision. It was the right thing to do," Mr Bush told reporters after delivering a speech to newspaper editors.

Mr Ivanov told CNN and NBC in an interview in Moscow: "What happened today is a return to the cold war. It is an attempt by those who do not want a constructive dialogue between our countries to push us backwards, to push us back into confrontation."

Washington's decision to get rid of so many Russian diplomats from the US followed the arrest of Mr Hanssen last month on charges of spying for Russia for 15 years. Mr Hanssen was arrested in Virginia moments after he dropped off a package, prosecutors say. He is next due in court on May 21.

Four of those expelled from the US are said to have been directly involved with Mr Hanssen, as were two others who had already left Washington before the decisions were announced. But the bulk of those who have been asked to leave were told to go because of "long-standing concerns about the level of their intelligence presence in the United States", a state department spokesman said.

Russian anger at the news had been predicted in Washington, but Moscow seemed to be opting for a tone of injured dignity rather than outrage.

High-ranking anonymous Kremlin sources said the move to expel such a large number of diplomats would have "inevitable consequences" for Russian-US relations.

webTitle: CIA drops its Middle East mediator role

fields.headline: CIA drops its Middle East mediator role
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The CIA has abandoned its efforts to persuade Israel and the Palestinians to renew security cooperation, further removing the Bush administration from the Middle East dispute.
fields.body:
The CIA has abandoned its efforts to persuade Israel and the Palestinians to renew security cooperation, further removing the Bush administration from the Middle East dispute.

The agency appears to have arrived at its decision to stop serving as messenger and mediator for two reasons: the six-month uprising which has destroyed Palestinian security cooperation with Israel; and the general resolve of the Bush administration to step back from the conflict.

"We continue to believe the resumption of direct discussions, including the bilateral security cooperation, is a realistic step towards restoring trust and confidence between the parties," a US embassy spokesman in Tel Aviv said yesterday.

Despite President George Bush's comments this week to the visiting Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, that his administration would facilitate deals, and not impose them, there is deep frustration with the failure to enforce the agreements the CIA helped broker.

"They decided this would not work - being the middle men in security cooperation - so long as neither side, particularly the Palestinians, is keeping deals," a US official in Washington said. "Why would they want the responsibility for two cats that are trying constantly to scratch each other's eyes out?"

The US, Israel and the Palestinians formally entered into a three-way security arrangement in the autumn of 1998, after the Wye Plantation agreement. But the agency began training Palestinian policemen, in an effort to turn guerrilla fighters into a professional force, from 1996.

For a time, the arrangements worked, with Palestinian police serving as the frontline of Israel's defence against Islamic militants by jailing hundreds of Islamic Jihad and Hamas activists.

Efforts to round up illegal weapons inside the West Bank and Gaza, however, were an utter failure - with only a few dozen guns, many of them antiques, turned in.

Although the CIA is stepping back from local security arrangements, its role in the region will not come to an end; it will continue contacts with Israeli intelligence.

However, while the uprising continues, it seems unlikely that it can go on with its training programme. The three-way security arrangement had begun to falter even before the Palestinian uprising erupted, with the former prime minister, Ehud Barak, eager to bypass the CIA and barrel ahead into negotiations with the Palestinians.

But when the intifada erupted, the CIA took an extraordinarily high-profile role to try to get security cooperation on track. The agency's director, George Tenet, turned up at an emergency summit in the Egyptian resort of Sharm al-Sheikh last October, which provided the guidelines for successive ceasefires that never lasted more than a few days.

It was uncertain yesterday what effect the CIA's withdrawal would have on the ground. Joint security cooperation, after all, ended six months ago. But despite the rhetoric of Mr Sharon, who has again taken to referring to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, as a terrorist, there have been some encouraging signs.

Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs met one week ago, and an Israeli army spokesmen said yesterday that Mr Arafat's Palestinian administration recently arrested some of the Islamic militants Israel blames for bombings inside the borders of the Jewish state.

However, the military official said the most important members of Hamas and Islamic Jihad remained at large.

For the Israeli government, the CIA's withdrawal is unlikely to be seen as a setback.

But for the Palestinians, the CIA's decision cuts another of its ties to the corridors of power in Washington. For Mr Arafat - the most frequent official foreign visitor to the White House during the Clinton years - the CIA's involvement was a crucial way of maintaining ties with the US.

Last month, Mr Arafat appealed directly to the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, who was on a visit to Ramallah, for the CIA to resume an active role. Mr Powell refused.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's
America
fields.trailText: BCCI case will go to trial
fields.body:
BCCI case will go to trial

Liquidators for collapsed bank BCCI were yesterday granted the right to sue the Bank of England for up to £1bn in damages.

Nearly 10 years after BCCI was closed, the House of Lords ruled by three to two that the liquidators could take their case to trial. Deloitte & Touche alleges the Bank of England acted with "wilful recklessness" or misfeasance in regulating BCCI.

In his judgment Lord Hope of Craighead said: "I would hold that justice requires that the claimants be given an opportunity to present their case at trial so that its merits may be assessed in the light of the evidence."

The high court will be told to arrange a trial at the earliest possible date. Liquidators said that would take at least a year.

FirstGroup chief's sell-off

John Osbaldiston, deputy chief executive of rail and bus business FirstGroup, and his wife yesterday made nearly £1m by selling shares in the company.

Sale of 332,500 shares, mainly executive options exercised at 123.5p each, was made at 298p each.

Mr Osbaldiston and his wife now own 3,500 shares in the company, worth £10,447 at FirstGroup's current price of 298.5p.

P&G to shed 9,600 staff

Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods group, confirmed it was cutting a further 9,600 jobs yesterday. About 60% of the cuts will come from outside the US. The company was unable to say how many of its 5,600 British jobs would go.

Under a plan announced in 1999, the manufacturer of Crest toothpaste and Pringles crisps expects to shed a further 7,800 jobs. In all, a 15.8% reduction of the company's 110,000 worldwide workforce is envisaged.

P&G has manufacturing plants in Northumberland and Kent. The redundancies are expected to cost about $1.4bn (£1bn), with the bulk of costs to be incurred this year.

The company said the cuts should result in savings of $600m-$700m the following year.

Farms crisis costs JCB jobs

Excavator company JCB is to cut up to 350 jobs at its British factories.

The company, which also makes agricultural equipment, said foot and mouth disease was partly to blame for a slowdown in business.

The cuts amount to 10% of its workforce and will affect its seven plants in Staffordshire and two in Wrexham, north Wales.

webTitle: Leader: Panic in Washington over spies

fields.headline: That sinking feeling
fields.standfirst:
Panic fears - and cold war echoes

Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: A particular nightmare surfaced this week in the form of Mr Bush's expulsion of 50 or so Russian "spies".
fields.body:
Russia's great novelist, Ivan Turgenev, once likened life to a man sitting in a small boat in a calm, limitless ocean, staring at the dark silt of the sea bottom where he discerns "shapeless monsters". These are life's hazards, looked at from afar. "Then one of the monsters begins to emerge from the murk, rising higher and higher, becoming ever more repellently, clearly discernible ... Another minute and its impact will overturn the boat. And then, once again, its outlines grow dimmer, it recedes to the sea bed, and there it lies motionless, but for a slight movement of its tail ... But the destined day will come, and then the boat will capsize."

Whether Vladimir Putin and George Bush subscribe to Turgenev's romantic fatalism is a question that may never be answered. But that they both worry about lurking, shapeless monsters is beyond doubt. A particular nightmare surfaced this week in the form of Mr Bush's expulsion of 50 or so Russian "spies". It is hard to exaggerate the distress caused within the US government by the alleged perfidy of FBI agent Robert Hanssen, arrested last month. Americans used to think all traitors were English homosexuals educated at Cambridge. The coming to light of a Russian-paid mole deep within their ranks was thus a doubly shocking horror that provoked, but only in part, this swingeing retaliation.

Mr Bush thinks he has other reasons for concern. Defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld again lambasted Russia this week as an "active proliferator" of mass destruction weapons. His deputy, Paul Wolfowitz, was ruder still. "These people seem to be willing to sell anything to anyone for money. It recalls Lenin's phrase that the capitalists will sell the very rope from which we will hang them."

While Mr Putin may enjoy the irony of a Pentagon chief excoriating Russian capitalism, he cannot mistake this toughening tone. From Washington's point of view, other objectionable Russian activities include attempts to scupper US missile plans, block Nato expansion, and meddle in Korea. Mr Putin wrote to Mr Bush in January suggesting a bilateral summit. But none has been fixed. Mr Bush is instead trying to fashion a more "realistic" Russia policy, one supposedly more focused on America's national interest than that pursued by Bill "Mr Softy" Clinton.

Mr Putin can understand that. It is exactly what he has been doing for Russia since becoming president. But he has his demons, too. One is what the Kremlin sees as an increasingly aggressive US military posture. Another is its disregard for international law, in Israel, Iraq and Serbia. Another is Mr Bush's lack of interest in continuing bilateral aid and his Chechnya "interference". These strains and tensions are serious and may get worse. But they do not add up to cold war II. The ideology is lacking. Russia is no match (and knows it). And neither really wants to start all that again. When it comes to the spectre of proliferation, terrorism, environmental degradation and, perhaps, an expansionist China, both are very much in the same boat, hoping Turgenev's "destined day" never comes.

webTitle: Larry Elliott on the US economy

fields.headline: The contagion spreads
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Now it's official. The Dow Jones index - symbol of blue-chip America - is in a bear market. A month ago the stock market carnage was confined to the over-hyped bubble stocks of the new economy. Yesterday it was stocks of companies in the real economy that were being caned.
fields.body:
Now it's official. The Dow Jones index - symbol of blue-chip America - is in a bear market. A month ago the stock market carnage was confined to the over-hyped bubble stocks of the new economy. Yesterday it was stocks of companies in the real economy that were being caned.

The spread of the contagion from the new to the old economy marks a new phase in the stock market decline of the past year. Until now, it had been possible to say that this was simply a case of over-exuberance in one specific sector, and that when the Nasdaq was going down the Dow was going up. No longer.

Three questions need to be answered: why is this happening, how much further have the markets got to fall, and what sort of damage will falling share prices do to the real economy around the world?

The answer to the first question is pretty simple. Despite all the guff about the dawn of a new golden age in the US, the truth has been much more prosaic. Yes, there has been a surge in productivity since the mid-1990s, but a large chunk of the improvement has been the result of an economy growing unsustainably fast. Britain experienced something similar in the late 1980s, when there was the same loose talk about the economy reaching a new plateau of achievement.

The boom, amplified by the laxity of monetary policy in the US to counter the non-existent threat of the millennium bug, turned to bust once the Federal Reserve started to jack up interest rates last year.

Growth is slowing down rapidly in the US, consumer and business confidence has fallen sharply, and there has been a blizzard of profits warnings from all parts of the economy. Alan Greenspan has cut interest rates three times since the start of the year, but - like Nigel Lawson - he is in danger of going from hero to zero in a matter of months.

There are those in the market who say this is a good time to buy. With the Nasdaq down more than 60% and the Dow off 20%, the smart investor should be prepared to stick it out for the long haul.

The performance of the Nasdaq this week gives some support to this theory, since it has remained fairly stable as the Dow has plunged.

However, this assumes that the Nasdaq will bounce back from its current bombed-out levels rather than remain in the doldrums for years to come. As Robert Shiller notes in his book, Irrational Exuberance, the real S&P composite index did not return to its levels in September 1929 - just before the great Crash - for 29 years. Measured by the price-earnings ratio of quoted US companies, the S&P is still trading above its long-term average, and may have further to fall once investors realise that the high ratings for defensive old economy stocks are not warranted during a downturn. As such, the message for those willing to take a punt is: be careful and be selective.

Of course, should the US economy shrug off the effects of the stock market meltdown then all the predictions of gloom will amount to a storm in a tea cup. There have been times, in 1987 for example, when what was happening on Wall Street had absolutely no effect on the real economy. But this appears to be different.

First, consumers are likely to take a big hit. While it is true that share prices are only back to the levels of a couple of years ago, Americans have also taken on much higher levels of debt. According to Graham Turner of GFC Economics, the stock market crash has taken real wealth levels back to where they were in early 1995..

Second, there are signs of increasing pain in the corporate sector. Bond spreads are widening, with many companies faced with higher interest rates even as their earnings are taking a nosedive. Interest rates may be coming down, but they are not coming down fast enough to save these firms from serious financial problems.

It is almost eight weeks before the Fed's next scheduled meeting to discuss interest rates. The odds on a cut before then are shortening by the day.
