webTitle: Comment:  US and Russia resume an old game

fields.headline: The US expels some Russian spies. It's the old chess game
fields.standfirst:
To be useful, intelligence must first of all be intelligent

Special report: Russia
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: To be useful, intelligence must first of all be intelligent.
fields.body:
The cold war is dead but won't lie down. In the same week that Egon Krenz's appeal against his conviction for being responsible for the murders of would-be escapers over the wall has failed, we have one of those huge expulsions of spies under diplomatic cover that provided periodic drama during the years of east-west confrontation. The Mir space station, it seems, is not the only chunk of the recent past falling about our ears.

The American action against the alleged Russian agents, like a whole range of other spy scandals and revelations in many countries, raises the issue of just what the role and value of espionage is in our supposedly new era. It also touches on the important question of whether, under Bush and Putin, some regression to the hostile relations of earlier years could be on the cards.

The two are connected, for espionage can be indulged and even encouraged between countries that are bent on good relations with each other. On the other hand, if they are heading toward a more difficult passage in their joint affairs, it can be used to trigger quarrels and stage humiliations that will make things worse. This is not to say that spying and foreign policy are the same thing, but only that they intersect in ways that can be illuminating.

The expulsion of the Russians is part of a longer story which probably began late last year with the defection of two senior Russian agents, one at the United Nations in New York, and one in Ottawa. The best guess is that these two provided information that led to the arrest last month of Robert Hanssen, the long time FBI mole whose traitorous career rivalled that of Aldrich Ames at the CIA. Further information from them, as well as the interrogation of Hanssen, may have helped identify some of the 50 now ordered to leave America. Or, more likely, the Americans already knew all or most of these men, but felt they needed a grand expulsion to offset the Hanssen affair.

The Hanssen arrest, in any case, may well have been the espionage equivalent of checkmate - a final move compromising everybody on both sides, and therefore making it necessary that the pieces be cleared from the board in preparation for a new game. Still, that could have been done both more gradually and more discreetly.

There can be no disputing the value to governments of good intelligence in the broadest sense. The debate over secret intelligence, however, revolves around the question of whether it is an expensive way of providing and protecting vital information or an expensive way of providing and protecting mediocre information.

There is the additional liability that intelligence agencies can skew their product to suit the prejudices of politicians or the needs of defence establishments. As far as human intelligence or "humint" is is concerned, the modern picture is often not encouraging. The former CIA agent Edward Shirley has written of American spies virtually confined to embassies, rarely walking the streets of the cities to which they are posted, and often without the language or other skills they need to interpret what little they do pick up. He has accused colleagues of pinching their "intelligence" from newspapers and pretending it was obtained covertly. But even where both human and other kinds of intelligence, from electronic eavesdropping and surveillance, are both good, there is the problem of interpretation. The history of secret intelligence notoriously shows many cases of good information being ignored or misinterpreted.

Counter-intelligence carries special political dangers, since it can become at once an instrument of domestic control and a permanent irritant in foreign relations. The "foreign enemy" and the "internal enemy" are concepts which feed and grow on each other. In Russia there are some signs of a worrying reversion to the bad habits of Soviet days, with a number of cases under way in which Russians have been accused of espionage for passing along information which was not secret in any military sense.

Sometimes the information has been controversial or embarrassing to the Russian state, like revelations about radioactive pollution. Sometimes it has simply been well-organised factual material, all on the public record, supplied to western businesses. Either way, a government run by a former KGB man and which now includes many ex-intelligence people among its officials seems to be signalling that it expects to control information and will punish those who break its rules.

Why are Russia and America, and perhaps other western countries as well, still pointing so many of their intelligence big guns at each other? Russia, the Americans say, normally has 450 agents in the United States. The Russians recently claimed to have identified 350 Russians working as spies for foreign states, presumably most of them Nato countries. It is admittedly important to Nato countries, for example, whether Russia is or is not cheating on arms control treaties by conducting nuclear tests in Novaya Zemla, and the state of the national missile defence project in America is unavoidably of interest to Russians.

But there are other critical matters around. Intelligence chiefs might reply that, in addition to keeping an eye on each other, they have reorganised to focus on new dangers such as nuclear proliferation, other weapons of mass destruction, terrorism, environmental threats, and organised crime. There is no shortage of grand mission statements on these lines. The trouble here is that it is not evident that secret intelligence should be in a lead role across this whole spectrum, nor that it has so far delivered much of value. There is a consensus that governments need to be better at forecasting risk, identifying conflicts before they erupt, and trying to alleviate the conditions that give rise to conflict. But, if this ambition is to be fulfilled, it will be by a concerted effort by many organisations, inside and outside government.

One of the ways intelligence services can best help is by sharing information, not something they find easy to do even when their governments are close allies. Policemen involved in the hunt for Balkan war criminals have described agonising sessions in which western intelligence agencies placed scraps of information on the table like poker players guarding their hands. And it is in the Balkans that the sharpest commentary on intelligence performance can be found today.

While Russian and American agents were manoeuvring in Washington and Moscow, a threat was developing in Macedonia that burst on the US and European governments, Nato, the EU, the Kosovo Force, and the Kosovo international administration like a thunderclap two weeks ago. If the leaders concerned had had any warning from their diplomats and their intelligence people they gave no sign of it. It only goes to underline that, to be useful, intelligence must first of all be intelligent, which is to say it should be looking for the right things.

fields.headline: Back to the bad old days?
fields.standfirst:
Washington and Moscow have never had the easiest of relationships. But this week's expulsions of Russian diplomats from the US amid allegations of espionage have sparked fears of a new cold war. Martin Kettle reports

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Washington and Moscow have never had the easiest of relationships. But this week's expulsions of Russian diplomats from the US amid allegations of espionage have sparked fears of a new cold war. Martin Kettle reports.
fields.body:
It would make a compelling opening scene for a spy movie. The head of the FBI, attending mass with his family on a typical Sunday morning at his local Catholic church. A few rows away another FBI agent, his wife and their six children, also regular worshippers at St Catherine of Siena. Elsewhere in the congregation, a Republican senator, an outspoken Supreme Court justice, and a former quarterback for the Washington Redskins. The Latin mass. Bach organ music. An eloquent priest whose weekly sermons enshrined an implacable view of what is right and wrong. Conservative America incarnate.

Louis Freeh, the FBI director, and FBI special agent Robert Hanssen worshipped the same god in the same church. But the two men, it seems, served very different secular masters. For six years, Freeh has ruled the bureau with a rod of conservative iron that often riled the Clinton administration and made him a darling of the Republicans. But for 15 years, until he was arrested near his home in Virginia last month, Hanssen is said to have had spied for Russia.

On Wednesday afternoon, after weeks of intense argument at the highest levels of George Bush's administration, the Americans unveiled a dramatic response to the 56-year-old family man's alleged treachery.

The US secretary of state Colin Powell summoned the Russian ambassador in Washington, Yuri Ushakov, to his offices on the top floor of the state department. Curtly, Powell told Ushakov that the US was expelling six Russians said to have been directly involved with Hanssen. Two had already left, including the embassy press attache Vladimir Frolov. Four more were to leave within days. And Powell announced that Washington wanted another 46 other named Russian diplomats to pack their bags and leave by July 1.

"It was the right thing to do," Bush told reporters yesterday, making it clear that he was directly responsible for the move. "I was presented with the facts. I made the decision. It was the right thing to do." In Moscow, Russian foreign minister Igor Ivanov has said the same number of American diplomats will be sent home.

The American purge is easily the largest expulsion of alleged spies in the decade since the collapse of the Soviet Union. It posts a wide range of big questions about the Bush administration's attitude to Russia, about its foreign policy and about the future of US-Russian relations. But it is important to remember that the expulsions almost certainly would not have taken place had it not been for the Hanssen case, which appears on course to be easily the most significant case of treachery in the 90s.

The scale of Hanssen's suspected betrayal is spectacular. Over 15 years he is said to have passed more than 6,000 pages of documents and 27 computer discs to his handlers from Moscow. A succession of immensely sensitive jobs made Hanssen a priceless espionage asset. He worked in FBI counter-intelligence for two thirds of the time he was spying for Moscow, while for five years he was the bureau's liaison man with the state department itself.

Perhaps the most spectacular piece of information that Hanssen is said to have passed to his handlers was the fact that the Americans had dug a secret surveillance tunnel underneath the newly built Soviet embassy - now the Russian embassy - that was erected on a hill above Washington's Georgetown in the 1980s. The tunnel remained in active use until well into the 90s, ostensibly enabling the Americans to eavesdrop on secret Soviet and Russian conversations and communications. Now, however, it appears the Russians knew what was going on beneath their embassy all along.

All this is classic secret-world stuff. Hanssen reportedly told his interrogators that he was led into spying through a fascination for the career of the British double agent Kim Philby. But while Philby and the spies of his generation took up treachery because of their ideological commitment to communism, Hanssen was allegedly in it for the money. He is accused of selling his secrets for an estimated $1.4m.

Fifteen years ago, round about the time that Hanssen allegedly began his career as an agent, the Reagan administration threw out more than 80 Soviet diplomats in an action known as Operation Famish. But that was then. This is now. And it raises all kinds of questions, not just about the continuing secret conflict between Washington and Moscow, but about the world in which such espionage still thrives.

Russian spying in the US and the west has "increased dramatically" in the past five years after a post-Soviet lull, according to Stranislav Lunev, a former spy who is the highest-ranking Russian defector ever to flee to the US. Its aim is "the restoration of power and influence", and above all, of industrial competitiveness, Lunev says. He estimates there were 450 Russian agents in the US before the new purge.

"If you are asking me whether this means we are going back to the cold war, then the answer is no," said Bill Clinton's former national security adviser, Tony Lake, yesterday. "There's no Soviet Union. You could not recreate those times."

Lake's response to the Bush administration's dramatic action was typical of the instant assessments being made elsewhere in the US and western Europe yesterday. In Moscow, Sergei Prikhodko, a foreign policy aide to President Vladimir Putin, may have condemned Washington's moves as a "campaign of spy mania" and as "a fallback to the cold war epoch", but the general response among foreign policy analysts is that the Bush administration is still shaping its strategy towards post-Soviet Russia.

"There is an instinct in every new administration to distinguish itself from the last," said Lake. "But there is almost always a swing back to pragmatism as the realities of the world intrude. Just because we've elected a new American president, it doesn't mean that we've elected new American interests."

In the cold war years when many of the officials around Bush cut their teeth as foreign policy specialists, the realities of the world were straightforward. There was a well-armed enemy, and everything was judged in the context of the struggle with communism. Today, the picture is far more fragmented and subtle.

"Many Russian futures are possible, ranging from political resurgence to dissolution," a Central Intelligence Agency assessment concluded late last year. "The general drift, however, is toward authoritarianism, although not to the extreme extent of the Soviet period. Russia will focus its foreign policy goals on reestablishing lost influence in the former Soviet republics to the south, fostering ties to Europe and Asia, and presenting itself as a significant player vis-a-vis the United States."

In the decade since the Soviet system collapsed, US-Russia relations have suffered far more setbacks than the confident mood at the start of the decade suggested. As the Bush advisers sat in exile in the foreign policy think tanks of Washington for eight years, they became increasingly disdainful towards the way that the Clinton administration handled Moscow. The charge that Clinton had "lost Russia" became widespread.

That has led many observers to suspect that the Bush team is overly eager to rebuild a relationship with Russia based on simple certainties. Condoleezza Rice, the White House national security adviser, is a Russia expert and is the leading exponent of the view that Russia must now be treated as a weakened, but dangerous, strategic threat to the US. Rice's hand can be seen behind this week's expulsions.

One thing, though, is already clear about the Bush administration's approach to the new Russia. It is in no hurry to put US-Russian relations on any kind of a pedestal.

"Russia acts as if the US still viewed the world through the prism of its relations with Russia," Thomas Graham of the Washington-based Carnegie Endowment for International Peace told Reuters yesterday. "Russia does not lie at the centre of US foreign policy, nor can it."

Bush has done little to suggest that Russia is either a friend or a priority. He has said that he will not negotiate reductions in nuclear arsenals with Putin; instead, he will simply act unilaterally. Bush and his advisers have dismissed the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, which Moscow routinely describes as a "cornerstone" of international security, as "ancient history".

There is an unmistakeable contempt in many comments that Bush and his advisers made about Putin's Russia during last year's election campaign. That mood has been carried through into the early weeks of the administration. While Bush has been available for meetings with leaders of allies such as Britain, Germany, Israel, South Korea and Japan, old foes such as Russia and China - and the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat - have been left in the cold. His meeting with China's vice-premier yesterday was shifted to allow him to meet the prime minister of Japan first. There are no plans for a Bush-Putin summit.

Yesterday, while the details of the expulsions were still being sorted, Bush seemed anxious to try to move on. "I'm confident that we can have good relations with the Russians. There are some areas where we can work together."

At the start of this week, Bush travelled to a place now officially known as the George Bush Centre for Intelligence, better known as the CIA headquarters at Langley, Virginia, but recently renamed in honour of the president's father. He went to address CIA staff, praising them as "dedicated and daring" and stressing that the US today faced "new and different threats, sometimes hard to define and defend against."

Those difficulties of definition and judgment are very real. In the past, the American preoccupation with the Russian threat was based on fear of Russia's strength. Nowadays, the preoccupation is with Russia's weakness. The change recalls the remark of Napoleon's foreign minister Talleyrand, that the real problem about Russia is that it is always, at one and the same time "too strong and too weak". If Bonaparte could not solve the riddle perhaps it is no surprise that Bush has not yet done so either.

But while Philby and the spies of his generation took up treachery because of their ideological commitment to communism, Hanssen was allegedly in it for the money. He is accused of selling his secrets for an estimated $1.4m. Fifteen years ago, round about the time that Hanssen allegedly began his career as an agent, the Reagan administration threw out more than 80 Soviet diplomats in an action known as Operation Famish. But that was then. This is now. And it raises all kinds of questions, not just about the continuing secret conflict between Washington and Moscow, but about the world in which such espionage still thrives. Russian spying in the US and the west has "increased dramatically" in the past five years after a post-Soviet lull, according to Stranislav Lunev, a former spy who is the highest-ranking Russian defector ever to flee to the US. Its aim is "the restoration of power and influence", and above all, of industrial competitiveness, Lunev says. He estimates there were 450 Russian agents in the US before the new purge. "If you are asking me whether this means we are going back to the cold war, then the answer is no," said Bill Clinton's former national security adviser, Tony Lake, yesterday. "There's no Soviet Union. You could not recreate those times." Lake's response to the Bush administration's dramatic action was typical of the instant assessments being made elsewhere in the US and western Europe yesterday. In Moscow, Sergei Prikhodko, a foreign policy aide to President Vladimir Putin, may have condemned Washington's moves as a "campaign of spy mania" and as "a fallback to the cold war epoch", but the general response among foreign policy analysts is that the Bush administration is still shaping its strategy towards post-Soviet Russia. "There is an instinct in every new administration to distinguish itself from the last," said Lake. "But there is almost always a swing back to pragmatism as the realities of the world intrude. Just because we've elected a new American president, it doesn't mean that we've elected new American interests." In the cold war years when many of the officials around Bush cut their teeth as foreign policy specialists, the realities of the world were straightforward. There was a well-armed enemy, and everything was judged in the context of the struggle with communism. Today, the picture is far more fragmented and subtle. "Many Russian futures are possible, ranging from political resurgence to dissolution," a Central Intelligence Agency assessment concluded late last year. "The general drift, however, is toward authoritarianism, although not to the extreme extent of the Soviet period. Russia will focus its foreign policy goals on reestablishing lost influence in the former Soviet republics to the south, fostering ties to Europe and Asia, and presenting itself as a significant player vis-a-vis the United States." In the decade since the Soviet system collapsed, US-Russia relations have suffered far more setbacks than the confident mood at the start of the decade suggested. As the Bush advisers sat in exile in the foreign policy think tanks of Washington for eight years, they became increasingly disdainful towards the way that the Clinton administration handled Moscow. The charge that Clinton had "lost Russia" became widespread. That has led many observers to suspect that the Bush team is overly eager to rebuild a relationship with Russia based on simple certainties. Condoleezza Rice, the White House national security adviser, is a Russia expert and is the leading exponent of the view that Russia must now be treated as a weakened, but dangerous, strategic threat to the US. Rice's hand can be seen behind this week's expulsions. One thing, though, is already clear about the Bush administration's approach to the new Russia. It is in no hurry to put US-Russian relations on any kind of a pedestal. "Russia acts as if the US still viewed the world through the prism of its relations with Russia," Thomas Graham of the Washington-based Carnegie Endowment for International Peace told Reuters yesterday. "Russia does not lie at the centre of US foreign policy, nor can it." Bush has done little to suggest that Russia is either a friend or a priority. He has said that he will not negotiate reductions in nuclear arsenals with Putin; instead, he will simply act unilaterally. Bush and his advisers have dismissed the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, which Moscow routinely describes as a "cornerstone" of international security, as "ancient history". There is an unmistakeable contempt in many comments that Bush and his advisers made about Putin's Russia during last year's election campaign. That mood has been carried through into the early weeks of the administration. While Bush has been available for meetings with leaders of allies such as Britain, Germany, Israel, South Korea and Japan, old foes such as Russia and China - and the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat - have been left in the cold. His meeting with China's vice-premier yesterday was shifted to allow him to meet the prime minister of Japan first. There are no plans for a Bush-Putin summit. Yesterday, while the details of the expulsions were still being sorted, Bush seemed anxious to try to move on. "I'm confident that we can have good relations with the Russians. There are some areas where we can work together." At the start of this week, Bush travelled to a place now officially known as the George Bush Centre for Intelligence, better known as the CIA headquarters at Langley, Virginia, but recently renamed in honour of the president's father. He went to address CIA staff, praising them as "dedicated and daring" and stressing that the US today faced "new and different threats, sometimes hard to define and defend against." Those difficulties of definition and judgment are very real. In the past, the American preoccupation with the Russian threat was based on fear of Russia's strength. Nowadays, the preoccupation is with Russia's weakness. The change recalls the remark of Napoleon's foreign minister Talleyrand, that the real problem about Russia is that it is always, at one and the same time "too strong and too weak". If Bonaparte could not solve the riddle perhaps it is no surprise that Bush has not yet done so either. fields.headline: Bové loses McDonald's attack case
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The anti-globalisation activist José Bové lost his appeal yesterday against a three-month jail sentence for wrecking a McDonald's restaurant.
fields.body:
The anti-globalisation activist José Bové lost his appeal yesterday against a three-month jail sentence for wrecking a McDonald's restaurant.

But Bové, 48, will take his case to France's highest appeal court, the Cour de Cassation.

"The appeal court did not understand what was at stake or the legitimacy of our action. We will continue in the street and in the courts," Mr Bové said. He called for a day of protests tomorrow against "the criminalisation of union movements".

The court in Montpellier also fined Bové Fr6,000 (£570) for briefly holding three civil servants captive during another protest, also in 1999.

Bové led the attack on the McDonald's in Millau, southern France, as a symbolic act against globalisation.

Eight other members of his Peasants' Confederation also charged were given suspended prison terms or were fined yesterday.

Last week Bové was given a 10-month suspended jail term for destroying genetically altered rice plants at a government research station in 1999.

webTitle: Designers apply themselves to handbagging crime figures

fields.headline: Designers apply themselves to handbagging crime figures
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Forget more bobbies on the beat: a sloping-topped dustbin and a handbag that refuses to open could prove vital tools in the fight against crime, according to research published yesterday.
fields.body:
Forget more bobbies on the beat: a sloping-topped dustbin and a handbag that refuses to open could prove vital tools in the fight against crime, according to research published yesterday.

Mobile phones that can only be charged from one specific charger, suitcases that have detatchable handles, and TVs fitted with unique plugs that only work in one home could also help curb opportunistic crime, which accounts for a vast proportion of the £60bn annual cost of crime.

The ideas for crime-deterrent products emerged in Cracking Crime Through Design, a report commissioned by the Design Council and written by Ken Pease, a criminologist. It urges government and business to do more to protect the public by using design in order to reduce crime.

The report was launched yesterday with the backing of the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, and the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens. It argues that most products are designed in a way that makes theft all too easy - from mobile phones with no effective security features, to wheelie bins that provide the perfect "leg-up" to burglars.

Products such as these, and bags which give quick and easy access to pickpockets, fuel the temptation to offend, the research shows.

However, the main aim of developing crime-resistant products, which in the case of cars have slashed car crime by a third, would be to protect victims of crime. This priority was highlighted by Diana Lamplugh, mother of the missing estate agent Suzy Lamplugh. She said that one of the factors in her daughter's abduction had been that her desk was situated in the window of her workplace.

Architects and designers could do much more to make buildings safer, particularly so that vulnerable young children or women could not be seen from outside, she added.

Andrew Summers, chief executive of the Design Council, said products being tested included anti-theft chairs, which allow bags to be held in indentations in the chair's seat, and deceptive handbags, which appear to have openings at the front but in reality open from the back.

He urged the government to encourage crime-resistant design, perhaps by tax breaks for manufacturers, and suggested manufacturers should join forces in think tanks.

fields.headline: Stolen car ruling 'a thieves' charter'
fields.standfirst: Judges back 'highly suspect' driver as original owner cannot be traced
fields.trailText: Judges back 'highly suspect' driver as original owner cannot be traced
fields.body:
Police hope to appeal against a ruling yesterday that a "highly suspect" driver arrested in possession of a stolen car was entitled to have it returned to him, plus damages for its wrongful detention by police since 1997.

In what Derbyshire police say amounts to a "thieves' charter," three judges ruled that because the car's identity had been changed it was impossible to trace the legal owner and therefore the person found in possession of it was entitled to keep it.

The three judges backed an appeal by Jason Costello against a decision by Derby county court not to return the car to him on the grounds that he knew it was stolen.

A spokesman for Derbyshire police said the force would be meeting next week to discuss an appeal. He said any damages awarded Mr Costello would probably not be large because the car was "a shell".

The case illustrates the old legal maxim that "possession is nine points of the law". The rule is that the person in possession of goods is deemed to be entitled to them unless someone with a better claim to them comes forward.

The owner of the Ford Fiesta could not be traced because the car's identification number had been obliterated and a new one welded on, and its engine number had been ground off.

"Possession is entitled to the same legal protection whether or not it has been obtained lawfully or by theft or other unlawful means," said Mr Justice Lightman after a review of previous court decisions.

"It vests in the possessor a possessory title which is good against the world, save against anyone claiming under a better title," said the judge, sitting with lords justices Robert Walker and Keene.

Earlier cases include one in which money was found in the public part of a jeweller's shop and another in which a bracelet was picked up at Heathrow airport. When the true owners failed to come forward, the finders were allowed to keep the goods.

Seeking permission to appeal against the decision to the Lords, Fiona Barton, for the chief constable of Derbyshire, said the judgment placed the police in real difficulty. It meant that it was in the interests of thieves and handlers to obliterate the identity numbers of stolen items so they could claim the goods back in the absence of the true owner.

Lord Justice Walker said the court was "not wholly unsympathetic" with police concerns. But the judges refused permission to appeal, leaving it to the police to ask the law lords themselves whether they will allow an appeal.

Mr Costello was stopped after a short chase in Derby and another man in the car was arrested and later convicted of stealing a different vehicle. Mr Costello was never charged.

Police retained the car under the 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act. A "ringing" kit - used to "ring the changes" in a car's identity - was found under the back seat.

Mr Costello claimed there could have been an honest and innocent explanation for the number changes - such as a change of body shell or engine - but the Derby county court judge who originally dismissed his claim to have the car returned in 1999 held that the car was stolen and that Mr Costello knew this.

Mr Justice Lightman said the judge had been fully entitled to reach that conclusion. Mr Costello's behaviour when the car was seized was, at its lowest, "highly suspicious", and he gave false evidence to the county court.

But the 1984 act gave police only a temporary right to retain goods for the purposes of a criminal investigation, for use as evidence at a trial or to establish lawful ownership.

The limited right of the police to retain property and their obligation to return it to the "owner" after completing their inquiries were "unaffected by any perceived public policy consideration that the fruits of his criminal activities ought to be withheld from a criminal", said the judge.

This conclusion was in accord with a principle"that even a thief is entitled to the protection of the criminal law against the theft from him of that which he has stolen".

The judges ruled that damages should be assessed by the county court.

webTitle: The 78 criminal gangs waging war on Ulster

fields.headline: The 78 criminal gangs waging war on Ulster
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Organised criminal gangs are threatening the development of civilised society in Northern Ireland, reveals report
fields.body:
Seventy-eight organised criminal gangs, raking in hundreds of millions of pounds a year, are threatening the development of normal civilised society in Northern Ireland, a report out today reveals.

The RUC report identifies the gangs, 43 of which have current or historical links to republican or loyalist paramilitary organisations; significantly, 35 have no such known connections.

Police are to target the province's top 20 ringleaders as part of a new government-led multi-agency crackdown to combat the spread of drug dealing, extortion, cross-border smuggling and other large-scale criminal ventures.

Thirty years of terrorism have left a web of networks in which organised crime can thrive and a climate of fear and secrecy that makes fighting such crime very difficult. "The Troubles might be coming to an end but we're left with the lasting legacy of terrorism - organised crime," explained Raymond White, RUC assistant chief constable and head of CID.

"Paramilitaries have lived their whole lives raising money through intimidation and racketeering. The networks are still there, so they're now making money for themselves rather than for their organisations, and the ready availability of guns means it's easy to resort to violence.

"Fewer checkpoints and security measures mean greater freedom for criminals, and there are burgeoning opportunities for increasingly sophisticated crimes, with the development of technology and international links."

RUC analysis shows that more than two-thirds of an estimated 400 gangsters are mixed up in selling drugs, 55% in counterfeiting and forgery, 50% in money laundering, just under half in car thefts, 23% in arms trading and 17% in extortion. Most groups are implicated in many types of crime, and there are clear links between certain undertakings, such as drugs and money laundering, car theft and fraud.

Certain paramilitary factions are also associated with certain enterprises; for example, loyalists with drug dealing and republicans with cross-border smuggling. But many of those operating other crime schemes, such as car theft, have no terrorist connection.

While Protestant paramilitaries do not control the whole drugs scene, they have substantial investment and often allow others to operate "franchise" arrangements on their patches. Newer dissident groups, such as the Loyalist Volunteer Force, are heavily involved because of the quick cash injection drugs can provide.

Smuggling of contraband, including illegal fuel, cigarettes, alcohol and cattle, and social security fraud is costing the public purse more than £350m a year in lost taxes and excise duties, and unlawful benefit payments.

Two gangs are especially active in cattle smuggling in the south Armagh region, a specific risk at present because of the danger of spreading foot and mouth disease.

The much cheaper cost of petrol and diesel in the Republic of Ireland means that laundering - taking identification dye out of fuel and then smuggling it across the border - is prevalent in the south Armagh area. Last year, police uncovered 13 big fuel-laundering plants with the capacity to produce more than 40m litres, and in January a further two mixing and one laundering plant were dismantled.

Seized

Cigarette and alcohol smuggling is also severely squeezing hundreds of small traders. In the past 12 months, 50m cigarettes have been seized in the province and 60m cigarettes bound for Northern Ireland have been seized elsewhere.

Holiday flights from the Canary Islands are an established route for smugglers. Last October 900,000 cigarettes were seized at Belfast international airport from passengers coming from Gran Canaria, the biggest seizure from one flight at any UK regional airport.

Some of the crime is ingenious; car theft schemes, for instance, where vehicles are brought from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, re-registered and then taken south of the border and resold, having been reported stolen.

"These guys could do exceptionally well as entrepreneurs if they were operating within the law," Mr White said.

All these scams have a knock-on effect on legitimate business, but it is much more difficult to estimate the full extent of private sector losses, primarily because many victims are too frightened to report blackmail and threats. Almost half the cases reported to police are withdrawn before investigations can get under way.

The RUC has just sent out a confidential survey to business people and hopes to assess the results in the next few months. The building trade alone, which is particularly vulnerable to paramilitary intimidation, loses millions of pounds a year.

"It is widely acknowledged that in parts of Belfast, organised paramilitary crime retains an important, often decisive role, in deciding who works, where and when," admits the taskforce report.

The former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, set up the taskforce last year to attack the "mafia-like virus" which he said could undermine peacetime society. It includes the police, customs and excise, the inland revenue, and trading standards authorities, among others, who will work together to try to thwart the gangs at each step of their operations.

Ulster's security minister Adam Ingram, who is heading it, said today's report "shines a light into the dark side of Northern Ireland" but admitted it would take public cooperation for criminality to be rooted out.

Traditional lack of nationalist confidence in the police, the massive reduction in officers under the new reforms, and a shortage of money are still big problems.

The Social Democratic and Labour Party and Sinn Fein are still refusing to join the ruling police board for the revamped service, which will see the original 13,500-strong RUC cut to around 7,500. The existing police authority says a further £20m is needed to meet this year's budget requirements.

Mr White admitted the taskforce would have to wage a long battle and overcome significant obstacles, not least the fear created by 30 years of terrorism.

"It is about educating people about the true cost of crime and its overall effects," he said. "There is a culture among certain sections of society - people who don't tax their cars, pay their TV licences, buy suspect goods in the pub. But those people have to realise how much this is costing their community. It eats away at money for new schools and new hospitals.

"Then, there is the conspiracy of silence which is part of the legacy of Northern Ireland. It takes personal bravery on the part of victims to break that and speak out. We know there is no quick win but we will never have a normal society unless these issues are tackled."

The price of gangsterism

 £350m of public money lost to fraud every year

 Last year police uncovered 13 fuel-laundering plants with capacity to produce 40m litres of illegal fuel

 More than 50m cigarettes seized in Northern Ireland and a further 60m bound for province recovered by police in past 12 months

 More than £4m worth of fake CDs, electronic goods, designer clothing seized in past two years

fields.headline: Pakistan protest 'will defy arrests'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Politicians in Pakistan vowed last night to go ahead with a large protest rally today despite the arrests of hundreds of party workers by the military regime.

Politicians in Pakistan vowed last night to go ahead with a large protest rally today despite the arrests of hundreds of party workers by the military regime.

In the biggest crackdown on political activity since the military took power in October 1999, troops this week rounded up 1,600 activists including 28 senior politicians ahead of the planned gathering.

Nawabzada Nasrullah Khan, who leads a broad opposition movement, the Alliance for the Restoration of Democracy, said the protest would go ahead despite the mass detentions.

"We believe in non-violence and have always demonstrated for the restoration of democracy," said Mr Khan, who was himself briefly arrested on Wednesday.

"To ban this kind of peaceful political activity does not inspire confidence among the people."

Few people expected the rally, to be held at Mochi Gate in Lahore, a traditional site of protest during British rule, to attract large crowds and international attention.

The protest was timed to coincide with Pakistan Day, when the military parades tanks, heavy artillery and missiles through the streets of Islamabad to commemorate the day in 1940 when Muslim politicians in India decided to work for a separate Islamic homeland.

But now the sudden military crackdown has brought the regime under renewed pressure to explain how exactly it intends to return Pakistan to democracy by October next year in line with a supreme court ruling.

The military has already banned public political meetings and has come down hard on any attempts to lead mass protest rallies, apparently concerned that it could appear weak.

"The government says this kind of political activity detracts from the agenda," said Rifaat Hussain, a political scientist at Quaid-i-Azam University in Islamabad.

"When the military is in charge weakness in law and order doesn't go down well for their image."

Last July Kulsoom Sharif, the wife of the deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, was detained for 10 hours and her car towed away while she sat inside after she tried to lead a similar anti-government rally.

The arrests overshadowed the second round of voting on Wednesday in local elections, the first to be held in Pakistan since 1987.

In staggered polls, which run until August, Pakistanis will be able to elect local councillors who will have unprecedented powers under reforms by the military.

fields.headline: Driver 'speechless' over Dover bodies
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A Dutch driver who arrived at Dover with 58 dead Chinese illegal immigrants in his lorry yesterday denied knowing they were on board.
fields.body:
A Dutch driver who arrived at Dover with 58 dead Chinese illegal immigrants in his lorry yesterday denied knowing they were on board.

Perry Wacker, 33, told a jury at Maidstone crown court that the discovery of the bodies had left him speechless.

Under questioning from his counsel, Michael Lawson QC, Wacker said in English that he had not seen the lorry loaded and, having examined the documentation, believed he was transporting tomatoes to Bristol.

He was stopped at Dover by customs officers around midnight on June 18. After reversing into an inspection bay, Wacker said that he helped the officers open one of the doors, which was stiff.

The court has heard the 58 bodies and two survivors, were found behind a screen of tomato pallettes, allegedly installed to conceal the real cargo.

"Were you concerned about what they might find?" asked Mr Lawson. "No."

"Did you know what the lorry contained?"

"No. When a load is sealed you can't check the load itself. All you can do is check the seal mark."

Wacker told the court he was unconcerned when he was stopped because it had happened 25 or 26 times before. He said he was surprised when a customs officer climbed a ladder at the rear of the trailer and started looking for people inside the container.

Wacker said that the first he knew of his real cargo was when he was arrested and charged with murder - later reduced to manslaughter - and people trafficking.

"They [the police and customs] told me they found people in the back of the lorry ... I had no words, none at all. It was a heavy impact," he said.

Wacker said he had collected the lorry at 3pm that day from an industrial estate in Waalhaven in Rotterdam docks.

Accompanied by his friend, Leo Nijveen, Wacker had found the keys under the bumper, and in a toolbox he found a mobile phone, the seal mark documentation which indicated the load was tomatoes, a map, and cash for the trip.

The court heard that Wacker was engaged to drive the lorry to the UK after a chance meeting with a friend, Wilhelm Jansen, a week before the fatal journey. Wacker told Jansen he was out of work and Jansen said he might be able to help.

Jansen introduced Wacker to a Mr Van Der Speck, who said he was starting a lorry company and that he would like Wacker to drive for him. Wacker said he had known Nijveen, also a lorry driver, since 1995 and that they had driven for a company owned by Wacker's uncle, Ronald.

In April last year Nyveen had been stopped at Dover driving a vehicle for Ronald Wacker, and 50 Chinese had been found in the back. Nyveen was fined £100,000.

Wacker acknowledged he knew about this, but said that his friend did not tell him how the Chinese came to be in the back of the lorry.

He revealed he had a criminal record for theft and insurance and welfare fraud.

Wacker denies 58 charges of manslaughter and four of conspiracy to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants.

Ying Guo 29, a translator from South Woodford, London, denies conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry.

webTitle: London asked to help find Milosevic millions

fields.headline: London asked to help find Milosevic millions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's new central bank chief will go to the Bank of England to trace some of the billions plundered by former president Slobadan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's new central bank chief will go to the Bank of England today in his attempt to trace some of the billions he says the regime of Slobodan Milosevic, his country's former president, plundered.

Mladjan Dinkic, the young, crusading governor of the Yugoslav National Bank, has included Britain on the list of countries he says were used by Mr Milosevic and his cronies to secrete their ill-gotten wealth.

The Serbian central banker, an opposition economist during the Milosevic era, is to see Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, and other officials at the bank. He is also expected to visit the Treasury.

"He wants to talk about asset-tracing," a well-placed western European diplomat in Belgrade said.

London is Mr Dinkic's third port of call since becoming the national bank chief. In recent weeks, Mr Dinkic has visited Switzerland and Cyprus, two of the key countries whose strict banking secrecy the Milosevic regime exploited.

One month after the overthrow of Mr Milosevic last October, the Bank of England, in line with the rest of the EU, lifted most of the economic sanctions against Yugoslavia; it did not lift those placed on suspected Milosevic family assets and the accounts of indicted war criminals.

Last night a Bank of England spokeswoman declined to say whether any bank accounts belonging to Yugoslavs in Britain were monitored or frozen.

Yugoslav assets worth more than $200m (£140m) are still frozen in the US.

Cyprus, long the hub for the regime's financial wheeler-dealing, has recently provided Mr Dinkic with some information. It has also transferred crates of documents on the regime's financial scheming to the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

About $38m (£27m) has been frozen in Swiss bank accounts, including the personal accounts of 35 Yugoslav citizens.

Investigators have failed to turn up any evidence that Mr Milosevic himself has secret bank accounts abroad, but Mr Dinkic returned from Cyprus last week declaring that he had discovered the details of a secret account belonging to a close relative of the indicted war criminal.

Mr Dinkic appears frustrated that there has been no concerted international effort to trace the missing money. Senior government officials in Belgrade complain that, in contrast to Germany, France, or Italy, Britain is being less than helpful to the new Serbian and Yugoslav governments.

Mr Dinkic estimates that there may be as much as $4bn ($2.8bn) missing from the Milosevic era.

It is clear that the bulk of that money did not go towards enriching individuals in the regime; rather it is thought to have funded some elaborate sanctions-busting schemes throughout the 90s which kept Yugoslavia trading, despite the economic embargo.

Nonetheless, it is thought that hundreds of millions of dollars have been purloined into private accounts abroad.

Mr Dinkic is expected to arrive at the Bank of England today with specific requests for information on bank accounts, perhaps supplied to him by the US Treasury's office for foreign assets control, which has been tracking the sophisticated global currency operations and transactions of the Milosevic inner circle for years.

British officials say they are in the dark as to the specifics of Mr Dinkic's interest in accounts in Britain.

A well-placed source in Belgrade, however, said assets worth tens of millions of pounds were frozen in Britain in the mid-90s as a result of the UN sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia because of the Kosovo war.

Those sanctions were lifted in 1996, but financial sanctions were reapplied in 1998, when Mr Milosevic launched his campaign in Kosovo.

Given the prominence of the City of London in international finance, experts do not doubt that ample volumes of Yugoslav money moved through Britain in the 90s.

But London is not believed to have been a major centre for the regime's operations.

fields.headline: Pet food poultry 'sold for humans'
fields.standfirst:
Officers seize carcasses from processing plant

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Officers seize carcasses from processing plant.
fields.body:
Police made 16 arrests yesterday as they investigated allegations that poultry destined for pet food was being prepared to be sent back to shops for human consumption.

Police and environmental health officers were issued with 20 warrants to search premises in five counties.

Local council officers yesterday seized carcasses weighing more than 2 tonnes at Denby Poultry Products, a pet food processing plant near Ripley in Derbyshire.

Detective Superintendent Fran Muldoon who is heading the investigation for Derbyshire police, said: "Yesterday's actions were the culmination of four months of observations. The arrests made do not mean the operation is complete. This is the initial stage".

The food standards agency yesterday said that it could not be certain of the level of public health risk. Police could not confirm how much of the products had allegedly entered the food chain, or for how long they may have been reaching consumers. "These are still only allegations," a spokesman said.

Peter Carney, chief executive of Amber Valley council, one of the organisations involved in the operation, said: "Maff [the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food] has exercised their statutory powers to suspend the plant's registration. The council is taking the necessary legal action today to have these products destroyed". The seized carcasses will be examined and destroyed if they are found to be unsafe.

Denby Poultry Products is registered by Maff under the Animal By-products Order 1999 to receive waste from poultry slaughter houses for use in pet food.

David Statham, director of enforcement and food standards at the FSA, said: "There are specific controls on meat to ensure it is fit for human consumption. Yesterday's actions to apply to seize the meat will protect the public from any further risks of this meat entering the food chain."

Mr Statham said the FSA was aware of the need for vigilance and "tough action" against people who flouted the controls on food safety.

He added: "The public needs protection where it is alleged that food unfit for human consumption is finding its way back into the food chain by whatever means".

Consumer groups are concerned at the emergence of another possible scandal involving how meat is handled and processed. The seizures follow on the heels of a meat recycling racket in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, last December when five men were sentenced after 1,300 tonnes of unfit chicken and turkey were diverted to shops.

The operation exposed legal loopholes and the possibility of similar activities elsewhere.

A spokeswoman for the Consumers Association said: "We welcome this joint initiative to stop further potentially contaminated chicken getting back into the human food chain. But how much has already been eaten and how much is on supermarket shelves and in our fridges and freezers? The suspect products must be traced quickly and consumers must be kept informed. Only last month Which? magazine highlighted unacceptable levels of food poison bacteria [salmonella, campylobacter] in chicken in supermarkets."

Police said paperwork and computers were also seized from premises in Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire, Derbyshire, Northamptonshire and Buckinghamshire which were supplied by the Derbyshire company.

Seven of those arrested are from the Derbyshire area, police said.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a panel headed Know your way round the courts, page 3, Media, March 19, we referred to a report in the Daily Mail about an Algerian asylum seeker.
fields.body:
In a panel headed Know your way round the courts, page 3, Media, March 19, we referred to a report in the Daily Mail about an Algerian asylum seeker. We said the paper accused the man of being a benefits scrounger and that pictures of him and his wives were published and the streets where the family live in two houses were identified. In fact, "scrounger" was not a word used anywhere in the Mail report. The paper did not publish pictures of his wives. It did publish pictures of the two houses saying they were in Aston and Newtown, but it did not name the streets.

In the Sexism in the City feature, page 2, G2, March 19, one of the interviewees spoke of her (male) colleagues renting rooms by the hour at the Great Eastern Hotel. While it is true that until the hotel closed for refurbishment in 1996, rooms were rented out at an hourly rate, this service has not been offered since the hotel reopened last year. Anglia Trains say that, contrary to what we indicated in a report headed Railtrack given new target for 'normal service', page 4, March 21, they intend to resume normal services from May 21. It was correct in an accompanying table.

In a feature about Osterley, page22, Space (a supplement to some southern editions), January 25, we compared the 46% GCSE pass rate (grades A* to C) of the Isleworth and Syon Boys' School, unfavourably with the pass rate at a private school. We did not point out the differences in the two schools, or say that the pass rate at the Isleworth and Syon Boys' School was significantly above the average for the borough of Hounslow, and above the national average for boys.

The world's first McDonald's hotel is not at Rümland in Switzerland (page 14, March 16), or Ramlüng (pages 6, G2, March 19) but Rümlang.

fields.headline: CBI warns of price cuts
fields.trailText: UK firms are being forced to slash prices in order to shift a growing mountain of stock, as concerns grow about the impact of the US slowdown, a survey revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
UK firms are being forced to slash prices in order to shift a growing mountain of stock, as concerns grow about the impact of the US slowdown, a survey revealed yesterday.

Order books are at their lowest level since mid-1999, according to the Confederation of British Industry, and few firms expect much improvement over the next three months.

"This survey is further evidence that the troubles of the UK's manufacturing sector are far from over," said Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economist. "The US slowdown may have a more serious impact on the UK than first predicted."

Manufacturers have built up their highest level of unsold stock since March 1999 and expect that they will have to cut prices further in order to shift them.

After a brief recovery late last year, spurred by the decline in the pound, manufacturing appears to be firmly back in the doldrums.

The CBI said while 15% of firms reported above average order books, 38% reported below average orders, taking the balance to minus 23%, a sharp fall on February's balance of minus 16%, the most negative result for order books since July 1999.

Export order books are still well below normal. The balance figure of minus 24% is the same as February.

fields.headline: Invensys sales slide again
fields.trailText: Engineering group Invensys yesterday issued its second profit warning in six months and said it was cutting an additional 2,000 jobs due to the slowdown in the US.
fields.body:
Engineering group Invensys yesterday issued its second profit warning in six months and said it was cutting an additional 2,000 jobs due to the slowdown in the US.

Shares in the company, which produces half of its sales across the Atlantic, slid 17% at one stage although chief executive Allen Yurko said he still hoped to go ahead with flotation of its power systems division.

Analysts cut their earnings forecasts and claimed the position of Mr Yurko was vulnerable. Many of the promises made at the time Invensys was formed through the merger of Siebe and BTR in 1999 had evaporated, they said.

Mr Yurko put the blame for the trouble firmly on macro-economic issues. "Like every company in our industry, we are watching the US economy closely... At this point it is not possible to be sure of the duration of the current downturn."

Invensys, which produces control systems for household goods such as fridges, expected second-half operating profits to be "marginally below" the first-half level.

By the end of this month the company will have cut its workforce by 5,000, or 6%, which is 2,000 more than expected.

Deutsche Bank cut its pretax profit forecast for Invensys from £780m to £725m while Ian Brown of Morley Fund Management said: "It reinforces our view that this is not a good stock to hold."

webTitle: Leader: BT in a sad state

fields.headline: Not managing very well
fields.standfirst: The state of BT is sad and disturbing
fields.trailText: British Telecom, once the global showpiece for privatisation, is now accused by its own investors of having lost its way.
fields.body:
Oh, how the mighty have fallen. British Telecom, once the global showpiece for privatisation, is now accused by its own investors of having lost its way. They want heads to roll, as roll they must if BT is to recover its self-confidence. Hardly anyone has a good word to say for the company these days.

Its international strategy has failed: its balance sheet is reeling under the burden of £30bn of debts (partly to pay for the third generation licences): critics assail it for not rolling out high-speed "broadband" access fast enough and by customers for high charges. At the start of the new millennium, its shares were traded at over 1,513p. Yesterday, they were 469p. Barely two years ago BT was capitalised on the stock markets at more than Vodafone, its upstart mobile rival. Now Vodafone is valued more than four times higher.

Of course, all shares have taken a battering recently - the FTSE index of leading UK stocks ended 225.9 down yesterday - and those of telcos more than most. It is also true that competitors like France Telecom and Deutsch Telekom have even bigger debts than BT, but that does not alter the fact that BT has lost its way and does not seem to know what to do. Earlier promises to cut £10bn from its debts by a fire sale of assets have foundered since the collapse of share prices means they are not worth selling.

One of the few realistic options open to the company is, humiliatingly, to cut its dividend and ask shareholders to cough up more money through a rights issue. Shareholders are unlikely to agree unless there is a change of management at the top or a new strategy is pulled from a hat. Meanwhile, BT's very low market capitalisation (only £30.8bn last night, a whisker above its debt) makes it a sitting target for a takeover bid, something that would have been almost unthinkable five years ago.

BT's problems are not all of its own making. It is not as easy for a former utility with inherited infrastructure to adjust to the speed of change of the new economy as it is for a newcomer like Vodafone. The last government was at fault for not breaking it up into competing units at privatisation or, at least, separating its "common carrier" functions from all the services it provided, as suggested at the time.

Instead BT, not unnaturally, has been keener to milk its monopoly than to bring the benefits of the information revolution, including broadband, to the community. Add to this the failure of its bid for MCI in the US and the problems with its Concert venture with AT&T and it can be seen why BT sometimes looks like a frightened rabbit caught in the headlights. This week's last-minute cancellation of a dinner with shareholders made things even worse.

For all the excuses, this is a failure of management, and highly paid management too. BT is too important for the economy, let alone its shareholders, to be allowed to wither in power, esteem and sense of purpose. Unless they can change their spots overnight, it is time for those responsible for BT's demise to move over and let someone else have a go.

webTitle: Notebook:  Pain to reach the property market

fields.headline: Slow-speed crash will cause lots of damage
fields.standfirst: Pain to reach the property market
fields.trailText: Pain to reach the property market.
fields.body:
Stock markets are not perfect. At the extremes they undershoot, they overshoot, they misforecast and they misallocate money. But on the whole, taking a smoothed view of past performance, markets do tend to get the general economic trend right - be it up or down or sideways. On the way up, it is said, shares climb a wall of worry. On the way down there is rarely time for reflection.

So, on one level, this particular bear market is special. It did not arrive on a windy October morning. It did not appear out of blue sky. The story is still struggling for a mention on the evening television news bulletins.

We are experiencing a slow-motion crash, where a sense of panic and the pain associated with the destruction of wealth has taken six months or more to develop. And there is not yet any indication that the selling has yet reached a peak.

In the same way that crashes are usually triggered by an "event," so investors, big and small, need a collective reason to buy, breaking the spiral where falling prices draw greater and greater numbers of distressed sellers.

There still appears to be plenty of panic left in the system.

This market is also special in the sense that many members of the wider financial and business community are still in denial about the course of share prices and the effect on the wider economy.

There are some who continue to argue that there is some sort of firebreak between the markets and what is termed the "real economy," arguing that the internet blow-out was a freak condition which, now it has passed, can safely be put on one side.

This ignores that old and very fundamental catalyst for economic activity: the feel-good factor.

The easiest analogy is house prices. If they are shooting ahead of inflation, house owners enjoy greater financial confidence. They borrow more and spend more.

The same goes for roaring stock markets. Sadly, the ephemeral sense of wealth fueled by the equity boom has evaporated, even if millions of British savers have yet realise the full extent of the damage done to their personal worth over recent months.

If feeling good is being replaced by feeling progressively worse, forecasting the broader effect on the economy is difficult and depressing. The betting is that this slow motion crash will prove excessively corrosive.

Watch first for the damage to show in London, where house prices have been propelled, rocket-like, by City bonuses and where so many exquisitely furbished restaurants and bars have opened during the past two or three years.

Watch for real pain in the financial services industry, where the annual ISA selling season has coincided with melting asset values.

It used to be the case that stock market investors appeared to be pre-programmed to always "buy on the dips." Every setback in share prices was viewed as an opportunity to invest. But, when the dips are outnumbering the blips by a factor of four to one, that strategy loses its attraction.

This bear market still has a good way to run.

Chickenfeed

In 1945, a chicken belonging to Lloyd Olsen of Fruita, Colorado, had its head cut off but went on to survive for 18 months.

A quick dip into the Guinness Book of Records also reveals that a Welshman named Bernard Lavery once cultivated a fuchsia with a height of 4.2 metres, and that the world's longest fjord is the Nordvest arm of Scoresby Sund in eastern Greenland. Cynics may scoff but for many readers, as one commentator recently put it, the Guinness Book of Records fills "a long, unfelt want".

The book occupies a unique place in British culture and it is sad that the publishing company is to be separated from the Guinness brewery. Diageo, the present owner, feels that books have little in common with brewing. The previous, rather dubious justification - that it might settle arguments in pubs - no longer applies, as Diageo has long since sold all its boozers.

Diageo's desire for "focus" means the disposal is entirely logical. But the business is such a small element of the group that its presence could surely be tolerated on the grounds of good public relations alone.

Founding editor Norris McWhirter yesterday bemoaned the book's obsession with glossy, saccharine trivia. McWhirter, now an ageing Eurosceptic tambourine-thumper, makes a living by writing rival record books for Virgin. His desire to turn the Guinness Book of Records back into a less frivolous tome is somewhat out of step with the times but he is right on one count - the business deserves to be nurtured by a careful owner. Mohammed Al Fayed has shown a liking for bits of British heritage. Perhaps he could be persuaded to put his hand in his pocket.

fields.headline: Whitbread in severance pay clash
fields.trailText: Whitbread was accused of being cheap and disloyal by a trade union yesterday, following claims that the leisure group had changed its policy on redundancy payouts shortly before selling its 3,000-strong pub estate.
fields.body:
Whitbread was accused of being cheap and disloyal by a trade union yesterday, following claims that the leisure group had changed its policy on redundancy payouts shortly before selling its 3,000-strong pub estate.

Pressure on the company to offer its tenants the right to buy their pubs increased with the release of a 1991 letter from management describing this as Whitbread's "usual practice".

The National Association of Licensed House Managers alleged that the company recently reduced pub managers' entitlement to severance pay for the first time in 20 years.

Peter Love, the union's national officer, said: "This company had a redundancy severance policy which went back as far as 1981."

He said the association, which is part of the Transport & General Workers' Union, was told by Whitbread just over a month ago that this policy was no longer in force: "Without any consultation with ourselves or with managers, they've changed the policy to something which is not as generous."

This was disputed by Whitbread, which described the allegation as outrageous. A spokesman said the company had not changed its policy on severance pay for more than a year. He refused to elaborate.

Whitbread this week agreed to sell its pubs and bars to Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, which wants to convert all the outlets to arms-length tenancies, with likely job losses among salaried pub managers.

Several hundred tenants want to buy their own pubs but Whitbread has refused, saying individual sales would be expensive and time-consuming.

A letter leaked to the Guardian yesterday reveals that the company took a different view in 1991. The letter, from field operations director PJ Carter, advises the landlord of the Old Coach House in Canterbury that his pub is to be put on the market.

Inviting the landlord to make a bid, Mr Carter wrote: "It is our usual practice to offer the existing licensee the first opportunity to purchase the house."

Former Whitbread chairman Sir Charles Tidbury has expressed support for the publicans' campaign to buy their own houses, as has Labour MEP Brian Simpson.

fields.headline: Morrison gamble pays off
fields.trailText: Supermarket group Wm Morrison yesterday announced profit and sales growth that rivals would die for - and hit out at planning restrictions that it claims prevent millions of shoppers from having access to its no-frills strategy.
fields.body:
Supermarket group Wm Morrison yesterday announced profit and sales growth that rivals would die for - and hit out at planning restrictions that it claims prevent millions of shoppers from having access to its no-frills strategy.

Morrison, which is the fifth biggest supermarket chain, reported profits up 15.8% at £219.1m. Like-for-like takings were up 9.1% - and there is no sign of growth slowing.

Like-for-like sales in the first six weeks of the new financial year have been 8.3% ahead of last year, or 6.3% when the impact of petrol prices is stripped out. The most recent figures from Tesco show underlying sales growth of 6.9%, while Safeway announced a 5.9% improvement with its recent figures. Finance director Martin Ackroyd said Morrison's success was a result of service and focus. "Perhaps some managers in other businesses have forgotten how to look after customers."

He said that at certain times last year the group was selling petrol for less than it was paying for it to keep customers coming in.

The group cut its margins to keep its prices keen, and reckons it will shave them again this year, but so far the gamble has paid off. Turnover last year was up 17.9%. Morrison's shares, which have risen 30% in the past 12 months, closed up 8p at a record 201.5p.

The chain is the highest rated food retailer in Britain. One analyst said he was "running out of superlatives" to describe its performance.

The group, which operates 110 stores, mostly in the north of England, wants to expand into new areas. Finance director Martin Ackroyd said consumers were suffering because of the lack of new development sites: "We could put up some competition against some of the lazier operators"

Morrison has long been tipped as a takeover target, even though the Morrison family retain a 38% stake.

Mr Ackroyd insisted the company wanted to stay independent. "I'd be disappointed if some johnny-come-lately, or insurance salesmen or Argentinians thought they could do better," he said - referring in turn to Asda, Sainsburys and Safeway, which is now headed by Carlos Criado-Peres. "That just leaves Tesco, and we are not looking for a bid."

webTitle: Laird defends move to hi-tech sector

fields.headline: Laird defends move to hi-tech sector
fields.trailText: Ian Arnott, chief executive of electronics group Laird, yesterday rebuffed suggestions that the company had made a mistake by refocusing its core business from the motor industry to the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
Ian Arnott, chief executive of electronics group Laird, yesterday rebuffed suggestions that the company had made a mistake by refocusing its core business from the motor industry to the hi-tech sector.

"In the short term it might appear to be a case of 'out of the frying pan and into the fire', but the electrics sector is the right location for us in the long term," he insisted.

Mr Arnott's comments, however, came as the company was forced to issue a profits warning yesterday, citing a slowdown in the electronics industry in the US as likely to affect sales.

"We are suffering at the moment because of destocking by many electrical goods companies and because of the slow-down in the US," Mr Arnott said. "We expect to see our trading environment improve later this year as destocking problems are resolved."

He claimed the company could had not have survived in the automotive industry unless it were able to become one of the largest industry players. "I have no doubt that it is the right thing to do," he said.

Laird's fortunes have also been hit by its reliance on the US market, where it does 60% of its trade. It has also been hit hard by a downturn in business at many of its customers, including Cisco and Siemens.

Laird has radically restructured its operations over the last two years, disposing of more than half of its automotive business last October when it sold Draftex, its car sealing systems business. In 1999, it also sold its printing and packaging activities.

At the time of the Draftex sale, Mr Arnott explained the decision. "You can't stand still and accept the valuations placed on you by the market," he said. "You've got to go out there and do something about it."

Yesterday, Laird recorded a pretax profit before exceptional items for last year of £56.5m, down from £60.7m the previous year. Turnover was £1.1m. Analysts had been forecasting profits of about £55.5m. Shares in Laird closed down 74p to 195p yesterday.

fields.headline: Telewest hits 500,000 mark
fields.standfirst: Digital television launch packs a lifetime into one year
fields.trailText: Digital television launch packs a lifetime into one year
fields.body:
Telewest yesterday sought to put the troubles of last year behind it with the announcement that its digital television subscriber base had reached the 500,000 mark.

Adam Singer, Telewest chief executive said the cable company had come through one of its most difficult periods during which it saw management change, digested several acquisitions and suffered technical problems in the launch of digital. "If Telewest were human, it would have been the equivalent of changing jobs, moving house, getting married and giving birth all in one year," he said.

The company reported a 42% increase in revenues to £1.1bn for 2000 while earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation were 11% higher at £247m. Pretax losses widened during the year from £530m to £701m.

The group managed to add only 106,000 customers during the year, 84,000 of which came from its takeover of Eurobell, the cable company it bought from Deutsche Telekom. In the first half of the year Telewest's subscriber base actually contracted but Mr Singer said the digital roll out was pushing customer numbers back in the right direction. The company has 1.7m homes subscribing to either TV or telephony.

He admitted that during launch, excess demand had meant there was only a 50/50 chance of getting through on the dial up internet product while faults on the digital network were too high. Both, he said, had been fully dealt with. Churn, the rate at which customers fail to renew their subscriptions, fell only marginally to 26%.

Mr Singer said the cable industry has a strong opportunity to steal a march on its rivals by deploying broadband, high-speed internet access. "We have 17,000 broadband customers, but 10,000 of those are also buying TV and telecoms from us. Those customers are paying £65 a month and there you can see the seeds of our future. This is the business we are building. It's not about another plain old telecoms company or pay TV company. The cable industry will not be built on the back of Granada Men & Motors and the Carlton Food Network." Average monthly revenues per subscriber climbed 7% to £37.45.

Mr Singer said the market's view of the company would be difficult to shift without a change in attitude to the wider media and telecoms sector. Telewest shares, which peaked at 570p a year ago closed almost 12% lower at 103.5p.

"This time last year we were really struggling and were worth much more than we are now. And yet now we are a a far better company in every way," he said.

fields.headline: Questions for Filtronic
fields.trailText: The bears have not finished with telecoms equipment maker Filtronic.
fields.body:
The bears have not finished with telecoms equipment maker Filtronic. Despite Wednesday's soothing trading update - the company said it would meet its profits forecasts for the fiscal year - a number of questions remain unanswered.

First, the bears note that Filtronic had held out the prospect of a higher result for the year to May 2001. This is no longer the case.

Second, they point to a note from WestLB Panmure which says Filtronic is burning through cash at a rate of £2m a month and will run into a problems by August unless it has managed to find a partner for its plant at Newton Aycliffe.

Although Filtronic expects to make an announcement on Newton by the end of May, it will need to find a partner who agrees that the plant is worth considerably more than £40m. In the current environment that will not be easy. Filtronic closed 10p higher at 170p.

fields.headline: At this price?  Cobham
fields.trailText: Technology stocks may generally be in free fall without a parachute, but a few in niche segments, maintain propulsion
fields.body:
Technology stocks may generally be in free fall without a parachute, but a few in niche segments, maintain propulsion. Take Cobham, a defence and aerospace group which yesterday proved the adage: in a bear market turn to the military.

Cobham's stock rose 2.5% on the back of a 24.2% rise in pretax profits for 2000 to £90.2m - and, critically, the prospect of future earnings growth from stakes in potentially lucrative projects.

Gordon Page, chief executive, could also point to a war chest worth several hundred millions to finance acquisitions out of own resources and without damaging the company's cash-generative performance.

Cobham has positioned itself as a relatively small but key player in some of the most vital civil and military aerospace projects, with a record £1.3bn order book.

"We are well-placed in technologies which are required even though there's pressure on defence budgets," Mr Page said. Cobham has more than £750,000 of equipment on each of the 600-plus Eurofighters being built, with hopes that Greece will buy a further 90.

George Bush may have called in the Joint Strike Fighter programme for review but Mr Page is confident it will be built and that Cobham technology will be present with its fuelling systems. And US military spending - Cobham's biggest market - will rise.

The company has joined up with French group Thales, pan-European group EADS, Rolls-Royce et al to bid against a BAE Systems-led consortium for the £13bn RAF in-flight refuelling tanker service.

Airbus is due to choose the supplier of fuel and oxygen systems for its A380 superjumbo, with Cobham again in the frame. It all enables Mr Page, due to step up to chairman, to say: "We wish to remain independent and see long-term growth; if anyone wants to buy in they will have to do so with a vengeance."
