fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: The Treasury seems determined to press ahead with its barmy public-private partnership scheme for the London Underground, despite the safety worries and funding problems.
fields.body:
The Treasury seems determined to press ahead with its barmy public-private partnership scheme for the London Underground, despite the safety worries and funding problems.

How severe some of these are has come to light thanks to the RMT union, which kindly publishes a confidential document that somehow fell onto a running photocopier. The document - an internal summary from a meeting of London Underground directors - shows that one of the public-private partnership "shadow" companies running the Bakerloo, Central and Victoria lines would have been bankrupted since it began "shadow running" the three lines in the manner of the Treasury's plan. And some £57m would be needed to address "immediate safety concerns," according to the leak. Most damningly, it notes a "poor correlation between contract performance and railway performance" and estimates a £700m annual government subsidy after public-private partnership is introduced. And this is from people in favour of the Treasury plan?

 The traditional British "dimpled" pint glass is soon to disappear, to be replaced by groovy European style straight-sided glasses. But (according to The Engineer magazine, a rivetting read) the two British companies that manufactured such glasses are bankrupt, so pubs will have to buy from continental Europe.

 In a day like yesterday on the financial markets, finding a winner for our Dog of the Day award wasn't hard. But this baby is something special, a hot, leading contender for the prestigious Dog of the Year award. Yesterday morning Lehman Brothers equity analyst Chris Heminway put out a "strong buy" research note on Invensys, the controls and automation manufacturer. "It still looks exceedingly cheap," he told his clients. Well, anyone who couldn't get hold of their broker to grab this bargain should not worry - because they got even cheaper yesterday. As Heminway's note was whizzing through cyberspace, Invensys put out a profits warning and announced it was about to cut 2,000 jobs. The share price fell like the Mir space station, and splashed down 10% lower at the end of trading. When we rang Heminway, he was (according to his colleague) travelling. Wise move, old boy.

 Perhaps Heminway was looking for Invensys chief exec Allen Yurko, who disappeared overseas when the profit warning was announced. Not so clever.

 The Ford Ka might (at best) be described as cute rather than sexy. But beauty is in the eye of the beholder, according to Norway's Telemarksavisa newspaper, which reports that a sex-starved moose mistook a yellow Ka for a possible mating partner, covering the hatchback in saliva and excrement in an attempt to arouse it. "I'm uncertain whether I should take the risk of letting the car stand alone and defenceless on the front yard from now on," said worried owner Leif Borgersen. Luckily there was no damage, to either moose or car.

webTitle: Shares in Bookham Technology go up

fields.headline: Hot gossip revives Bookham
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Just before 2pm yesterday a very strange thing happened. Shares in Bookham Technology went up.
fields.body:
Just before 2pm yesterday a very strange thing happened. Shares in Bookham Technology went up.

While the rest of the tech sector, and for that matter the market, headed south, Bookham shares finished 31p, or 9.48%, higher at 358p.

The hot, or some would say off-the-wall, rumour pushing the optical components maker higher was that it had attracted the attention of a predator. The finger of suspicion was pointed in the direction of Alcatel, the French telecoms equipment maker.

Earlier this week Alcatel's president, Christian Reinaudo, said the company was poised to take advantage of the steep drop in valuations in the sector and buy an optical components maker.

Analysts said the story was credible, as long as Alcatel believed Bookham's silicon- based technology would become the market leader.

Not everybody was convinced. Because Bookham shares have fallen so far - from £54 in July to 327p earlier this week - it is more susceptible than most to unscrupulous bid rumours. Moreover, with £250m of cash on the balance sheet Bookham is not exactly a cash strapped dot.com.

Buyers were in short supply in the wider market as the FTSE 100 set all sorts of unwanted records.

With the Dow Jones entering bear market territory, the blue chip index closed down 225.9 points at 5,314.8. This was the second biggest one-day points drop on record and the largest since Britain left the ERM in October 1992.

What really concerned traders was evidence that the US economic contagion had landed in Europe. Invensys , down 12.75p to 116.25p, Laird , off 71.5p to 197.5p, BPB , 30p lower at 224p, Capital Radio , 207.5p worse at 670p, and Swiss insurance group Zurich Financial all warned that profits had been hit by slowing consumer demand for their products.

"There is complete buyers' strike at the moment. The phones are not ringing," one trader said.

The FTSE Techmark 100 ended 112 points lower at 1,864.6, but for once the losses were not confined to the tech and telecom sector. Banks, fund managers and drugs stocks were all caught up in the sell-off. Barclays fell 115p to £18.85p, Amvescap shed 130p to 863p and Shire Pharmaceuticals dipped 140p to 865p. Yesterday's fall means Shire is now trading below the "collar" - or floor - price for its all-paper acquisition of Canadian firm BioChem Pharma.

Elsewhere in the drug world, Nycomed Amersham , which makes costly gene sequencing machines, lost 39p to 428.5p after a profits warning from a US rival, Applied Biosystems. Traders reckon the news puts the flotation of its life science venture, APBiotech, on Nasdaq in serious doubt.

Over in the telecom sector Cable & Wireless closed down 26p at 430p, even as dealers reported gossip that the company will announce the sale of its Australian operation, Optus, in the next few days. Other fallers included Vodafone , which surrendered 10.5p to 193p, and BT , off 25p to 469p.

The utility sector was about the only thing going up. Powergen added 26p to 714p, on news that it is still in talks with German utility E.ON, while International Power moved up 8p to 243p and Scottish & Southern Energy gained 13p to 613p.

At the other end of the corporate spectrum Ascot , the chemical engineering group, advanced 25.5p to 265p on rumours that Johnson Matthey , down 97p at 950p, has approached it.

Ambulance chaser Claims Direct climbed 5p, or 55.5%, to 14p as a huge institutional sell order was finally completed. Dealers said Merrill Lynch had placed the 6.4% stake of Capital Group.

webTitle: Kabul collection - Taliban unlock museum to show destroyed statues

fields.headline: Kabul collection - Taliban unlock museum to show destroyed statues
fields.trailText: Journalists toured Afghanistan's national museum in Kabul yesterday to see the results of the Taliban's destruction of statues.
fields.body:
Journalists toured Afghanistan's national museum in Kabul yesterday to see the results of the Taliban's destruction of statues.

Only pathetic fragments of the original collection of statues remained, including broken pottery and wooden engravings. A large Buddha - briefly displayed last August - had been pulverised, officials said.

The museum was opened up for the first time since Taliban leader Mullah Mohammed Omar ordered the destruction of all pre-Islamic statues three weeks ago.

"You know what has happened to the statues. They have been destroyed," the museum chief, Naqibullah Ahmadyar, said.

The lobby yesterday contained only a handful of exhibits including a limestone inscription in Greek dating back nearly 2,000 years.

Western experts now fear that the Taliban are melting down Afghanistan's fabled Bactrian treasures - 20,000 gold objects about 2,000 years old. The Bactrians, who settled in northern Afghanistan, were a Greek dynasty founded by Alexander the Great.

webTitle: Horror in Spain at girls who killed friend for kicks

fields.headline: Horror in Spain at girls who killed friend for kicks
fields.trailText: Raquel and Iria, teenage girls from the southern Spanish city of Cadiz, wanted to find out what it would feel like to kill someone.
fields.body:
Raquel and Iria, teenage girls from the southern Spanish city of Cadiz, wanted to find out what it would feel like to kill someone.

So they lured their 16-year-old friend Clara Garcia to a patch of wasteland, persuaded her to close her eyes for a "surprise" and stabbed her 18 times with a kitchen knife. Then they went out drinking with friends.

Spaniards have looked on aghast at the trial of the girls, who are aged 16 and 17. Yesterday they were sentenced to eight years of youth custody.

Neither has shown remorse for the murder, in May last year. They had sought, and found, the thrills of murder and the fame that came with it, they told police.

Clara, a friend who previously shared their taste for black, gothic clothing and the horror stories of Dean Koontz, had simply been the easiest victim they could think of.

She had been spending less time with them since finding a boyfriend and they claimed she had become "weak" and "normal".

Clara, whose body was found in the morning by her boyfriend, had bled to death. Police, who knew she had arranged to meet her friends, found the knife and blood-stained clothing at the homes of the two girls, whose full names cannot be revealed because they were minors at the time of the crime.

Crowds of angry neighbours gathered around the court house door to hurl insults at the two girls as they were driven off. "They acted with caution, premeditation and in full consciousness," the sentence issued by the juvenile court in Cadiz declared.

The savage killing of Clara Garcia has caused consternation in Spain. Psychologists and politicians fear that the increase in the number of children who apparently kill for kicks is a sign that the strong moral bonds of Spain's traditionally tight-knit families and close communities are beginning togive way.

"I think we are, in some way, all to blame," Clara's father, Jose Antonio Garcia, said.

Figures show that the number of murders, many of them similarly brutal and motiveless, carried out by under-18s has increased by 60% in the past six years. The killers had collected press clippings about recent murders in Spain, especially those committed by young people.

They had also written a fan letter to a 16-year-old from Murcia, south-east Spain, who last year used a samurai sword to hack to death his parents and his 11-year-old sister, who had Down's syndrome.

The youth, who will appear in court soon, has admitted his crime but has also shown no remorse for what police said was a brutal and carefully-planned, night-time attack.

"The cause of juvenile violence is a society which educates children as to their rights but not as to their obligations," said a forensic psychologist, Javier Urra. "Society has lost its moral strength."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe bans British exams
fields.body:
Zimbabwe bans British exams

Zimbabwe has banned schools from entering pupils for British O-level and A-level exams.

The education minister, Samuel Mumbengegwi, said pupils were "subjected to emotional and psychological stress" while studying for foreign exams, and claimed the ban would create a national identity. Chris McGreal, Harare

Cloning doctor faces questions

The Rome chapter of Italy's national medical association questioned an Italian fertility doctor, Severino Antinori, yesterday over his plan to clone humans.

Last week, the chapter's president said members who tried to clone humans risked sanctions ranging from a warning to expulsion, which prohibits doctors from practising medicine in Italy. AP, Rome

£6m for NYPD torture victim
Abner Louima, who was sexually tortured in a New York police station, has reached a $9m (£6.3m) civil settlement in return for dropping demands to reform the city's police department, the Daily News reported.

Mr Louima was beaten by police and then abused after his arrest outside a nightclub in 1997. The officer who admitted sexual torture has been jailed for 30 years. Reuters, New York

Hindus attack mosque in India

Indian police commandos were posted to the northern city of Amritsar yesterday to prevent a religious clash after Hindu nationalists desecrated a mosque with pork, and burned copies of the Koran.

The All India Hindu Protection Committee said the attack was in retaliation for the slaughter of cows in Afghanistan by the Islamic fundamentalist Taliban regime. AP, Amritsar

Kerouac scroll up for sale

Jack Kerouac's original typescript of On the Road, the book that chronicled his postwar travels with drifter Neal Cassady and inspired the Beat generation, is expected to fetch up to £1m when it is auctioned in New York in May.

The 37-metre (120ft) long paper roll was typed by Kerouac in a three-week marathon, said to have been fuelled by coffee and drugs, in April 1951.

Candid camera spied in sauna
A German sauna has banned a man caught filming naked customers with a tiny camera hidden in his shower gel bottle.

"The suspect claimed he wanted to use the material for 'artistic purposes'," said Bad Homburg police, who are deciding whether to charge the 37-year-old man. Reuters, Frankfurt

webTitle: East Germany's ex-leader loses European appeal

fields.headline: Ex-leader of East Germany loses final European appeal
fields.trailText: Egon Krenz, last communist leader of East Germany, saw his claim denying responsibilty for the death of four people shot trying to scale the Berlin Wall quashed yesterday.
fields.body:
East Germany's last communist leader, Egon Krenz, yesterday saw his controversial attempt to claim that he was not responsible for the death of four people shot trying to scale the Berlin Wall quashed once and for all.

The judgment was greeted in some quarters as a message to the world's dictators that they cannot pay lip service to human rights while simultaneously abusing them, and that they will be held to account by successor governments.

Others claimed, however, that the ruling set a utopian precedent that would be impossible to enforce and which, if properly applied, would see Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, dragged before the European Court of Human Rights for atrocities allegedly committed by his troops in Chechnya.

The Strasbourg court unanimously rejected Krenz's appeal against a manslaughter verdict handed out by a German court after reunification.

Krenz, 63, will now have to serve the remainder of his six-and-a-half year prison sentence.

Together with two former senior members of the country's politburo and a border guard, he had tried to argue that stopping people fleeing the now defunct communist state using "proportionate force" was perfectly legal under East German law.

It would be unreasonable, they claimed, to convict them retrospectively under today's federal laws.

But the court cleverly skirted the murky legal waters of whether federal German law supersedes East German law when the 17 judges ruled that the behaviour of Krenz and his two subordinates was illegal under the German Democratic Republic's (GDR) laws anyway.

It was true, the court said, that the GDR had a policy of protecting its border "at all costs", but the need to preserve human life was also enshrined in the country's constitution, and that was more important.

"Because of the very senior positions they occupied in the state apparatus, they evidently could not have been ignorant of [East Germany's] constitution and legislation, or of its international obligations and the criticisms of its border-policing regime that had been made internationally."

But Piers Gardner, the British barrister representing the four defendants, argued that the court's finding that shooting people on the wall was unlawful under East German law was questionable.

"It is difficult to agree that the law of the GDR was as the court found it," he said. "This judgment should make everyone think from here to Vladivostock."

More than 200 people are estimated to have been shot while trying to clamber over the Berlin Wall during the cold war. Prosecutors argued that Krenz, as a leading politburo member responsible for security issues from 1983, was directly responsible.

A defiant Krenz disdainfully dismissed yesterday's ruling: "They took the West German historic point of view rather than the legal reality."

"For me, it will be interesting how the German government deals with the politicians from Russia who had responsibility for the Soviet Union. There my military commander was [Mikhail] Gorbachev."

The victims' families took a different view of the judgment.

Krenz "understood nothing", she said.

If Krenz, a former politician, can be charged with man- slaughter, the source argued, then so can the prime minister at the time of the Bloody Sunday massacre and politicians from Russia to Ukraine.

And that, he said, simply is not going to happen.

The judgment was greeted in some quarters as a message to the world's dictators that they cannot pay lip service to human rights while simultaneously abusing them, and that they will be held to account by successor governments. Others claimed, however, that the ruling set a utopian precedent that would be impossible to enforce and which, if properly applied, would see Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, dragged before the European Court of Human Rights for atrocities allegedly committed by his troops in Chechnya. The Strasbourg court unanimously rejected Krenz's appeal against a manslaughter verdict handed out by a German court after reunification. Krenz, 63, will now have to serve the remainder of his six-and-a-half year prison sentence. Together with two former senior members of the country's politburo and a border guard, he had tried to argue that stopping people fleeing the now defunct communist state using "proportionate force" was perfectly legal under East German law. It would be unreasonable, they claimed, to convict them retrospectively under today's federal laws. But the court cleverly skirted the murky legal waters of whether federal German law supersedes East German law when the 17 judges ruled that the behaviour of Krenz and his two subordinates was illegal under the German Democratic Republic's (GDR) laws anyway. It was true, the court said, that the GDR had a policy of protecting its border "at all costs", but the need to preserve human life was also enshrined in the country's constitution, and that was more important. "Because of the very senior positions they occupied in the state apparatus, they evidently could not have been ignorant of [East Germany's] constitution and legislation, or of its international obligations and the criticisms of its border-policing regime that had been made internationally." But Piers Gardner, the British barrister representing the four defendants, argued that the court's finding that shooting people on the wall was unlawful under East German law was questionable. "It is difficult to agree that the law of the GDR was as the court found it," he said. "This judgment should make everyone think from here to Vladivostock." More than 200 people are estimated to have been shot while trying to clamber over the Berlin Wall during the cold war. Prosecutors argued that Krenz, as a leading politburo member responsible for security issues from 1983, was directly responsible. A defiant Krenz disdainfully dismissed yesterday's ruling: "They took the West German historic point of view rather than the legal reality." "For me, it will be interesting how the German government deals with the politicians from Russia who had responsibility for the Soviet Union. There my military commander was [Mikhail] Gorbachev." And that, he said, simply is not going to happen.

fields.headline: No 1845
fields.standfirst: Asterix
fields.trailText: Asterix.
fields.body:
Do you mean the star-shaped symbol used to refer readers to a note, frequently at the foot of the page? Nope.

So what are you talking about? The pugnacious, true-blue French hero dedicated to keeping the marauding invaders from the south at bay.

Ah. Jean-Marie Le Pen! Mais non! Asterix is the creation of animators Goscinny and Uderzo, whose defiance of the Romans has delighted les Français for 40 years.

Defying the Romans? That takes Gaul. Asterix is supported in his campaign by his sidekick Obelix, the druid Getafix, and their chieftain, Vitalstatistix.

Are their names any funnier in French? In their original language, Vitalstatistix is called Abraracourcix. So no, not really.

Wasn't there a movie about Asterix a while back? Seeking to out-Hollywood Hollywood, the French film industry spent FF274m (£27m) and cast Gerard Depardieu as the bumbling Obelix. The blockbuster doubled the audience for French films in Europe in 1999.

Formidable! Recent polls show Asterix is the best-known comic character in Europe, beating Mickey Mouse and Tintin.

Still battling (cultural) imperialism, after all these years. So indelibly is Asterix associated with that struggle, that Jose Bové, the yeomanish anti-McDonald's crusader and folk hero, is constantly being compared to his cartoon predecessor.

Isn't that just because of that silly moustache? Peut- être.

So is Asterix back? Seven years after announcing his retirement, and five years after changing his mind, Asterix's surviving creator, Albert Uderzo, has just released the 31st volume of the Gaul's adventures, Asterix and the Actress.

And has it shifted faster than snails in a bistro? Sold 800,000 copies on its first day of release in France. The initial international print run is 3m.

Do exclaim: "Vive Asterix, a vibrant part of French culture!"

Don't ask: "Aren't comics for children?"

webTitle: G2: Profile of a rare disease patient

fields.headline: Danny's big fight
fields.standfirst: At 20, Danny Bond has had 301 operations for a rare, excruciating condition. He was on the point of giving up. But, as  Emma Brockes reports, he has now been given one last hope
fields.trailText: At 20, Danny Bond has had 301 operations for a rare, excruciating condition. He was on the point of giving up. But, as Emma Brockes reports, he has now been given one last hope.
fields.body:
It was on the eve of his 300th operation that Danny Bond decided he wanted to die. The 20-year-old's chest looked like an Ordnance Survey map: a collision of scars drawn from 18 colostomies, 19 ileostomies, 150 septicaemic infections, a dozen haemorrhages and the sharp contours of malnutrition - a summary of Danny's life in ward E7 of Southampton general hospital. His mother Beverley, a nurse, held his hand over the rim of the bed. "I've had enough, mum," he said, and she nodded.

A fortnight ago, Danny submitted to his 301st operation, a procedure to untwist his bowel. He is suffering from a rare condition called chronic pseudo obstruct, which prevents the nerves between the brain and the digestive system communicating. When Danny tries to digest, his brain tells his gut to clench then forgets to release it. The result is permanent obstruction: he is attached to a feeding machine 10 hours a day, has had the pain in his gut likened by doctors to childbirth and has never been able to empty his bowel. For now, however, Danny's decision to refuse further treatment has been suspended.

Since appearing on a BBC2 documentary last month, Danny has been flooded with letters praising his courage and urging him to seek treatment from a pioneering American bowel specialist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota. "It's $5,000 just to sit on Dr Camilleri's couch," says Danny's mother. Before he gives up, her son would like to exhaust this final possibility.

While the money is being raised, Danny must undergo the sickening routine of more surgery. In a side room of Southampton hospital's west wing, he awaits the latest round with mounting distress. "How are you with vomit?" his mum asks brightly, and explains that Danny has become so terrified of the operating table that he starts throwing up 12 hours before surgery and doesn't stop until he has been knocked out.

"Hello," he whispers, lifting an eyelid and shutting it again. He is the colour of milk, protecting himself in these hours before surgery by withdrawing from the world and letting Beverley speak, largely, for him. Even at his weakest, however, he manages to communicate a healthy intolerance of his mother. "I like sport," he croaks, when asked about his interests. "I'm good at all of them." "He's a natural mimic," interjects Beverley, "so if he sees someone swing a golf cue, he's got the rhythm straight off."

Under his lids, Danny's eyes roll. "Golf club, not cue," he corrects, witheringly.

Danny Bond was born 20 years ago, 12 weeks prematurely, and had to be resuscitated immediately. He is the second of Beverley Dodds's three children, the eldest of whom, a 23-year-old daughter, is presently three beds down from Danny with suspected appendicitis. His stepfather, Mike, is a hostage negotiator with the police force. After Danny was ventilated and placed in a special baby unit, he had a haemorrhage and developed an infection in his bowel lining. At five weeks, he underwent heart surgery. Since then, he has never spent more than a couple of months out of hospital and has only celebrated two birthdays and two Christmases at home.

The biggest problem for Danny's family was that until the age of 12, nobody knew what was wrong with him. "We were told he was anorexic," says Beverley. "We were told it was all in his head - or in my head. They sent him to a residential home to get him away from mother for a week, as if it were a nervous disorder." At one stage, Danny had 21 exploratory operations in six months. "In the end we said, if this is in his head then he's very good at it, seeing as whenever you open him up his guts are all twisted."

At 11, Danny's weight plummeted to two stones and he was admitted to Great Ormond Street hospital, where he was finally diagnosed with chronic pseudo obstruct.

The pain that followed was unimaginable. "Have you ever seen [the film] Alien?" he asks. "It's like one of these little creatures inside your stomach trying to pop out."

The disruptions ruled out regular school and although there was a school in the hospital, he was always too ill to attend. When he won a place at a higher education college, he was only there for 11 weeks and had to forfeit his tuition fees. The strength of the drugs he was on made his mind cloudy and unfit for exams.

Worst of all, says his family, was the psychological damage done by wave after wave of frustrated expectations. "Every time you meet a new surgeon they always say: 'I've got a knack, I've got this way you've never had before, it will work,' " says Beverley. "This is what he hates, don't you Dan? We now say to them, don't do that. Just be honest. Because every time they say it, a little bit of you hopes they're right, and then you feel let down and betrayed."

The two disagree over just how many operations he has had. Only including the major procedures, Beverley has counted 300, mention of which makes Danny grimace and exhale loudly. "Dan thinks it's in the 500s, don't you? But we've stopped counting the nips and tucks." Three years ago, Danny contracted the penicillin-resistant superbug, MRSA, which raised the tally of operations by repeatedly infecting the line in his chest.

The constant in all this turmoil has been Beverley's good humour: while Danny is unwell, she is ferociously upbeat for him, so utterly in his corner that, she says, his siblings have all felt jealous, then they feel guilty for feeling jealous.

The minute Danny enters one of his short-lived periods of stability, Beverley and her husband deflate. "Dad and I keep on going day in, day out and when he has a couple of weeks of feeling better, we go to pieces. It's during the quiet times that your brain has time to think."

During a quiet time two months ago, Beverley thought Danny had come to the end of the line. Nerve damage was making his operations increasingly painful and the more disheartened he grew, the less able he was to cope. His bones hurt, his muscles hurt, he became clinically depressed.

Twice, he gained access to the pill box and tried to commit suicide. "There are times when you just sit there and don't know what to say or think," his mother says. "There are times when you wonder if you should put a pillow over his head. Then you take a deep breath and cope with the next onslaught."

Eventually, Danny told his family he didn't want to have any more surgery.

They supported him, a decision for which they expected to be vilified. On the night that the documentary was screened, they left the house. As it turned out, the family didn't get one crank letter. Someone sent Danny some cut-outs of the Virgin Mary, but he reckoned they couldn't do him any harm. As the encouragement rolled in, something in his outlook began to change.

"He said that the response from the public made him feel like there was some hope out there. There are so many nice people rooting for him that maybe it wasn't time to give up."

He still has the pain and the utter boredom to deal with - Danny's main diversion is a Playstation 2 - but during the worst periods he retreats into the memory of his only three months of normal life. When he was 17, Danny rallied enough to live on his own in a flat he rented from his aunt. "Parties, late nights, no parents. You were wild, weren't you Dan?"

He smiles, weakly.

fields.headline: The luck of the draw
fields.standfirst: Tetbury
fields.trailText: Tetbury.
fields.body:
Looking back over our 10 years of fun farming, with a flock of sheep that never exceeded about 60, it has to be said that we were lucky. Foot and mouth, now bringing pain and grief to farmers all over the country, did not occur at all during that period.

We had the occasional lambing disaster that required veterinary assistance and sometimes a caesarean section (a very good test of veterinary skills, since three separate layers need to be stitched back), but on most occasions, we were able to supervise unaided the small miracle of a live birth.

We never had contagious abortion, a condition dangerous to young women in the later stages of pregnancy, since it can be transmitted to humans. We did have orf, a nasty summer skin disease, and we shared the discomfort of the flock. But with the right treatment both sheep and humans recovered quickly. No summer was complete without at least one outbreak of fly strike, usually in the very best lambs in the flock. A blowfly lays its eggs in dung-stained wool, the hatching grubs burrow into the skin and the condition, if ignored, means that the poor creature is being literally eaten alive.

Look at your beasts every day is not just wise counsel, it is a necessary part of the responsible stewardship of livestock. Compulsory dipping ceased to be an annual requirement during our shepherding years, so we lost the routine of a day when a visiting contractor would come, erect a mobile sheepdip, and immerse them all in the organophosphates which bear a close relationship to nerve gas. Even clad in a rubber suit and mask the noxious chemical seemed, on a hot and sweaty day, to get through to you.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

E1 Labour MP Neil Turner humiliated a constituent with

(a) Dyslexia

(b) Dyspraxia

(c) Dysglossia

(d) Dysentry

E2 Which of the following can't spell very well?

(a) The Witches of Eastwick

(b) The Blair Witch

(c) Evil Edna

(d) Medea

E3 Grease is

(a) A good cure for a hangover

(b) A beautiful place to go on holiday

(c) The word

(d) Not good for your arteries

E4 In the beginning was the word, and the word was

(a) Aardvark

(b) God

(c) Spread

(d) A late night programme on C4, hosted by Terry Christian

E5 "I" before "e" except after

(a) C

(b) Sea

(c) See

(d) Si

 Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by March 28. The winner will be notified by April 6. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at Guardian Unlimited Quiz Room.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: My partner uses phone sex lines, and when I found out he told me that men need cheap thrills. Must I just learn to live with it?
fields.trailText: My partner uses phone sex lines, and when I found out he told me that men need cheap thrills. Must I just learn to live with it?
fields.body:
My partner of five years, with whom I have a two-year-old child, is addicted to telephone sex lines. After I found this out from his mobile phone bill, he admitted that he has used them since he was a teenager. He also said that it is a gender thing - men need cheap thrills. We're in our late 20s and I'm an attractive woman who loves sex. Why am I not enough? I made him understand how I felt about him calling these lines by describing myself getting off on what a man might say to me on a sex line. He was disgusted by the image and said that, in reality, he wouldn't be able to cope with it at all. It seems that it is acceptable for men to do this, but not women. I need some honest answers from both men and women - must I just get used to it?

Consider counselling

Your partner's problem is neither a universal fact nor something you have to get used to. There are two separate issues here: his behaviour and your feelings about it. You feel diminished by your discovery; you should not. This is not about you or your desirability; it is rooted in your partner's behaviour. Decide what it is about this issue that upsets you: discovery or exclusion. In my own life it was not the discovery that upset me, it was the time devoted by my partner to something which is merely a fantasy. Your partner probably finds it impossible to discuss his true feelings with you.

This predates your relationship and, although many people find this subject difficult, he is avoiding it completely. Since he feels secure with phone sex, perhaps he could call you instead of a stranger.

The disgust your partner displayed at your description of role reversal is an indication of his intimidation by real sex. If you cannot accommodate this in your relationship, I recommend that you obtain counselling. Do not postpone acting, nor allow your partner to. My partner claimed it was "a phase" and that she did not require help to resolve it. It has all but ended our relationship. Sex is the glue that bonds people. You only come unstuck if you want to.
Name and address withheld

Uncover his fantasies

What sort of idiot is this guy? Does he have nothing better to do with his money than waste it talking to strangers? Is he not brave enough to tell you what it is that he wants? Telling you what he likes, fantasises about, is the best thing he could do. It opens up so many possibilities and would certainly be more interesting than listening to some remote "sex goddess" babble on about some nonsense that she has told so many other blokes, it has become an utterly boring, non-interactive experience for her.

If he's not willing to tell you what goes on in his head, get rid of him.
Name and address withheld

Men are not all like him

No, all men do not need cheap sexual thrills. All men do not use chat lines or similar forms of stimulation. Most men perhaps succumb to their curiosity about such things occasionally. Most men want their partner to be the primary focus of their sexual interest. Their minds will wander - some will be unfaithful - but the ambition at heart is to have a relationship where the sex is good and intrinsic to how well they get on.

He defends his use of sex lines by making generalisations which he must know aren't true. Would he tell his male friends he uses chat lines? I doubt it. But if all men needed cheap thrills, they would be the first to understand, wouldn't they?

Most men, if in a good relationship, masturbate as a corollary to the relationship. Many fantasise about their own partners. All relationships have fallow periods of sexual interest. Sometimes it is less fuss to nip into the spare room for a quick yank of nature's stress reliever.
John O'Halloram, Belfast

Turn the tables

A man I knew bought porn mags regularly, which caused immense distress to his wife. Whenever she expressed her unhappiness he would say: "Don't be like that. It's only a bit of harmless fun. All the chaps at the office do it."

One night hubby got home and found his wife ogling photos of naked men with enormous penises and licking her lips. Hubby was absolutely devastated. "Don't be like that," she said, "It's only a bit of harmless fun. All the girls at the office do it." That put an end to his top-shelf purchases.

Try similar tactics with sex lines. Tell your partner you are sorry you made such a fuss about his sex lines, that they are terrific fun and that you understand fully why he finds them so addictive. When forced to confront the reality of his actions he will probably mend his ways. If not, a young, attractive and sexy woman like you should have no problem finding a replacement.
Claude Shields, Bucks

Next week

I can't decide whether to divorce. I'm 45, have been married for 20 years and have children of 16,13 and five. I care for but don't love my husband - as he has aged he has become miserable and pedantic. I think it's partly genetic (members of his family are the same), but made worse by work problems and my lack of love for him. He is a good person with many qualities, an excellent father, he loves me, is 100% supportive of my ideas and thinks the marriage is good.

I want to meet someone I feel passionate about and give us both the chance for a new start. I've spent years dithering about whether to go. I'm nervous about being lonely, hard up, unable to cope and unable to find a new partner, and fear that I'll regret leaving. And, of course, it would devastate the children as well as my husband. He says he'd fight for custody. Neither of us could bear to lose them. I feel guilty even contemplating breaking up the family, but the prospect of growing old with a man who irritates more than excites me fills me with depression.

fields.headline: Les Medley
fields.standfirst: Key player in Spurs' great push-and-run days
fields.trailText: Key player in Spurs' great push-and-run days.
fields.body:
At outside-left, Les Medley, who has died in Canada aged 80, was an essential member of Tottenham Hotspur's fabled push-and-run team which won the FA second division in 1949/50 and the league championship the following year.

Of the Spurs forward lines which flourished under the inspired managership of Arthur Rowe, himself a former Tottenham centre-half, four out of five were Londoners: Sonny Walters on the right wing, Les Bennett at inside-right, Eddie Bailey at inside-left, the exception being the centre forward, Len Duquemin, a Channel Islander.

Medley's quicksilver partnership with Eddie Bailey was a notable one. Each was sharp in both thought and movement, and Bailey's neat, one-touch passing was calculated to keep Medley, a natural winger at a time when they emphatically existed, on the move. Medley had the winger's gift of acceleration and tight ball control - he could use either foot to advantage, crossed the ball effectively, and often moved inside for a crack at goal.

His football career, however, followed a somewhat unorthodox path. Born near the Spurs ground, at White Hart Lane, Edmonton, he played, while a pupil at Latymar school, for Edmonton, London and Middlesex boys, and, in 1935, for England schoolboys against Scotland. As a 17-year-old, he joined the club in 1937 as an amateur, and was put into Tottenham's nursery team of the time, Northfleet United.

Turning professional in February 1939, the war saw him join the RAF and go to Canada, where he met his Canadian wife, Thelma. He hardly played for Spurs till 1944, making altogether 60 wartime appearances for 19 goals.

Medley figured in Tottenham's first 10 second division matches when football officially resumed in 1946/47, but then seemed lost to the English game when his wife's homesickness saw him emigrate to Canada. He stayed for 15 months, working in a steel foundry, and turning out for the Toronto Greenbacks and Ulster United, returning to England in January 1948.

Medley regained his place in the Tottenham team in April 1949 and, the next season, played in all 42 second division games, winning a championship medal. The following season, when Spurs won the first division title, he scored 11 times in 35 games. Altogether, he scored 65 goals in 224 senior matches.

His international career was brief but intense. It was a time when there was competition at outside-left, first from Bobby Langton, then, when he switched from right to left wing, from the illustr-ious Tom Finney. Medley made his England debut at Sunderland against Wales in November 1950, appeared the following week at Highbury against Yugoslavia, and won another of his six caps there the following season against France. He was also chosen to play for the Rest of the United Kingdom in a celebration match against Wales.

After making a final appearance for Spurs against Wolves in April 1953, at the age of 32, he returned with his wife to Canada. But his playing career was not over. Moving to South Africa, he played, between 1958 and 1961, for the Wanderers, and was both player and coach at Rondfontein.

In 1961, he moved to Horsham, Sussex, but, after Thelma's death the following year, returned to Canada, where he ran a fish and chip shop in London, Ontario, for 15 years. He is survived by his daughter Carol, son Steven and six grandchildren.

 Les Medley, footballer, born 1920; died February 22 2001.

fields.headline: Martin Wright
fields.standfirst: Inventor who developed the breathalyser, reduced cot deaths and helped asthmatics
fields.trailText: Inventor who developed the breathalyser, reduced cot deaths and helped asthmatics.
fields.body:
Martin Wright, who has died aged 88, was a prolific medical inventor, whose instruments have helped millions of people and influenced many areas of medical practice.

He worked on two breathalysers, the second of which, the alcolmeter, developed with Tom Jones, won a Queen's Award for Industry and is today the most commonly used roadside breathalyser. Later, he developed a pocket-sized, battery-powered syringe driver, which allowed children with thalassaemia (a hereditary haemoglobin disorder) to receive lengthy infusion treatments while going about their daily lives. It has since been used in a wide range of other conditions, from providing slow injections on neo-natal intensive care units to the continuous infusions of pain-relieving drugs to terminally-ill patients, with 150,000 syringe drivers sold to date.

Wright's training and rapport with the medical profession, coupled with entirely self-taught engineering skills and flair for design, allowed him to produce simple, compact pieces of precision engineering that could be manufactured economically, applied on a large scale, and became design classics in the medical world.

Born in Dulwich, the second son of a clergyman, he was educated at Winchester and Trinity College, Cambridge. He had wanted to study engineering, but was dissuaded on the grounds that it was an unsuitable profession. Graduating with first-class honours in physiology, he went on to St Bartholomew's hospital, London, with an exhibition, and qualified as a doctor in 1938.

Like so many of his generation, the outbreak of war altered his career path. After working at Bart's as a medical registrar, in 1942 he enlisted in the Royal Army Medical Corps as a pathologist. This took him into research on the physiological effects of tank warfare, then to Freetown, Sierra Leone and, at the end of the war, to Singapore, where he rose to the rank of colonel, while reconstructing medical laboratory services there. These experiences, requiring maximum improvisation with minimum equipment, gave him his first opportunity to develop his technical talent.

By demobilisation, Wright had become a pathologist largely by default, and, in this capacity, was recruited by the Medical Research Council (MRC) for a pioneering unit at Llandough hospital, South Wales, studying the miners' disease, pneumoconiosis, through a range of scientific disciplines.

It soon became apparent that the unit needed specialised equipment, which Wright developed himself, starting with machines to produce experimental dust conditions for his own research. He was soon serving as inventor-in-residence, and, in response to the need for a standard measure of lung function, he developed his most influential instrument, the peak flow meter.

The device's invention in 1956 was followed by publication of results in 1959, and peak flow rapidly became a standard measure of respiratory function in most lung disease, particularly in the assessment of asthma and bronchitis. The miniature, plastic version developed in the 1970s can now be found in every medical bag and consulting room, as well as in the homes of many asthmatics. Seven million peak flow meters have been distributed since production began.

In 1957, recognising his unique skills, the MRC employed Wright to work solely on instrument development at the National Institute for Medical Research, Mill Hill, London. There, he was actively involved in the study of breath alcohol, and advised the government on the implementation of the 1967 drink-driving laws.

In 1969, he went to the MRC's Hampstead laboratories, in preparation for a further move in 1971 to the new clinical research centre, at Northwick Park hospital, Harrow. Here, he particularly valued the opportunity to work closely with clinicians. Like the peak flow meter, his most successful machines were developed as solutions to specific practical problems, but subsequently proved to have much wider applications.

Wright had a constant stream of good ideas, many of which were never commercially produced. His inventions spanned many disciplines: epidemiologists remember him for his random zero blood-pressure machine, anaesthetists for his Wright respirometer, and paediatricians for his apnoea (temporary inability to breathe) alarm, the MR10.

This was developed in re sponse to two tragic deaths in Northwick Park's special-care nursery. Previous alarms designed to detect that a baby had stopped breathing were cumbersome and unreliable. The new alarm detected breath movements via a small capsule taped to the abdomen, and is still widely used for monitoring babies born prematurely or at risk from cot death.

Wright was also a daring ocean-going yachtsman, but gave up his more adventurous exploits when, in 1952, he married Sheila Smith, then working at the MRC head office. The arrival of three sons and two daughters put his experience to good use in various contraptions with which to amuse his children, including an aerial railway that conveyed a bathtub and a bicycle. He loved all machines and mechanical devices, and was never happier than when a washing machine reached the end of its useful life, so he could reuse its moving parts.

Although his workshop often appeared similarly improvised, the final instruments were simple, but superbly elegant, solutions to most complex technical problems.

Wright cared little about financial gain or professional advancement, had no postgraduate or formal professional qualifications, and assiduously avoided committee and administrative work. The MRC held his patents and received the lion's share of their royalties, employing him, in return, for a happy lifetime doing what he most enjoyed. He worked on well into his 70s when, finally, he was made an honorary fellow of the Royal College of Physicians and a Cambridge DM. He also received a prize from the Institute of Mechanical Engineers to add to the two design awards and the gold medal he had won at the international inventors' fair.

Wright's one ambition - that his inventions should be widely used and respected - has been realised abundantly. They will continue their mission of preventing illness and alleviating pain for many years to come. He is survived by his wife and children.

 Basil Martin Wright, bio-engineer, born December 20 1912; died March 4 2001.

fields.headline: Market suffers biggest plunge since 1992
fields.trailText: Britain's stock market yesterday suffered its worst one-day loss since the pound crashed out of the exchange rate mechanism in 1992. Deepening gloom about the prospects for the American economy sent shockwaves through the world's financial markets.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Britain's stock market yesterday suffered its worst one-day loss since the pound crashed out of the exchange rate mechanism in 1992. Deepening gloom about the prospects for the American economy sent shockwaves through the world's financial markets.

The FTSE-100 Index dropped by 226 points, the second largest fall ever, as investor confidence ebbed away. The frenetic trading session wiped £52bn off the value of Britain's leading companies.

Most of the leading global stock market indices are now "bear markets" because they have dropped by more than 20% from their peaks.

The Nasdaq, the bellwether of the dot.com sector, is more than 60% down since its peak a year ago. Analysts said Tuesday's half point cut in American interest rates was regarded as too timid

webTitle: League table of solicitors proposed to cut clients' complaints

fields.headline: League table of solicitors proposed to cut clients' complaints
fields.trailText: The Law Society is considering publishing a league table of solicitors, giving them a risk rating of between one and five according to the number of complaints of misconduct or poor service upheld against them.
fields.body:
The Law Society is considering publishing a league table of solicitors, giving them a risk rating of between one and five according to the number of complaints of misconduct or poor service upheld against them.

The society's chief executive, Janet Paraskeva, said she would consider putting the idea to the society's governing council once new measures to identify high-risk firms and to try to help them resolve clients' complaints were fully operational.

Ms Paraskeva unveiled a package of measures yesterday designed to tackle the profession's poor record on complaints. The numbers of clients accusing solicitors of delays, bad service and other failings have soared in recent years, leading to a huge backlog of complaints for the society's regulatory arm, the Office for the Supervision of Solicitors (OSS).

The backlog led the government to take reserve powers to strip the profession of its self-regulatory role, and the society has been warned it will lose the right to police itself unless it meets targets for clearing the old complaints and resolving new ones.

Ms Paraskeva, a former schools inspector, said: "The risk rating is a power that has never been used before. The end result is that we could have a publishable list. We will be in a position to recommend to members of the public the firms which have a low risk rating.

"The purpose is to try to encourage people to get good ratings. Firms would be in a position to advertise 'we're a good firm with a low risk rating'."

Ratings will be worked out by the society's monitoring unit, which will visit firms which seem to need help. At present, the unit intervenes only when a red flag has been raised, but in future it would step in sooner.

A new customer assistance unit, set up to try to resolve complaints quickly over the phone by conciliation between client and solicitor, will be expanded and widely publicised.

For the first time, the society proposes to coopt lay people on to its governing council and to give them a role in writing the rules which govern solicitors' conduct. The society's 80,000 members in England and Wales will be sent a postal ballot today asking them to vote on plans to increase the size of the 75-member council and to have a 5% lay membership.

The eventual aim is that 25% of those who write the rules for regulating the profession will be non-lawyers.

As part of its move to a tougher enforcement regime, the profession is thinking of adopting a policy whereby the firms giving rise to the most complaints pay a larger share of the cost of enforcement.

The OSS has been set targets of resolving 50% of complaints within three months, 80% within six months, 90% within a year and 100% within 18 months. It now takes nine months on average for a complaint to be processed.

Ms Paraskeva said monthly performance statistics would be published on the society's website, and she would consider publishing the names of solicitors disciplined for serious professional misconduct - 183 in the year to April 2000 - on the website, rather than just in the society's journal. "Just publishing to the profession is only half the story," she said. "It's something the public needs to know."

We will be in a position to recommend to members of the public the firms which have a low risk rating. "The purpose is to try to encourage people to get good ratings. webTitle: Police hold 34 in games city raids

fields.headline: Police hold 34 in games city raids
fields.trailText: Police made 34 arrests yesterday after dawn raids on homes in east Manchester in an operation to crack down on crime in one of Britain's most deprived inner city areas.
fields.body:
Police made 34 arrests yesterday after dawn raids on homes in east Manchester in an operation to crack down on crime in one of Britain's most deprived inner city areas.

The area is the focus of new public and private investment due to a stadium and other sporting facilities being built for the Commonwealth Games next year. Police and organisers are concerned to promote the games zone as safe and secure for the thousands of visitors expected from around the world. However, residents also co-operated with police in an effort to free their area of crime.

"We targeted 49 addresses in the area and now have 34 in custody for a variety of offences including supply of drugs, burglary and handling stolen goods," said Superintendent David Jones of Greater Manchester police.

"This was the culmination of a year long intelligence gathering operation in which we have been working very closely with local residents."

The raids in the Beswick, Clayton and Openshaw districts, involving 300 officers, formed part of Operation Excalibur, launched a year ago in a link-up with Manchester city council and New Deal for Communities, the government's showpiece regeneration project.

Mr Jones said officers had responded to calls for action from residents, who were becoming increasingly willing to supply police with names of troublemakers. The games were "a catalyst, and the new stadium is a symbol of regeneration in the area," said Mr Jones. "But the games will run for two weeks, and we are here to look after people who have been here for 15 years and will be here for 15 years after the games are over."

Officers from the tactical aid unit in riot gear, plus uniformed and plain clothes officers, gathered in 40 teams. They were briefed in the city's velodrome because no police station was big enough to accommodate all the officers. "Your job this morning is to get the people into custody, securing the evidence that will get them put away," Med Hughes, assistant chief constable, told them. The teams left in a convoy of 55 cars and vans.

Mr Jones said: "These arrests will represent something of a relief for law abiding locals in the area. These people are fed up with the day to day crime affecting their everyday life. In the past we've had people giving us names of criminals then claiming we don't do anything about it. I'm sure this operation will show we do.

"You get people whom we call crime generators, who are responsible for a substantial number of offences. One of my officers says these are not the Al Capones of the business but more like the Bill Sykeses."

Operation Excalibur aims to reduce crime and the fear of crime in East Manchester by 30% over three years.

The crime figures for the period from April 1 to December 31 last year compared with the same period in 1999 show that burglary is down by 46%, theft from motor vehicles is down by 42% and theft from the person is down by 34%.

"There has been an increased police presence, and there have 1,000 fewer victims compared with the same period last year," said Mr Jones.

Sean McGonigle, principal regeneration officer for New Deal for Communities, said: "Those who commit crimes affect the quality of life for law abiding people in the area, and we have the chance to make this area hostile to the criminals."

webTitle: Foot and mouth crisis: in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: • The body of a 32 foot humpback whale will have to stay on Sandwich beach in Kent because of foot and mouth restrictions on nearby   farmland. Dover council contractors had been hoping to move the 20 tonne carcass, found on Wednesday, but will now have to wait for the go-ahead from Maff officials.
fields.body:
 The body of a 32 foot humpback whale will have to stay on Sandwich beach in Kent because of foot and mouth restrictions on nearby farmland. Dover council contractors had been hoping to move the 20 tonne carcass, found on Wednesday, but will now have to wait for the go-ahead from Maff officials.

 Police yesterday called on the organisers of a mass protest against an animal experiments laboratory to call off a planned weekend demonstration because of the worsening crisis. Up to 1,000 animal right demonstrators have vowed to meet in Dunmow, Essex, on Sunday, near the headquarters of Huntingdon Life Sciences.

 The Italian health ministry reported a suspected case of foot and mouth in a goat imported from France. The goat, found in a farm in Pisa, in Tuscany, was put down as a precaution.

 Country clothing manufacturer Barbour yesterday announced plans to donate £250,000 to farmers and the country community most affected by the foot-and-mouth crisis. Company chairman Margaret Barbour said the money would come from the firm's charitable trust.

 A rural stress counselling service has recruited more staff to cope with demand prompted by the crisis. The Rural Stress Network has also installed extra phone lines to offer anxious farmers and rural businesses advice on how to cope.

webTitle: Double whammy of sun and smoking

fields.headline: Double whammy of sun and smoking
fields.trailText: Scientists today offer an explanation as to why women who smoke and sunbathe look old before their time.
fields.body:
Scientists today offer an explanation as to why women who smoke and sunbathe look old before their time.

They suggest these habits make a "double whammy" attack on their skin.

Smoking helps to activate an enzyme, matrix metalloproteinase (MMP-1), that breaks down collagen, the connective tissue that maintains the skin's elasticity, researchers at the St John's institute of dermatology at St Thomas's hospital, London, suggest in the Lancet.

Sunlight is already known to have an ageing effect, especially on parts of the body most exposed to ultraviolet rays, but there may be new understanding of how its effects in combination with smoking make matters worse.

The researchers believe that smoking helps to generate genes reponsible for MMP-1.

The study, involving 14 smokers and 10 non-smokers, revealed that the smokers had far more genetic material associated with MMP-1.

Antony Young, who led the research, said this was unlikely to be down to chance.

"Smoking exerts a noticeable effect on the skin. Smokers have more wrinkles, and their skin tends to have a greyish pallor compared to non-smokers."

His team had been investigating the effects of sunlight by examing skin from the buttocks of volunteers irradiated with ultraviolet light to see if this encouraged the formation of MMP-1. They found some volunteers who were not exposed to radiation nevertheless had unusual amounts of genetic material linked to the enzyme.

These participants were smokers, had an average age of 30 and had smoked 10-20 cigarettes a day for between three and 25 years. Professor Young suggested they had had a double dose of MMP-1 from the action of sunlight and tobacco.

The enzyme usually helped tissue rebuilding, but a natural inhibitor within the body that regulated its performance had not increased in the same way.

Amanda Sandford, research director for Action on Smoking and Health, said it was ironic that teenagers took up smoking to look more mature. "For smokers, middle age starts in their early 30s as the tell-tale wrinkles around the mouth and eyes begin to appear.

"Young female smokers are likely to be wasting money on anti-wrinkle creams if they continue to smoke. The best beauty treatment by far is to quit smoking."

webTitle: Millionaire's wife acquitted of murder bid

fields.headline: Millionaire's wife acquitted of murder bid
fields.trailText: A garden designer was acquitted yesterday of attempting to murder her millionaire husband by adding drugs to his breakfast cereal and then trying to suffocate him using a plastic bag.
fields.body:
A garden designer was acquitted yesterday of attempting to murder her millionaire husband by adding drugs to his breakfast cereal and then trying to suffocate him using a plastic bag.

The jury at Winchester crown court took 51 minutes to find that 41-year-old Melanie Cangardel did not intend to kill her husband Jean Marc, 50, at the couple's £1.2m manor house in Dorset last September.

In a trial notable for tales of high society intrigue and testimony from the novelist Joanna Trollope, the prosecution argued that Mrs Cangardel had crushed antihistamine tablets into her husband's Weetabix in order to knock him out.

She then attempted to suffocate him with a bag from the shoe chain Shelly's, it was claimed, because their marriage was falling apart and she did not want to give up her luxurious life at their home in Cheselbourne. She stood to gain more, Anthony Donne QC suggested, from a "dead husband" than a "dead marriage."

Mr Cangardel told the court: "All I felt was the bag being held down over my mouth. I thought I was going to die. I was running out of air. I was in a complete panic. I screamed: 'You are trying to kill me!' She said: 'Yes, I am. If that doesn't work, I will shoot you with your gun'."

But the jury eventually accepted a different version of events, in which Mrs Cangardel, trapped in an unhappy marriage, suffering from depression and driven to distraction by her husband's taunts and criticisms, had entered a dissociative state and placed the bag over her husband's head only to frighten him. She had secretly crushed the tablets into his cereal, they found, to treat fleabites from a family dog she knew he did not like.

Joanna Trollope, a friend of Mrs Cangardel, told the court how, accompanying the couple at a dinner in Kensington last year, she had seen Mr Cangardel object to his wife wearing a tweed jacket. To Miss Trollope's "great embarrassment", he had indicated the author and said to his wife: "Why can't you dress like that? I wouldn't want to be seen in the street with you looking like this."

When the two women met four days before the alleged murder attempt, Miss Trollope said, her friend had wept because of "intimate and sexual" insults Mr Cangardel had made.

Mrs Cangardel, a graduate of Oxford University, described how she had initially been "thunderstruck" by Jean Marc, a widower who made his fortune in computers, and married him in 1998. But relations soured, she told the court, until one day she had found her husband in bed during the day.

"I thought, I've not been sleeping, and does he understand just how worn out and exhausted I am by having to bear the burdens of all the problems?" she said.

"I don't know where I picked up the bag - I was sort of in a dream. I didn't pick up a knife or a hammer, I didn't want to hurt him, but how else can you shock someone without hurting them? The awful thing is, I think he thinks I wanted to kill him, but I didn't at all."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Women target green beret
fields.body:
Women target green beret

Three female soldiers are to undergo commando training for the green beret at the Royal Marine training centre at Lympstone, east Devon. Capt Claire Philips, 28, and L/Cpl Joanna Perry, 29, from the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, and Capt Pip Tattersall, 26, from the Adjutant Generals Corps, will be among 84 soldiers on the course which finishes with a 30-mile run in full kit.

More back on beat - or less?

The number of police officers has increased by the largest amount for more than 10 years, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday. Cash from the crime fighting fund helped boost numbers for January by 1,367 but the total for England and Wales stood at 125,537 officers, 1,621 less than before the last election.

Premiere boost for Edinburgh

Four world and 20 British premieres will be among the attractions at the Edinburgh International Festival. Among highlights will be the Vienna Burgtheater's first UK performance and the premieres of film director Francois Girard's Novecento and Scottish playwright Shan Khan's Office.

PC ends stress claim

A former police officer Riccard Parsonson, who sued the Metropolitan police for around £400,000 for alleged stress as the result of a transfer to frontline duties, yesterday dropped his high court damages action after his counsel said both parties had agreed terms.

10-ton landslide blocks line

Rail services were disrupted yesterday after a 10-ton landslide blocked the tracks near Sommer Hill tunnel in Kent, between Tonbridge and Tunbridge Wells.

22-year-old murder charge

A man appeared before Wirral magistrates on Merseyside yesterday charged with murdering his wife more than 22 years ago. Thomas Bowman, 58, of no fixed address, is alleged to have murdered Mary Bowman,44, whose body was exhumed on Wednesday morning.

webTitle: Doctor 'should keep job' despite fatal gas error

fields.headline: Doctor 'should keep job' despite fatal gas error
fields.trailText: A hospital consultant should be allowed to keep his job despite giving a three-year-old a fatal dose of laughing gas instead of oxygen, an inquiry ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
A hospital consultant should be allowed to keep his job despite giving a three-year-old a fatal dose of laughing gas instead of oxygen, an inquiry ruled yesterday.

An investigation into the incident at Newham general hospital, east London, found Andrew Hobart, a former chairman of the BMA's junior doctors' committee, made a "medical error" by inadvertently turning the wrong valve of a resuscitation machine and flooding Najiyah Hussain's body with nitrous oxide, an anaesthetic highly toxic in its purest form.

But, although he then failed to notice his mistake, the internal inquiry stopped short of calling for his dismissal or referral to the General Medical Council. Instead, it acknowledged his "genuine remorse" and recommended he be allowed to return to work after supervised retraining.

The findings by Newham Healthcare NHS trust were swiftly denounced as a "whitewash" by the family of the girl, who died on January 18 after being taken to the hospital's accident and emergency department for treatment for a fit.

"I do not think he should be allowed to practice again," said her father, Akmul Hussain, 42, from his home in Manor Park, east London.

"At the very least, he should be referred to the GMC. How do we know he won't do this again?"

Najiyah's cousin, Mohammed Miah, 25, added: "Mr Hobart has come out of this report smelling of roses. There has to be some kind of accountability for what has happened."

A statement from Mr Hobart said: "I would like to express my deepest sympathies to the family of Najiyah Hussain and to say how very sorry I am about the death of their daughter."

The family are planning to sue the hospital for compensation. Meanwhile, the prosecution service is assessing whether to prosecute for man-slaughter by gross negligence.

The inquiry found that, when Najiyah was brought into the hospital on January 18 for resuscitation, Mr Hobart, the leader of seven doctors and nurses, took charge of her airway and breathing.

But, instead of turning the larger white valve for oxygen, he turned a smaller blue one, two valves away. The mistake was discovered only eight to 10 minutes later when the paediatric cardiac arrest team arrived, and corrected the error which should have been noted by Mr Hobart. The report notes that this failure to check why there was so little oxygen in Najiyah's body "compounded the original mistake".

Najiyah's breathing and heart were restarted but after four hours she was withdrawn from life support when it was clear further interventions would have no success.

Mr Hobart, who made front page news two years ago when he broke down in tears during a speech at a BMA conference, was suspended after the incident, but yesterday's report found his record showed he was "appropriately trained, competent and safe to practice within the speciality".

There was "no evidence of a record of carelessness, previous clinical incidents or medical errors on his part" and he had "demonstrated genuine remorse for his error and made it clear he is prepared to learn from his mistake".

Asked how the consultant could have made the mistake, the trust's medical director, Dr Charles Gutteridge, said "It's a bit like the situation where occasionally people put their foot on an accelerator rather than a brake."

While the report found it was the consultant's mistake that caused the death, it also made 20 recommendations for improving the safety of equipment used in A&E departments throughout the country, including removing nitrous oxide from resuscitation rooms and fitting Boyles machines with audible alarms for when the oxygen supply failed.

fields.headline: Britain ages as pregnancies fall
fields.standfirst: Retirement at 72 needed to keep workforce balance
fields.trailText: Retirement at 72 needed to keep workforce balance
fields.body:
The average retirement age would have to rise to 72 to maintain the present balance between the working population and numbers of older dependents, according to demographic forecasts published yesterday by the office for national statistics.

It said that the ageing of the British population was inevitable over the next 40 years, even if there were sharp increases in the birth rate and net immigration averaging 1m a year.

The forecasts came as the office published figures showing the first fall since 1995 in the teenage pregnancy rate, suggesting progress towards the government's target of halving the numbers by 2010. The downturn was particularly sharp in the case of girls under 16, with the rate falling to its lowest since 1994.

The analysis of ageing Britain was based on examining the consequences of children born after the second world war and in the 1960s baby boom reaching the traditional retirement ages of 60 for women and 65 for men between 2006 and the late 2030s. Even assuming unrealistically high increases in immigration and fertility, this was bound to cause a dramatic fall in the support ratio - the relationship between the number of people of working age and the number of pensioners.

In 1999 there were 4.2 people aged 15-64 for every person aged 65 and over. This would fall steadily to about 2.5 in 2040. "Even massive constant net migration inflows could not prevent support ratios ultimately falling," said Chris Shaw of the government actuary's department, in the spring issue of Population Trends.

The proposal to raise the state retirement age to 65 for women - to be phased in between 2010 and 2020 - would for a while reduce the economic impact of ageing. But an increase in the average retirement age to 72.3 years would be needed to maintain the present support ratio after 2040. There was no suggestion that the government was considering changing the state retirement age.

The average age at retirement for members of occupational pension schemes was well below 60, and a third of people aged between 50 and the state pension age are not now working.

"Measures such as raising workforce participation rates or discouraging early retirement are likely to remain a more practical tool for increasing the working population than attempting to influence demographic behaviour," he said.

The ONS expects the size of the UK population to peak in 2036 at 64.9m before declining to about 60m by the end of the century. The decline might be averted if fertility rates were to increase from 1.8 to two children per woman, and if net immigration rose from 95,000 to 145,000 a year.

"In theory, given appropriate levels of fertility or migration, population size could stabilise in the second half of the century, but only at a somewhat higher level than today," Mr Shaw said.

Conception figures for England and Wales in 1999 showed a 3% drop in pregnancies for women of all ages, but a bigger fall for teenagers. The conception rate for the under-18s declined by 4% to 46.5 per 1,000 and for under-16s it was down 7% to 8.3 per 1,000.

Teenage conception rates fell in the early 1990s but rose after a health scare about contraceptive pills in 1995.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, said: "These figures are encouraging and suggest that we may be starting to see a reduction in teenage pregnancies.

"However, teenage pregnancies remain far too high. That is why we have begun a nationwide strategy to tackle teenage pregnancies and why we are introducing measures this year to bring teenage pregnancy rates down."

Jan Barlow, chief executive of Brook advisory service, said: "These figures show how important positive steps at a local level can be in tackling the problem. However, much more still needs to be done to equip young people with the skills they need to protect themselves from sexually transmitted infections and unplanned pregnancy."

webTitle: Judges stress freed man was innocent

fields.headline: Judges stress freed man was innocent
fields.standfirst: 'Reprehensible' police treatment of murder suspect
fields.trailText: 'Reprehensible' police treatment of murder suspect.
fields.body:
Three appeal judges yesterday took the unusual step of stressing that a man released after serving 17 years for a double murder was totally innocent, and had not been freed on just a technicality.

Peter Fell, 39, spent nearly all his adult life behind bars after confessing to the murder of two women who were walking their dogs. The judges branded as "reprehensible" Hampshire police's denial of a solicitor to Mr Fell, who was held incommunicado by detectives for 54 hours, during which time he made a confession that has been found to be unsafe.

"We believe that he was innocent of these terrible murders, and he should be entitled to have us say so," said Lord Justice Waller, sitting with Mr Justice Garland and Mr Justice Sachs.

Mr Fell, who was freed on bail last December pending the hearing of his fresh appeal, had his convictions quashed earlier this month.

The former Bournemouth hospital porter was jailed for life in August 1984 for murdering Ann Lee, 44, wife of a retired army major, and Margaret "Peggy" Johnson, 65, wife of a banking director.

They were repeatedly stabbed at Aldershot Common, Hampshire, in May 1982.

Defence lawyers had told the appeal judges that Mr Fell was a victim of "oppressive" police interrogation during which he was denied access to a solicitor.

Psychiatric evidence showed he was vulnerable to suggestion and a "serial confessor", they argued.

Mr Fell had phoned police while he was drunk and depressed, and named himself as the killer. A month later he was arrested and detained for three days. Eventually he admitted hitting the women with his fists. Once the police had his admission to making the calls, the pressure on him gradually built up until it became overwhelming.

"The length of the interviews, the non-communication for 54 hours other than with the police, the lack of food and the method in interrogation all contributed," said Lord Justice Waller. "Constantly he asked for a solicitor, and constantly that request was ignored. He asked for a doctor and that too was ignored.

"Finally, under the impression he may have gained that time was running out and that he was bound to be charged with something, it seems he sought the compromise of seeking to admit to manslaughter, not murder."

Yet, when he did so the account he gave was inaccurate in many respects. The judges said the decision of the police not to allow Fell access to a solicitor was "reprehensible". Lord Justice Waller added: "They allowed their quest for a conviction to override their responsibilities to an accused, and particularly to a vulnerable accused. If that fundamental right had not been denied, a false confession would not have been made."

After the judgment Mr Fell said: "I am relieved and happy. It's nice to know their reasons were not just technical but that the convictions were quashed because I am innocent.

"The police will now have to reopen the murder inquiry. They have no alternative."

Hampshire police refused to say whether they would reopen the murder investigation or issue an apology to Mr Fell, who is waiting for news of compensation.
