webTitle: Priest prays as Hanratty's remains exhumed

fields.headline: Priest prays as Hanratty's remains exhumed
fields.trailText: The sounds of a priest intoning prayers for the dead drifted across a windswept Hertfordshire graveyard early yesterday morning as police exhumed the remains of James Hanratty in an attempt to resolve Britain's longest-running case of alleged miscarriage of justice.
fields.body:
The sounds of a priest intoning prayers for the dead drifted across a windswept Hertfordshire graveyard early yesterday morning as police exhumed the remains of James Hanratty in an attempt to resolve Britain's longest-running case of alleged miscarriage of justice.

Cemetery workers using mechanical lifting equipment joined about 20 police and forensic experts, a Home Office pathologist, and a priest to oversee the opening of Hanratty's waterlogged grave at Carpenders Park cemetery near Bushey. His remains were taken to a nearby mortuary for DNA sampling before being reburied at a private service. The remains of his aunt, Annie Cunningham, who was buried above him, were also removed and reinterred.

Police said some members of Hanratty's family were present at the exhumation, which was shielded from waiting photographers by a white tent.

Detectives hope to use the genetic evidence obtained to prove that the 25-year-old was indeed guilty of the murder of Michael Gregsten, 36, a scientist, and the rape of his 22-year-old girlfriend, Valerie Storie, on the A6 at Deadman's Hill near Bedford. Hanratty was hanged in 1962.

The case attracted many campaigners, who believed Hanratty's claim that he had been staying in a guest house in Rhyl, north Wales, at the time of the murder. The landlady corroborated his version of events, and supporters say numerous witnesses have since confirmed it. They argue that Hanratty was merely a petty criminal.

DNA tests last July on fluid samples that had been kept in Home Office vaults revealed a one-in-a-billion chance that he was innocent, but his family argue they may have been contaminated.

They said they were distressed by yesterday's operation, expressing through their solicitor the view that it was "a pointless exercise", but did not formally oppose it.

The case was referred back to the court of appeal after the criminal cases review commission considered claims that police had suppressed essential evidence.

The appeal may be heard in September.

webTitle: Poets big winners in £21m boost for arts funding

fields.headline: Poets big winners in £21m boost for arts funding
fields.trailText: Hundreds of arts organisations were last night celebrating their biggest boost in funding for nearly 20 years.
fields.body:
Hundreds of arts organisations were last night celebrating their biggest boost in funding for nearly 20 years.

Literature, for long the Cinderella of the subsidised sector, was the biggest winner from the extra £21m shareout announced yesterday by the Arts Council, with core funding increased by 75%.

A large chunk of that will go to the most impoverished writers of all - poets - through the Poetry Society, the Poetry Book Society and the Arvon Foundation.

The still more impecunious world of performance poetry was given a lift with a fivefold rise so the Apples and Snakes group could expand its "slams" (performances) nationally.

The visual arts also did well with grants up by nearly a third, while dance stands to gain an extra 17 % from 2002.

More significantly, 50 organisations, led by the Centre for Children's Books and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, whom the Arts Council admitted had previously had a "hand to mouth existence", were also given the security of guaranteed three year funding.

The extra money, which follows £25m to help revive battered producing theatres and a further £40m for the arts-in-education Creative Partnerships scheme, comes as the culture secretary, Chris Smith, floated the idea of more money to help individual artists by reviving state commissioning. Mr Smith believes that money should be set aside to help the "lost generation" of young artists who missed out on money to develop their talent through the barren Conservative years of the early 1990s when subsidy was slashed and bureaucracy stifled experiment.

Mr Smith said he would like to see these young and not-so-young artists, writers and directors given medium term bursaries or fellowships and being "allowed to get on and do what they do best".

He also wants to revive the tradition of greater state commissioning of the type which the Arts Council pioneered in its early years after the second world war.

Peter Hewitt, Arts Council chief executive, described the funding round as "the best for the arts in many, many years".

Of the big national institutions, the Royal Shakespeare Company did best, with its budget increased by a quarter from next year, while the National Theatre got a much more modest 7.6 % rise.

However, Mr Hewitt denied they were punishing the National, which has come in for sustained criticism during the early years of Trevor Nunn's term as artistic director.

There were similar large-scale rises across the regional arts boards.

However, there were also a few losers, led by the London International Festival of Mime and the Visions theatre festival in Brighton, which will not be receiving any extra funding.

webTitle: Government more concerned with conformity than poverty

fields.headline: Government more concerned with conformity than poverty
fields.standfirst: The SEU's approach is more about the pursuit of moral conformity and social order than ending poverty, writes Ruth Levitas
fields.trailText: The SEU's approach is more about the pursuit of moral conformity and social order than ending poverty, writes Ruth Levitas.
fields.body:
The latest report from the Social Exclusion Unit (SEU) seeks to demonstrate the success of the unit, and of the government, in tackling social exclusion. The report, Preventing Social Exclusion, deluges the reader with miscellaneous unexplained statistics, breathless celebration of endless government initiatives and vignettes of hapless individuals whose lives have been transformed by Blairite projects.

Among the incoherent battery of figures and policies flung into the report are two paragraphs on healthy eating. There is now a national school fruit scheme. And 135,000 people in deprived areas have been sent a leaflet telling them to eat five helpings of fruit and vegetables a day.

The problem is that no one is quite sure what social exclusion is, still less how to measure it. The SEU calls it a "shorthand term for what can happen when people or areas suffer from a combination of linked problems such as unemployment, poor skills, low incomes, poor housing, high crime, bad health and family breakdown". But this is a "deliberately flexible definition". These are "only examples" and "others could be added".

Social exclusion is clearly a complex problem, and no single indicator will suffice. But some judgment must be made about which are most important.

Social exclusion used to be understood as an inability to participate in common social activities, chiefly as a result of poverty. It followed that its eradication meant the elimination of poverty and the reduction of inequality through a policy of redistribution. The programme on which the Blair government was elected rejected this view, and interpreted social exclusion primarily as non-participation in paid work. The new deals, especially those for lone parents and for disabled people, present work both as the only proper route out of poverty and as an intrinsic good.

The approach of the SEU itself is more directly about the pursuit of moral conformity and social order, presented as help. Its targets are rough sleepers, truants, pregnant teenagers (including 18- and 19-year-olds, who are legal adults) and deprived estates. The coercive elements in its policies are either glossed over or celebrated in this new report.

Truancy rates have not, it seems, come down, despite the increased powers to punish parents which were enshrined in the Crime and Disorder Act. But, we are triumphantly told, what does work is encouraging the police to conduct "truancy sweeps" to return children to school.

Those who fail to fall in line with the dominant morality are stigmatised. Young motherhood is now so socially unacceptable that "a preference for being a young mother" is cited as a risk factor. Peer education is directed at eradicating this preference. Young women are not allowed to be full-time mothers. Those who cannot live with their parents or partners will be compelled to live in "supported housing" and to return to education, training or employment - and thus to social inclusion.

Government strategy to tackle and measure social exclusion veers wildly between the three approaches. Poverty is now recognised as an issue, but is not given sufficient priority. The SEU itself identified poverty as a major risk factor of teenage pregnancy, but did not suggest that an anti-poverty strategy might be part of the solution.

And while the problems of truancy and teenage pregnancy may be real, in numerical terms they are small. Poverty is both a much wider problem, and a primary cause of social exclusion. The recent report on Poverty and Social Exclusion in Britain published by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation showed that, at the end of 1999, 26% of the population, or 14.5m people, were poor. Almost 7.5m were too poor to be able to engage in such common social activities as visiting friends and family, attending weddings and funerals, and having modest celebrations on special occasions.

What we need is a radical reduction in inequality, a clear commitment to redistribution, and up-to-date figures on the government's record on these. Oddly enough, they don't seem to be here.

 Ruth Levitas is a reader in sociology at the University of Bristol. She is author of The Inclusive Society? Social Exclusion and New Labour (1998).

webTitle: Comment: Quebec City protesters are controlled by exclusion

fields.headline: They call us violent agitators
fields.standfirst:
The global free traders want to make protest seem dangerous

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: "I'm worried that free trade is leading to the privatisation of education," an elementary school teacher in Ottawa tells me. "I want to go to the protests in Quebec City, but is it going to be safe?"
fields.body:
"I'm worried that free trade is leading to the privatisation of education," an elementary school teacher in Ottawa tells me. "I want to go to the protests in Quebec City, but is it going to be safe?"

"I think free trade agreements have increased the divide between rich and poor," a young mother in Toronto tells me, "but if I go to Quebec, will my son get pepper sprayed?"

"I want to go to Quebec City," a Harvard undergraduate in the anti-sweatshop movement says, "but I heard no one is getting across the border."

"We're not even bothering to go," a student in Mexico says. "We can't afford to get arrested in a foreign country."

If you think that the next big crackdown on political protest is going to take place when 5,000 police officers clash with activists outside the Summit of the Americas in Quebec City next month, you are mistaken. The real crackdown is already taking place. It is happening silently, with no fanfare, every time another would-be protester decides not to publicly express his or her views about the largest free trade zone in the world: the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA).

It turns out that the most effective form of crowd control isn't pepper spray, water cannons, teargas, or any of the other weapons being readied by Quebec police in anticipation of the arrival of 34 heads of state. The most cutting-edge form of crowd control is controlling the crowds before they converge: this is state-of-the-art protest deterrence - the silencing you do yourself. It happens every time we read another story about how Quebec will be surrounded by a three-meter high fence. Or about how there's nowhere to sleep in the city except the prisons, which have been helpfully cleared out.

A month before the summit, Quebec City has been successfully transformed into a menacing place, inhospitable to people with concerns about corporate-driven trade and economic deregulation. Protesting, rather than being a healthy part of democracy, seems like an extreme and dangerous sport, suitable only for hard-core activists, with bizarre accessories and doctoral degrees in rock climbing.

More protest deterrence takes place when we accept the stories in the papers, filled with anonymous sources and unattributed statements, about how some of these activists are actually "agitators" who are "planning to use violence", packing bricks and explosives. The only proof provided for such inflammatory allegations is that "anarchists" are organising into "small groups" and these groups are "autonomous" (meaning that they don't tell each other what to do).

The truth is this: not a single one of the official groups organising protests is planning violent action. A couple of the more radical organisations, including the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, have said they respect "a diversity of tactics" ranging from popular education to direct action. They have said they will not, on principle, condemn other activists for their tactics. This admittedly complicated position has been distorted in the press as tantamount to planning violent attacks on the summit - which it most certainly is not. The position has also been a source of frustration for many activists who argue that it would be infinitely easier if everyone just signed a statement saying the protests will be non-violent.

The problem is that one of the fundamental arguments against the FTAA's Darwinian economic model is that it increases violence: violence within poor communities and police violence against the poor. In a speech deliv ered last year, Pierre Pettigrew, Canada's minister of international trade, helps explain why. In the new economy, he said, "the victims are not only exploited, they're excluded. You may be in a situation where you are not needed to create that wealth. This phenomenon of exclusion is far more radical than the phenomenon of exploitation."

Indeed it is. Which is why a society that blithely accepts this included/excluded ledger is an unsafe society. It is filled with people who have little faith in the system, who feel they have nothing to gain from the promises of prosperity coming out of gatherings like the Summit of the Americas, who see the police only as a force of repression. If this isn't the kind of society we want - one of included and excluded, and ever higher walls dividing the two - then the answer is not for "good" activists to pre-emptively condemn "bad" activists. The answer is to reject the politics of division wholesale. And the best place to do it is in Quebec City, where the usually invisible wall of exclusion has been made starkly visible, with a brand new, chain-link fence and crowd control methods that aim to keep us out before we even get there.

fields.bodyText: "I'm worried that free trade is leading to the privatisation of education," an elementary school teacher in Ottawa tells me. "I want to go to the protests in Quebec City, but is it going to be safe?" "I think free trade agreements have increased the divide between rich and poor," a young mother in Toronto tells me, "but if I go to Quebec, will my son get pepper sprayed?" "I want to go to Quebec City," a Harvard undergraduate in the anti-sweatshop movement says, "but I heard no one is getting across the border." "We're not even bothering to go," a student in Mexico says. "We can't afford to get arrested in a foreign country." If you think that the next big crackdown on political protest is going to take place when 5,000 police officers clash with activists outside the Summit of the Americas in Quebec City next month, you are mistaken. The real crackdown is already taking place. It is happening silently, with no fanfare, every time another would-be protester decides not to publicly express his or her views about the largest free trade zone in the world: the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA). It turns out that the most effective form of crowd control isn't pepper spray, water cannons, teargas, or any of the other weapons being readied by Quebec police in anticipation of the arrival of 34 heads of state. The most cutting-edge form of crowd control is controlling the crowds before they converge: this is state-of-the-art protest deterrence - the silencing you do yourself. It happens every time we read another story about how Quebec will be surrounded by a three-meter high fence. Or about how there's nowhere to sleep in the city except the prisons, which have been helpfully cleared out. A month before the summit, Quebec City has been successfully transformed into a menacing place, inhospitable to people with concerns about corporate-driven trade and economic deregulation. Protesting, rather than being a healthy part of democracy, seems like an extreme and dangerous sport, suitable only for hard-core activists, with bizarre accessories and doctoral degrees in rock climbing. More protest deterrence takes place when we accept the stories in the papers, filled with anonymous sources and unattributed statements, about how some of these activists are actually "agitators" who are "planning to use violence", packing bricks and explosives. The only proof provided for such inflammatory allegations is that "anarchists" are organising into "small groups" and these groups are "autonomous" (meaning that they don't tell each other what to do). The truth is this: not a single one of the official groups organising protests is planning violent action. A couple of the more radical organisations, including the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, have said they respect "a diversity of tactics" ranging from popular education to direct action. They have said they will not, on principle, condemn other activists for their tactics. This admittedly complicated position has been distorted in the press as tantamount to planning violent attacks on the summit - which it most certainly is not. The position has also been a source of frustration for many activists who argue that it would be infinitely easier if everyone just signed a statement saying the protests will be non-violent. The problem is that one of the fundamental arguments against the FTAA's Darwinian economic model is that it increases violence: violence within poor communities and police violence against the poor. In a speech deliv ered last year, Pierre Pettigrew, Canada's minister of international trade, helps explain why. In the new economy, he said, "the victims are not only exploited, they're excluded. You may be in a situation where you are not needed to create that wealth. This phenomenon of exclusion is far more radical than the phenomenon of exploitation." Indeed it is. Which is why a society that blithely accepts this included/excluded ledger is an unsafe society. It is filled with people who have little faith in the system, who feel they have nothing to gain from the promises of prosperity coming out of gatherings like the Summit of the Americas, who see the police only as a force of repression. If this isn't the kind of society we want - one of included and excluded, and ever higher walls dividing the two - then the answer is not for "good" activists to pre-emptively condemn "bad" activists. The answer is to reject the politics of division wholesale. fields.headline: Ten Glosses
fields.standfirst: New verse by Seamus Heaney
fields.trailText:
Ten Glosses

1 The Marching Season
'What bloody man is that?' 'A drum, a drum!'
Prepossessed by what I know by heart,
I wait for Banquo and Macbeth to come
Unbowed, on cue, and scripted from the start.

2 The Catechism
Q. and A. come back. They 'formed my mind'.
'Who is my neighbour?' 'My neighbour is all mankind'.

3 The Bridge
Steady under the strain and strong through tension,
Its feet on both sides but in neither camp,
It stands its ground, a span of pure attention,
A holding action, the arches and the ramp
Steady under strain and strong through tension.

4 A Suit
'I'll make you one,' he said, 'and balance it
Perfectly on you.' So I could almost feel
The plumbline of the creased tweed hit my heel,

Ten Glosses

1 The Marching Season
'What bloody man is that?' 'A drum, a drum!'
Prepossessed by what I know by heart,
I wait for Banquo and Macbeth to come
Unbowed, on cue, and scripted from the start.

2 The Catechism
Q. and A. come back. They 'formed my mind'.
'Who is my neighbour?' 'My neighbour is all mankind'.

3 The Bridge
Steady under the strain and strong through tension,
Its feet on both sides but in neither camp,
It stands its ground, a span of pure attention,
A holding action, the arches and the ramp
Steady under strain and strong through tension.

4 A Suit
'I'll make you one,' he said, 'and balance it
Perfectly on you.' So I could almost feel
The plumbline of the creased tweed hit my heel,

My shoulders like a spar or arms of a scale
Under the jacket, my whole shape realigned
In ways that suited me down to the ground.

So although a suit was the last thing that I needed
I weighed his words and wore them and decided
There and then it was going for a song.

5 The Party
Overheard at the party, like wet snow
That slumps down off a roof, the unexpected,
Softly powerful name of Wilfred Owen.
Mud in your eye. Artillery in heaven.

6 W.H. Auden, 1907-73
After Oxford and Iceland and Spain and Berlin and Freud,
After Marx and the Thirties, it was New York and Chester and God.
A pause for po-ethics. The moral ascent of Parnassus.
Then retrenchment, libretti, martinis, the slippers, the face.
Conceived in the Danelaw, a language shift and a ruction,
He was barker of stanzas, a star turn, a source of instruction,
And the definite growth rings of genius rang in his voice.

7 The Lesson
According to Hammond, who heard it out on a spree
From a man who had known the priest who was chaplain on duty
The morning the last man was hanged in Crumlin Road Jail,
What the man said as he shook hands and went to the hangman
Was, 'Father, this is going to be a lesson to me.'

8 Moling's Gloss
(from the Irish)

Among my elders, I know better
And frown on any carry-on;
Among the brat-pack on the batter
I'm taken for a younger man.

9 Colly
Niamh's horse for Oisin was grand, but saddle me colly,
Giddy on wind and black as the hair on King Billy,
Chimney flakes flecking the air, carbon-dotting the white
Wash on the line, a fly-past, a freak-out of soot.

10 A Norman Simile
To be marvellously yourself like the river water
Gerald of Wales says runs in Arklow harbour
Even at high tide when you'd expect salt water.

 From Electric Light by Seamus Heaney. Published next month by Faber and Faber, price £8.99.

fields.headline: Seeing the Sick
fields.standfirst: New verse by Seamus Heaney
fields.trailText:
Anointed and all, my father did remind me
Of Hopkins's Felix Randal.
And then he grew
(As he would have said himself) 'wee in his clothes' -
Spectral, a relict -
And seemed to have grown so
Because of something spectral he'd thrown off,
The unbelonging, moorland part of him
That was Northumbrian, the bounden he
Who had walked the streets of Hexham at eighteen
With his stick and task of bringing home the dead
Body of his uncle by cattle-ferry.

Anointed and all, my father did remind me
Of Hopkins's Felix Randal.
And then he grew
(As he would have said himself) 'wee in his clothes' -
Spectral, a relict -
And seemed to have grown so
Because of something spectral he'd thrown off,
The unbelonging, moorland part of him
That was Northumbrian, the bounden he
Who had walked the streets of Hexham at eighteen
With his stick and task of bringing home the dead
Body of his uncle by cattle-ferry.

Ghost-drover from the start. Brandisher of keel.

None of your fettled and bright battering sandal.

Cowdung coloured tweed and ox-blood leather.

*

The assessor's eye, the tally-keeper's head
For what beasts were on what land in what year
But then that went as well. And all precaution.
His smile a summer half-door opening out
And opening in. A reprieving light.
For which the tendered morphine had our thanks.

 From Electric Light by Seamus Heaney. Published next month by Faber and Faber, price £8.99.

fields.headline: Goram leads the deadline deals
fields.trailText: With purse strings tight while doubts linger over the future of the transfer system, the transfer deadline was more about quantity than quality as managers, haunted by the threat of relegation, looked to bolster their squads with cut-price additions.
fields.body:
With purse strings tight while doubts linger over the future of the transfer system, the transfer deadline was more about quantity than quality as managers, haunted by the threat of relegation, looked to bolster their squads with cut-price additions.

The former Scotland and Rangers goalkeeper Andy Goram admitted to being "shell-shocked" after completing his move from Motherwell to Manchester United as cover for Fabien Barthez and Raimond van der Gouw. The 36-year-old, who was born in Bury, has signed a three-month loan deal worth £100,000. Also leaving Fir Park was the former Sunderland and Wolves striker Don Goodman, who joined Walsall on a free transfer.

The Danish striker David Nielsen, who scored six goals in 19 games during a loan spell with Grimsby this season, has signed for the First Division's Wimbledon from FC Copenhagen for £300,000. Guy Whittingham has joined the FA Cup semi-finalists Wycombe Wanderers on a free transfer from Portsmouth, and Sheffield United have taken Manchester City's talismanic defender Andy Morrison on loan.

The former England international Tony Cottee, who resigned as player-manager of Barnet last week, has joined Millwall on a free transfer; the Lions become his fourth different club and division this season. The Canadian internationals Jim Brennan and Paul Peschisolido have joined Huddersfield and Norwich on loan from Nottingham Forest and Fulham respectively.

Carlisle United's Richard Prokas, whose crunching tackle on Arsenal's Patrick Vieira in January's third-round FA Cup tie caused nationwide controversy, has moved to the Second Division's Cambridge United. Steve Morrow, who scored the winning goal and then broke his arm in the post-match celebrations after Arsenal's League Cup win in 1994, has left Queens Park Rangers to join Peterborough on loan.

Northampton's Steve Howard has joined Luton at the foot of the Second Division for £50,000, but missed the noon deadline to be eligible for this evening's game against Brentford by three minutes.

The Hull manager Brian Little has boosted his side's play-off chances by signing Rob Matthews from Stockport County and the former Blackburn midfielder Mark Atkins, a member of the Rovers side that won the Premiership in 1995, on loan from Doncaster.

fields.headline: Jinxed Gerrard is England doubt
fields.trailText: Steven Gerrard's England career is in danger of being put on hold yet again. The Liverpool midfielder woke up yesterday with a stiff back and is a doubt for tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield, his home ground.
fields.body:
Steven Gerrard's England career is in danger of being put on hold yet again. The Liverpool midfielder woke up yesterday with a stiff back and is a doubt for tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against Finland at Anfield, his home ground.

The 20-year-old may be the most exciting midfield prospect the country has seen since Bryan Robson but already he is proving an even bigger liability injurywise than Captain Marvel ever was. Back, groin and thigh problems have so far forced him to withdraw from nine England squads.

He may be able to play against Finland but yesterday's reminder of his fragile fitness almost certainly means that Sven-Goran Eriksson, the England coach, cannot realistically think about playing him both in this game and the qualifier in Albania four days later.

The Liverpool man himself recognised the risk he was running by coming off the bench soon after half-time in Sunday's Premiership match against Derby County three days after an impressive Uefa Cup performance to help his club beat Porto.

He admitted that had he played two full games in four days he probably would not have recovered in time to face the Finns.

The England medical staff hope the hot bath and massage he had yesterday morning, which allowed him to do some light jogging, has eased his back sufficiently to prevent further crises. All the same Manchester United's Nicky Butt now seems even more likely to play in Tirana.

The news about David Seaman, another back sufferer, was better. The Arsenal goalkeeper came through a full practice session with no problems and will almost certainly return to the side. There are, however, slight doubts about Sol Campbell's fitness.

In the meantime the England captain of a match and a half has been at pains to assure the nation that despite doubts about his form, his fame and his future, life could not be better. "I'm happier at present than I've ever been," David Beckham piped yesterday. "I enjoy my life and I enjoy my football. "Playing is what matters to me; I've learned to let everything else go over my head. Whatever anyone says about me I'm a footballer and I enjoy that more than anything. After all, it is football that has made me what I am."

Yet just what Beckham is, in football terms, will remain a matter for debate. In recent Champions League matches there have been signs of opposing defenders realising that if they force him back towards halfway the excellence of his crosses and crossfield passes will be less of a threat.

Beckham recognises this but feels he can deal with it. "Sometimes I have two defenders marking me," he explained, "and the reason I go so far back is that I want to get the ball. Players are marking me so high up the field that I have to find different positions to gain possession."

At the same time, he concedes that his form has dipped. "Maybe I haven't been playing as well as I can. I've realised that if you set high standards and drop below them by 5% a lot will be made of it."

Which is true enough. When Sir Alex Ferguson rested him for Manchester United's last week's Champions League match against Sturm Graz and the league game with Leicester City, serious doubts were raised about his being in the England team, let alone leading it.

Beckham is confident that his enforced break has left him fresh to resume his international duties. "The manager probably didn't realise it but he was doing me a favour," he said. "I've relaxed for several days and am now feeling in better physical shape than I've done for a couple of months. I probably needed the break."

Tomorrow will be Beckham's biggest test as England captain, and listening to his thin Leytonstone lilt it would be easy to compare his role to the idea of Private Pike leading Captain Mainwaring's men on manoeuvres. But he has an inner toughness which has taught him to cope with the abuse he regularly receives from the Kop at Anfield and which even now threatens to mar his first competitive game for England as captain, especially if his wife Victoria gets her share.

"When my wife is watching there is always the concern that she will get into and out of the ground without any problems," he admitted. "I hope that when I lead England out of the tunnel at Anfield the Kop will be getting behind the whole team."

In all probability the Kop will, but when Manchester United are there the following weekend Beckham can expect a more familiar welcome. Always assuming, of course, that Ferguson picks him.

webTitle: Next and Selfridges show how retail can do it right

fields.headline: Next and Selfridges show how retail can do it right
fields.trailText: Two of Britain's top retail names yesterday reported profits and buoyant trading, bucking the market trend and sending their share prices to record highs.
fields.body:
Two of Britain's top retail names yesterday reported profits and buoyant trading, bucking the market trend and sending their share prices to record highs.

As the FTSE 100 registered its second-biggest points fall in history, shares in Next rose nearly 12%, closing up 97p at 920.5p, while Selfridges shares, which have risen by more than 50% in the past year, closed up 4.5% at 351p.

The two span middle and upmarket shoppers, and their success in a highly competitive market is likely to show just how poorly Marks & Spencer is performing when it provides a trading update early next month.

M&S has already admitted that its Autograph range of designer clothes - an attempt to win back shoppers now taking their custom to Selfridges, is missing sales targets. There is mounting speculation that its entire womenswear range has flopped this year. Some analysts believe sales could be down 15%.

Next's shares took off as the group, which now has 336 stores, reported full-year profits of £217.1m, up from £195.6m a year ago. The result was at the top end of analysts' expectations but the real boost was provided by new trading figures which showed like-for-like sales up 11% in the first seven weeks of the new financial year. Orders placed through mail order were up 17% on last year.

The boost comes only two months after Next warned that its Christmas sales had fallen short of expectations. But chief executive David Jones warned that second-quarter comparisons would be more demanding. He described the recent figures as "wind-assisted".

Selfridges' profits climbed nearly 40% to £38.6m in the year to the beginning of February and it has seen underlying sales climb by 11% in the first weeks of its new year.

"People are trading up," said finance director Peter Williams. "Consumers have wardrobes full of clothes, but they will still spend a bit more money on things that catch their eye." Sales of perfumery, womenswear and menswear all rose 7% last year.

The store is now reaping the rewards of its £100m makeover and its strategy of concentrating on top brands, Its Manchester store has current like-for-like sales up 34% on last year. "It proves the rationale for taking Selfridges outside London," said Mr Williams. A store in central Birmingham is due to open in 2003 and the group is looking for 200,000sq ft sites in Glasgow, Newcastle and the south-west.

The group plans a development at the back of its Oxford Street store, with a further 100,000sq ft of retail space plus offices, a hotel and leisure facilities. However, ambitions to build a Selfridges Tower to rival Centrepoint seem to have been thwarted. After talks with English Heritage and Westminster council, it says the scheme will be more "in keeping with the urban landscape".

fields.headline: Out comes the Cavallo knife
fields.standfirst: Millions were left jobless when 'Super-Mingo' last held office in Argentina. Now he's back. The job? To save a continent
fields.trailText: Millions were left jobless when 'Super-Mingo' last held office in Argentina. Now he's back. The job? To save a continent.
fields.byline: Mark Milner, Larry Elliott, Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro and  Uki Goni  in Buenos Aires
fields.body:
One hundred kilometre winds blew four-metre waves from the River Plate across the coastal embankment and brought a taste of an early southern winter to Buenos Aires this week.

To the millions left jobless by Domingo Cavallo's free-market economic programme during the 1990s, the return of "Super-Mingo" to the economy ministry was as ominous as the flash floods that the surprise storm caused in many parts of the city. He arrived back at the helm as Argentina, long the wealthiest nation in Latin America, felt the pressure of a deepening political, social, and economic crisis.

Strikes left its majestic capital, Buenos Aires, without buses and other public services, schools were closed and thousands of protesters filled the Plaza de Mayo in front of President Fernando De La Rua's governmental palace. A bomb exploded at the premises of a political party led by Mr Cavallo, appointed on Tuesday as Argentina's third economy minister in as many weeks - a man seen by Wall Street as a white knight but by much of the population as promising more hardship.

The new Thailand

"We don't see the slightest chance that Cavallo's policies will bring relief to those who really need it," Hugo Moyano said at a gathering of his powerful CGT labour federation. "But we do know that Cavallo's first measure was to confirm De la Rua as president," the trade union boss quipped.

Yet a lot is now riding on Mr Cavallo, and not just in Argentina. The fear is that the country could become the new Thailand, where the rush to the exit by international investors in the summer of 1997 precipitated the financial crisis across south-east Asia and beyond in 1997 and 1998. The Economist Intelligence Unit yesterday warned of a possible downgrade to its rating for Argentina, and with global stock markets in the middle of a prolonged nose dive and the world's biggest economy, the United States, standing on the brink of recession, the risk is that a collapse in Argentina could prove contagious.

Latin American finance ministers have already expressed concern that the crisis in Latin America's second-biggest economy could scare investors and push up their borrowing costs. "It affects the credit ratings of the whole region," Peru's economy minister, Javier Silva Ruete, said at the close of this week's Inter-American Development Bank annual meeting. "With Cavallo's experience, we trust he will be able to take adequate action to overcome Argentina's problems and avert contagion to our countries."

Not everybody is so confident. Gerard Lyons, chief economist at Standard Chartered Bank, is compiling a league table of those countries' crash resistance. "Argentina is currently in bottom position, he said. "Contagion is a real concern."

Argentina is by no means a carbon copy of Thailand or Indonesia in 1997. There, the problem was an excess of liquidity. Banks borrowed massively in dollars but lent in local currency, relying on the Thai baht maintaining its peg against the greenback. The Argentinian peso is also pegged against the dollar, but at a one-for-one exchange rate which has kept the economy deep in the doldrums for years.

As such, it is not just a case of the new finance minister announcing a package of austerity measures to choke off excess demand and put the economy back on the straight and narrow. Argentina has been in recession for nigh on three years. At 10%, real interest rates are crippling, unemployment is running at around 15%, prices are falling in the shops, living standards are declining. All this at a time when the rest of the world has been growing steadily.

Yet Mr Cavallo's first act will not be to announce a Keynesian reflation programme involving cheaper money and increases in spending. Instead, he will have to try to ram a $3bn package of cuts through parliament. Why? Because Argentina has been the beneficiary of a massive support package from the International Monetary Fund, and the only way to keep the men from Washington on side is to stick to the tight exchange rate regime. Abandoning the dollar peg would make it far more expensive to finance Argentina's debt, and raise fears of a relapse into the years of hyper-inflation, which Mr Cavallo brought to an end in the first half of the 1990s.

Argentina, in other words, is caught in the same dilemma as Britain was in 1992, when the weakness of the real economy was crying out for lower interest rates and a devaluation of sterling, but the government's commitment to the exchange rate mechanism deprived it of the flexibility it needed.

So what happens now? The problem is that the economic crisis has sparked a political one. Attempts by Mr Cavallo's predecessor, Ricardo López Murphy, to address the country's economic difficulties split the ruling coalition, and few politicians seem to have the appetite for the unpopularity that forcing through yet more austerity will almost certainly bring. The opposition Peronists have already rejected calls for a national government, and unrest has spilled on to the streets.

As the thousands of workers protesting against the government flooded the Plaza de Mayo and marched through the country's other main cities, blocking avenues and attacking public buildings, university students in Buenos Aires brought their desks and benches out of the lecture halls and held class on the city's main avenues, creating traffic chaos throughout the week.

"He's not going to last," said 46-year-old architect Mariano Gómez, "one man alone is not enough to fix this situation."

Businesswoman Cora Iriart, walking past a group of students holding class on the wide avenue in front of the city's law faculty, agreed. "Can Cavallo pull off this miracle? I don't think so. He's a face from the past."

If the social upheaval were not traumatic enough, more than 20 cases of foot-and-mouth disease were this week confirmed in the worst outbreak since the cattle-exporting country was declared free of the highly contagious virus. The country of 36m people that is almost the size of India has also been hit by a high-profile money-laundering scandal.

Yet, for all the difficulties, Mr Cavallo is seen as the one man with a chance of pulling off what would be little short of a miracle. His handling of the economy in the early 90s won him admirers at home and among the international investment community. What he would like to do is tough it out, hoping that a show of strength will keep the IMF and its $40 bn of support on board.

Risk categories

If that proves impossible, if he is unable to forge the political consensus necessary to get his painful measures through parliament, he has only three options: devaluation, dollarisation or default. None appeals. Devaluation might allow the domestic economy some breathing space but would make paying Argentina's debt more expensive and wreck Mr Cavallo's own credibility. Dollarisation would tie Argentina's policy to that of the US at a time when the Americans are struggling to keep their own house in order. In the last resort, default is preferable to a prolonged economic slump but it would blow the country's credit rating out of the water and scare off foreign investors.

It could also prompt holders of emerging market debt to rush for the exit. When panic sets in, lenders are often inclined to lump countries into risk categories rather than consider them on an individual basis. If Argentina goes, Brazil - where interest rates were raised to defend the real yesterday - will be next in the spotlight, even though the country has recovered impressively from its own financial crisis in early 1999.

According to Mr Lyons, the likes of Indonesia and South Africa would feel a chill wind, too. "At the moment, Argentina is rooted to the bottom of my league table," he said. "But there are other strugglers."

fields.headline: Paul McCartney
fields.standfirst:
Everyman Theatre, Liverpool
**
fields.trailText:
Everyman Theatre, Liverpool
**
fields.body:
Billed as an evening with playwright Willy Russell and friends, this event deteriorated into a media circus for the launch of Paul McCartney's new career as a poet. McCartney, it was announced, would fill the last spot in the event (ostensibly a tribute to Adrian Henri, the poet and painter who died in December), following contributions from the acerbic Newcastle poet Tom Pickard and the equally left-wing Adrian Mitchell.

Pickard treated the eager, star-struck audience to a rambling, incoherent performance. A few dour pieces about shipyards gave way to a graphic eulogy to fornication from his Fuckwind tome.

Mitchell regaled them with tales of his poetic adventures, recited with humour and passion, before conceding defeat and with a cheerful shrug announcing his protege.

Dressed in black, McCartney sauntered to the rostrum, fresh-faced as a cheeky choirboy, to read a handful of poems from his Blackbird Singing collection, published earlier this month. He began with a look at his Liverpool childhood, then became intense as he explained the background to the next poem, Jerk of Jerks, inspired by John Lennon's murderer. The same mood was adopted as he talked about coming to terms with Linda's death and how the introspection of poetry had helped. None really struck a chord.

On he trawled, reciting some pieces written as poems, others merely the lyrics of Beatles songs, such as Maxwell's Silver Hammer, which, despite the reverence in which they are held, are not the stuff of elegy or resonance on the page.

The finale, when all four "poets" recited from Henri's paean to love, Without You, only stressed the paucity of McCartney's grasp of the genre.

fields.headline: Badmarsh and Shri
fields.standfirst:
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.trailText:
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.body:
Badmarsh and Shri's mix-up of hip-hop, dancehall, funk and classical Indian styles may be one of the best-kept secrets on the (Asian) underground, but the venue is packed . Shri, a prematurely grey 33 year old from Bombay, is the focus of attention, displaying his skills on a variety of instruments, from bass to tablas to flute. Michelle Drees on drums is a close second in the attention stakes, while DJ/programmer Badmarsh (it means "black sheep" in Hindi) hides behind his arsenal of gadgetry.

The show begins gently, with Gharana's mellow blend of east and west flavours. Even so, hyperactive rapper UK Apache, who joins them on a few songs, is itching to start a rumpus, coming over all Timmy Mallett-does-Ali G as he shouts: "Are you ready, London massive?" He gets his chance on Get Up, the band's call to direct action, although in this instance, disaffected members of the community are urged to "put down the knife, put down the gun, let's get together". In contrast to this benign message is Shri's murderous bassline, so fast and intricate it sounds programmed.

B&S have a topsy-turvy musical policy: on Sign, the tablas are triggered by DAT operator Badmarsh, while the jittery, propulsive bassline comes live from Shri. B&S are determined to keep at least half of their sound full of natural goodness. That way, Shri gets to prove what he can do. For 130 bpm, he plays his fretless bass with one hand while sawing away at it using a bow with the other. During Flute Solo, he simultaneously plays flute and scat-sings. Shri's tabla-thumping during Jugalbundi, however, is a virtuoso display too far, evoking horrible memories of early 1970s prog-rock drum solos.

webTitle: Opera review:  The Barber of Seville

fields.headline: The Barber of Seville
fields.standfirst:
Coliseum, London
***
fields.trailText:
Coliseum, London
***
fields.body:
Jonathan Miller's Barber of Seville is back again. Any other directors who have ambitions to stage Rossini's most popular comedy at the Coliseum will just have to wait. This production may be on its seventh revival (in the hands of William Relton) but has yet to grow weary or dated, and the company won't be mothballing the costumes just yet.

The staging has Miller's signature all over it: in the swaying of the serenaders in the opening scene, in the slapstick visual gags, in the way in which the best and juiciest lines of Anthony and Amanda Holden's witty English translation are placed so that no one in the audience can miss a joke. The drawback is that some of the humour seems tacked on, and even occasionally interferes with the music. The staging of some of the ensembles means the singers are so involved in their actions that their sound becomes underwhelming when a big, dramatic noise is called for.

The evening was carried largely by the comedy rather than the musical performance. The orchestra played with poise under Michael Lloyd, but there were one or two slips in ensemble during the first act and, although lively, the score never fizzed quite as much as it can. The continuo, so solid and reliable during the recitatives, could have been more adventurous.

Luckily, the cast boasted two natural comic actors. Dr Bartolo, with his troublesome hernia, is the butt of many jokes, and Gordon Sandison knew how to keep the audience laughing. Mark Beesley, as the pasty-faced, lank-haired Don Basilio, relished singing one of the slimiest characters heard here for some time.

As for the heroes, Toby Spence didn't sing with the agility of a natural Rossini tenor but had enough presence to make Almaviva likeable, even standing alongside Christopher Maltman's charismatic Figaro. Although recovering from flu, Maltman found a full, rewarding tone for most of the evening.

Anyone who has caught this production recently may already have heard these four singers in these roles. But there is a good reason to go back and see it again: Christine Rice, who made a sparkling job of her first Rosina. Approaching the role as a real mezzo, with plenty of body in her lower notes, she made the fiendishly difficult coloratura seem easy. She could perhaps find more brilliance on her topmost notes; if that doesn't develop during this run, it should when the ENO stages its next revival. That's when, not if.

 In rep until April 26. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

fields.headline: Linton Kwesi Johnson
fields.standfirst:
Wardrobe, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Wardrobe, Leeds
****
fields.body:
It's 26 years since Linton Kwesi Johnson became the world's first and foremost dub poet with the single Dread Beat An' Blood. For this rare appearance, the beat remains at home, as Linton is touring with nothing but the words and indignation with which his career began. It has been said that Linton, approaching 50, has mellowed. In under an hour, he disproves that view.

With his dapper suit, trilby and red tie he could pass for a schoolteacher, but he stands skewed, like a gunslinger, as he delivers his words. The place is packed, but you can hear a pin drop as he launches into the diatribes of his youth. Sonny's Lettah, the tale of a Brixton youth imprisoned for defending his brother from policemen, remains as harrowing as the day it was written. Reggae Fi Dada is his moving tribute to his father, who died in Jamaica after losing both legs and "never getting his just dessert".

His older poems, encompassing the Sus laws, the New Cross "massakah" and innumerable racist outrages, have not dated and underline how little has changed. Between poems, he explains his early motivation: "We were the rebel generayshan. What they [his elders in the black community] tolerated, we refused to tolerate."

Even without Dennis Bovell's basslines, there is so much rhythm, or riddim, in LKJ's voice that heads still sway. As he moves on to more recent works, it becomes clear that he has developed a new perspective. He ponders the fate of the black rebel ("Dazed, demolished") but is positive, rather than defeatist. BG ("mi champion, mi main man") holds up the late Bernie Grant as an example of what can be achieved.

 Linton Kwesi Johnson is at the Cornerhouse, Middlesbrough (01642 253053), tomorrow.

webTitle: To perk or not to perk

fields.headline: To perk or not to perk
fields.standfirst: Judi James fights for the workplace biscuit and a pot a freshly-brewed coffee
fields.trailText: Judi James fights for the workplace biscuit and a pot a freshly-brewed coffee.
fields.body:
The "That just about takes the biscuit award" this week goes to the British car firm whose boss sent a memo to staff on cost-cutting that included recommendations on going to the loo before they leave home, rather than weeing during company time, and raising the height of the cubicle doors so that workers who do get caught short can be identified by their shoes.

This outlandish act is extreme but not - unfortunately - a one-off. As companies across the UK become increasingly cost-conscious the workplace perk is fast vanishing from corporate culture. The company car - once one of the super-perks for most jobs - is now a huge tax liability. Boozy business lunches have gone the same way, to be replaced by filling-station sarnies.

Prices in most staff canteens are almost up to Pret-A-Manger levels. Free tea and coffee is a thing of the past. Even the humble biscuit - the greatest symbol of the valued and nurtured employee - has been banished to Bourbon heaven.

Currently the only place to find a freebie is on a training course. Glacier mints are commonly available in bowls, alongside bottles of fruit cordial and the odd free pencil or two. No wonder delegates fill their pockets like hibernating squirrels when they leave. God knows what the tax implications would be if the inland revenue started frisking them on the way out.

Perks are a useful tool in business life. Their usefulness in terms of staff loyalty and motivation far outweighs their cost. The same can be true for corporate image. One very bland factory I toured recently suddenly looked perceptibly more up-market and employee-friendly when I spotted the huge bowls of miniature Mars Bars in the training room, and the large pots of freshly ground, luxury-brand coffee in the canteen.

Another impressed me when they put out free slabs of home made fruit cake with the afternoon tea. I felt instantly in love with one recruitment firm I visited when the boss went to what he called "the goodie drawer" during a meeting and passed around individual-size boxes of Smarties to everyone present.

When I was a kid the kudos of any job was mainly defined by the perks that were brought home at the end of the day. The lady from the cake shop was the most envied high-flier locally because she got bags full of left-over doughnuts and chocolate eclairs. My uncle got computer paper for us to crayon on. My friend's dad got tins of broken biscuits. Another friend's father was an accountant and we all felt sorry for her because there were no free bunts.

Never take a perk-cull lying down. Today's free chocolate biscuit is tomorrow's toilet paper and tap water. Never ask if the fight is worth it, understand that it is. Any perk that has ever been a historical part of the culture should be fought for tooth and nail, even if no-one has ever taken it up, from the Oxtail soup option on the coffee machine to the plastic hygiene seat covers in the toilet.

Holding on to the freebies is not a sign of poverty or meanness. The Clintons cannot be short of money but look at the furore they caused when they were accused of de-perking the White House.

Bosses love freebies as much as lower-level workers. I once passed a millionaire businessman leaving his firm's annual staff buffet with a Tupperware box filled with leftover sausage rolls. I'm sure from his delighted expression that they meant more to him at that moment than lunch at The Ivy. He probably threw them away when he got home and found out his family were underwhelmed by the pathetic-looking booty.

fields.headline: Gucci's smart performance
fields.trailText: The US economy may be hitting the buffers and Japan mired in recession but Gucci, the group that covers everything from haute couture to handbags, hasn't noticed.
fields.body:
The US economy may be hitting the buffers and Japan mired in recession but Gucci, the group that covers everything from haute couture to handbags, hasn't noticed.

Demand in Japan was up by a third last year and by 40% in the three months to the end of January. As for last month, it "accelerated" president and chief executive officer Domenico de Sole said.

Gucci's US performance was more restrained. Sales were up by just under 17% on the year and by just over 14% in the final quarter.

Anecdotal evidence from the US, according to Mr de Sole, suggests "inventory" problems. Buyers from the big stores were out in force in July when the US economy was still hot - only for sentiment to change sharply in the late autumn. Gucci, however, remains moderately upbeat.

Last year, Gucci's string of acquisitions included designer Alexander McQueen's own label business. Now Mr McQueen has parted company with LVMH, the French group that owns 20% of Gucci and with which Gucci is locked in a protracted battle.

Full-year figures show revenues up 83% to $2.258bn (£1.5bn) and operating profits 49% ahead at $408.4m. However the cost of write-downs against goodwill and trademarks left pre-tax income at $385.4m, slightly down on 1999.

webTitle: Guinness book needs rescuing, says founder

fields.headline: Record froth
fields.standfirst: Guinness book needs rescuing, says founder
fields.trailText: Guinness book needs rescuing, says founder.
fields.body:
The Guinness Book of Records has become downmarket "liquorice", packed with ephemeral pop trivia, according to its founding editor Norris McWhirter, who wants a highbrow British publisher to "rescue" it.

Guinness World Records, which publishes the book, has been put up for sale by drinks group Diageo, which regards it as a distraction from producing beers, wines and spirits. The business is thought to be worth some £60m. Mr McWhirter, who parted company with Guinness in 1995, is keen for it to remain in British hands: "It was essentially a British creation and I think the British would probably do it better."

Industry sources suggested that possible buyers could include Virgin or Pearson, which owns Penguin books. However, insiders at both companies said they were "unlikely" to be interested. Overseas media groups such as AOL Time Warner, Walt Disney and News International were also mentioned as bidders.

Mr McWhirter, 75, wants any new owner to restore the book's reputation as a reference work.

He said: "It's virtually unrecognisable now, it's gone so downmarket. It's like a stick of multi-coloured liquorice - it doesn't contain many of the basic records."

He criticised the publishers' emphasis on pop music and football, pointing out that when he was editor, the book contained records for 84 different sports.

The son of an Associated Newspapers executive, Mr McWhirter became interested in statistics after playing with piles of newspapers as a child. Along with his late twin brother, Ross, he established a business supplying facts and figures to the media.

They were asked to edit the first Guinness Book of Records in 1954 by Sir Hugh Beever, then boss of the Guinness brewery, who wanted a publication to "settle arguments" in pubs throughout the country. Mr McWhirter now writes rival record books for Virgin. He is president of the right-wing Freedom Association. However, he said: "I would be happy to be of help to whoever acquires the Guinness business."

Guinness World Records, based in north London, also produces the British Book of Hit Singles. It is involved in making a world records television show, and has an extensive website. The business makes annual profits of £6m, from sales of £23m.

fields.headline: Bears maul Wall Street
fields.standfirst:
After three-day rout, analysts see no end to investors' fright and flight trend

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: After three-day rout, analysts see no end to investors' fright and flight trend
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in New York and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Three days of turmoil on Wall Street sent panicked American investors racing for the exits yesterday, pushing the US stock market deep into bear territory.

The market rout, which began last year with the crash in technology stocks, has now infected 30 of the biggest and best-known companies in America.

By mid-morning the Dow Jones index of leading shares was down more than 300 points to 9,159.76, passing easily through the entry point to a bear market, defined as falling 20% below its highest close. The Dow, which peaked at 11,722.98 on January 14 last year, is the last leading world index to succumb to the equities meltdown.

The S&P 500 Index, a broad-based indicator, fell 3% and the shock waves continued to spread to Europe. Robin Griffiths, chief technical analyst at HSBC Securities in New York, said: "There was a period when people in Europe said that this was an American hi-tech problem and that European markets could continue to rise even as American markets fell. They've had to abandon that nonsense."

"I think that everybody is sitting there and watching their 401(k) [pension] plans deteriorate," said Ned Collins, a trader at Daiwa Securities America. "We had some years of about 25% returns in the market. It's payback time."

Although the Dow pegged back some of its earlier losses, by 2pm it was still trading down 250 points at 9228.

Yesterday's sell-off came after two consecutive days when the blue-chip share index had lost more than 200 points. Traders blamed the decision by the Federal Reserve earlier in the week to cut US interest rates by half a point when the markets had been hoping for a deeper cut to stop the slide in the US economy.

"There has been a growing realisation that the Fed will not come to the rescue of the equity markets," said Nick Stamenkovic, senior strategist at Nomura International in London.

Economists and analysts said there was still little evidence that prices had reached bottom. Ian Shepherdson at High Frequency Economics said: "We are in the grip of fear, which makes the markets difficult to predict."

Investors were discouraged by another wave of negative corporate announcements yesterday. Charles Schwab and Procter & Gamble reported large layoffs and forecast difficult markets. Lower earnings expectations mean shares continue to look expensive on traditional price/earnings multiples even as share prices slump.

Among the biggest losers yesterday were "old economy" stocks, previously seen as defensive bets against the turmoil in the high-growth technology and telecommunications sectors. Shares in Philip Morris, the tobacco company, and drugs groups Merck and Johnson & Johnson all fell.

Shares in General Electric, America's most highly valued company, have fallen 20% in the past month.

Amid such gloom, the Nasdaq Composite index struggled into positive territory as investors looked for some bargains in a market that has fallen 60% in the past year.

Shares in Microsoft, a major Nasdaq component, were up 5% at one point in spite of a downgrade from an influential analyst at Goldman Sachs, who cited weak demand for personal computers for cutting his earnings forecast for this year.

Other negative news included an increase in jobless claims to a higher-than-expected 379,000. The figure was slightly above the level of claims during the early stages of the 1990-91 recession, according to High Frequency Economics.

fields.headline: Noël Coward reveals himself
fields.standfirst:
Semi-Monde
Lyric Shaftesbury, London
***
fields.trailText:
Semi-Monde
Lyric Shaftesbury, London
***
fields.body:
It is strange seeing Coward's Semi-Monde in the same week as Wedekind's Lulu. Both view human beings as caged animals driven by sexual desire. The key difference is that Noël Coward's creatures camouflage their erotic itch under a savage politesse, and the author himself views them with a mixture of voyeuristic glee and puritanical disdain. But then Coward always carefully kept a foot in both camps.

Written in 1926 and unperformed until the Glasgow Citizens revived it in 1977, the play now gets its London premiere in another sumptuous Philip Prowse production. We are in the Paris Ritz lounge and bar, where we are offered a glittering kaleidoscope of dressy decadence. Rich women find ingenious ways to deceive their menfolk. An ageing novelist seduces a young bride while the dullish groom goes off with the writer's daughter. Meanwhile, a callow youth hovers between the sexes while elderly gays make witty remarks with feline intensity, and promiscuous lesbians quarrel with their partners. This is Grand Hotel seen through a glass darkly.

As a young dramatist, Coward has problems handling 28 characters in a seething social panorama. Everyone, of whatever gender, tends to speak with His Master's Voice. A waspish Sapphist describes an unfortunate prima donna as "the most constipated Carmen I've ever heard" while the hetero novelist dislikes Rapallo because "it's filled with double-breasted American matrons". Yet the play constantly intrigues because of Coward's equivocal attitude to this opulent menagerie. He was always a mixture of cosmopolitan sophisticate and Teddington maiden aunt, and here you feel he both admires the characters' verbal style and deplores their sexual intemperance. The giveaway comes when the novelist remarks of a group of epicene gigglers that "they're not even real of their kind", as if gay sex should always be closeted under good manners.

It's not a great play but it offers a revealing portrait of Coward's divided self. And Prowse's design and production make it a feast for the eye. Under an ornate golden cupola black-clad couples come and go while Derwent Watson picks out Coward standards mixed with Tristan and Isolde on the piano, and Nichola McAuliffe flashes her sensational legs and drily intones Parisian Pierrot.

Prowse's one mistake is to project the action forwards, in the final act, into the fascist 1930s, with swastika leaflets descending from the flies. Coward was offering a panorama of hedonism rather than a prophecy of Nazism.

The vast cast contains some memorable cameos. McAuliffe turns plausibly from chanteuse to errant nymph, John Carlisle is excellent as a dessicated novelist. There is good work from Benedick Bates as a wandering bisexual, and Frances Tomelty as an angry lesbian. You never get to know any of the characters very well, but this is Coward acting as the Daumier of 1920s decadence and, through his lightning cartoons, revealing more of his own moral confusion than he realised.

 Booking until April 28. Box office: 020-7494 5045. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: Hello Again
fields.standfirst:
Bridewell, London
****
fields.trailText:
Bridewell, London
****
fields.body:
Arthur Schnitzler's turn-of-the-19th-century sexual daisy-chain drama La Ronde has inspired numerous artists, from film-maker Max Ophuls to playwright David Hare, whose overrated The Blue Room updated the story to our own times. But few have been as successful as American Michael John LaChiusa's musical version, which gets its European premiere at the ever-enterprising Bridewell, a theatre that is almost single-handedly keeping British musical theatre on beat.

This is an early-ish work from the composer and writer of Marie Christine and The Wild Party, but it is an immensely assured one. As the flippant title may suggest, LaChiusa often treats his material with wit and irony, making the most of scenes that include fellatio conducted by a young married woman on her lover under cover of the New York Times, and a gay seduction taking place on the Titanic as it sinks.

Both LaChiusa and director Clive Paget cleverly negotiate the mixture of the comic and the tragic, creating a sophisticated 90-minute play that combines the thrill of seduction with post-coital self-disgust, and the knowledge that sex may be the imperative but seldom turns out to be enough.

There are times when the music is so plangent that it coils through the theatre like the smoke from the cigarette of the soldier who eagerly has sex with the prostitute and then deserts her with a torrent of abuse.

LaChiusa has two trump cards that make his version of La Ronde both different and better. The first is a time frame that criss-crosses the 20th century, jumping backwards and forwards so that the piece becomes about not just the way we were but the way we are now. LaChiusa suggests that human impulse, human nature and human desire have changed very little over the years. He treats his material like an anthropologist, not a moralist.

His second triumph is the way he makes the music work for the story. The different periods are reflected in melodies and rhythms that derive from each era. It means that there is an enthralling and entirely appropriate variation in musical style throughout the evening. But LaChiusa ensures the continuity by having melodies and songs follow from one scene to another, up and down the years. There are moments when the sudden reappearance of a tune is like having someone run a finger lightly down your spine. Shivery, delicious, almost painful.

Inevitably some scenes work rather better than others, and the shifts in tone can be hard for both the audience and the cast to negotiate. But there is no more entertaining or, at times, wistful evening in town to remind us why romance and sex are easy and love so hard.

 Until April 14. Box office: 020-7936 3456.

fields.headline: Sumptuous Dvorak from the LSO
fields.standfirst:
LSO/Davis
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
LSO/Davis
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.body:
The London Symphony Orchestra's Bohemian Spring series has now reached its halfway point, with Colin Davis taking over the baton from Jiri Belohlavek for a tricky programme that doesn't so much explore the Czech musical heritage as reflect a certain ambivalence towards it.

Dvorak's Seventh Symphony - marking the composer's effective emergence on to the international circuit - was commissioned by London's Royal Philharmonic Society and veers away from a tangy, folk-based vocabulary towards Austro-German Classicism, and Brahms in particular. Bohuslav Martinu, meanwhile, represented here by two works disparate in tone and quality, spent most of his life in self-appointed exile and only seemed capable of responding to Czech tradition by absenting himself from it.

Martinu remains a deeply controversial figure. Only a handful of works from his colossal output are worth preserving, chief among them being the Concerto for Two String Orchestras, Piano and Timpani, dating from 1938. Initially triggered by an unhappy love affair, it turned into a fiercely political work when the Nazis rampaged into the Sudetenland. Strident with protest, it is music that dramatises irreconcilable conflict.

The two string orchestras, facing each other across the platform, slug it out with little hope of concord, while the piano seems to be trapped in the middle, making futile attempts at mediation. Davis unleashes a cyclone of discords that repeatedly collapse into exhaustion. Played by John Alley, the piano's phrases have a lacerating, nostalgic sweetness that recalls Ravel. The work was written in Paris, and you wonder whether the piano's bewildered, solitary voice is Martinu's own.

The Rhapsody-Concerto for Viola and Orchestra, however, represents Martinu at his weakest. Written in 1952, it aspires to a bitter-sweet pastoral nostalgia, occasionally interrupted by pattering drum-beats that hint at a calm landscape disturbed by a military presence (Soviet, this time). But it is loosely structured and seems to meander turgidly all over the place. No one could have any doubts about Dvorak's Seventh on this occasion, however. Far from dithering over the work's debt to Brahms, Davis plays it up, achieving an almost ideal balance between Romantic feeling and classical concision that sweeps you away. The LSO, infinitely responsive, sumptuous in tone, captures every flicker of emotion and revels in its rhythmic exuberance. There have been more than enough performances of the work in London of late, though this, unquestionably, was the finest.

Dvorak's Seventh Symphony - marking the composer's effective emergence on to the international circuit - was commissioned by London's Royal Philharmonic Society and veers away from a tangy, folk-based vocabulary towards Austro-German Classicism, and Brahms in particular. Bohuslav Martinu, meanwhile, represented here by two works disparate in tone and quality, spent most of his life in self-appointed exile and only seemed capable of responding to Czech tradition by absenting himself from it. Martinu remains a deeply controversial figure. Only a handful of works from his colossal output are worth preserving, chief among them being the Concerto for Two String Orchestras, Piano and Timpani, dating from 1938. Initially triggered by an unhappy love affair, it turned into a fiercely political work when the Nazis rampaged into the Sudetenland. Strident with protest, it is music that dramatises irreconcilable conflict. The two string orchestras, facing each other across the platform, slug it out with little hope of concord, while the piano seems to be trapped in the middle, making futile attempts at mediation. Davis unleashes a cyclone of discords that repeatedly collapse into exhaustion. Played by John Alley, the piano's phrases have a lacerating, nostalgic sweetness that recalls Ravel. The work was written in Paris, and you wonder whether the piano's bewildered, solitary voice is Martinu's own. fields.headline: Northern Stage Ensemble's staggering 1984
fields.body:
Faced with Orwell's savage prophecy of surveillance screens, thought-crime and Newspeak, we might be forgiven for feeling relieved that we got off lightly with yuppies, ra-ra skirts and Spandau Ballet. Orwell's broader image of the future, however, was of a boot stamping on a human face forever. Here, the audience faces the stage while Alan Lyddiard's Northern Stage Ensemble puts the boot in.

The ensemble is an egalitarian, project-based group of artists, technicians and support staff and has aggressively forged a new identity for regional theatre in the 21st century. Not so much a rep as a total theatre-machine, Northern Stage specialises in techno-drama for the digital age, which can make old-fashioned analogue theatre-going seem very tame by comparison. Animal Farm and William Trevor's Ballroom of Romance have already been given the treatment; and the present production reunites the creative team responsible for the much-acclaimed A Clockwork Orange. One wonders what Lyddiard and company intend to do when they run out of dystopian novels to assault; but, for the moment, 1984 is a staggering, if slightly stomach-turning, experience.

While some have dismissed Orwell as a false prophet, the current production treats him as an oracle. His pessimistic vision is, after all, insinuated throughout modern society in ways that he could not possibly have foreseen. Perhaps there are no telescreens, but we have call-monitoring, CCTV and an internet terminal in every home. And what is double-think but the definition of political spin, or the neutered language of Newspeak but the rapidly shrinking lexicon of the text-message?

Northern Stage's pacy, jump-cut adaptation is a volatile combination of video ultra-violence, sound-montage and sadism, cast in monochrome shadow and interrogative white light. Neil Murray's minimal design of circling and realigning screens enables a running commentary to develop between Lyddiard's live actors and Mark Murphy's brutalist film sequences, shot in Newcastle and Moscow.

It is usually the human dimension that suffers in such ambitious attempts at mixing media, but if the fragile figure of Craig Conway's Winston Smith is occasionally trampled on by the march of technology, then it is a perfectly apposite metaphor for Orwellian oppression. Cait Davis's Julia provides a poignant vessel of animal necessity and humane instinct.

A plus-good piece of work all round. Double-plus-good, in fact.

 Until April 7. Box office: 0191-230 5151. Then tours to Derby, Warwick, Poole, Brighton, Stirling and Newbury until June 9.

fields.headline: Orange silences its critics
fields.trailText: Orange, the mobile phone group that floated last month, went some way to silencing its critics yesterday after reporting a 59% rise in turnover last year, to €12bn (£8bn).
fields.body:
Orange, the mobile phone group that floated last month, went some way to silencing its critics yesterday after reporting a 59% rise in turnover last year, to €12bn (£8bn).

The group also recorded a 68% rise in its customer base to 30.5m and is understood to have already secured 750,000 new UK subscribers in the first two months of 2001, taking the total to 10.6m - well ahead of expectations.

The telecoms group had come under intense scrutiny in the run-up to flotation last month after some analysts expressed concern that the group's growth momentum had stalled and that the offer price was too high.

Answering the company's critics, chief executive Jean-François Pontal said: "At the time of the flotation, we announced that we were going to grow faster than the market as a whole, and that is what we are doing."

He added: "Of course, we cannot help falling victim to exaggerated market scepticism."

In the UK and French markets, which together account for almost 80% of Orange's business, the group has maintained it strong market shares.

Juliet Telford, an analyst at JP Morgan, said Orange - which is majority owned by France Télécom - was now poised to take a clear lead over BT as Britain's second largest mobile telecoms provider behind Vodafone.

"Orange is widely recognised as having the most reliable network and they have a great brand - Orange phones are very popular," she said.

However, she added that, while earnings growth was in line or above expectations, Orange still needed to prove it could continue to reduce losses, in order to reach profitability targets. It recorded pretax losses for last year of £409m, and the company is not expected to make a profit until 2004.

Mr Pontal said the plan to extend the Orange brand to operations in 20 European countries was still on course. "We expect that this will give us a competitive advantage in newer markets," he said.

The group also hopes to have a presence in about 50 countries by 2005. Last year Orange's telecoms interests in Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark and Slovakia performed particularly well, Mr Pontal said.

"This year, we shall build on our momentum, rolling out the Orange brand and GPRS," he said.

The group aims to launch GPRS - the intermediate stage before the third generation of mobile phones - in July or August though is unlikely to have a strong impact until 2002.

There will be a range of between 10 and 15 GPRS handsets available by 2001, the group said.

Yesterday, shares in Orange closed down 16.5p at 536.5p.

Meanwhile, parent company France Télécom reported marginally weaker than expected results for 2000, with net profit up 32% to €3.66bn.

Its internet service provider Wanadoo turned in a net loss of €102m, but this was better than the market had been expecting.
