webTitle: No rival in sight for troubled Post Office

fields.headline: Post Office gets a free run
fields.standfirst: No rival in sight for troubled service
fields.trailText: No rival in sight for troubled service.
fields.body:
The Post Office, which on Monday officially loses its monopoly over the 80m letters delivered daily, is likely to continue to be the sole provider of mail to the UK's 27m addresses for months to come.

No would-be rival operator has applied to the new regulator, PostComm, for a licence to supply mail costing less than £1 despite the prospect of hundreds of new local operators being allowed to mount the greatest challenge to the Royal Mail for 350 years.

PostComm, which is expected to finalise the Post Office's licence later today, backed off plans to launch a handful of licences after John Roberts, PO chief executive, threatened to resign over the issue, according to industry sources.

The corporation, which becomes Consignia and acquires plc status on Monday, has, insiders said, mended fences with the new regulator which is chaired by Graham Corbett and gets its new powers to issue licences the same day.

A PO spokesman said yesterday that it was "absolute nonsense" to suggest Mr Roberts had threatened to resign or pull out of negotiations with PostComm over its first licence. The PO chief is said to be "bewildered and amused" at such reports.

But the PO is reeling from the twin impact of rail delays and a spate of wildcat strikes that have seen it lose 56,000 working days so far this financial year (to March 31) compared with just 22,000 last year.

Mr Roberts admitted this week only 89% of first class letters would have been delivered the next working day - compared with a 92% target. He has had to agree new targets of 92.1% this year and 92.5% next year.

One third of the 56 Royal Mail night trains are still arriving late every night, five months after the Hatfield crash, with the date for normal service to be resumed constantly put back.

It is understood that some senior PO directors are so incensed that they are urging the board to rescind the 10-year contract with the rail industry even though it still has five years to run.

A PO spokesman said that, while it was technically feasible to switch to air and road, it would be impossible to do so overnight. "We have no plans to pull the contract but we do need to get a more efficient, faster and more flexible service - and compensation worth tens of millions when calm is restored to the rail network,"officials said.

Frustrated by the lack of competitors beating a path to the door, Postwatch, the consumer watchdog launched this week, wants 1p off the price of first class stamps to be imposed by the regulator over the next two years while PostComm decides on its price control formula.

The watchdog claims that almost 2m first class letters fail to be delivered on time every day while 1m items of mail are "lost" each week, a figure hotly disputed by the PO.

Mr Roberts admitted this week that further problems of delivery caused by strikes and transport would drive customers into the hands of eventual competitors.

But the PO expects - and hopes - that eventual competitors, who will be able to undercut it substantially, will merely serve niche markets such as business clients seeking an enhanced courier service.

webTitle: Morale among overstressed GPs at all time low, says report

fields.headline: Morale among overstressed GPs at all time low, says report
fields.trailText: Morale among GPs is at an all time low, according to a report yesterday which claims four out of five would leave the NHS if they could.
fields.body:
Morale among GPs is at an all time low, according to a report yesterday which claims four out of five would leave the NHS if they could.

High stress levels and disenchantment with government health policy are to blame for the growing feeling of hopelessness, a report in the Doctor claimed.

Recent cash incentives introduced by Tony Blair, including a £10,000 "golden handshake" for new GPs, have done nothing to improve morale, the newspaper claims.

The research said 68% of GPs were considering retiring early while 80% would not recommend general practice as a career to young doctors.

Lester Russell, 41, a GP in Southsea, told Doctor he was leaving his job next month. "I have only one choice. When the job starts interfering with family, then family comes first."

Jenny Reynolds, a GP from Sutton Coldfield, said of the government's recent financial incentive scheme: "Take your offer and shove it. They would have to add a zero for me to even seriously think about it."

The main complaint was constant change. Nine out of 10 GPs said NHS reforms were adversely affecting morale.

More than 90% said they were stressed at work and 69% said they would take industrial action to vent their anger.

Phil Johnson, editor of Doctor, said: "The shocking results of our survey reveal a profession not just down-hearted but at the end of its tether."

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said: "The unprecedented scale of disillusionment amongst GPs, which this survey reveals, is a shocking indictment of Labour's incompetence."

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said: "There are over 29,000 GPs in the country of which around 550 have responded to this survey. However, we do know that many GPs are under pressure from the pace of change. The department greatly appreciates the work that GPs.

"That's why we have introduced a raft of measures to improve working lives of GPs. These include cutting paperwork, recruiting 2,000 more GPs, introducing a payment of £5,000 for all new GPs and £10,000 for GPs who work until 65."

Press Association

webTitle: Can my bosses make me wear a uniform?

fields.headline: Can my bosses make me wear a uniform?
fields.trailText: 23 March: I travel home late at night and I am worried about my personal safety.
fields.body:
The problem

I work for an international security firm, dealing in large amounts of cash, who propose to bring uniforms in for all staff this month. I have several objections to this, the main one being that to wear clothing to and from work that bears the company logo could jeopardise my personal safety.

There is nowhere to change on site and we are not allowed to bring bags into the building in any case. We are women, working late at night and we do not have access to transport home from the company. But if we do not wear the uniform our wages will be deducted.

The solution

I think your company is being unreasonable and that your offer to change on site is entirely reasonable. When a company brings in a uniform policy, they are, in effect, changing your terms of employment, since they are saying that they will not pay you if you do not accept these new conditions. As you have a reasonable reason for rejecting these new terms, I do not think they can be enforced on you and you might be able, in theory, to sue for breach of contract. I also do not believe that the company is acting lawfully in making deductions from your wages like this (although it depends on your contract).

I suggest that you write to your line manager and explain your reservations about wearing the uniform. Repeat your offer to wear the uniform on site if the company will provide facilities such as somewhere to leave your uniform and somewhere to change (are the toilets adequate?).

Before you send the letter, contact your union or ACAS for further advice. If the company refuses to facilitate your changing on the premises and you are forced to go home rather than compromise your safety, then you may well have a case for constructive dismissal (since, no doubt, you will have to leave to get a job that does pay!). Take advice, try and be as reasonable as you can and see if the company will change their attitude in order to protect your safety.

 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Market in biggest fall for nine years

fields.headline: Market in biggest fall for nine years
fields.trailText: Britain's stock market suffered its biggest one-day loss since Black Wednesday yesterday as deepening gloom about the outlook for the American economy sent shockwaves around the world.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Britain's stock market suffered its biggest one-day loss since Black Wednesday yesterday as deepening gloom about the outlook for the American economy sent shockwaves around the world.

The FTSE-100 index of blue-chip stocks closed down 226 points, or 4.1% lower, the steepest one-day percentage loss since the aftermath of the pound's exit from the ERM in September 1992.

The decline, the second largest points fall ever, was triggered by concern about the slowing US economy and disappointing corporate earnings which savaged telecoms and bank stocks.

"Investor confidence is collapsing, a lot of people are just throwing in the towel and no one has any intention of buying," said a senior trader, commenting on a trading session which saw £52bn wiped off the value of Britain's leading companies.

The London market was already down more than 100 points at lunchtime but it sank further at the start of trading in New York where, after grinding relentlessly lower since the beginning of the month, the Dow Jones industrial average finally entered official bear market territory by dropping more than 20% from its peak.

The milestone has already been passed by most of the other leading global stock market indices, including the FTSE-100, the technology-rich Nasdaq composite index, the US's broader Standard & Poors 500 index and Japan's Nikkei 225 index.

"The Nasdaq... has just been devastated and it's so low that it's just a matter of when it bottoms," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Weatherly Securities.

The Nasdaq, bellwether of the new economy, is now down more than 60% since its peak in March last year.

Analysts said yesterday's sell-off in global stock markets reflected deep-seated anxiety that Tuesday's half point cut in interest rates by the US Federal Reserve was too timid to prevent the world's biggest economy sliding into recession.

"This is about a market that is forecasting a recession," said Gary Kaltbaum of First Union Securities.

"It's a dangerous situation," said Dan Ascani, president of the market research firm, GMSTechstreet.com "It's dangerous to the economy, because the markdown in asset values on such broad levels marks down the net worth of consumers."

In Britain, the engineering group Invensys became the latest UK company to fall victim to the US slowdown.

Its stock plummeted 10% after issuing its second profit warning in six months and saying it would cut an extra 2,000 jobs.

The news follows a series of warnings from European companies whose business relies on a healthy US economy.

Banks as a group sliced 50 points off the FTSE-100 with Barclays down 5.8% and HSBC off 5.2%. Telecoms took 41 points off the FTSE as Vodafone lost 5.2% and BT 5%.

In New York, Charles Schwab, the online broker which doubled its workforce on the back of the boom in US share trading, announced 3,400 job cuts, or between 11% and 13% of its staff. Shares in Schwab have fallen 61% in the past year.

After rallying on Tuesday in the wake of the Bank of Japan's decision to effectively reduce interest rates to zero, the benchmark Nikkei 225 average ended down 1.91% yesterday at 12,855.98.

The Nasdaq, bellwether of the new economy, is now down more than 60% since its peak in March last year. Analysts said yesterday's sell-off in global stock markets reflected deep-seated anxiety that Tuesday's half point cut in interest rates by the US Federal Reserve was too timid to prevent the world's biggest economy sliding into recession. "This is about a market that is forecasting a recession," said Gary Kaltbaum of First Union Securities. "It's a dangerous situation," said Dan Ascani, president of the market research firm, GMSTechstreet.com "It's dangerous to the economy, because the markdown in asset values on such broad levels marks down the net worth of consumers." In Britain, the engineering group Invensys became the latest UK company to fall victim to the US slowdown. Its stock plummeted 10% after issuing its second profit warning in six months and saying it would cut an extra 2,000 jobs. The news follows a series of warnings from European companies whose business relies on a healthy US economy. Banks as a group sliced 50 points off the FTSE-100 with Barclays down 5.8% and HSBC off 5.2%. Telecoms took 41 points off the FTSE as Vodafone lost 5.2% and BT 5%. In New York, Charles Schwab, the online broker which doubled its workforce on the back of the boom in US share trading, announced 3,400 job cuts, or between 11% and 13% of its staff. Shares in Schwab have fallen 61% in the past year. After rallying on Tuesday in the wake of the Bank of Japan's decision to effectively reduce interest rates to zero, the benchmark Nikkei 225 average ended down 1.91% yesterday at 12,855.98.
